State Law reference- Wards, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-20-15. 

Sec. 2-25. - Designated generally. 
    The city shall be and is divided into four wards as provided by statute. 
(Code 1977, § 1.12.010; Code 1990, § 2-26; Ord. No. 2002-2014, § 1, 6-18-2002) 
Sec. 2-26. - Ward One. 
    The boundary of Ward One shall be as follows: Beginning at the north city limits and the extension of 5th Avenue then running south on 5th Avenue to Gait Avenue, then south on Gait Avenue to West 7th Street, then west on West 7th Street to 8th Avenue, then south on 8th Avenue to Route 30, then west on Route 30 to 11th Avenue, then south on 11th Avenue to Suzanne Street, then west on Suzanne Street to 12th Avenue, then south on 12th Avenue to 16th Street, then west on 16th Street to 13th Avenue, then south on 13th Ave to 17th Street, then west on 17th Street to the west city limits. 
(Code 1977, § 1.12.020; Code 1990, § 2-27; Ord. No. 2002-2014, § 1, 6-18-2002) 
Sec. 2-27. - Ward Two. 
    The boundary of Ward Two shall be as follows: Beginning at the north city limits and the extension of 5th Avenue, then south on 51st Avenue to Gait Avenue, then south on Gait Avenue to West 7th Street, then west on West 7th Street to 8th Avenue, then south on 8th Avenue to Route 30, then east on Route 30 to 5th Avenue/16th Street, then east on West 16th Street to 1st Avenue, then north on 1st Avenue to East 10th Street, then east on East 10th Street to Avenue C, then north on Avenue C to East 8th Street, then east on East 8th Street to Avenue D, then north on Avenue D to the former Burlington Northern Railroad right-of-way, then northwest on the railroad right-of-way to East 5th Street, then west on East 5th Street to Avenue A, then north on Avenue A and the extension thereof to the north city limits. 
(Code 1977, § 1.12.030; Code 1990, § 2-28; Ord. No. 2002-2014, § 1, 6-18-2002) 
Sec. 2-28. - Ward Three. 
    The boundary of Ward Three shall be as follows: Beginning at the north city limits and the intersection of the extension of Avenue A, then south on Avenue A to East 5th Street, then east on East 5th Street to the former Burlington Northern Railroad right-of-way intersection, then southeasterly on the railroad right-of-way to the north line (extended westerly) of the city industrial park subdivision No. 6, then east on that line extended to the east city limits. 
(Code 1977, § 1.12.040; Code 1990, § 2-29; Ord. No. 2002-2014, § 1, 6-18-2002) 
Sec. 2-29. - Ward Four. 
    The boundary of Ward Four shall be as follows: Beginning at the west city limits intersection with West 17th Street as extended, then east on West 17th Street to 13th Avenue, then north on 13th Avenue to West 16th Street, then east on West 16th Street to 12th Avenue, then north on 12th Avenue to Suzanne Street, then east on Suzanne Street to 11th Avenue, then north on 11th Avenue to Route 30, then east on Route 30 to 3rd Avenue/West 16th Street, then east on West 16th Street to 1st Avenue, then north on 1st Avenue to East 10th Street, then east on East 10th Street to Avenue C, then north on Avenue C to East 8th Street, then east on East 8th Street to Avenue D, then north on Avenue D to the former Burlington Northern Railroad right-of-way, then southeasterly along the railroad right-of-way to the line (extended westerly) of the north line of the city industrial park subdivision No. 6, then easterly along that boundary line to the east city limits. 
(Code 1977, § 1.12.050; Code 1990, § 2-30; Ord. No. 2002-2014, § 1, 6-18-2002) 
Secs. 2-30-2-46. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - MAYOR 

Sec. 2-47. - Duties. 
    The mayor and shall perform such duties as may be required of him by statute or ordinance. He shall have supervision over all of the executive officers and employees of the city. 
(Code 1977, § 2.04.020; Code 1990, § 2-47) 
Sec. 2-48. - Appointment of officers. 
    The mayor shall appoint, by and with the advice and consent of the council, all officers of the city whose election or appointment is not otherwise provided for. Any vacancies occurring in an appointive office shall be filled in the same manner. 
(Code 1977, § 2.04.030; Code 1990, § 2-48) 
Sec. 2-49. - Designation of officers' duties. 
    Whenever there is a dispute as to the respective duties or powers of any appointed officer of the city, this dispute shall be settled by the mayor after consultation with the city attorney. The mayor shall have the power to designate to any appointed officer any duty which is to be performed when no specific officer has been directed to perform that duty. 
(Code 1977, § 2.04.040; Code 1990, § 2-49) 
Sec. 2-50. - Representative at formal occasions. 
    The mayor shall act for and on behalf of the city on formal occasions and receptions. 
(Code 1977, § 2.04.070; Code 1990, § 2-52) 
Sec. 2-51. - Health and life insurance. 
    The mayor shall be entitled to and be covered by the employee health benefit plan. The mayor shall pay the percentage of 20 percent of premium costs or as determined from time to time by ordinance. 
(Code 1990, § 2-54; Ord. No. 2010-2432, § 1, 12-7-2010) 
Secs. 2-52-2-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - CITY COUNCIL 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-76. - Regular meetings. 
    The regular meeting of the city council shall be held on the first and third Tuesdays of each month at the hour of 6:30 p.m.; provided that, if the regular meeting falls on a legal holiday, the meeting shall take place on the next day following the holiday, at the same hour. Adjourned meetings may be held at such other times as the city council may determine. 
(Code 1977, § 2.08.020; Code 1990, § 2-72; Ord. No. 96-1760, § 1, 1-2-1996; Ord. No. 2002-2025, § 1, 11-5-2002; Ord. No. 2003-2067, § 1, 10-21-2003) 
Sec. 2-77. - Special meetings. 
    Special meetings of the council may be called by the mayor or three aldermen. A written notice of such meeting shall be given to each member of the council at least 24 hours before the time set for the meeting. In case all of the elected members of the council are present at any special meeting, then the requirement of notice shall be unnecessary and shall be deemed waived. 
(Code 1977, § 2.08.030; Code 1990, § 2-73) 
Sec. 2-78. - Presiding officer. 
    The mayor shall be the presiding officer of the council when the council meets as a committee of the whole. 
(Code 1977, § 2.08.040; Code 1990, § 2-74) 
Sec. 2-79. - Standing committees. 
    The following shall be established standing committees of the council and the areas of responsibility of each in regards to matters of the city. From time to time, additional duties may be added and/or transferred to other committees with advice and consent of the council. 
(1)  Building code. The committee shall review and recommend to the city council, any building code changes deemed to be necessary for the city. Additionally they will assist the building inspector in recommending guideline to the city council for which homes within the city limits are investigated for building code violations and or remediation. 
(2)  Public works; public property. The committee is charged with the overseeing of the street and garbage services of the city. This committee reviews information and makes recommendations as are necessary to the city council. Department considerations include, but are not limited to the items covered under the current garbage refuse contract, and any roads, sidewalks, curbs and or ADA compliance matters. In addition, the committee oversees all the property that the city owns and is intended to be used by the public, including public buildings and parking lots. 
(3)  Ordinance; license; personnel; safety. The committee shall review all proposed ordinance changes and shall make recommendations for adoption. Any license applications referred from the city clerk's office shall be reviewed prior to awarding the license. In addition, they shall be charged with interviewing for all positions of the city with the exception of the police and/or fire services. They shall also review on a quarterly basis reports covering worker compensation incidents, as well as, liability and property claims against the city. Review department safety meeting minutes and take any necessary action to insure compliance of all safety policy and procedures. If the office of city administrator is vacant for any reason, the committee shall also be involved in the IBEW grievance process at step two. 
(4)  Utility committee. The utility committee shall be responsible for overseeing the operations of the electric, water, wastewater, broadband (Rock Falls Fiber.Net) and the customer service office. All recommendations of finance or policy and procedures will be sent to the city council for final approval. There responsibilities shall include, but not be limited to development of capital plans, both long and short term including their implementation. In addition, monitoring performance accountability, identify key performance areas, indicators and metrics, establish benchmarking to measure utility performance, communicate utility performance to community stakeholders, and provide long-term goals and strategies to ensure reliability, affordability, responsibility, safety and quality of life. Any utility projects involving streets and or alleys should be coordinated with the public works/public property committee. 
(5)  Finance; insurance; investment. The committee shall review the finances of each of the municipal utilities, as well as, the general fund. They shall make recommendations to the city council regarding the long and short term financial well-being of those entities. They shall be charged with creation and supervision of the city budget in association with the city administrator and office of the city clerk. They shall also review information regarding the health/dental/liability insurance for the city. They shall make recommendations to the city council regarding these items from time to time. In addition, they shall review the investments of the city and shall make recommendations on those investments. 
(6)  Police; fire. The committee shall receive from time to time information regarding the operations of the police and fire departments. They shall review work procedures, manning and make recommendations to the city council following consultation with the fire and police chiefs respectively. The committee does not replace or supersede the police and fire commission established under Illinois Revised Statute, Chapter 24, 10-2.1-1 
(7)  Committee of the whole (COW). This committee is a discussion committee of the city council, and consists of all of the members of the city council. No actions and or recommendations can be made or voted on at these meetings. 
(8)  Tourism. The committee is responsible for the review of proposals, submitted requesting tourism grant funds and recommendation to the council of those projects that meet the requirements as outlined in the Illinois Statute. In addition, the committee will coordinate with the tourism director on all operations to do with advertising, conferences, trade shows, as well as, membership in other related tourism programs. In addition, tourism will be responsible for usage requests of the RB&W riverfront property and the Veteran's Memorial Park (Galt Avenue & 5 th Street), as well as the area known as the "slab" until such time the property is sold and is no longer usable for community events. 
(Code 1977, § 2.08.060; Code 1990, § 2-76; Ord. No. 94-1716, § 1, 7-25-1994; Ord. No. 2001-1961, § 1, 1-2-2001; Ord. No. 2004-2086, § 1, 4-20-2004; Ord. No. 2005-2134, § 1, 5-17-2005; Ord. No. 2007-2228, § 1, 5-1-2007; Ord. No. 2009-2352, § 1, 8-4-2009; Ord. No. 2013-2117, § 1, 7-2-2013; Ord. No. 2013-2117, § 1, 7-2-2013; Ord. No. 2017-2329, § 1, 7-5-2017) 
Sec. 2-80. - Special committees. 
    The mayor shall appoint such special committees as he may deem necessary or as may be directed by the council. 
(Code 1977, § 2.08.070; Code 1990, § 2-77) 
Sec. 2-81. - Committee membership. 
(a)  The members of standing and special committees shall be appointed by the mayor, with the advice and consent of the city council. 
(b)  The chairperson of each committee shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the city council. 
(c)  Each committee of the city council shall consist of at least three members including the chairperson, except that the committee of the whole shall consist of all members of the city council with the mayor presiding as chairperson. 
(d)  The mayor shall be an ex-officio member of each committee of the city council entitled to vote on matters brought before the committee, and whose presence shall be counted in considering whether a quorum exists. However, absence of the mayor at any committee meeting shall not, of itself, create a lack of a quorum. 
(Code 1977, § 2.08.080; Code 1990, § 2-78; Ord. No. 2001-1961, § 2, 1-2-2001; Ord. No. 2004-2086, § 2, 4-20-2004; Ord. No. 2009-2340, § 1, 4-21-2009) 
Sec. 2-82. - Open meetings act; compliance; training. 
    The city clerk shall submit to the state public access counselor the names of any officers or employees hereafter designated by the city council to receive training on compliance with the Illinois Open Meetings Act (5 ILCS 120/1 et seq.) within 30 days of such designation. 
(Code 1990, § 2-87; Ord. No. 2009-2377, § 4, 12-15-2009) 
Sec. 2-83. - Health and life insurance. 
    The elected members of the city council, as well as, the elected treasurer, shall be entitled to and be covered by the employee health benefit plan. The members of the city council shall pay the entire cost of premium costs or as determined from time to time by ordinance. 
(Code 1990, § 2-88; Ord. No. 2010-2432, § 2, 12-7-2010) 
Sec. 2-84. - Disturbing meetings. 
    It is unlawful to disturb any meeting of the council or of any committee thereof, or to behave in a disorderly manner at any such meeting. 
(Code 1977, § 2.08.160; Code 1990, § 2-86) 
Secs. 2-85-2-111. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - RULES OF ORDER AND PROCEDURE 

Sec. 2-112. - Suspension of rules. 
    Except for provisions that reflect statute, the provisions of this division may be suspended at any time by consent of a majority of the members present at any council meeting. 
(Code 1977, § 2.08.130; Code 1990, § 2-83) 
Sec. 2-113. - Robert's Rules of Order. 
    Except when in conflict with the provisions in sections 2-112 and 2-114 through 2-116, Robert's Rules of Order, 11th Edition, shall the conduct of meetings of the council. 
(Code 1977, § 2.08.140; Code 1990, § 2-84) 
Sec. 2-114. - Order of business. 
(a)  The order of business at meetings of the council shall be determined by the mayor, and a copy of the order of business shall be delivered to or made available to each member of the city council at least 24 hours in advance of the convening of the meeting. No alderman shall be prohibited from addressing the council on a matter of business by the order of business adopted. The order of business for any special, emergency or reconvened meeting of the council shall conform to the requirements of any applicable state legislative statute. The order of business may be changed by the mayor from time to time as the mayor determines necessary or desirable. 
(b)  Each meeting of the city council, whether regular, special, emergency or reconvened, shall begin with a roll call. 
(Code 1977, § 2.08.090; Code 1990, § 2-79; Ord. No. 94-1723, § 1, 10-17-1994) 
Sec. 2-115. - Resolutions. 
    Any resolution submitted to the council shall be reduced to writing before being voted upon, at the request of any two members of the council. 
(Code 1977, § 2.08.110; Code 1990, § 2-81) 
Sec. 2-116. - Procedure for addressing council. 
    No person other than the mayor or a member of the council shall address that body at any regular or special meeting of the council, except upon consent of a majority of the members present. 
(Code 1977, § 2.08.120; Code 1990, § 2-82) 
Secs. 2-117-2-147. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - PUBLIC COMMENT AT MEETINGS 

Sec. 2-148. - Public meetings; public comment. 
    Any person seeking to address the members of the city council, or any commission, committee or other official body of the city at any public meeting will be permitted to speak on any matter listed on the agenda, or on any other matter of public concern, in accord with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1990, § 2-500; Ord. No. 2011-2480, § 1, 9-20-2011) 
Sec. 2-149. - City council meetings. 
(a)  The agenda for each meeting of the city council shall specify a time during the meeting at which any member of the public may address the council. Any person so addressing the council shall be required to speak into the microphone provided, and shall state the name and address of the person and the topic of discussion at the beginning of that person's comments. 
(b)  No person shall speak or address the city council unless first recognized by the mayor or other presiding officer at the appropriate agenda time. 
(c)  Subject to section 2-150, public comment at a city council meeting shall be limited to no more than five minutes per commenter and to no more than one hour, total, per meeting, unless either of said time limits is extended by majority vote of the members present. The mayor may designate the city clerk, chief of police or other officer of the city to monitor the time utilized by each speaker, and to notify the speaker when the allotted time has expired. 
(d)  At any meeting of the city council, the mayor, at his discretion, may require that any person desiring to address the council at that meeting sign in on a request to comment form providing the name, address and topic to be discussed or addressed by the speaker. 
(e)  If the mayor recognizes that more than 20 persons desire to address the council at any one meeting, he may limit each speaker to comment of no more than three minutes and, whenever any group of persons wishes to address the members of the city council on the same subject matter, the mayor may ask that a spokesperson be chosen from the group, but provided that if a spokesperson speaks on behalf of multiple members of the group, the mayor may permit the spokesperson to address for a period longer than the otherwise required time limits. In addition, if other matters are to be presented by other persons in the same group, the mayor may request that the group limit the number of such persons, or may request that the additional comment be limited to information which has not already been presented by the group spokesperson or other members of the group, in order that the total comment period for that meeting not be exceeded. 
(f)  Any person invited by the mayor or a member of the city council to address the members of the council at a meeting are subject to such time limitations as the majority of the members of the council present may prescribe. 
(Code 1990, § 2-501; Ord. No. 2011-2480, § 1, 9-20-2011) 
Sec. 2-150. - Committees, commissions and other boards. 
(a)  The time limits specified by section 2-149 shall not apply to persons addressing the planning and zoning commission, or the police fire commission, when either of those bodies is conducting a quasi-judicial hearing on a zoning or variance request, or on a disciplinary matter, and in such instances, the usual and customary rules as applied by that body shall govern speech by members of the public; provided, however, that the planning and zoning commission may establish reasonable rules and time limits regarding the number and amount of time that persons advocating for or against any zoning request must follow, so long as such rules conform to other requirements of law. 
(b)  Committees of the city council, the industrial development commission or any other committee or commission duly appointed or acting pursuant to authority of the city council may establish rules for public comment and persons wishing to address that committee, commission, or body, but provided that no rules shall be adopted by any of such committees or commissions that are more restrictive than the rules established for comment to the city council by the provisions of section 2-149. 
(Code 1990, § 2-502; Ord. No. 2011-2480, § 1, 9-20-2011) 
Sec. 2-151. - Publication. 
    The city clerk shall post the provisions of sections 2-149 and 2-150 on the city's official website, and shall provide a copy of this article to any person making and submitting a request. In addition, the city clerk shall create and provide a request to comment sheet for use for signing in prior to each city council meeting. 
(Code 1990, § 2-503; Ord. No. 2011-2480, § 1, 9-20-2011) 
Secs. 2-152-2-170. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES GENERALLY 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-171. - Personnel manual. 
    The council shall adopt a personnel manual containing rules and regulations pertaining to wages, hours, leave time and other personnel matters. 
(Code 1990, § 2-106) 
Sec. 2-172. - Appointments. 
    Employees shall be selected by the mayor in the absence of any provision to the contrary. 
(Code 1977, § 2.68.010; Code 1990, § 2-107) 
Sec. 2-173. - Terms of office. 
    Every appointive officer of the city shall hold office for a term of one year or until his successor is appointed and qualified, unless it is otherwise provided by ordinance. Employees selected shall serve so long as their services are desired. 
(Code 1977, § 2.68.020; Code 1990, § 2-108) 
Sec. 2-174. - Disposition of moneys received. 
    Every officer of the city shall at least once every day turn over all moneys received by him in his official capacity to the clerk with a statement in which he shows the source from which the same was received. 
(Code 1977, § 2.68.060; Code 1990, § 2-111) 
Sec. 2-175. - Records; inspection. 
    All records kept by any officer of the city shall be open to inspection by any member of the council at all reasonable times, whether or not such records are required to be kept by statute or ordinance. 
(Code 1977, § 2.68.070; Code 1990, § 2-112) 
Sec. 2-176. - Compensation. 
    All officers and employees of the city shall receive such salaries as may be provided from time to time by ordinance. No officer or employee receiving a salary from the city shall be entitled to retain any portion of any fees collected by him in the performance of his duties as municipal officer or employee in the absence of a specific ordinance provision to that effect. 
(Code 1977, § 2.68.090; Code 1990, § 2-114) 
Sec. 2-177. - Termination of office. 
    Every officer of the city upon the termination of his office for any cause whatsoever, shall deliver to his successor all books, records and other property of the city in accordance with state statutes. If no successor has been appointed within one week after the termination of office, such property shall be delivered either to the clerk or to the treasurer. 
(Code 1977, § 2.68.100; Code 1990, § 2-115) 
Sec. 2-178. - Impersonation. 
    It is unlawful for any person, without lawful authority to impersonate any city officer or employee. Any person violating this section shall be guilty of a Class A violation and subject to penalty as set forth and provided for in section 1-41 of the Municipal Code. 
(Code 1977, § 2.68.110; Code 1990, § 2-116; Ord. No. 2016-2248, § 1, 1-5-2016) 
Secs. 2-179-2-196. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - SALARIES OF ELECTED OFFICIALS 

Sec. 2-197. - Mayor. 
(a)  The salary for the office of mayor of the city is hereby fixed at $6,000.00 per year, to be payable in equal monthly increments and said salary shall become effective at the commencement of and during the term of office of mayor beginning next after the election to be held on the first Tuesday in April, 2005. 
(b)  The salary for the office of mayor of the city is hereby fixed at $12,000.00 per year, to be payable in equal monthly increments and said salary shall become effective at the commencement of and during the term of office of mayor beginning next after the election to be held on the first Tuesday in April, 2009. 
(Code 1990, § 2-400; Ord. No. 2000-1951, § 1, 9-19-2000; Ord. No. 2004-2101A, § 1, 8-3-2004; Ord. No. 2008-2285, § 1, 7-15-2008) 
Sec. 2-198. - City clerk. 
(a)  The salary for the office of city clerk is hereby fixed at $3,600.00 per year, to be payable in equal monthly increments, and said salary shall become effective at the commencement of the term of office of the city clerk beginning next after the election to be held on the first Tuesday in April, 2017. 
(Code 1990, § 2-401; Ord. No. 2000-1951, § 1, 9-19-2000; Ord. No. 2002-2008, § 1, 5-21-2002; Ord. No. 2004-2101A, § 2, 8-3-2004; Ord. No. 2008-2289, § 1, 9-16-2008; Ord. No. 2016-2282, § 1, 9-20-2016) 
Sec. 2-199. - City treasurer. 
    The salary for the office of city treasurer is hereby fixed at $3,600.00 per year, to be payable in equal monthly increments, and said salary shall become effective at the commencement of the term of office of the city treasurer beginning next after the election to be held on the first Tuesday in April, 2013. 
(Code 1990, § 2-402; Ord. No. 2000-1951, § 1, 9-19-2000; Ord. No. 2012-2064, § 1, 7-13-2012) 
Sec. 2-200. - Alderman. 
    The salary for the office of alderman is hereby fixed at $300.00 per month for each alderman, and said salary shall become effective at the commencement of the term of office of aldermen beginning next after the election to be held on the first Tuesday in April, 2001. 
(Code 1990, § 2-403; Ord. No. 2000-1951, § 1, 9-19-2000) 
Secs. 2-201-2-223. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - EMPLOYEES ETHICS 

Sec. 2-224. - Adoption of Act. 
(a)  The regulations of section 5-15 (5 ILCS 430/5-15) and article 10 (5 ILCS 430/10-10 through 430/10-40) of the State Official and Employees Ethics Acts, 5 ILCS 430/1-1 et seq., (hereinafter referred to as the "Act" in this division) are hereby adopted by reference and made applicable to the officers and employees of the city to the extent required by 5 ILCS 430/70-5. 
(b)  The solicitation or acceptance of gifts prohibited to be solicited or accepted under this Act, by an officer or any employee of the city, is hereby prohibited. 
(c)  The offering or making of gifts prohibited to be offered or made to an officer or employee of the city under the Act, is hereby prohibited. 
(d)  The participation in political activities prohibited under the Act, by an officer or employee of the city, is hereby prohibited. 
(e)  For purposes of this division, the terms "officer" and "employee" shall be defined as set forth in 5 ILCS 430/70-5(c). 
(f)  The penalties for violations of this division shall be the same as those penalties set forth in 5 ILCS 430/50-5 for similar violations of the Act. 
(g)  This division does not repeal or otherwise amend or modify any existing ordinances or policies which regulate the conduct of the city officers and employees. To the extent that any such existing ordinances or policies are less restrictive than this division, however, the provisions of this division shall prevail in accordance with the provisions of 5 ILCS 430/70-5(a). 
(h)  Any amendment to the Act that becomes effective after the effective date of the ordinance from which this division is derived shall be incorporated into this division by reference and shall be applicable to the solicitation, acceptance, offering and making of gifts and to prohibited political activities. However, any amendment that makes its provisions optional for adoption by municipalities shall not be incorporated into this division by reference without formal action by the city council. 
(i)  If the state supreme court declares the Act unconstitutional in its entirety, then this division shall be repealed as of the date that the state supreme court's decision becomes final and not subject to any further appeals or hearings. This division shall be deemed repealed without further action by the city council if the Act is found unconstitutional by the state supreme court. 
(j)  If the state supreme court declares part of the Act unconstitutional but upholds the constitutionality of the remainder of the Act, or does not address the remainder of the Act, then the remainder of the Act as adopted by this division shall remain in full force and effect; however, that part of this division relating to the part of the Act found unconstitutional shall be deemed repealed without further action by the city council. 
(Code 1990, § 2-300; Ord. No. 2004-2090, § 1, 5-18-2004) 
Sec. 2-225. - Ethics advisor. 
(a)  The mayor, with the advice and consent of the city council, shall designate an ethics advisor for the city. The duties of the ethics advisor may be delegated to an officer or employee of the city unless the position has been created as an office by the city. 
(b)  The ethics advisor shall provide guidance to the officers and employees of the city concerning the interpretation of and compliance with the provisions of this division and state ethics laws. The ethics advisor shall perform such other duties as may be delegated by the city council. 
(Code 1990, § 2-301; Ord. No. 2004-2090, § 1, 5-18-2004) 
Sec. 2-226. - Ethics commission. 
(a)  There is hereby created a commission to be known as the ethics commission. The commission shall be comprised of three members appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the city council. No person shall be appointed as a member of the commission who is related, either by blood or marriage up to the degree of first cousin, to any elected officer of the city. 
(b)  At the first meeting of the commission, the initial appointees shall draw lots to determine their initial terms. Two commissioners shall serve two-year terms, and the third commissioner shall serve a one-year term. Thereafter, all commissioners shall be appointed to two-year terms. Commissioners may be reappointed to serve subsequent terms. The commissioners shall choose a chairperson from their number. Meetings shall be held at the call of the chairperson or any two commissioners. A quorum shall consist of two commissioners, and official action by the commission shall require the affirmative vote of two members. 
(c)  The mayor, with the advice and consent of the city council, may remove a commissioner in case of incompetency, neglect of duty or malfeasance in office after service on the commissioner by certified mail, return receipt requested, a copy of the written charges against the commissioner and after providing an opportunity to be heard in person or by counsel upon not less than ten days' notice. Vacancies shall be filled in the same manner as original appointments. 
(d)  The commission shall have the following powers and duties: 
(1)  To promulgate procedures and rules governing the performance of its duties and the exercise of its powers. 
(2)  Upon receipt of a signed, notarized, written complaint, to investigate, conduct hearings and deliberations, issue recommendations for disciplinary action and refer violation of this division to the appropriate attorney for prosecution. The commission shall, however, act only upon the receipt of a written complaint alleging a violation of this division and not upon its own prerogative. 
(3)  To receive information from the public pertaining to its investigation and to require additional information and documents from persons who may have violated the provisions of this division. 
(4)  To compel the attendance of witnesses and to compel the production of books and papers pertinent to an investigation. It is the obligation of all officers and employees of the city to cooperate with the commission during the course of its investigations. Failure or refusal to cooperate with requests by the commission shall constitute grounds for discipline or discharge. 
(5)  The powers and duties of the commission are limited to matters clearly within the purview of this division. 
(e)  The following procedures shall govern the filing of complaints: 
(1)  Complaints alleging a violation of this division shall be filed with the ethics commission. 
(2)  Within three business days after the receipt of a complaint, the commission shall send by certified mail, return receipt requested, a notice to the respondent that a complaint has been filed against him or her and a copy of the complaint. The commission shall send by certified mail, return receipt requested, a confirmation of the receipt of the complaint to the complainant within three business days after receipt by the commission. The notices to the respondent and the complainant shall also advise them of the date, time, and place of the meeting to determine the sufficiency of the complaint and to establish whether probable cause exists to proceed. 
(3)  Upon not less than 48 hours' public notice, the commission shall meet to review the sufficiency of the complaint and, if the complaint is deemed sufficient to allege a violation of this division, to determine whether there is probable cause, based on the evidence presented by the complainant, to proceed. The meeting may be closed to the public to the extent authorized by the Open Meetings Act (5 ILCS 120/1.01 et seq.). The commission shall issue notice to the complainant and the respondent of the commission's ruling on the sufficiency of the complaint and, if necessary, on probable cause to proceed within seven business days after receiving the complaint. 
(4)  If the complaint is deemed sufficient to allege a violation of this division then the commission shall notify in writing the attorney designated by the city council to prosecute such actions and shall transmit to the attorney the complaint and all additional documents in the custody of the commission concerning the alleged violation. If the complaint is deemed not sufficient to allege a violation or if there is no determination of probable cause, then the commission shall send by certified mail, return receipt requested, a notice to the parties of the decision to dismiss the complaint, and that notice shall be made public. 
(Code 1990, § 2-302; Ord. No. 2004-2090, § 1, 5-18-2004) 
Secs. 2-227-2-245. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - SPECIFIC OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 2-246-2-268. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CITY ADMINISTRATOR 

Sec. 2-269. - Definitions. 
    The city administrator shall also be known as an employee of the city and as an appointed officer of the city herein. The city shall also be referred to in this division as the "city" and as the "employer." 
(Code 1990, § 2-120; Ord. No. 2002-1993, § 1, 2-5-2002) 
Sec. 2-270. - Creation of office. 
    There is hereby created the office of city administrator for the city. 
(Code 1990, § 2-121; Ord. No. 2002-1993, § 1, 2-5-2002) 
Sec. 2-271. - Appointment, term of office, other terms and conditions of employment. 
(a)  Appointment; term of office. The city administrator shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the city council by a majority vote. At the time of his appointment, the city administrator need not be a resident of the city, but he shall establish residency within the limits of the electric utility of the city within one year from the date of his appointment. No elected official of the city shall receive such appointment while he is serving as an elected official or within one year after leaving office. 
(b)  Hours, compensation and terms of employment. The position of city administrator shall be a full-time position, and the administrator appointed shall devote substantially full-time to the duties of the position, and shall be required to attend all city council meetings (unless specifically excused from doing so by the mayor in advance) and such other meetings of committees of the city council and other agencies and bodies as he may from time to time be directed by the mayor or city council. Rate of compensation of the administrator shall be fixed by the city council and may be adjusted from time to time. Subject to the terms and conditions of state law and this division, the city council may enter into an employment contract with the person appointed as city administrator by which other conditions of employment, fringe benefits, terms and conditions of discipline, terms and conditions of severance or separation and all other appropriate matters may be agreed. In the absence of any provision in an employment agreement, compensation, fringe benefits, levels of support for continuing professional education, separation pay, causes for discipline or termination and procedures for imposition of discipline or termination, performance expectations and performance evaluations and other conditions of employment shall be fixed and determined by the city council, and the appointment shall be considered as employment at the will and discretion of the city council. 
(c)  Removal from office. The person appointed as city administrator shall be subject to removal from office at any time by vote of the city council. 
(Code 1990, § 2-122; Ord. No. 2002-1993, § 1, 2-5-2002; Ord. No. 2011-2475, § 1, 8-2-2011) 
Sec. 2-272. - Duties and responsibilities as city administrator. 
    The city administrator shall be the chief administrative officer of the city. He shall report to and be responsible to the mayor and city council for the proper administration of all affairs of the city except such matters as the mayor and city council may from time to time determine shall be under its direct control and supervision, or as the mayor and city council have determined to be under the control or direction of any other officer. For the carrying out of his duties and responsibilities, the city administrator shall have the powers and duties as follows: 
(1)  To recommend appointment, discipline, suspension or removal of any employee of the city, except police or fire personnel under the jurisdiction of the board of fire and police commissioners, and except as herein otherwise provided. The city administrator, however, shall not have power to appoint, suspend or remove as to the following offices; city attorney, chief of police, fire chief, superintendent of streets, superintendent of electric utility, superintendent of water, superintendent of wastewater, director of economic development, city accountant, city engineer, building official, deputy city clerk and any other officers which are appointed by the mayor. 
(2)  Prepare an annual budget and capital program and submit it to the city council together with a message describing its important features and be responsible for its administration after adoption. Department budgets shall be prepared in consultation with the head of each respective department. 
(3)  Administer and supervise departmental compliance with the provisions of the annual budget as adopted by the city council. 
(4)  Prepare and submit to the mayor and city council as of the end of each fiscal year a complete report on the finances and administrative activities of the city for the preceding year, and keep the mayor and city council advised of the financial condition and future needs of the city, and make such recommendations as he may deem advisable with respect thereto. 
(5)  Recommend to the city council a schedule of pay for each appointive office and position in the city service, including minimum, intermediate and maximum rates, and provide supporting material relied upon in determining the recommendations. 
(6)  Advise the city council on pending decisions of public policy, and recommend to the city council (from time to time) adoption of such measures as he may deem necessary or expedient for the health, safety or welfare of the community for the improvement of administrative services. 
(7)  Recommend consolidation, combination or separation of offices, positions, departments or units under his jurisdiction, to the city council. 
(8)  Attend all meetings of the city council unless excused therefrom and take part in the discussion of all matters coming before the city council. He shall be entitled to notice of all regular and special meetings of the city council. He shall attend meetings of such other committees, boards and organizations as from time to time directed by the mayor or city council, and upon request of the city council, provide a report of such meeting. 
(9)  Supervise the purchase of all materials, supplies and equipment for which funds are provided in the budget; let contracts necessary for operation or maintenance of city services for amounts up to and including $5,000.00; review sealed bids for purchases or contracts in excess of $10,000.00 and make recommendations for approval or rejection of them to the city council; advise the city council on the advantages or disadvantages of contract and bid proposals; and, if authorized by a vote of the aldermen then holding office, enter into contracts for work or purchases in excess of $10,000.00. No purchase shall be made, contract let, or obligation incurred for any item or service which exceeds the current budget appropriation without a supplemental appropriation by the city council. The city administrator may issue such rules governing purchasing procedures within the administrative organization as the city council shall approve. Competitive bids need not be advertised for nor received, and the city administrator may enter into contracts (other than contracts for public works projects) which by their nature are not adapted to award by competitive bidding, such as, but not limited to, contracts for the services of individuals possessing a high degree of professional skill where the ability or fitness of the individual plays an important part, and contracts for supplies, materials, parts or equipment which are available only from a single source, if such contract or purchase is authorized by a vote of the city council then holding office. 
(10)  Recommend to the city council all matters pertaining to the enforcement of laws and ordinances. 
(11)  Investigate the affairs of any department or division under his jurisdiction; investigate all complaints in relation to matters under his jurisdiction concerning the administration of the government of the city, and in regard to service maintained by the public utilities in the city and see that all franchises, permits and privileges granted by the city are faithfully observed. 
(12)  Devote all reasonable time to the discharge of his official duties. The city administrator shall act so as not to create any conflict of interest between his personal activities and his official duties. He shall have no financial or personal interest in any contract or undertaking in any way involving the city. 
(13)  Make, or cause to be made, monthly and annual reports to the mayor and the city council of the activities of all departments under his jurisdiction and of financial reports in such form as requested by the mayor and city council. 
(14)  Provide background and supporting material to the negotiating committee of the city council and participate in collective bargaining as requested by mayor. He shall also meet with department heads of affected departments to obtain background and supporting materials for collective bargaining sessions and shall meet with department heads from time to time to provide education to the department head in order to allow the department head to comply with the terms and requirements of any collective bargaining agreement covering employees within that department head's control. 
(15)  Meet the public on behalf of the mayor and city council; receive suggestions; hear and investigate complaints in relation to all matters concerning the administration of the government of the city. 
(16)  Inform succeeding mayors and city councils of the general principles of administrative programs and policies of previous administrations so that a continuity of programs and policies may be possible. 
(17)  Perform such other duties as may be prescribed by the mayor and city council, not inconsistent with ordinances or laws. 
(18)  Inform the city council of current federal and state legislation affecting the city and be responsible for obtaining federal and state grants applicable to the city. 
(19)  As required by the terms of any collective bargaining agreement governing employees of the city, hear and adjust, or recommend solutions or dispositions of, grievances submitted by any employee or group of employees. 
(Code 1990, § 2-123; Ord. No. 2002-1993, § 1, 2-5-2002; Ord. No. 2011-2464, § 1, 6-21-2011; Ord. No. 2011-2475, § 2, 8-2-2011) 
Sec. 2-273. - Qualifications and duties as city administrator. 
(a)  The city administrator shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the city council solely on the basis of executive and administrative qualifications and shall possess: 
(1)  A degree in public administration or public finance or experience in employment as a public administrator; 
(2)  Knowledge of accepted practice in respect to the administration of local government and the duties of the office of city administrator. 
(b)  The appointment shall be made without consideration of race, gender, political affiliation, nationality, age or religious beliefs. 
(Code 1990, § 2-124; Ord. No. 2002-1993, § 1, 2-5-2002) 
Sec. 2-274. - Bond. 
    Prior to undertaking his duties, the city administrator shall furnish a fidelity bond in the penal sum of $10,000.00 to be approved by the city council, such bond to be conditioned on the faithful performance of his duties and the payment of all money received by the administrator, according to law and ordinance. The premium of the bond shall be paid by the city. 
(Code 1990, § 2-125; Ord. No. 2002-1993, § 1, 2-5-2002; Ord. No. 2011-2475, § 3, 8-2-2011) 
Sec. 2-275. - Ex officio member of boards and commissions. 
    The city administrator shall be an ex officio member of the planning and zoning commission, zoning board of appeals, or other committees that the city council may designate from time to time. 
(Code 1990, § 2-126; Ord. No. 2002-1993, § 1, 2-5-2002) 
Secs. 2-276-2-298. - Reserved.

Sec. 2-308. - Other duties.

(Code 1990, § 2-147; Ord. No. 2008-2289, § 3, 9-16-2008; Ord. No. 2016-2292, § 1, 12-20-2016)

DIVISION 5.5. - CITY COLLECTOR 

Sec. 2-390. - Establishment. 
    There is hereby created the office of city collector, an administrative office of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2016-2293, § 1, 12-20-2016) 
Sec. 2-391. - Appointment. 
    The collector shall be annually appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the city council. Said appointment shall be considered by the council on the basis of the individual's administrative qualifications, with special reference to actual experience in or knowledge of accepted practice with respect to the duties of office. The city council shall annually determine the salary of the position. 
(Ord. No. 2016-2293, § 1, 12-20-2016) 
Sec. 2-392. - Duties generally. 
(a)  The collector shall preserve all warrants returned to the collector's office, and the collector shall keep books and accounts in the matter that the city council may prescribe. All warrants, books, vouchers, and papers pertaining to the office of collector may be examined at any time by the mayor, city clerk, city treasurer or committee of the city council. The collector shall weekly pay over to the treasurer all funds of the city received by the collector from any source, taking the treasurer's receipt in duplicate and filing one of the receipts immediately with the clerk. At that time, or upon demand, the clerk shall give the collector a copy of any receipts so filed. 
(b)  The collector shall be responsible for filing and recording liens on real property for money owed to the city. 
(c)  The collector shall keep the special assessment warrant books, published for delinquent special assessments, and send notices of such delinquencies to the county collector. 
(d)  When required by the city council, the collector shall make a written report to the city council or to any officer designated by the city council of all money collected by the collector, the account collected upon, or of any other official matter. Between April 1 and April 10 of each year, the collector shall file with the clerk's office a statement of all the money collected by the office during the year, the particular warrant, special assessment or account upon which collected, the balance of money uncollected on all warrants in the collector's possession, and the balance remaining uncollected at the time of the return on all warrants that the collector returned to the clerk during the preceding fiscal year, The clerk shall publish the statement at least once, within ten days in a newspaper with general circulation within the city. 
(e)  The collector is prohibited from keeping the money of the municipality in his or her possession, or in the possession of any person for his or her use, beyond the time prescribed for its payment to the treasurer. Any violation of this provision shall subject the collector to immediate removal from office. 
(f)  The collector shall have whatever further duties and responsibilities as may be delegated or assigned to that office by the mayor and the city council. 
(Ord. No. 2016-2293, § 1, 12-20-2016) 
Sec. 2-393. - City clerk as collector. 
    In the event the city clerk is appointed by the mayor and the city council as collector, such appointee shall be entitled to the compensation for both offices. 
(Ord. No. 2016-2293, § 1, 12-20-2016) 
Sec. 2-394. - City collector designated Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) officer. 
(a)  The collector is hereby appointed by the city council to be the designated chief Freedom of Information Act officer for the city to be responsible for and to perform those duties required by the Illinois Freedom of Information Act (5 ILCS 140/1 et seq.). In such capacity the collector shall be responsible for maintaining the city's compliance with all statutory obligations of the Act and be empowered to consult with the city attorney for all issues relating to the Act. The deputy clerk shall also serve as a designated Freedom of Information Act officer and shall assist the city collector in performing such duties as necessary to maintain the city's compliance with the Act. 
(b)  The city collector shall make available for inspection and copying upon request or through the mail: 
(1)  The directory of FOIA officers; 
(2)  The address where request for public records should be directed; and 
(3)  Any schedule of fees allowable under Section 6 of the act (5 ILCS 140/6) and shall also cause that information to be posted on the official website of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2016-2293, § 1, 12-20-2016) 
Secs. 2-395-2-404. - Reserved.

(b)  All monies received from any source by the commission, or by the city for industrial development purposes, shall be deposited in such fund. 
(c)  All expenditures made by the commission shall be made from such fund and must be authorized by a majority vote of all commission members. Expenditures authorized by the commission shall not exceed funds available in the industrial development fund. The commission shall not incur financial obligations for the city in excess of funds available in the industrial development fund. The industrial development fund shall be subject to audit in the same manner as all other funds and monies of the city. 
(Code 1990, § 4-92; Ord. No. 86-1460, § 2.96.70, 11-17-1986)
