State Law reference- Environmental Protection Act, 415 ILCS 5/1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 8-1-8-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - GROUNDWATER SUPPLY PROTECTION[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Illinois Groundwater Protection Act, 415 ILCS 55/1 et seq. 

Sec. 8-19. - Purpose and intent. 
(a)  In the interest of securing and promoting the public health, safety, and welfare, to preserve the quality and quantity of groundwater resources in order to ensure a safe and adequate water supply for the present and future generations, and to protect and preserve groundwater resources currently in use and those aquifers having a potential for future use as a public water supply, provisions of this article shall apply to all properties located within the city and the five-year recharge zone. This article establishes regulations for land uses within the groundwater protection areas for: 
(1)  Inspection and monitoring standards for new regulated substance facilities; 
(2)  Uniform standards for release reporting; 
(3)  Emergency response; 
(4)  Substance management planning; 
(5)  Permit procedures; and 
(6)  Enforcement. 
(b)  It is the intent of this article to provide a method: 
(1)  To protect the groundwater resources of the city, and the surrounding area. 
(2)  To provide a means of regulating land uses within the groundwater protection area. 
(3)  To protect the city drinking water supply and that of the surrounding area from potential impacts by facilities that store, handle, treat, use, or produce substances that pose a hazard to groundwater quality. 
(Code 1990, § 15.6-1; Ord. No. 99-1892, § I, 7-6-1999) 
Sec. 8-20. - Definitions. 
    Except as stated in this article, and unless a different meaning of a word or term is clear from the context, the definition of words or terms in this article shall be the same as those used in the Illinois Environmental Protection Act (415 ILCS 5/1 et seq.) and title IV of the Environmental Protection Act (415 ILCS 5/14 et seq.), as amended from time to time. 
    Act means the Illinois Environmental Protection Act (415 ILCS 5/1 et seq.). 
    Agency means the state environmental protection agency. 
    Aquifer means saturated (with groundwater) soils and geologic material which are sufficiently permeable to readily yield economically useful quantities of water to wells, springs, or streams under ordinary hydraulic gradients. 
    Board means the state pollution control board. 
    Containment device means a device that is designed to contain an unauthorized release, retain it for cleanup, and prevent released materials from penetrating into the ground. 
    Facility means: 
(1)  Any building, structure, installation, equipment, pipe or pipeline including, but not limited to, any pipe into a sewer or publicly owned treatment works, well, pit, pond, lagoon, impoundment, ditch, landfill, storage container, motor vehicle, rolling stock, or aircraft; or 
(2)  Any site or area where a hazardous substance has been deposited, stored, disposed of, or placed, or otherwise come to be located. 
    Groundwater means underground water which occurs within the saturated zone and geologic materials where the fluid pressure in the pore space is equal to or greater than atmospheric pressure. 
    Groundwater protection area (GWPA) means the portion of an aquifer within the minimum setback zone, maximum setback zone, or five-year capture zone of a well or well field, as delineated in exhibit 1 of this article. 
    Groundwater protection overlay zones are zones of the GWPA designated to provide differential levels of protection. Each GWPA is subdivided into three groundwater protection overlay zones as described below and as illustrated in exhibit 1: 
(1)  Zone 1: Minimum setback zone. The geographic area located between a well or well field providing potable water to a community water supply and a radial area of 400 feet (122 meters). 
(2)  Zone 2: Maximum setback. The geographic area located between a well or well field providing potable water to a community water supply and a regular or irregularly shaped area not to exceed 1,000 feet (305 meters) from the wellhead, but excluding the minimum setback zone. 
(3)  Zone 3: Five-year capture zone. The geographic area located between a well or well field providing potable water to a community water supply and the delineated five-year zone of capture but excluding Zones 1 and 2. 
    New potential primary source means: 
(1)  A potential primary source which is not in existence or for which construction has not commenced at its location as of July 6, 1999; 
(2)  A potential primary source which expands laterally beyond the currently permitted boundary, or if the primary source is not permitted, the boundary in existence as of July 6, 1999; or 
(3)  A potential primary source which is part of a facility that undergoes major reconstruction. Such reconstruction shall be deemed to have taken place where the fixed capital cost of the new components constructed within a two-year period exceed 50 percent of the fixed capital cost of a comparable entirely new facility. 
Construction shall be deemed commenced when all necessary federal, state and local approvals have been obtained, and work at the site has been initiated and proceeds in a reasonable continuous manner to completion. 
    New potential route means: 
(1)  A potential route which is not in existence or for which construction has not commenced at its location as of July 6, 1999; or 
(2)  A potential route which expands laterally beyond the currently permitted boundary or, if the potential route is not permitted, the boundary in existence as of July 6, 1999. 
Construction shall be deemed commenced when all necessary federal, state and local approvals have been obtained, and work at the site has been initiated and proceeds in a reasonably continuous manner to completion. 
    New potential secondary source means: 
(1)  A potential secondary source which is not in existence or for which construction has not commenced at its location as of July 6, 1999; 
(2)  A potential secondary source which expands, laterally beyond the currently permitted boundary or, if the secondary source is not permitted, the boundary in existence as of July 6, 1999, other than an expansion for handling of livestock waste or for treating domestic wastewaters; or 
(3)  A potential secondary source which is part of a facility that undergoes major reconstruction. Such reconstruction shall be deemed to have taken place where the fixed capital cost of the new components constructed within a two-year period exceed 50 percent of the fixed capital cost of a new comparable entirely new facility. 
Construction shall be deemed commenced when all necessary federal, state and local approvals have been obtained, and work at the site has been initiated and proceeds in a reasonably continuous manner to completion. 
    Operator means any person in control of, or having responsibility for daily operation of a facility. 
    Owner means any person who owns a site, facility or unit or who owns the land on which the site, facility or unit is located. 
    Potable water means water that is satisfactory for drinking, culinary, and domestic purposes meeting currently accepted water supply practices and principals. 
    Potential primary source means any unit at a facility or site not currently subject to a removal or remedial action which: 
(1)  Is utilized for the treatment, storage, or disposal of any hazardous or special waste not generated at the site; 
(2)  Is utilized for the disposal of municipal waste not generated at the site, other than landscape waste and construction and demolition debris; 
(3)  Is utilized for the landfilling, land treating, surface impounding or piling of any hazardous or special waste that is generated on the site or at other sites owned, controlled or operated by the same person; or 
(4)  Stores or accumulates at any time more than 75,000 pounds (34,020 kilograms) above ground, or more than 7,500 pounds (3,042 kilograms) below ground, of any hazardous substances. 
    Potential route means abandoned and improperly plugged wells of all kinds, drainage wells, all injection wells, including closed loop heat pump wells, and any excavation for the discovery, development or production of stone, sand or gravel. 
    Potential secondary source means any unit at a facility or a site not currently subject to a removal or remedial action, other than a potential primary source which: 
(1)  Is utilized for the landfilling, land treating, or surface impounding of waste that is generated on the site or at other sites owned, controlled or operated by the same person, other than livestock and landscape waste, and construction and demolition debris; 
(2)  Stores or accumulates at any time more than 25,000 pounds (11,340 kilograms) but not more than 75,000 pounds (34,020 kilograms) above ground, or more than 2,500 pounds (1,134 kilograms) but not more than 7,500 pounds (3,402 kilograms) below ground, of any hazardous substances; 
(3)  Stores or accumulates at any time more than 25,000 gallons (94,633 liters) above ground, or more than 500 gallons (1,893 liters) below ground, of petroleum, including crude oil or any fraction thereof which is not otherwise specifically listed or designated as a hazardous substance; 
(4)  Stores or accumulates pesticides, fertilizers, or road oils for purposes of commercial application or for distribution to retail sales outlets; 
(5)  Stores or accumulates at any one time more than 50,000 pounds (22,680 kilograms) of any de-icing agent; or 
(6)  Is utilized for handling livestock waste or for treating domestic wastewater other than private sewage disposal systems as defined in the Private Sewage Disposal Licensing Act (225 ILCS 225/1 et seq.). 
    Recharge area means the area through which precipitation and surface water can enter an aquifer. 
    Regulated substance means any extremely hazardous substance listed in appendix A of 40 CFR part 355 that is present at a facility in an amount in excess of its threshold planning quantity, any hazardous substance listed in 40 CFR section 302.4 that is present at a facility in an amount in excess of its reportable quantity or in excess of its threshold planning quantity if it is also an extremely hazardous substance, and any petroleum including crude oil or any fraction thereof that is present at a facility in an amount exceeding 100 pounds unless it is specifically listed as a hazardous substance or an extremely hazardous substance. The term "regulated substance" does not mean any substance to the extent it is used for personal, family, or household purposes, or to the extent it is present in the same form as a product packaged for distribution to and use by the general public. The term "regulated substance" does not mean agricultural chemicals and petroleum utilized at a farm or farm residence for the purpose of agricultural production. The term "regulated substance" means the same as the term "chemical substance" as defined in 430 ILCS 45/3. 
    Saturated zone means the zone in which the voids in the rock or soil are filled with water pressure greater than atmospheric pressure. 
    Setback zone means a geographic area designated pursuant to the Act and this article, containing a potable water supply well or a potential source or potential route, having a continuous boundary, and within which certain prohibitions or regulations are applicable in order to protect groundwaters. 
    Site means any location, place, tract of land, or facilities, including, but not limited to, buildings, and improvements used for purposes subject to regulations or control by the Act or regulations thereunder. 
    Unauthorized released means any spilling, leaking, emitting, discharging, escaping, leaching, or disposing of a regulated substance in a quantity greater than one gallon (eight pounds) from a facility into a containment system, into the air, into groundwater, surface water, surface soils or subsurface soils. The term "unauthorized release" does not include: 
(1)  Intentional withdrawals of regulated substances for the purpose of legitimate sale, use, or disposal; and 
(2)  Discharges permitted under federal, state, or local law. 
    Underlying permit includes the building permits, sewer tap agreements, stormwater retention permits, occupancy permits, preliminary plat and final plat (required by the city, subdivision ordinance) and any other applicable approval or permit required by the city in relation to the facility. 
    Unit means any device, mechanism, equipment, or area (exclusive and land utilized only for agricultural production). 
    Well means any excavation that is drilled, cored, bored, driven, dug, fitted or otherwise constructed when the intended use of such excavation is for the location diversion, artificial recharge, or acquisition of groundwater. 
    Well field means an area which contains one or more wells for obtaining a potable water supply. 
    Well number means a well number owned and operated by the city water department, as depicted on exhibit 2. 
(Code 1990, § 15.6-2; Ord. No. 99-1892, § I, 7-6-1999) 
Sec. 8-21. - Establishment of setback zones. 
(a)  Minimum setback zones are hereby established as set forth in exhibit 1, as that area within a 400-foot (122-meter) radius of each existing or permitted community water supply well within the city or within 400 feet (122 meters) of the city limits of the city. 
(b)  Maximum setback zones are hereby established as set forth in exhibit 1, as that area within a regular or irregular shaped 1,000-foot (305-meter) radius of each existing or permitted community water supply well within the city, or within 1,000 feet (305 meters) of the city limits of the city. 
(c)  Five-year capture zones are hereby established as set forth in exhibit 1, which incorporates and adopts the recharge areas identified by the groundwater protection needs assessment performed for the city pursuant to section 17.1 of the Act. 
(Code 1990, § 15.6-3; Ord. No. 99-1892, § I, 7-6-1999) 
Sec. 8-22. - Applicability. 
(a)  Every person owning real property and/or owning or operating a business within the city shall make a determination of the applicability of this groundwater protection ordinance as it pertains to the property or business. A failure to do so shall not excuse any violation of this article. This obligation shall be joint and several upon all persons owning an interest in the property or business. 
(b)  All facilities within a groundwater protection area must comply with this article prior to issuance of any underlying permits. Existing facilities which are not applying for an underlying permit shall have one year from the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived to come into compliance. 
(c)  If the city code enforcement officer determines that a facility, otherwise exempt from the permit requirements of this article, has a potential to degrade groundwater quality, then the city code enforcement officer may classify that facility as a new potential primary source, a potential route, or potential secondary source, and require that facility to comply with this article accordingly. Such determination shall be based upon site-specific data and shall be eligible for appeal pursuant to section 8-32. 
(d)  The following are exempt from this article: 
(1)  Fuel tanks and fluid reservoirs attached to a private or commercial motor vehicle and used directly in the operation of that vehicle. 
(2)  Existing heating systems using fuel oil. 
(3)  The activities of construction, repairing or maintaining any facility or improvement on lands within Zones 1, 2, or 3 provided that all contractors, subcontractors, laborers, material men and their employees when using, handling, storing or producing regulated substances in Zones 1, 2, or 3 use those applicable "best management practices" set forth in exhibit 3, attached hereto and incorporated herein. 
(4)  Cleanups, monitoring and/or studies undertaken under supervision of the state environmental protection agency or other state regulatory agency or the United States Environmental Protection Agency. 
(5)  Activities specifically regulated under 35 Ill. Admin. Code 601, 615, 616, and 617 (Regulations for existing and new activities within setback zones and regulated recharge areas); 8 Ill. Admin. Code 255 and 256 (Regulations for secondary containment for agricultural pesticide and fertilizer facilities); and 8 Ill. Admin. Code 257 (Cooperative groundwater protection program for agricultural chemical facilities with appropriate setback zones. 
(6)  If the owner of a new potential primary source, new potential secondary source, or new potential route is granted an exception by the board (other than land filling or land treating) pursuant to the Act, such owner shall not be subject to this article to the same extent that such owner is not subject to the Act. 
(7)  If the owner of a new potential primary source, new potential secondary source, or new potential route is issued a certificate of minimal hazard by the agency pursuant to the Act, such owner shall not be subject to this article to the same extent that such owner is not subject to the Act. 
(e)  Any action by the agency or board referred to this section shall not be final and binding on the city under this article until the city has received notice of such proposed action and has had reasonable opportunity to present evidence concerning its interest. 
(Code 1990, § 15.6-4; Ord. No. 99-1892, § I, 7-6-1999) 
Sec. 8-23. - Regulated substances management plan. 
(a)  Regulated substances management plan. 
(1)  A regulated substances management plan indicating procedures to be followed to prevent, control, collect, and dispose of any unauthorized released of a regulated substance shall be required. If a spill prevention control plan or similar contingency plan has been prepared in accordance with the state or United States Environmental Protection Agency requirements, a regulated substance management plan is not required as long as all of the regulated substances are included in the spill prevention control plan. 
(2)  The regulated substances management plan shall include: 
a.  Provisions to address the regulated substances monitoring requirements. 
b.  Provisions to train employees in the prevention, identification, reporting, control, disposal, and documentation of any unauthorized release of a regulated substance. 
(b)  The owners or operators of all new facilities shall implement regulated substances monitoring as part of the regulated substances management plan required by this section. Visual monitoring must be implemented unless it is determined by the city, to be unfeasible. 
(c)  All regulated substance monitoring activities shall include the following: 
(1)  A written routine monitoring procedure which includes, when applicable: The frequency of performing the monitoring method, the methods and equipment to be used for performing the monitoring, the location from which the monitoring will be performed, the name or titles of the person performing the monitoring and/or maintaining the equipment, and the reporting format. 
(2)  Written records of all monitoring performed shall be maintained on site by the operator for a period of three years from the date the monitoring was performed. The city, may require the submittal of the monitoring records or a summary at a frequency that the city may establish. The written records of all monitoring performed in the past three years shall be shown to the city upon demand during any site inspection. Monitoring records shall include, but not be limited to: 
a.  The date and time of all monitoring or sampling; 
b.  Monitoring equipment calibration and maintenance records; 
c.  The results of any visual observations; 
d.  The logs of all readings of gauges or other monitoring equipment, or other test results; and 
e.  The results of inventory readings and reconciliation. 
(3)  Reporting. 
a.  The storage, handling, treatment, use, or processing of new regulated substances; 
b.  Changes in monitoring procedures; or 
c.  The replacement or repair of any part of a facility that is related to the regulated substance. 
(d)  Procedures for the in-house inspections and maintenance of containment devices and areas where regulated substances are stored, handled, treated, used, and produced shall be in writing, and a log shall be kept of all inspections and maintenance activities. Such logs shall be submitted to the code enforcement officer with the renewal applications available for inspection at other times upon 48 hours' notice. Inspection and maintenance logs shall be maintained on site by the owner or operator for a period of at least three years from the date the monitoring was performed. 
(Code 1990, § 15.6-5; Ord. No. 99-1892, § I, 7-6-1999) 
Sec. 8-24. - Groundwater protection overlay zones. 
(a)  The location of groundwater protection areas in the city are defined in exhibit 1 to this article. Groundwater protection area maps shall be placed on file with the department of planning/zoning/building/public works, and the fire department. 
(b)  In determining the location of facilities within the zones defined by exhibit 1, the following rule shall apply. 
(1)  Facilities located wholly within a GWPA zone shall be governed by the restriction applicable to that zone. 
(2)  Facilities having parts lying within more than one zone of a GWPA shall be governed by the restrictions applicable to the more restrictive zone. 
(3)  Facilities having parts lying both in and out of a GWPA shall be governed by the restrictions applicable to the more restrictive zone. 
(Code 1990, § 15.6-6; Ord. No. 99-1892, § I, 7-6-1999) 
Sec. 8-25. - Regulations which apply within the minimum setback zone (Zone 1) of the GWPA. 
(a)  Prohibited uses and activities. 
(1)  Except as provided in section 8-24, no person shall place a new potential primary source, new potential secondary source, or new potential route within the minimum setback zone of any existing or permitted community water supply well in the city or within 400 feet (122 meters) of the city limits of the city. 
(2)  Except as provided in section 8-24, no person shall alter or change an existing potential primary source, potential secondary source, or potential route where the alteration or change would result in a potential source or route that would be prohibited under this article if it were a new potential source or route. 
(3)  No person shall conduct any activity or engage in a use of property which shall constitute an interference with the health and safety or welfare of a community water supply well. Such activities are declared to be a public nuisance and are prohibited by this article. 
(b)  Review and approval of proposed activities. 
(1)  All proposals for new facilities which use, store, handle, treat or produce a regulated substance within the minimum setback zone (Zone 1) must be reviewed by the code enforcement officer for compliance with this article, prior to issuance of any underlying permit. 
(2)  No permits will be issued unless a finding is made by the code enforcement officer that the facility will not impact the long term, short term or cumulative quality of the aquifer. The finding shall be based on the present or past land use activities conducted at the facility; regulated substance stored, handled, treated, used or produced; and the potential for the activated or regulated substances to degrade groundwater quality. 
(3)  New sources of sanitary sewerage (residential or nonresidential) shall, as a condition of the building permit, be required to connect to an IEPA permitted central sanitary sewer system prior to occupancy. 
(Code 1990, § 15.6-7; Ord. No. 99-1892, § I, 7-6-1999) 
Sec. 8-26. - Regulations which apply within the maximum setback zone (Zone 2) of the GWPA. 
(a)  Prohibited uses and activities. 
(1)  Except as provided in section 8-24, no person shall place a new potential primary source within the maximum setback zone of any existing or permitted community water supply well in the city or within 1,000 feet (305 meters) of the city limits of the city. 
(2)  Except as provided in section 8-24, no person shall alter or change an existing potential primary source where the alteration or change would result in a potential source or route that would be prohibited under this article if it were a new potential source or route. 
(3)  No person shall conduct any activity or engage in a use of property which shall constitute an interference with the health and safety or welfare of a community water supply well or other water well by the accidental, negligent, or intentional introduction of contaminants. Such activities are declared to be a public nuisance and are prohibited by this article. 
(b)  Review and approval of proposed activities. 
(1)  All proposals for new facilities which use, store, handle, treat or produce a regulated substance within the maximum setback zone (Zone 1) must be reviewed by the code enforcement officer for compliance with this article, prior to issuance of any underlying permit. 
(2)  No permits will be issued unless a finding is made by the code enforcement officer that the facility will not impact the long term, short term or cumulative quality of the aquifer. The finding shall be based on the present or past land use activities conducted at the facility; regulated substance stored, handled, treated, used or produced; and the potential for the activities or regulated substances to degrade groundwater quality. 
(3)  New sources of sanitary sewerage (residential or nonresidential) shall, as a condition of the building permit, be required to connect to an IEPA permitted central sanitary sewer system prior to occupancy. 
(Code 1990, § 15.6-8; Ord. No. 99-1892, § I, 7-6-1999) 
Sec. 8-27. - Regulations which apply within the five-year capture zone (Zone 3) of the GWPA; review and approval of proposed activities. 
(a)  All proposals for new facilities which use, store, handle, treat or produce a regulated substance within the five-year capture zone (Zone 3) must be reviewed by the code enforcement officer for compliance with this article, prior to issuance of any underlying permit. 
(b)  No permits will be issued unless a finding is made by the code enforcement officer that the facility will not impact the long term, short term or cumulative quality of the aquifer. The finding shall be based on the present or past land use activities conducted at the facility; regulated substance stored, handled, treated, used or produced; and the potential for the activities or regulated substances to degrade groundwater quality. 
(c)  New sources of sanitary sewerage (residential or nonresidential) shall, as a condition of the building permit, be required to connect to an IEPA permitted central sanitary sewer system prior to occupancy. 
(Code 1990, §§ 15.6-9, 15.6-10; Ord. No. 99-1892, § I, 7-6-1999) 
Sec. 8-28. - Unauthorized releases. 
(a)  General provisions. All unauthorized releases shall be reported to the city fire department according to the provisions of this section. All unauthorized releases shall be recorded in the owner's inspection and maintenance log. An unauthorized release is an "unauthorized release requiring recording" if the release is completely captured by the containment device. If the containment device fails to contain the entire release, the release is an "unauthorized release requiring reporting." 
(b)  Unauthorized releases requiring recording. 
(1)  Unauthorized releases requiring recording shall be reported to the city fire department within 24 hours after the release has been, or should have been detected. 
(2)  The incident report shall be accompanied by a written record including the following information: 
a.  The type, quantities, and concentration of regulated substances released. 
b.  Method of cleanup. 
c.  Method and location of disposal of the released regulated substances including whether a hazardous waste manifest is used. 
d.  Method of future release prevention or repair. 
e.  Facility operator's name and telephone number. 
(3)  The city fire department shall review the information submitted pursuant to the report of an unauthorized release requiring recording, and may inspect the facility. The city fire department shall either find that the containment standards of this article can continue to be achieved or shall recommend that appropriate modifications are made to allow compliance with the standards. 
(c)  Unauthorized releases requiring reporting. 
(1)  Unauthorized releases requiring reporting shall be verbally reported to the city fire department immediately. 
(2)  A written report shall be submitted promptly thereafter containing the following information that is known at the time of filing the report: 
a.  List of type, quantity, and concentration of regulated substances released. 
b.  The results of all investigations completed at the time to determine the extent of soil or groundwater or surface water contamination because of the release. 
c.  Method of cleanup implemented to date, proposed cleanup actions and approximate cost of actions taken to date. 
d.  Method and location disposal of the released regulated substance and any contaminated soils, groundwater, or surface water. 
e.  Proposed method of repair or replacement of the containment device. 
f.  Facility owner's name and telephone number. 
(3)  Until cleanup is complete, the owner shall submit reports containing the reporting required by section 8-23(c) to code enforcement officer and the city fire department every month or at a more frequent interval specified by the fire department. 
(4)  The city fire department shall either find that the containment standards of this article can continue to be achieved or shall recommend that appropriate modifications are made to allow compliance with the standards. 
(d)  Upon confirmation of an unauthorized release to groundwater, the owner shall be responsible for immediately accomplishing the following: 
(1)  Locate and determine the source of the unauthorized release of the regulated substance. 
(2)  Stop and prevent any further unauthorized release. 
(3)  Comply with the requirements for an unauthorized release requiring reporting. 
(e)  No new regulated substance may be introduced at the site of the regulated substance that caused the violation. 
(f)  If an unauthorized release creates or is expected to create an emergency situation with respect to the drinking water supply of the city or a public water supply well within 1,000 feet (305 meters) of the city, and if the facility owner fails to address the unauthorized release within 12 hours, the city or its authorized agents shall have the authority to implement removal or remedial actions. Such actions may include, but not be limited to, the prevention of further groundwater contamination; installation of groundwater monitoring wells; collection and laboratory testing of water, soil, and waste samples; and cleanup and disposal of regulated substances. The facility owner and operator jointly and severally shall be responsible for any costs incurred by the city or its authorized agents in the conduct of such remedial actions, including, but not limited to, all consultant engineering and attorney fees. 
(g)  Reporting a release to the city fire department does not exempt or preempt any other reporting requirements under federal, state, or local laws. 
(Code 1990, § 15.6-11; Ord. No. 99-1892, § I, 7-6-1999) 
Sec. 8-29. - Penalties. 
(a)  A violation of this article shall be punishable as a Class B violation as provided in section 1-41. 
(b)  In addition to any other fines and penalties set forth in this Code, the owner or operator shall reimburse the city, for all reasonable costs incurred as a result of responding to, containing, cleaning up and disposal of any spilled or leaked regulated substance including, but not limited to, consultant, engineering and legal fees. 
(Code 1990, § 15.6-12; Ord. No. 99-1892, § I, 7-6-1999; Ord. No. 2011-2458, § 61, 4-5-2011) 
Sec. 8-30. - Enforcement. 
(a)  The city shall be the administering agency and shall have the power and authority to administer and enforce the provisions of this article. The city shall have the right to conduct inspections of facilities at reasonable times to determine compliance with this article. 
(b)  The code enforcement officer may revoke any underlying permit issued to the facility after notice to the permittee and after affording the permittee an opportunity to meet either in person or by telephone if it finds that the permit holder: 
(1)  Has failed or refused to comply with any provision of this article; 
(2)  Has submitted false or inaccurate information in a permit application; 
(3)  Has refused lawful inspection; 
(4)  Has an unauthorized release and the code enforcement officer finds that the containment standards of this article cannot continue to be achieved. 
(Code 1990, § 15.6-13; Ord. No. 99-1892, § I, 7-6-1999) 
Sec. 8-31. - Notice of violation. 
    Whenever it is determined that there is a violation of this article, the notice of violation issued shall: 
(1)  Be in writing and delivered to the owner or operator by regular mail; 
(2)  Be dated and signed by the authorized city agent making the inspection; 
(3)  Specify the violation or violations; and 
(4)  Specify the length of time (not less than 72 hours) to correct the violation after receiving the notice of violation. 
(Code 1990, § 15.6-14; Ord. No. 99-1892, § I, 7-6-1999) 
Sec. 8-32. - Appeals. 
    The mayor shall appoint, with the advice and consent of the city council, a groundwater appeals committee. Said committee shall include the following persons: chief of the fire department, superintendent of the water department, superintendent of the waste water department, code enforcement officer, director of economic development and two aldermen. 
(1)  Any decision by the code enforcement officer denying a permit or placing restrictions or conditions on a permit may be appealed to the groundwater appeals committee. 
(2)  The groundwater appeals committee shall also hear petitions to exempt a facility from the requirements of section 8-24 as follows: 
a.  The applicant may demonstrate that the five-year capture zone area map incorrectly identify the facility as being within the groundwater protection overlay zone. The burden of proof shall rest upon the applicant to demonstrate that the facility location is not within a delineated five-year capture zone area. The applicant is required to present detailed hydrogeologic and hydrologic information to the groundwater appeals committee that the facility location is, in fact not within a five-year capture zone area. 
b.  The applicant may be required to present detailed technical information that a material on the regulated substance list does not endanger the GWPA in the event of an unauthorized release. To continue the permit appeal process, the applicant must provide funds to the groundwater appeals committee to pay for the technical review by the groundwater appeals committee's choice of consultants of said hydrogeologic and hydrologic information and shall base its recommendation, in part, on the report by said consultant 
(3)  Procedures. Appeals to the groundwater appeals committee shall be perfected by filing an appeal in writing with the city clerk within 14 days after receipt of a decision in writing from the code enforcement office or the fire department. Petitions to the groundwater appeals committee will be held within 30 days of submission of the appeal or petition. A decision by the groundwater appeals committee will be made in writing within 30 days of the hearing. 
(Code 1990, § 15.6-15; Ord. No. 99-1892, § I, 7-6-1999) 
Sec. 8-33. - Exhibits. 
EXHIBIT 1 

EXHIBIT 2 

EXHIBIT 3
"BEST MANAGEMENT PRACTICES" FOR THE CONSTRUCTION INDUSTRY 
(a)  The general contractor, or if none, the property owner, shall be responsible for assuring that each contractor or subcontractor evaluates each site before construction is initiated to determine if any site conditions may pose particular problems for the handling of any chemical substances. For instance, handling chemical substances in the proximity of a groundwater protection overlay zone or water bodies may be improper. 
(b)  If any chemical substances are stored on the construction site during the construction process, they shall be stored in a location and manner which will minimize any possible risk of release to the environment. Any storage of 55 gallons (208 liters) or 440 pounds (200 kilograms) or more, containing chemical substances shall have constructed below it an impervious containment system constructed of materials of sufficient thickness, density and composition that will prevent the discharge to the land, groundwater, or surface water, of any pollutant which may emanate from said storage container or containers. Each containment system shall be able to contain 110 percent of the contents of all storage containers above the containment system. 
(c)  Each contractor shall familiarize himself with the manufacturer's safety data sheet supplied with each material containing a chemical substance and shall be familiar with procedures required to contain and clean up any releases of the chemical substances. Any tools or equipment necessary to accomplish same shall be available in case of a release. 
(d)  Upon completion of construction, all unused and waste chemical substances and containment systems shall be removed from the construction site by the responsible contractor, and shall be disposed of in a proper manner as prescribed by law. 
(Code 1990, ch. 15.6, exhs. 1-3) 
Secs. 8-34-8-54. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - PROTECTION OF SHORELAND AND WATERCOURSES 

Sec. 8-55. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to prevent and control water pollution and to preserve shore cover and natural beauty. 
(Code 1977, § 17.36.010; Code 1990, § 15.5-21; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 3(16-331), 4-19-1993) 
Sec. 8-56. - Applicability. 
    The provisions of this article shall apply to the shorelands of Rock River. 
(Code 1977, § 17.36.020; Code 1990, § 15.5-22; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 3(16-332), 4-19-1993) 
Sec. 8-57. - Setback. 
    For lots that abut on Rock River all buildings and structures except accessory uses which require a lesser setback as determined by the board of appeals, lots shall be set back at least 100 feet from the high water line and elevated at least two feet above the experienced high water elevation unless otherwise specified by a floodplain zoning ordinance. 
(Code 1977, § 17.36.030; Code 1990, § 15.5-23; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 3(16-323), 4-19-1993) 
Sec. 8-58. - Special use permit-When required. 
    A special use permit shall be required for any dredging or channeling or for any filling or grading of more than 500 square feet of any wetland which is contiguous to Rock River or more than 2,000 square feet on non-wetland soils located adjacent the river. For purposes of this article, the term "wetland" means any area where groundwater is at or near the surface a substantial part of the year as determined by the building official. 
(Code 1977, § 17.36.040; Code 1990, § 15.5-24; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 3(16-324), 4-19-1993) 
Sec. 8-59. - Same-Conditions. 
    In granting a special use permit for filling or grading, the zoning board of appeals may attach the following conditions in addition to those specified elsewhere in this chapter: 
(1)  The smallest amount of bare ground shall be exposed for the shortest time feasible; 
(2)  Temporary ground cover such as mulch is used and permanent cover such as sod is planted; 
(3)  Diversions, silting basins, terraces and other methods to trap sediment are used; 
(4)  Fill is stabilized according to accepted engineering standards; 
(5)  Fill will not restrict a floodway or destroy the storage capacity of a floodplain; 
(6)  Walls of a channel or artificial watercourse are stabilized to prevent slumping; 
(7)  Sides of channels or artificial watercourses are constructed with side slopes of two horizontal to one vertical or flatter, unless vertical bulkheading is provided. 
(Code 1977, § 17.36.050; Code 1990, § 15.5-25; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 3(16-335), 4-19-1993) 
Chapter 10 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 10-1-10-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FIRE SERVICE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to provide fire protection, 65 ILCS 5/11-6-1 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 10-19. - Created; composition. 
(a)  There is created an executive department of the city to be known as the fire service, which department shall be under the supervision of the mayor of the city, and shall consist of the following: 
(1)  One chief; 
(2)  One deputy chief; 
(3)  Three fire captains; 
(4)  Firefighters, the number of which shall be determined from time to time by resolution of the city council. 
(b)  In addition thereto, the fire service shall utilize such number of paid on-call firefighters as may be provided for by the annual appropriation ordinance adopted by the council from year to year. 
(Code 1990, § 7-76; Ord. No. 86-1451, § 2.38.010, 9-15-1986; Ord. No. 89-1529, 6-19-1989; Ord. No. 98-1836, § 1, 3-3-1998; Ord. No. 2015-2232, § 1, 9-15-2015) 
Sec. 10-20. - Members appointed by mayor. 
    The chief of the fire service shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the council. 
(Code 1990, § 7-77; Ord. No. 86-1451, § 2.38.020, 9-15-1986) 
Sec. 10-21. - Employees appointed by board of fire and police commissioners. 
    All employees of the fire service, except the chief, paid on-call firefighters and any administration or clerical employee who does not engage in fire suppression activities, shall be appointed by the board of fire and police commissioners as provided by law. Such employees shall perform their duties under the supervision of the chief and deputy chief of the fire service, the mayor and the police-fire committee of the city council. 
(Code 1990, § 7-78; Ord. No. 86-1451, § 2.38.030, 9-15-1986; Ord. No. 2013-2140, § 1, 12-17-2013; Ord. No. 2015-2232, § 2, 9-15-2015) 
State Law reference- Appointments of members of fire and police departments, 625 ILCS 5/10-2.1-4. 
Sec. 10-22. - Rules, regulations. 
    Members of the fire service will abide by and be governed by the rules and regulations which may be adopted for the service by the chief and the council, as the same may be in effect from time to time, and by the personnel policy manual of the city to the extent applicable. 
(Code 1990, § 7-79; Ord. No. 86-1451, § 2.38.040, 9-15-1986) 
Editor's note- The rules and policies referred to in the above section are on file in the office of the city clerk. 
Sec. 10-23. - Chief-Office created; duties. 
    There is created the office of chief of the fire service whose duties shall be as prescribed in this section, and in sections 10-24 through 10-30, and who shall be the head of the service. All rules and regulations shall be promulgated through him. He and all members of the fire service shall devote their entire time to the duties of their office, which shall be to protect property in the city from destruction by fire, and to fight fires as they occur. The chief shall direct and supervise all activities of the fire service, shall prepare the annual budget for the fire service, shall approve requisitions for necessary equipment and supplies, shall plan for and develop training programs and improvements in administrative, firefighting and fire prevention procedures, shall prepare, maintain and interpret to his subordinates rules and regulations covering the fire service, respond to calls on fires and take command if required, advise the mayor and police-fire committee on fire service matters, study the need for and advise the council on new and revised ordinances pertaining to the fire service, advise and assist subordinates in the fire service in firefighting procedures, personally participate in command of fighting of more serious fires and perform all duties related to the administrative control of the fire service. 
(Code 1990, § 7-80; Ord. No. 86-1451, § 2.38.050, 9-15-1986) 
Sec. 10-24. - Same-Attendance at council meetings. 
    The chief of the fire service, or a designated representative of the fire service, shall attend meetings of the council. 
(Code 1990, § 7-81; Ord. No. 86-1451, § 2.38.060, 9-15-1986) 
Sec. 10-25. - Deputy chief. 
    The chief of the fire service may, from time to time, request that the board of fire and police commissioners appoint from the ranks of the three captains in the department a deputy chief to perform such administrative duties as may be prescribed from time to time by the chief, and to be in charge of the service in the absence of the chief. If both the chief and deputy chief are absent from the department at the same time, then the senior captain shall then be in charge of the department. 
(Code 1990, § 7-82; Ord. No. 86-1451, § 2.38.070, 9-15-1986; Ord. No. 92-1639, 12-21-1992; Ord. No. 2015-2232, § 3, 9-15-2015) 
Sec. 10-26. - Fire prevention officer-fire inspector. 
    At the discretion of the chief of the fire service, the chief may appoint from the ranks of the captains or firefighters a fire prevention officer-fire inspector to perform such duties as may be prescribed by the chief of the fire service and as are required by the fire prevention and building codes of the city. 
(Code 1990, § 7-83; Ord. No. 86-1451, § 2.38.080, 9-15-1986; Ord. No. 2015-2232, § 4, 9-15-2015) 
Sec. 10-27. - Report of conduct unbecoming an employee. 
    The chief of the fire service shall report promptly in writing to the mayor and the board of fire and police commissioners any member of the fire service who is guilty of drunkenness, neglect of duty, disobedience of orders, violation of the standing rules and regulations of the fire service or other conduct unbecoming an employee. 
(Code 1990, § 7-84; Ord. No. 86-1451, § 2.38.090, 9-15-1986) 
Sec. 10-28. - Reports to mayor. 
    The chief of the fire service shall make reports in writing to the mayor when requested by him. Such report shall show the state of the fire service, with such statistics and suggestions as he deems advisable for the improvement of the fire service, or of the discipline and government of same. 
(Code 1990, § 7-85; Ord. No. 86-1451, § 2.38.100, 9-15-1986) 
Sec. 10-29. - Paid on-call fire persons. 
    The mayor may appoint such paid on-call firefighters as may be deemed necessary and as allowed and provided by the council, with persons so appointed to be made from a list of persons after screening and upon recommendation of the chief of the fire service. The total number of paid on-call firefighters shall not exceed 25. Persons appointed by the mayor as paid on-call firefighters shall be designated to perform such firefighting duties as prescribed by the chief and such other duties as may be required from time to time by the council or the chief. Paid on-call firefighters shall receive training as the same is made available at the expense of the city, and will be subject to any and all rules and regulations and physical requirements of the fire service which may be adopted from time to time. Paid on-call firefighters shall be paid at an hourly rate determined by the council from time to time for each hour of fire service performed, provided that such fire service is performed at the direction of the chief. The mayor may reappoint from year to year, those paid on-call firefighters who meet the rules and regulations of the fire service and with the recommendation of the fire chief. The reappointments will take place on the first council meeting after May 1 of each year. The mayor, or with the recommendation of the fire chief and for just cause, may terminate paid on-call firefighters. 
(Code 1990, § 7-86; Ord. No. 86-1451, § 2.38.110, 9-15-1986; Ord. No. 89-1533, 9-18-1989) 
Sec. 10-30. - Uniforms, equipment. 
(a)  It shall be the policy of the fire service to furnish each new employee with such articles of uniform clothing and items of equipment as may be required by the service. The employees shall use reasonable care to prevent the uniform and equipment from undue damage, and the articles of clothing and equipment shall remain the property of the city. An annual replacement allowance for uniforms and equipment shall be established by the council, and shall be administered by the chief of the fire service. 
(b)  All equipment shall be used in accordance with the rules and regulations of the fire service. 
(Code 1990, § 7-87; Ord. No. 86-1451, § 2.38.120, 9-15-1986) 
Sec. 10-31. - Hazardous material emergency response reimbursement. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Hazardous material means any material or substance designated as hazardous material, hazardous substance or hazardous waste by the United States Secretary of Transportation, and as set out in the Hazardous Materials Table in 49 CFR 172.101 in a quantity and form determined by the United States Department of Transportation to be capable of posing an unreasonable risk to health and safety or property when transported in commerce. 
    Hazardous material emergency incident means any incident or accident wherein a hazardous material is released from the container or other packaging structure within which the hazardous material has been stored or transported, and which release is not in conjunction with approved plans and design, and which release is deemed by the chief of the fire department to pose or present a risk or hazard to the health or safety of persons or property. 
(b)  Reimbursement responsibility. 
(1)  Pursuant to the authority granted by 430 ILCS 55/5, it is hereby determined to be the policy of the city that those persons deemed to be a responsible party within the meaning of 430 ILCS 5/3, reimburse the city for costs and expenses incurred in the course of providing emergency action in response to a hazardous materials emergency incident. 
(2)  The chief of the fire department is hereby directed to determine a schedule of rates and charges to be made in order to reimburse to the city the reasonable costs incurred by the city in responding to a hazardous materials emergency incident, and such schedule of rates and charges shall include amounts to reimburse for equipment, manpower and payments to outside providers of services or resources. 
(3)  The chief of the fire department shall determine the amounts necessary to properly reimburse the city for such costs, from time to time, and shall cause the schedule of such rates and charges to be delivered over to the city council and to be published. The amounts so determined in the schedule of rates and charges published by the chief of the fire department shall be deemed to be the schedule in effect and applicable for any reimbursement obligation, unless the city council shall, within 30 days following delivery of such schedule to the city council, adopt a resolution rejecting the schedule of rates and charges and directing the chief of the fire department to review such schedule and make amendments or alterations thereto in accordance with the direction of the council. In the event that the council shall reject any proposed schedule of rates and charges as submitted by the chief of the fire department, then the previously existing schedule of rates and charges as published shall stand until a revised schedule has become effective pursuant to this section. 
(4)  In the event of any hazardous materials emergency incident, it shall be the duty of the chief of the fire department to determine, with the aid and assistance of the office of the state fire marshal, the police department, and such other law enforcement agencies as are necessary or desirable, the responsible party for such incident. Upon determination of the responsible party, the chief of the fire department shall forthwith make demand upon such responsible party for reimbursement in accordance with the schedule of rates and charges then in effect for the cost incurred by the city in such emergency response. If the responsible party fails, within a reasonable time, to make the reimbursement demanded, then the chief of the fire department is directed to make application to the emergency response reimbursement fund in the state treasury for reimbursement for that emergency response. 
(Code 1990, § 7-88; Ord. No. 2002-2026, § 1, 11-5-2002) 
Sec. 10-32. - Standby services; charges. 
(a)  Upon request from time to time by persons conducting special events or activities, for which emergency fire or rescue services may be required, the chief of the fire department is authorized to assign personnel and equipment of the fire department to standby duty at such event or activity. 
(b)  The city shall be reimbursed for the cost of providing equipment and personnel to standby duty for such special events or activities at the rate of $125.00 per hour per vehicle, and $35.00 per hour per person assigned. Such amounts shall be due from the sponsor of the event or activity, and shall be payable upon submission of written invoice for the services. The chief of the fire department is authorized and directed to take such other steps, as the chief in his discretion deems necessary or desirable, to ensure that proper reimbursement and payment will be made by the sponsoring party, including demand for payment of an advance deposit against anticipated charges. 
(c)  The chief of the fire department, with the advice and consent of the police/fire committee of the city council, is authorized to waive charges otherwise due and payable under this section for any bona fide not-for-profit organization conducting an event for charitable, educational or civic purposes or benefit. 
(Code 1990, § 7-89; Ord. No. 2002-2032, § 1, 11-19-2002) 
Secs. 10-33-10-52. - Reserved.

Sec. 10-53. - Election to participate in program.

Sec. 10-55. - Completion of program. 
    The firefighter II training must be completed by the trainee within his probationary period of 12 months, except for volunteers, part-time and paid on-call personnel. 
(Code 1977, § 2.78.030; Code 1990, § 7-103)

ARTICLE III. - FIRE PREVENTION 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 10-84-10-109. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - FIRE PREVENTION CODE 

Sec. 10-110. - Adopted; amendments. 
(a)  There is hereby adopted as the fire code of the city, for the purpose of regulating and governing the safeguarding of life and property from fire and explosion hazards arising from the storage, handling and use of hazardous substances, materials and devices, and from conditions hazardous to life or property in the occupancy of buildings and premises, and providing for the issuance of permits and collection of fees therefor, that certain document entitled "International Fire Code, 2012 Edition" (referred to herein as the "2012 IFC") as published by the International Code Council, including appendices A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H, I and J thereto. Each and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of said 2012 IFC, as on file in the office of the building official of the city are hereby referred to, adopted and made a part hereof, as if fully set out in this article, with the additions, insertions, deletions and changes as prescribed in subsections (b) and (c) of this section. 
(b)  The following sections of the International Fire Code are hereby revised by completion of blanks, addition or deletion therein as follows: 
(1)  Section 101.1. Insert: City of Rock Falls, Illinois. 
(2)  Section 109.4. Insert: $75.00; $750.00. 
(3)  Section 111.4. Insert: $100.00; $750.00. 
(c)  The geographic limits referred to in certain sections of the 2012 IFC, are hereby established as follows: 
(1)  Section 5704.2.9.6.1 (Geographic limits in which the storage of flammable cryogenics fluids in stationary containers is prohibited): Areas zoned R 1-4. 
(2)  Section 5706.2.4.4 (Geographic limits in which the storage of Class I and Class II liquids in above-ground tanks outside of buildings is prohibited): Areas zoned R 1-4. 
(3)  Section 5806.2 (Geographic limits in which the storage of Class I and Class II liquids in above-ground tanks is prohibited): Areas zoned R 1-4. 
(4)  Section 6104.2 (Geographic limits in which the storage of liquefied petroleum gas is restricted for the protection of heavily populated or congested areas): Areas zoned R 1-4. 
(5)  Any reference within the 2012 IFC to any plumbing code shall mean the Illinois Plumbing Code. 
(Code 1977, § 8.08.010; Code 1990, § 7-51; Ord. No. 94-1707, § 1, 5-16-1994; Ord. No. 2005-2154, §§ 1-3, 12-20-2005; Ord. No. 2010-2421, §§ 14, 15, 10-5-2010; Ord. No. 2010-2429, § 7, 11-16-2010; Ord. No. 2012-2067, § 7, 7-17-2012) 
State Law reference- Adoption by reference, 65 ILCS 5/1-3-1 et seq. 
Sec. 10-111. - Permits and licenses. 
    The permits as required in the code adopted in this division will be a part of the conditions necessary in obtaining a license from the city, as such licenses are required. The city license shall not be issued until the chief of the fire service has certified that the applicant for a license is in compliance with the fire prevention code. 
(Code 1977, § 8.08.030; Code 1990, § 7-53) 
Sec. 10-112. - Granting of modifications; records. 
(a)  The chief of the fire service shall have power to modify any of the provisions of the code adopted in this division upon application in writing by the owner or lessee, or his duly authorized agent, when there are practical difficulties in the way of carrying out the strict letter of the code; provided, that the spirit of the code shall be observed, public safety secured and substantial justice done. 
(b)  The particulars of such modification, as set out in subsection (a) of this section, when granted or allowed and the decision of the chief of the fire service thereon shall be entered upon the records of the fire department and a signed copy shall be furnished the applicant. 
(Code 1977, § 8.08.040; Code 1990, § 7-54) 
Sec. 10-113. - Enforcement authority. 
    The code adopted pursuant to this division shall be enforced by the chief of the fire service. 
(Code 1977, § 8.08.050; Code 1990, § 7-55) 
Sec. 10-114. - Fire prevention bureau; officers. 
(a)  There is created the fire prevention bureau of the fire service and the fire code official as appointed by the mayor and approved by the city council. 
(b)  The fire code official may appoint a deputy code official. 
(c)  From time to time as deemed necessary, the fire code official or his deputy may name officers of the fire service to serve upon the bureau. The names of these individuals shall be filed with the office of the city clerk and shall be filed with the building official, and the names shall be open to public inspection at all time. 
(Code 1977, § 8.08.070; Code 1990, § 7-56; Ord. No. 2010-2430, § 1, 11-16-2010) 
Sec. 10-115. - Fire code official-Duties. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the fire code official, his deputy or appointed officers of the fire service, to enforce the regulations governing conditions hazardous to life and property from fire as set forth in the fire code, state life safety code NFPA 101 and any other ordinances adopted by the city. 
(b)  The fire code official shall work in conjunction with the building official and any other city officials as may be necessary in the performance of his duties. 
(c)  The fire code official shall inspect all buildings and premises, except the interiors of dwellings, for the purpose of ascertaining and causing to be corrected any conditions liable to cause fire, endanger life from fire, or any other violations of the provisions or intent of the fire code, state life safety code NFPA 101 and of any other ordinances affecting the fire hazard. 
(Code 1977, § 8.08.080; Code 1990, § 7-57; Ord. No. 2010-2430, § 2, 11-16-2010) 
Sec. 10-116. - Same-Subject to fire service regulations; performance of additional duties. 
    The fire prevention officer shall at all times be subject to the rules and regulations affecting all regular members of the fire service and may be required by the chief to perform duties in addition to those specifically provided in section 10-115. 
(Code 1977, § 8.08.090; Code 1990, § 7-58) 
Sec. 10-117. - Right of plan review; inspections; occupancy. 
(a)  Right of plan review. 
(1)  One copy of the plans for all remodeling or new construction of all multiple-family dwelling units, institutional, commercial or industrial buildings shall be delivered by the applicant for a building permit to the chief of the fire service for examination and review by the fire prevention bureau of the city, and the fire prevention bureau shall within seven days of receipt of such plans by the chief of the fire service examine such plans to determine whether they comply with the applicable fire protection standards of the bureau of fire prevention and of the ordinances of the city. If the plans do meet such standards, the fire prevention bureau shall endorse the plans accordingly and deliver them to the building official. If the plans do not meet the standards, then the plans shall be returned to the applicant with a memorandum of the specific deficiencies noted. 
(2)  The building official shall not issue any building permit for multiple dwelling units, institutional, commercial or industrial buildings unless or until the plans for same have been approved by the fire prevention bureau, and a memorandum noting such approval has been delivered to the building official. If no notice of deficiency shall have been received by the building official within seven days from the date of delivery of the plans to the chief of the fire service in accordance with this section, approval of the fire prevention bureau shall be deemed to have been given, and the building official may issue the building permit thereon. 
(b)  Inspections. The fire prevention bureau or any of its members shall make whatever inspections are deemed necessary at any reasonable time during the course of remodeling or construction of any of the buildings affected by this section to ensure that such remodeling or construction complies with the provisions of the fire prevention code of the city. Upon making such inspection, the fire prevention bureau shall have power to note any deficiencies and shall deliver a memorandum detailing the deficiencies to the building official until such time as all deficiencies noted by the fire prevention bureau have been corrected. 
(c)  Occupancy. No multiple dwelling unit, institutional, commercial or industrial building shall be occupied until such time as a final inspection has been made by the fire prevention bureau or any of its designated members, and by the building official, and an occupancy permit has been issued thereon. 
(Code 1977, § 8.08.100; Code 1990, § 7-59) 
Chapter 12 - HUMAN RELATIONS

ARTICLE II. - FAIR HOUSING[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal regulation of housing practices, 65 ILCS 5/11-11.1-1; real estate transactions, 775 ILCS 5/3-101 et seq.; promotion of equal opportunities, 775 ILCS 5/7-106. 

Sec. 12-19. - Construction of terms. 
    In construing the intended meaning of terminology used in this article, the following rules shall be observed: 
(1)  Words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in section 12-20, unless the context indicates otherwise; terms not defined in section 12-20 shall have their standard English dictionary meanings. 
(2)  All time periods expressed in days shall be construed as calendar days, not working days. 
(3)  References to sections shall be deemed to include all subsections within that section, but a reference to a particular subsection designates only that subsection. 
(4)  A general term that follows or is followed by enumerations of specific terms shall not be limited to the enumerated class unless expressly limited. 
(Code 1977, § 9.24.050; Code 1990, § 10-51) 
Sec. 12-20. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Dwelling means any building or portion thereof containing one or more dwelling units, or any parcel of land offered for sale or lease for the construction or placement of such building. 
    Dwelling unit means one or more rooms designated or used as living quarters by one family. 
    Financial institution means any bank, savings and loan association, insurance company, or any other person or firm whose business consists, in whole or in part, of making or guaranteeing loans. 
    Housing is a synonym for dwelling . 
    Rent means to lease, sublease, let or otherwise grant or receive for consideration the right to occupy any dwelling not owned by the occupant. 
(Code 1977, § 9.24.060; Code 1990, § 10-52) 
State Law reference- Definitions relating to human rights and real estate transactions, 775 ILCS 5/1-103, 5/3-101. 
Sec. 12-21. - Violations. 
    Any violation of this article shall constitute a Class B misdemeanor. 
(Code 1977, § 9.24.210; Code 1990, § 10-53) 
Sec. 12-22. - Statement of policy. 
(a)  When certain individuals are treated differently in the housing market because of racial, religious or other prejudices, the entire community suffers. Discrimination frequently denies its immediate victims their right to acquire a decent home in a safe and pleasant neighborhood. Discrimination also typically causes neighborhoods to become highly segregated, and engenders instability on the fringes of such areas. This instability seriously impairs any sense of community responsibility and accelerates neighborhood decay. Neighborhood decay reduces the housing supply and deflates the tax base. Concurrently, it increases the need for government services and necessitates a higher tax rate. 
(b)  Although discrimination in housing is proscribed by the United States and Illinois Constitutions and by various federal laws, the problem is best handled at the local level because there is no state-wide enforcement program, and the federal enforcement machinery is disturbingly slow, inadequate, and sometimes simply unresponsive to local needs. 
(c)  In light of the above, the council hereby declares that it is the public policy of the city to endeavor to ensure all persons an equal opportunity to provide for themselves a home of their own choosing that is as sufficient as their individual talents, industry and circumstances may permit. 
(Code 1977, § 9.24.010; Code 1990, § 10-54) 
State Constitution reference- Discrimination in the sale or rental of property, Art. I, §§ 17, 19. 
Sec. 12-23. - Purpose; scope. 
    The purpose of this article is to implement the policy set forth in section 12-22 by: 
(1)  Prohibiting discrimination against persons of a particular race, color, religion, sex, creed, ancestry, national origin, or physical or mental handicap in the marketing, disposition and financing of housing; and 
(2)  Establishing procedures for the fair and efficient administration and enforcement of such regulations. 
(Code 1977, § 9.24.020; Code 1990, § 10-55; Ord. No. 99-1873, § 1, 2-16-1999) 
Sec. 12-24. - Jurisdiction. 
    This article shall be applicable within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Code 1977, § 9.24.030; Code 1990, § 10-56) 
Sec. 12-25. - Interpretation. 
    Every provision of this article shall be construed liberally to further the policy and purpose of this article, and every requirement imposed herein shall be deemed minimal. 
(Code 1977, § 9.24.040; Code 1990, § 10-57) 
Sec. 12-26. - Effect on other rights and remedies. 
    Nothing in this article shall prevent any person from exercising any right or seeking any remedy to which he might otherwise be entitled. 
(Code 1977, § 9.24.070; Code 1990, § 10-58) 
Sec. 12-27. - Disclaimer of liability. 
(a)  Except as may be provided otherwise by statute or ordinance, no councilmember, agent, official or employee of this city shall render himself personally liable for any damage that may accrue to persons or property as a result of any act required or permitted in the discharge of his duties under this article. 
(b)  Any suit brought against any official, councilmember, agent or employee of this city as a result of any act required or permitted in the discharge of his duties under this article shall be defended by the city attorney until the final determination of the legal proceedings. 
(Code 1977, § 9.24.080; Code 1990, § 10-59) 
Sec. 12-28. - Discrimination in sale or rental of housing. 
    It is unlawful to refuse to sell or rent, or to otherwise make unavailable, any dwelling to persons of a particular race, color, religion, sex, creed, ancestry, national origin, or physical or mental handicap. 
(Code 1977, § 9.24.090; Code 1990, § 10-60; Ord. No. 99-1873, § 2, 2-16-1999) 
Sec. 12-29. - Discrimination in incidents of sale. 
    It is unlawful to discriminate against persons of a particular race, color, religion, sex, creed, ancestry, national origin, or physical or mental handicap with respect to: 
(1)  The terms, conditions or privileges of sale or rental of any dwelling; or 
(2)  The provision of information, services or facilities in connection with the sale or rental of any dwelling. 
(Code 1977, § 9.24.100; Code 1990, § 10-61; Ord. No. 99-1873, § 3, 2-16-1999) 
Sec. 12-30. - Discriminatory advertising. 
    It is unlawful to print or publish any statement or advertisement that, with respect to the sale or rental of any dwelling, indicates any discrimination or intent to discriminate against persons of a particular race, color, religion, sex, creed, ancestry, national origin, or physical or mental handicap. 
(Code 1977, § 9.24.110; Code 1990, § 10-62; Ord. No. 99-1873, § 4, 2-16-1999) 
Sec. 12-31. - Discrimination in financing. 
(a)  Discrimination against applicant directly. It is unlawful for any financial institution to discriminate against any applicant because the applicant is a person of a particular race, color, religion, sex, creed, ancestry, national origin, or physical or mental handicap with respect to: 
(1)  The approval/provision of any loan or other financial assistance for the purpose of purchasing, constructing, improving, repairing or maintaining any dwelling; 
(2)  Any term or condition of the loan/financial assistance including, but not limited to, loan amount, down payment, earnest money, duration of loan, interest rate and/or closing costs. 
(b)  Discrimination against applicant's associates, redlining. It is unlawful for any financial institution to discriminate with respect to any of the matters indicated in subsection (a) of this section because: 
(1)  The applicant's personal or business associates; 
(2)  Any person having any interest in the dwelling or financial transaction in question; 
(3)  The present or prospective occupants of the dwelling; or 
(4)  The present or prospective residents of the neighborhood in which the dwelling is located; 
are persons of a particular race, color, religion, sex, creed, ancestry, national origin, or physical or mental handicap. 
(Code 1977, § 9.24.120; Code 1990, § 10-63; Ord. No. 99-1873, § 5, 2-16-1999) 
Sec. 12-32. - Misrepresenting availability of housing. 
    It is unlawful to represent to any person or persons that because the person is of a particular race, color, religion, sex, creed, ancestry, national origin, or physical or mental handicap, that any dwelling is not available for inspection, sale or rental when the dwelling is in fact so available. 
(Code 1977, § 9.24.130; Code 1990, § 10-64; Ord. No. 99-1873, § 6, 2-16-1999) 
Sec. 12-33. - Blockbusting. 
    It is unlawful, for profit, to induce or attempt to induce any person to sell or rent any dwelling by making representations (whether true or false), regarding the entry or prospective entry into the neighborhood in which the dwelling is located of persons of a particular race, color, religion, sex, creed, ancestry, national origin, or physical or mental handicap. 
(Code 1977, § 9.24.140; Code 1990, § 10-65; Ord. No. 99-1873, § 7, 2-16-1999) 
Sec. 12-34. - Steering. 
    It is unlawful, for profit, to induce or attempt to induce any person to refrain from buying or renting a dwelling: 
(1)  By making representations (whether true or false), that occupants or prospective occupants of other dwellings in the neighborhood where the dwelling is located are persons of a particular race, color, religion, sex, creed, ancestry, national origin, or physical or mental handicap; or 
(2)  By showing the potential buyer/renter available dwellings only in certain neighborhoods, because the potential buyer/renter is a person of a particular race, color, religion, sex, creed, ancestry, national origin, or physical or mental handicap. 
(Code 1977, § 9.24.150; Code 1990, § 10-66; Ord. No. 99-1873, § 8, 2-16-1999) 
Sec. 12-35. - Membership in real estate organizations. 
    It is unlawful to discriminate against any person because the person is of a particular race, color, religion, sex, creed, ancestry, national origin, or physical or mental handicap with respect to access to or membership in or participation in: 
(1)  Any multiple listing service; 
(2)  Any real estate brokers organization; or 
(3)  Any other service, organization or facility connected with the business of buying, selling or renting dwellings. 
(Code 1977, § 9.24.160; Code 1990, § 10-67; Ord. No. 99-1873, § 9, 2-16-1999) 
Sec. 12-36. - Interference with others' rights. 
(a)  It is unlawful to coerce, intimidate, threaten or interfere with any person: 
(1)  In the exercise of enjoyment of any right protected by this article, or because he has exercised or enjoyed any such right, or because he intends to do so; or 
(2)  In the aiding or encouraging of another person to exercise or enjoy the right protected by this article, or because he has proffered such aid or encouragement, or because he intends to do so. 
(b)  It is unlawful to knowingly make false statements, allegations or complaints concerning violations of this article. 
(Code 1977, § 9.24.170; Code 1990, § 10-68) 
Sec. 12-37. - Complaint procedure. 
    Any person aggrieved by an unlawful practice prohibited by this article may file a complaint with the city attorney within 30 days after the aggrieved person becomes aware of the alleged unlawful practice, and in no event more than 60 days after the alleged unlawful practice occurred. The city attorney or his duly authorized representative shall investigate each complaint and attempt to resolve each complaint. Failure to achieve a resolution acceptable to both parties and compliance with this article shall cause the city attorney to forward the complaint and his findings to the appropriate state and federal officials. 
(Code 1977, § 9.24.180; Code 1990, § 10-69) 
Sec. 12-38. - Appeals. 
    Any person aggrieved by any action or inaction of the city attorney pursuant to this article may appeal to the circuit court and seek appropriate relief in accordance with the provisions of the administrative review law (735 ILCS 5/3-101 et seq.). 
(Code 1977, § 9.24.190; Code 1990, § 10-70) 
Sec. 12-39. - Additional remedies. 
    Nothing contained in this article shall prevent any person from exercising any right or seeking any remedy to which he might otherwise be entitled or from filing his complaint with any appropriate governmental agency. 
(Code 1977, § 9.24.200; Code 1990, § 10-71) 
Chapter 14 - LAW ENFORCEMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal police protection and tax, 65 ILCS 5/11-1-1 et seq.; city marshal, 65 ILCS 5/3.1-35-140. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 14-1-14-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - POLICE SERVICE 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 14-19. - Created; composition. 
    There is created an executive department of the city to be known as the police service, which department shall be under the supervision of the mayor of the city, and shall consist of the following: 
(1)  Chief; 
(2)  Police commanders (two); 
(3)  Police sergeants (four); 
(4)  Police officers (number to be determined by resolution of council from time to time); 
(5)  Desk personnel (number to be determined by resolution of council from time to time); 
(6)  Community service officer. 
(Code 1990, § 11-1; Ord. No. 88-1505, § 2.36.010, 4-4-1988; Ord. No. 90-1572, 12-17-1990) 
Sec. 14-20. - Members appointed by mayor. 
    The chief, commanders and desk personnel of the police service shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the council. 
(Code 1990, § 11-2; Ord. No. 88-1505, § 2.36.020, 4-4-1988; Ord. No. 90-1572, 12-17-1990) 
Sec. 14-21. - Employees appointed by board of fire and police commissioners. 
    All employees of the police service, except those listed in section 14-20, shall be appointed by the board of police and fire commissioners as provided by law. Such employees shall perform their duties under the supervision of the chief of police. 
(Code 1990, § 11-3; Ord. No. 88-1505, § 2.36.030, 4-4-1988) 
State Law reference- Board of fire and police commissioners, 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-1 et seq. 
Sec. 14-22. - Rules and regulations. 
    Members of the police service shall be governed by and will abide by the rules and regulations which may be adopted for the department by the chief and the council, as the same may be in effect from time to time, and by the personnel policy manual of the city to the extent applicable. 
(Code 1990, § 11-4; Ord. No. 88-1505, § 2.36.040, 4-4-1988) 
Editor's note- The personnel policy manual is on file in the office of the city clerk. 
Sec. 14-23. - Uniforms, equipment. 
(a)  It shall be the policy of the police service to furnish each new employee with such articles of uniform clothing and items of equipment as may be required by the service. The employees shall be required to use reasonable care to prevent undue damage to the uniform and equipment, and the articles of clothing and equipment shall remain the property of the city. An annual replacement allowance for uniforms and equipment shall be established by the council, and shall be administered by the chief of the police service. 
(b)  All equipment shall be used in accordance with the rules and regulations of the police service. 
(Code 1990, § 11-5; Ord. No. 88-1505, § 2.36.130, 4-4-1988) 
Sec. 14-24. - Community service officer. 
(a)  There is hereby created within the police service a position known as community service officer. This position shall include the positions of parking control officer and ordinance control officer. All community service officers shall be under the control of the chief of police, and shall be appointed by the chief of police, with the approval of the police-fire committee of the council.
