(b)  The community service officer shall enforce all parking regulations and other city ordinances which do not create an immediate hazard, and shall report to the shift supervisor. The community service officer shall patrol downtown parking areas and other areas as necessary to control and regulate the parking laws and regulations of the city and state. The community service officer shall also investigate complaints relating to weed control, abandoned autos, garbage and refuse offenses and other ordinance violations, shall give information to all interested citizens of the city, shall assist in maintaining an effective relationship between the police service and the community, create and file records as may from time to time be required by the chief, and shall execute complaints and testify in court as needed, and perform such other related duties as may be prescribed from time to time by the council or the chief. 
(Code 1990, § 11-6; Ord. No. 88-1505, § 2.36.140, 4-4-1988) 
Sec. 14-25. - Detectives. 
    Officers may be selected by the chief to operate as detectives, and while acting as such they are not required to wear any certain uniform, but shall at all times be subject to the rules and regulations affecting and subject to the same duties as all regular members of the police service. 
(Code 1990, § 11-7; Ord. No. 88-1505, § 2.36.120, 4-4-1988) 
Secs. 14-26-14-53. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - CHIEF OF POLICE 

Sec. 14-54. - Office created; duties generally. 
    There is created the office of chief of police with the combined duties as prescribed in this article, who shall be the head of the police service. All rules and regulations shall be promulgated through the chief. He and all members of the police service shall devote their entire time to the duties of their office, which shall be the preservation of the peace, order, safety and cleanliness of the city; enforcement of all laws of the state, the United States, ordinances and police regulations of the city; and all lawful orders of the mayor and council. 
(Code 1990, § 11-26; Ord. No. 88-1505, § 2.36.060, 4-4-1988) 
State Law reference- Power of city to prescribe the duties and powers of police officers, 65 ILCS 5/11-1-2. 
Sec. 14-55. - Attendance at council meetings. 
    The chief of police or a designated representative of the police service shall attend meetings of the council. 
(Code 1990, § 11-27; Ord. No. 88-1505, § 2.36.070, 4-4-1988) 
Sec. 14-56. - Informing city attorney of impending suits. 
    It shall be the duty of the chief of police to cause the city attorney to be informed of any suits instituted by him, or through his department, wherein the interests of the city may require the presence of the city attorney at the trial thereof. 
(Code 1990, § 11-28; Ord. No. 88-1505, § 2.36.080, 4-4-1988) 
Sec. 14-57. - Reports on employees' conduct. 
    The chief of police shall report promptly in writing to the mayor and the board of police and fire commissioners any member of the police service who is guilty of drunkenness, neglect of duty, disobedience of orders, violation of the standing rules and regulations of the police service or other conduct unbecoming an employee. 
(Code 1990, § 11-29; Ord. No. 88-1505, § 2.36.090, 4-4-1988) 
Sec. 14-58. - Reports to mayor. 
    The chief of police shall make reports in writing to the mayor when requested. Such reports shall show the state of the police service, with such statistics and suggestions as he deems advisable for the improvement of the police service, or of the discipline and government of same. Such reports shall also show the number of arrests made by the police during the preceding year, the offense charged and the disposition of the case. 
(Code 1990, § 11-30; Ord. No. 88-1505, §§ 2.36.100, 2.36.110, 4-4-1988) 
Secs. 14-59-14-89. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SPECIAL POLICE SCHOOL PATROL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- School crossing guards, tax authorized, 65 ILCS 5/11-80-23. 

Sec. 14-90. - Created. 
    There is hereby created the position of special police school patrol, which shall be appointed by the mayor with the confirmation of the council, to do special duty at any fixed place or area in the city. 
(Code 1977, § 10.40.010; Code 1990, § 11-66) 
Sec. 14-91. - Badge; approval of chief. 
    It is unlawful for any person appointed as special police school patrol to wear or display any badge except those issued by the chief of police, or to wear any insignia, cap, device, button or uniform unless the same has been first approved by the chief of police. 
(Code 1977, § 10.40.030; Code 1990, § 11-67) 
Sec. 14-92. - Rules and regulations; powers. 
    The special police school patrol shall conform to and be subject to all rules and regulations governing police officers of the city, and to such additional rules and regulations as the chief of police may make concerning the special school patrol, and the special police school patrol so appointed shall possess all the powers of the regular police at the places or areas for which they are respectively appointed. 
(Code 1977, § 10.40.040; Code 1990, § 11-68) 
Sec. 14-93. - Removal or discharge from service. 
    The special police school patrol may be removed or discharged from service as such special police school patrol at any time by the mayor. Any special police patrol so discharged or removed shall immediately return the badge issued to him by the chief of police. 
(Code 1977, § 10.40.050; Code 1990, § 11-69) 
Sec. 14-94. - Impersonation a misdemeanor. 
    Any person who knowingly misrepresents himself to be a special police school patrol, or who falsely displays any badge designated by the chief of police for a special police school patrol shall be guilty of a Class B misdemeanor. 
(Code 1977, § 10.40.060; Code 1990, § 11-70) 
Chapter 16 - LICENSES AND BUSINESS REGULATIONS 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 16-1. - Small animal store generally. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Small animal store means and includes any establishment for the raising, training, boarding or selling of dogs, cats, birds, mice, rats, rabbits, rodents, snakes, reptiles, fish or other small animals of the same nomenclature for hire or profit, or where more than three dogs, cats or rabbits are harbored or kept; but provided, however, that the keeping of more than three dogs, cats or rabbits shall not be construed as a small animal store if the dogs, cats or rabbits in excess of three are the offspring of adult dogs, cats or rabbits owned as domestic pets, and provided further that such offspring are eliminated from the household prior to attainment of age of six months. 
(b)  Sanitation; treatment. Every place used as a small animal store shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition, and no refuse or waste material shall be allowed to remain thereon for more than 24 hours. All animals shall be humanely treated, and any animal having any disease shall be promptly isolated and treated. 
(Code 1977, §§ 5.58.010, 5.58.030; Code 1990, § 8-1; Ord. No. 96-1767, § 1, 2-20-1996) 
Sec. 16-2. - Sale, keeping of animals; license. 
(a)  It is unlawful to operate a small animal store anywhere in the city without first securing a license therefor. The annual fee for a license for operation of a kennel or pet shop shall be $50.00. 
(b)  A violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class C violation as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1977, § 5.58.020; Code 1990, § 8-2; Ord. No. 2011-2458, § 3, 4-5-2011) 
Secs. 16-3-16-22. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LICENSES AND PERMITS GENERALLY 

Sec. 16-23. - Persons subject to license. 
(a)  No person shall conduct, engage in, maintain, operate, carry on or manage any business, occupation, activity or establishment either by himself or through an agent, employee or partner, for which a license is required by this Code or by any municipal ordinance, without first having obtained a license for such business, occupation, activity or establishment. 
(b)  Whenever in this Code a license is required for the maintenance, operation or conduct of any business or establishment, or for doing business or engaging in any activity or occupation, any person or corporation shall be subject to the requirement if by himself or through an agent, employee or partner, he holds himself forth as being engaged in the business or occupation; or solicits patronage therefor, actively or passively; or performs or attempts to perform any part of such business or occupation in the city. 
(c)  A license shall not be issued to any applicant if it is determined that such applicant has been engaged in the business, occupation, activity or establishment for any prior period for which a license was required under this Code or any prior code or ordinance, and if such license has not been obtained by the applicant or if the fee has not been paid, and the license shall be issued to such applicant only upon payment of all fees for prior periods for which a license was required, together with the necessary fee for issuance of the license for which application has been made. 
(Code 1977, § 5.02.020; Code 1990, § 8-22) 
Sec. 16-24. - Application; information required; renewal. 
(a)  Applications for all licenses and permits required by ordinance shall be made in writing to the city clerk in the absence of provisions to the contrary. Each application shall state the name of the applicant, the permit or license desired, the location to be used, if any, the time covered and the fee to be paid. Each application shall contain such additional information as may be needed for the proper guidance of the city officials in the issuing of the permit or license applied for. The city clerk may require documentary proof of the accuracy of the information requested in the application. 
(b)  If the applicant is an individual or sole proprietorship, the application shall contain his name, residence address and telephone number. If the applicant is a partnership or other noncorporate entity, the application shall contain the name and residence address and telephone number of each partner, principal or member thereof. If the applicant is a corporation, the application shall contain the name, residence address and telephone number of each principal officer and the name and address of the registered agent thereof. 
(c)  Each application shall also contain: 
(1)  A designation of the type or kind of license or permit desired; 
(2)  The location or proposed location of the place of business, occupation or activity; 
(3)  The applicable fee to be paid as provided in this article; 
(4)  The number of the certificate of registration required under the Retailers' Occupation Tax Act (35 ILCS 120/1 et seq.), Service Occupation Tax Act (35 ILCS 115/1 et seq.), and/or Use Tax Act (35 ILCS 105/1 et seq.), if applicable, or proof of application thereof; 
(5)  Such additional information as may be needed for the proper guidance of municipal officials in the evaluation of the application, including proof of any insurance or bond required by this Code. 
(d)  The city clerk shall mail to each licensee at least 30 days prior to the expiration date of the license at the address as stated in the license notification of the time of expiration of the license held by such licensee. If the licensee has not applied for renewal of the license on or before the expiration date of the previous license, the city clerk shall send notification of expiration of the previous license within ten days following the date of expiration of the previous license. If the licensee shall not have renewed the license within 25 days from the expiration of the previous license, and if such license is required by this Code or any ordinance to renew such license or obtain additional licenses, there shall be delivered to such licensee notice that unless such license shall be obtained within two business days following delivery of the notice, that the licensee shall be subject to fine for violation of this article. Such notice shall be sent by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the licensee or permittee at his last known address. 
(Code 1977, §§ 5.02.030, 5.02.080; Code 1990, § 8-23; Ord. No. 2011-2458, § 4, 4-5-2011) 
Sec. 16-25. - Forms on file. 
    Forms for all licenses and permits, and applications therefor, shall be prepared and kept on file by the city clerk. 
(Code 1977, § 5.02.040; Code 1990, § 8-24) 
Sec. 16-26. - Signatures required. 
    Each license or permit issued shall bear the signatures of the mayor and the city clerk in the absence of any provision to the contrary. 
(Code 1977, § 5.02.050; Code 1990, § 8-25) 
Sec. 16-27. - Inspection, investigation prior to issuance. 
    Upon receipt of an application for a license or permit where ordinances of the city necessitate an inspection or investigation before the issuance of such permit, the city clerk shall refer such application to the proper officer for making such investigation within 48 hours of the time of receipt. All applications for business licenses shall be referred to the zoning and building official of the city within 48 hours of receipt of the application, and the zoning and building official shall be authorized and directed to make such inspections and investigations into the premises and the condition of the premises as he deems appropriate in order to ensure that the premises from which the licensed business will be conducted complies with all building and zoning codes of the city. Any officer of the city charged with the duty of making an inspection or investigation shall make a report thereon, favorable or otherwise, within ten days after receiving the application or a copy thereof. The city shall make or cause to be made any inspection in regard to such license in connection with the care and handling of food, the prevention of nuisances and the spread of disease, for the protection of health. The zoning and building official shall make or cause to be made any inspections relative to the construction of buildings or other structures. All other investigations, except where otherwise provided, shall be made by the chief of police or some other officer designated by the mayor. 
(Code 1977, § 5.02.060; Code 1990, § 8-26; Ord. No. 97-1821, § 1, 9-30-1997) 
Sec. 16-28. - Fees paid in advance. 
    In the absence of provisions to the contrary, all fees and charges for licenses or permits shall be paid in advance at the time application therefor is made to the city clerk. Except as otherwise provided, all license fees shall become a part of the corporate fund. 
(Code 1977, § 5.02.070; Code 1990, § 8-27) 
Sec. 16-29. - Termination of annual license; notice to licensee; renewal. 
(a)  All annual business licenses shall terminate on the last day of the fiscal year during which they are issued, where no provision to the contrary is made. 
(b)  A failure by the city clerk to send out any notice provided for in section 16-24(d), or any failure of the licensee to receive any such notice, shall not excuse the licensee from the obtaining of a new license or renewal of a previously issued license, nor shall failure to receive notification be a defense in any action for operation without a license. 
(Code 1977, § 5.02.080; Code 1990, § 8-28) 
Sec. 16-30. - Buildings, premises to comply with city requirements. 
    No license shall be issued for the conduct of any business, and no permit shall be issued for any thing or act, if the premises and building to be used for the purpose do not fully comply with the requirements of the city. No such license or permit shall be issued for the conduct of any business or performance of any act which would involve a violation of the city zoning ordinance. 
(Code 1977, § 5.02.090; Code 1990, § 8-29) 
Sec. 16-31. - Separate license for each location; change in location. 
(a)  No license or permit for the operation of a business, establishment or activity in the city shall be construed to permit its operation in more than one location in the city; a separate license or permit shall be required for each location. For purposes of this Code, the existence of a single location shall be evidenced by the fact that all buildings containing the principal or accessory uses: 
(1)  Shall be connected or shall be located on the same lot or parcel; 
(2)  Shall be operated and managed by the same person or owner; and 
(3)  Shall be an establishment with the same classification. 
(b)  The location of any licensed business or occupation or of any permitted act, other than the sale of alcoholic liquors, may be changed, provided ten days' notice thereof is given to the city clerk, in the absence of any provision to the contrary; provided that the building, zoning and frontage requirements of the ordinances shall be complied with. 
(Code 1977, § 5.02.100; Code 1990, § 8-30) 
Sec. 16-32. - Nuisance business. 
(a)  Generally. No business or establishment, whether or not licensed, shall be so conducted or operated as to constitute a nuisance in fact; and no building, vehicle, structure, yard, lot, premises, or part thereof, shall be used, kept, maintained or operated in connection with any business or establishment so as to occasion any nuisance, or so as to be dangerous to life or detrimental to health. Any charge of conducting or operating a nuisance may be made under this article or under the provisions of this Code prohibiting nuisances generally. 
(b)  Unsafe or unhealthful business. 
(1)  No building or structure utilized, constructed, or maintained in connection with any business or occupation shall evidence an unsanitary, unsafe or dangerous condition. 
(2)  No substance, matter or thing of any kind whatever, which shall be dangerous or detrimental to health, shall be allowed to exist in connection with any business or occupation, or be used in any work or labor performed in the city. 
(c)  Refuse disposal. 
(1)  Refuse containers. Refuse containers shall be required as provided in section 32-505. 
(2)  Refuse removal. It shall be the duty of the occupant of every building, structure or premises used or maintained in connection with any business or occupation to cause to be removed at his own cost and expense at least once each week all refuse produced therein. 
(3)  Removal of refuse by businesses and occupations. Every person owning or controlling any hotel, restaurant, cafe, retail food establishment or other business or occupation, where more than 32 gallons of refuse is normally produced weekly, shall cause all substances deposited in such containers to be removed as often as shall be necessary, including daily removal from his premises, to ensure the healthful environment surrounding such establishment. Such removal shall be at his own expense. 
(Code 1977, § 5.02.110; Code 1990, § 8-31) 
Sec. 16-33. - Inspection of building or premises; analysis of commodity. 
(a)  Whenever inspections of the premises including the contents thereof used for or in connection with the operation of a licensed business or occupation are provided for or required by ordinance, or are reasonably necessary to secure compliance with any ordinance provisions, it shall be the duty of the licensee, or the person in charge of the premises to be inspected, to admit thereto for the purpose of making the inspection any officer or employee of the city who is authorized or directed to make such inspection at any reasonable time that admission is requested. 
(b)  Whenever any analysis of any commodity or material is reasonably necessary to secure conformance with any ordinance provision or to detect violations thereof, it shall be the duty of the licensee of the municipality whose business is governed by such provision to give to any authorized officer or employee of the city requesting the same sufficient samples of such material or commodity for such analysis upon request. 
(c)  In addition to any other penalty which may be provided, the mayor may revoke the license of any licensed proprietor of any licensed business in the city who refused to permit any such officer or employee who is authorized to make such inspection or take such sample to make the inspection, or take an adequate sample of the commodity, or who interferes with such officer or employee while in the performance of his duty in making such inspection; provided that no license shall be revoked for such cause except after notice of hearing as provided in section 16-36(c). 
(d)  Before any new business license is issued, it shall be mandatory that a building, electrical and fire inspection be made by the building official, and no such license shall be issued until such officer has completed the inspection and given approval therefor. 
(Code 1977, § 5.02.120; Code 1990, § 8-32) 
Sec. 16-34. - Posting of license; unauthorized destruction or removal. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of any person conducting a licensed business in the city to keep his license posted in a prominent place on the premises, machine or vehicle used for such business at all times. 
(b)  No person shall destroy, obliterate, take, remove or carry away without the consent of the owner any license, certificate, plate or sticker which has been issued by the city except when such license, certificate, plate or sticker has been discontinued or the licensed premises has been abandoned. Nothing in this section shall prevent the mayor or his duly authorized representative from removing any license, certificate, plate or sticker from the possession of a former licensee, his premises, any vehicle or any machine when such license has been revoked under the provisions of this Code. 
(Code 1977, § 5.02.130; Code 1990, § 8-33) 
Sec. 16-35. - Violations; penalties; enforcement powers. 
(a)  Unless otherwise expressly provided, a violation of this article shall be punishable as a Class B violation as provided in section 1-41. 
(b)  Whenever a person neglects or refuses to procure any license required by this Code, or otherwise violates the terms of this article, the mayor is authorized to cause appropriate legal action and proceedings to be instituted to enforce the license requirement. 
(c)  The clerk shall take all necessary and appropriate action to compel compliance with the regulatory provisions of this article. When necessary and expedient, he may call upon the chief of police to assist in such enforcement and it shall be the duty of the chief of police to perform such enforcement acts as may be required of him. All municipal employees duly authorized and acting as license inspectors shall be conservators of the peace and police powers for the purpose of enforcing the provisions of this Code and other municipal ordinances relating to the licensing of businesses and occupations and their regulations. 
(Code 1977, § 5.02.150; Code 1990, § 8-35; Ord. No. 2011-2458, § 5, 4-5-2011) 
Sec. 16-36. - Suspension, revocation; appeals. 
(a)  When the conduct or operation of any business, occupation, activity or establishment, whether licensed or unlicensed, constitutes a nuisance in fact and a clear and present danger to the public health, safety or general welfare, the mayor shall be authorized to summarily order the cessation of business and the closing of the premises and suspension of the license until the danger no longer exists. 
(b)  Within eight days after a license or permit is suspended, the mayor shall call a hearing for the purpose of determining whether or not the license or permit should be revoked. 
(c)  Licenses and permits issued by the city, unless otherwise provided, may be revoked by the mayor after notice and hearing as provided in subsections (d) and (e) of this section for any of the following causes: 
(1)  Any fraud, misrepresentation or false statement contained in the application for the license or permit; 
(2)  Any violation by the licensee or permittee of provisions of this Code or other ordinances of the city relating to the license or permit, the subject matter of the license or permit or the premises occupied; 
(3)  Conviction of the licensee or permittee of any felony or of a misdemeanor where such conviction indicates their inability to operate a safe, honest and legitimate business operation within the city; 
(4)  Failure of the licensee or permittee to pay any fine, penalty or charge owed to the city; 
(5)  Refusal to permit an inspection or sampling or any interference with a duly authorized municipal officer or employee while in the reasonable performance of his duties in making such inspections, as provided in section 16-31. Such revocation, if ordered, shall not preclude prosecution and imposition of any other penalties provided for the violation of other applicable provisions of this Code or other ordinances of the city. 
(d)  Notice of the hearing for revocation of a license or permit shall be given in writing, setting forth specifically the grounds of the complaint and the time and place of the hearing. Such notice shall be sent by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the licensee or permittee at his last-known address, at least five days prior to the date set for the hearing. If the licensee requests a continuance in the date of the hearing, the ten-day suspension shall be in effect until two days after the final hearing date. 
(e)  At the hearing, the city attorney shall present the complaint and shall represent the city. The licensee or permittee shall be permitted counsel and shall have the right to submit evidence and cross examine witnesses. The mayor shall preside and shall render the decision. 
(f)  A stenographic or electronically recorded record of the hearing shall be kept. The city shall pay the cost of attendance fees of the reporter and the cost of the transcript, if such transcript is ordered by the city. The licensee or permittee shall pay the cost of any transcript ordered by him. 
(g)  Within a reasonable time after the conclusion of the hearing, but not later than 30 days after such conclusion, the mayor shall file a written decision in which he has summarized the evidence and has stated the reasons for his decision. 
(h)  Any person aggrieved by the decision of the mayor in regard to the denial of an application for a business license, as provided in this Code, or in connection with the revocation of a license or permit, or the closing of an establishment dangerous to the public, as provided in this Code, shall have the right to appeal to the council. Such appeal shall be taken by filing with the clerk, within ten days after notice of a denial of an application or revocation of a license or permit, a written statement under oath setting forth specifically the grounds for appeal. The council shall thereupon set the time and place for a hearing on such appeal, and notice of such hearing shall be given to the applicant or licensee or permittee in the same manner as provided in this section. The decision of the council on such appeal shall be final. 
(Code 1977, § 5.02.160; Code 1990, § 8-36) 
Secs. 16-37-16-62. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - ADVERTISING 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 16-63-16-82. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - OUTDOOR ADVERTISERS 

Sec. 16-83. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Outdoor advertiser means any person engaged in the business of placing, posting or painting any sign, advertisement, notice or display in or on any place for the purpose of outdoor advertising so that the resultant display is visible from any street, alley, sidewalk or other public place. No person shall be deemed to be an outdoor advertiser and therefor subject to the licensing requirements of this division solely as a result of placing, posting or painting any sign, advertisement, notice or display in or on the business premises owned and occupied by that person. 
(Code 1977, § 5.68.010; Code 1990, § 8-81; Ord. No. 85-1419, § 5.68.010, 8-19-1985) 
Sec. 16-84. - License-Required; scope. 
    It is unlawful for any outdoor advertiser to do business in the city without first having secured a license therefor as is required in this section; provided that no license issued under this division shall be construed to permit the use for advertising purposes of any structure, natural or artificial, which is located in any public street, alley or other public place in the city. A violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class B violation as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1977, § 5.68.020; Code 1990, § 8-82; Ord. No. 2011-2458, § 6, 4-5-2011) 
Sec. 16-85. - Same-Application. 
    Applications for outdoor advertising licenses shall be made in writing to the city clerk and shall be accompanied by a list of all places, including billboards or natural structures, on which it is intended to place signs or advertisements. The list shall be added to from time to time by the licensee as the right to post or place advertisements or signs on additional places is acquired. 
(Code 1977, § 5.68.030; Code 1990, § 8-83) 
Sec. 16-86. - Same-Fee. 
    The annual fee for an outdoor advertising license shall be $50.00. 
(Code 1990, § 8-84; Ord. No. 85-1419, § 5.68.040, 8-19-1985; Ord. No. 2000-1939, § 12, 6-6-2000) 
Sec. 16-87. - Name of advertiser to be visible. 
    It is unlawful for any outdoor advertiser to carry on his business unless the name of such advertiser is attached, displayed or printed on all billboards or signboards used by him or on any notices, placards or advertisements posted by him, in such lettering as to be visible from a distance of at least five feet from the notice or advertisement. A violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class B violation as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1977, § 5.68.050; Code 1990, § 8-85; Ord. No. 2011-2458, § 7, 4-5-2011) 
Sec. 16-88. - Use of poster panels, billboards, signboards. 
    No person shall post or maintain any advertisement or sign on any poster panel, billboard or signboard which does not fully comply with the ordinances of the city. 
(Code 1977, § 5.68.060; Code 1990, § 8-86) 
Sec. 16-89. - Consent of owner of premises. 
    It is unlawful to post any advertisements on any premises in the city without the consent of the owner of such premises. Such consents shall be in writing and must be filed with the city clerk. 
(Code 1977, § 5.68.070; Code 1990, § 8-87) 
Sec. 16-90. - Disposal of refuse. 
    It is unlawful for any person engaged in outdoor advertising to permit any refuse resulting from this work to accumulate anywhere in the city, except by placing it in properly established refuse receptacles. It is unlawful to permit any loose, flapping or combustible materials to hang from or be attached to any billboard, signboard or other place used for display or advertising purposes. All refuse resulting from the operation of this business must be carefully gathered up and properly disposed of. A violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class B violation as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1977, § 5.68.080; Code 1990, § 8-88; Ord. No. 2011-2458, § 8, 4-5-2011) 
Sec. 16-91. - Trimming vegetation at base of billboards. 
    It shall be the duty of every outdoor advertiser to keep all grass and weeds and other growths, except trees and ornamental shrubbery, cut down so that the same shall not grow to a height greater than ten inches within six feet of any billboard or signboard used by him. This obligation shall extend only to property controlled by the advertiser. 
(Code 1977, § 5.68.090; Code 1990, § 8-89) 
Sec. 16-92. - Mutilating, disfiguring signs or advertisements. 
    It is unlawful to mutilate or disfigure in any way any lawful signs or advertisements in the city. A violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class B violation as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1977, § 5.68.100; Code 1990, § 8-90; Ord. No. 2011-2458, § 9, 4-5-2011) 
Sec. 16-93. - Certain advertisements prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person to post or display any advertisement of an obscene character, or any advertisement tending to promote or cause a riot or breach of the peace, or any advertisement of any unlawful gathering, or advertisements of unlawful sales. A violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class B violation as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1977, § 5.68.110; Code 1990, § 8-91; Ord. No. 2011-2458, § 10, 4-5-2011) 
Sec. 16-94. - Exemptions. 
    The provisions of this division shall not be construed to apply to the posting of signs or notices by order of any court or by any public officer in the performance of his duties, nor shall such provisions be construed to be in conflict with the Highway Advertising Control Act of 1971 (225 ILCS 440/1 et seq.) or any other state law. 
(Code 1977, § 5.68.120; Code 1990, § 8-92) 
Sec. 16-95. - Certificate of insurance. 
    Any application for an outdoor advertising license pursuant to this division shall be accompanied by a certificate of insurance issued by an insurer doing business within the state. Such certificate shall be valid for a period of one year from the date of application, and shall certify that the applicant is insured against liability for personal injury or property damage arising out of the placing, posting, painting or construction of any sign, advertisement, notice or display in minimum amounts of $100,000.00 per person and $300,000.00 per occurrence. 
(Code 1990, § 8-93; Ord. No. 85-1419, § 5.68.130, 8-19-1985) 
Secs. 16-96-16-118. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - AMPLIFIERS 

Sec. 16-119. - License-Required. 
    It is unlawful to maintain or operate any loudspeaker or amplifier connected with any radio, phonograph, microphone or other device by which sounds are magnified and made audible over any public street or public place without first having obtained a license therefor. A violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class B violation as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1977, § 5.08.010; Code 1990, § 8-111; Ord. No. 2011-2458, § 11, 4-5-2011) 
Sec. 16-120. - Same-Application. 
    Any person desiring a license for the use or operation of an amplifying device shall file an application therefor with the city clerk, upon a form provided by him, setting forth the name and address of the applicant, the name of the owner of such device, the date upon which it is intended to be used and such other information as may be prescribed. 
(Code 1977, § 5.08.020; Code 1990, § 8-112) 
Sec. 16-121. - Same-Issuance; fee. 
    A license under this division shall issue upon the payment of the license fee of $30.00 to the city clerk and approval of the council and shall permit the use of any such device subject to the terms and conditions of this division, only upon the date specified on such license and on no other. 
(Code 1977, § 5.08.030; Code 1990, § 8-113; Ord. No. 2003-2060, § 1, 9-2-2003) 
Sec. 16-122. - Use restrictions. 
(a)  No licensee under this division shall use, operate or employ any amplifying device within the city limits on Sunday, or after the hour of 8:00 p.m., prevailing time of any day, or before the hour of 8:00 a.m., prevailing time of any day unless the license granted and issued by the city shall specifically designated additional hours for the use or operation of such device. No licensee shall use, operate or employ any such device within a radius of two blocks from any hospital or within the radius of two blocks from any church while religious or funeral services are being held there. 
(b)  Subsection (a) of this section shall not apply to radios in homes or in private pleasure vehicles, when the same are operated in such manner as not to be audible at a distance of 50 feet from such vehicle, nor to noise devices, bands or other musical devices used in any public parade or procession which is operated under a permit in accordance with the ordinance of the city. 
(Code 1977, §§ 5.08.040, 5.08.050; Code 1990, § 8-114; Ord. No. 2007-2231, § 1, 6-19-2007) 
Sec. 16-123. - Obscene language, false representation. 
    No licensee under this division shall cause or permit to be emanated or emitted from any amplifying device any obscene language or sounds, or any false representation of any matter, produce or project advertised thereby, the sale of which is prohibited by law, ordinance or statute. 
(Code 1977, § 5.08.060; Code 1990, § 8-115) 
Secs. 16-124-16-144. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - SALE OF GOODS GENERALLY 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 16-145-16-171. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - VENDING MACHINES 

Sec. 16-172. - License-Required. 
    No person shall operate or maintain within the city any automatic vending machine for the sale of any merchandise, except dispensing stamps or hygienic (sanitary) equipment, nor sell or offer for sale any such merchandise by means of any automatic vending machine (coin-operated) without first having obtained a license for each of such automatic vending machines as provided in this division. 
(Code 1977, § 5.94.010; Code 1990, § 8-156) 
Sec. 16-173. - Same-Application; issuance; term. 
    Any person desiring to sell any merchandise by means of automatic vending machines (coin-operated) shall make application for a license for that purpose to the city clerk. Such application shall set forth the name and address of the applicant, the number of vending machines for which the applicant desires licenses, the address at which such vending machines will be located, and the merchandise being offered for sale by means of such automatic vending machines. If the applicants are found to be of good character and reputation, the city clerk, upon approval of the council, shall cause a license or licenses to be issued to such applicant upon the payment of the license fees set forth in this division, which license shall be valid for one year. Such period for which each annual license is issued shall be from May 1 to April 30 inclusive. 
(Code 1977, § 5.94.020; Code 1990, § 8-157) 
Sec. 16-174. - Same-Fee. 
    An applicant for a vending machine license shall pay a fee at the time of application according to the following schedule: 
(1)  Any person seeking a license to do business as a vending machine operator shall pay an annual fee of $50.00 at the time of such application. 
(2)  Any person operating any vending machine subject to this division in conjunction with or ancillary to the operation of any other business operated by such person shall pay an annual fee of $10.00, such fee to be paid in addition to any other license fees required by ordinance for the operating of other businesses by the applicant. 
(Code 1977, § 5.94.030; Code 1990, § 8-158; Ord. No. 2003-2060, § 2, 9-2-2003) 
Secs. 16-175-16-202. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - LUMBER DEALERS 

Sec. 16-203. - License-Required; application. 
    No person shall establish, conduct or maintain a lumberyard in the city without having first obtained a license therefor as is required in this division. Any place used for the storage of lumber, wooden containers or wood in an amount exceeding 5,000 board feet shall be construed to be a lumberyard. Applications for such licenses shall be made to the city clerk in writing and shall state thereon the location and size of the lumberyard for which such license is intended. 
(Code 1977, § 5.62.010; Code 1990, § 8-176) 
Sec. 16-204. - Same-Fee. 
    The annual fee for a license for a lumberyard shall be $25.00. 
(Code 1977, § 5.62.020; Code 1990, § 8-177; Ord. No. 2000-1939, § 10, 6-6-2000) 
Sec. 16-205. - Manner of storing, piling lumber. 
    It is unlawful to pile any lumber in a lumberyard in such a way that the lumber is hanging over, or in danger of falling onto, any adjoining property, street, alley or public way. Lumber and materials stored within a lumberyard shall be stacked in such a manner so as to permit access thereto by fire or other emergency vehicles, and the items shall be stacked to provide rows of sufficient width to permit such vehicles to drive between such rows. 
(Code 1977, § 5.62.050; Code 1990, § 8-179) 
Sec. 16-206. - Inspections. 
    It shall be duty of the fire chief to inspect or cause to be inspected every lumberyard in the city to ensure compliance with the provisions of this division. Such inspections shall occur at least semiannually. 
(Code 1977, § 5.62.060; Code 1990, § 8-180) 
Secs. 16-207-16-235. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - AUCTIONEERS 

Sec. 16-236. - License-Required. 
    It is unlawful for any person to engage in the business of auctioneer or to hold auctions in the city without having first obtained a license therefor. A violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class B violation as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1977, § 5.12.010; Code 1990, § 8-196; Ord. No. 2011-2458, § 12, 4-5-2011) 
Sec. 16-237. - Same-Fees. 
    The annual fee for engaging in the business of auctioneer shall be $75.00. 
(Code 1977, § 5.12.020; Code 1990, § 8-197; Ord. No. 2000-1939, § 2, 6-6-2000; Ord. No. 2003-2060, § 3, 9-2-2003; Ord. No. 2010-2392, § 1, 3-16-2010) 
Sec. 16-238. - Conduct of auction. 
    All auctions shall be conducted in an orderly manner, and it shall be unlawful to create or permit any disturbance or disorderly conduct at any auction. 
(Code 1977, § 5.12.030; Code 1990, § 8-198) 
Sec. 16-239. - Fraudulent statements. 
    It is unlawful for any person selling goods at auction to make any fraudulent or untrue statements concerning the goods or articles sold. A violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class B violation as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1977, § 5.12.040; Code 1990, § 8-199; Ord. No. 2011-2458, § 13, 4-5-2011) 
Sec. 16-240. - Articles open to inspection. 
    Every article offered for sale at a public auction shall be open to the inspection of any person wishing to purchase it at some time before or during the bidding. 
(Code 1977, § 5.12.050; Code 1990, § 8-200) 
Secs. 16-241-16-258. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - SECONDHAND STORES 

Sec. 16-259. - License-Required; fee. 
(a)  No person shall operate a secondhand store without first having obtained an annual license therefor, in compliance with the provisions of this division. The annual fee for a license for a "secondhand store" shall be $75.00, and no license shall be issued except after payment of the fee and certification by the building and zoning official of compliance of the premises with the building and zoning codes of the city. 
(b)  As used herein, the term "secondhand store" means any business selling or offering for sale merchandise: 
(1)  Which has previously been sold or used at or through another retail sale outlet; 
(2)  Which has been previously used by any consumer or other business for either personal use or use within the other business; or 
(3)  Which has been purchased for resale from individuals, consumers, or other businesses not as a part of any new inventory purchase. 
A business may be a secondhand store if it sells new merchandise or inventory in addition to previously used merchandise or inventory; provided, however, a secondhand store shall not include any business from which the sale of used merchandise consists only of motor vehicles or books. 
(Code 1977, § 5.80.010; Code 1990, § 8-216; Ord. No. 2000-1939, § 15, 6-6-2000; Ord. No. 2003-2060, § 4, 9-2-2003; Ord. No. 2010-2392, § 6, 3-16-2010; Ord. No. 2012-2495, § 1, 4-3-2012) 
Sec. 16-260. - Same-Application; investigation of applicant and premises. 
    An application for secondhand store license shall be made to the city clerk in writing, and shall state the location from which the business will be operated. Upon receipt of such application, the clerk shall refer the application to the zoning and building official for investigation of the premises to determine that the premises are in compliance with the building and zoning codes of the city, and no such license shall be issued for operation of a secondhand store that is not in compliance with the building and zoningcodes. The zoning and building official shall report to the city clerk on the condition of the premises and compliance thereof. In addition, the city clerk, or any person directed or authorized by the mayor, shall investigate the character of the applicant and shall report to the mayor the result of such investigation. No license shall be issued to a person who has been convicted of receiving stolen goods, burglary, robbery or any Class X felony or capital offense. 
(Code 1977, § 5.80.020; Code 1990, § 8-217; Ord. No. 2012-2495, § 2, 4-3-2012) 
Sec. 16-261. - Records; inspection; storage of materials. 
(a)  Every person operating a secondhand store shall keep a record of all articles purchased, which records shall specify the description of the article and the name, age and address of the person from whom purchased. Such record, together with the articles so purchased, shall be open to inspection by any police officer at all reasonable times. 
(b)  In the operation of a secondhand store, no merchandise shall be displayed nor offered for sale outside of the building at the premises of the business except between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. All articles and merchandise offered for sale shall otherwise be stored within the building located at the premises to which the license is applicable. 
(Code 1977, § 5.80.030; Code 1990, § 8-218; Ord. No. 2012-2495, § 3, 4-3-2012) 
Sec. 16-262. - Sales of secondhand merchandise; residentially zoned locations. 
(a)  Sales of used or secondhand items or merchandise, where such merchandise is displayed and members of the public are invited to a specific location to view and purchase the merchandise, when the location of display is zoned for residential use shall be conducted in accordance with the requirements of this section only. Such sales are sometimes commonly known as "yard sales," "garage sales," "rummage sales" or other similar designations. 
(b)  Such sales of secondhand or used items or merchandise shall not be conducted or held at any single address or location within the city on more than six calendar days (or parts thereof) in any calendar year, and no items or merchandise shall be offered for sale or displayed at any one location for more than three consecutive calendar days (or parts thereof). 
(c)  A violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class C violation as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1990, § 8-219; Ord. No. 93-1676, §§ 1, 2, 9-7-1993; Ord. No. 2011-2458, § 14, 4-5-2011) 
DIVISION 5.5. - PAWNBROKERS 

Sec. 16-263. - Definition-Pawnbroker. 
    Every individual or business entity which lends money on the deposit or pledge of physically delivered personal property, other than property the ownership of which is subject to a legal dispute, securities, printed evidence of indebtedness or printed evidence of ownership of the personal property, or who deals in the purchase of such property on the condition of selling the property back again at a stipulated price, shall be held and is hereby declared and defined to be a pawnbroker. The business of a pawnbroker does not include the lending of money on deposit or pledge of title to property. For purposes of this definition, the term pawnbroker does not include the operator of a "second hand store" within the meaning of section 16-259 of this article, nor a "junk dealer" within the meaning of section 16-288 of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2016-2255, § 1, 6-7-2016) 
Sec. 16-264. - License-Required. 
    It is unlawful to operate or carry on the business of a pawnbroker or to operate a pawnshop without first having obtained a license therefor from the city. In addition, it shall be unlawful to operate or carry on the business of a pawnbroker or to operate a pawnshop without having first obtained a license issued by the department of financial and professional regulation pursuant to the Pawnbroker Regulation Act, 205 ILCS 510/0.01 et seq., and any other licenses required thereunder for managerial employees, pursuant to 205 ILCS 510/1(b). 
(Ord. No. 2016-2255, § 1, 6-7-2016) 
Sec. 16-265. - Application for license. 
    Application for such license shall be made in accordance with the provisions of article II of this chapter, and in accordance with the requirements of the Pawnbroker Regulation Act, 205 ILCS 510/0.01 et seq. 
(Ord. No. 2016-2255, § 1, 6-7-2016) 
Sec. 16-266. - Fee. 
    The fee for the license for operation as a pawnbroker shall be $200.00 per year. No such license shall be issued to any person, corporation, partnership, association, or other business entity other than the actual proprietor of the business and the place of business for which it is issued. 
(Ord. No. 2016-2255, § 1, 6-7-2016) 
Sec. 16-267. - Non-use and transfer of license. 
    If a pawnbroker fails to conduct said business for a continuous period of 90 days, the license shall be null and void. Pawnbroker licenses shall not be transferable. 
(Ord. No. 2016-2255, § 1, 6-7-2016) 
Sec. 16-268. - Compliance with state law. 
    Pawnbrokers shall comply with all requirements of the Pawnbroker Regulation Act, 205 ILCS 510/0.01 et seq., and all regulations promulgated thereunder, as may be amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 2016-2255, § 1, 6-7-2016) 
Sec. 16-269. - Revocation of license. 
    The city council may revoke any license issued under this division for a violation or violations of the provisions of this division, including violations of the Pawnbroker Regulation Act, 205 ILCS 510.001 et seq., or any regulation promulgated thereunder, after notice of the alleged violation or violations and an opportunity for a hearing before the city council prior to such revocation. 
(Ord. No. 2016-2255, § 1, 6-7-2016) 
Sec. 16-270. - Acts of employees. 
    Any licensee under this division shall be responsible for any and all acts of employees within the scope of employment for the licensee and for any violation by them of the provisions of this division. 
(Ord. No. 2016-2255, § 1, 6-7-2016) 
Sec. 16-271. - Employee/principal party registration. 
    Every employee and principal party of a pawnshop as herein defined shall, within 30 days from the effective date of this division, or within 30 days from the date of his or her hire or association with a pawnshop, register his or her name, address, and photograph with the police department of the city. For the purposes of this section, an "employee" shall include all persons working in a pawnshop and "principal party" means any officer or director of a pawnshop or a corporation that owns or seeks to own a pawnshop; any manager of a limited liability company that is a pawnshop or that owns or seeks to own a pawnshop; any shareholder or member owning ten percent or more of the outstanding stock or membership interests of a pawnshop, or a business entity that owns or seeks to own a pawnshop; or any partner, whether general or limited, of a partnership that is a pawnshop or that seeks to own a pawnshop. 
(Ord. No. 2016-2255, § 1, 6-7-2016) 
Sec. 16-272. - Location. 
    No pawnbroker's license shall be issued for any location where such business is not permitted by the zoning ordinances of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2016-2255, § 1, 6-7-2016) 
Sec. 16-273. - Penalty. 
    Unless otherwise specified herein, any violation of this division shall be punishable as a Class A violation as provided in subsection 1-41(d)(1) of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 2016-2255, § 1, 6-7-2016) 
Secs. 16-274-16-287. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - JUNK DEALERS AND JUNKYARDS 

Sec. 16-288. - License-Required. 
    It is unlawful to operate or carry on the business of junk dealer or to keep any junkyard, store or place for the purchase or sale of junk, rags, old rope, paper or bagging, old iron, brass, copper or empty bottles, without having obtained a license therefor. A violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class B violation as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1977, § 5.56.010; Code 1990, § 8-236; Ord. No. 2011-2458, § 15, 4-5-2011) 
Sec. 16-289. - Same-Application. 
    Applications for such licenses shall be made in conformance with the provisions of article II of this chapter. 
(Code 1977, § 5.56.020; Code 1990, § 8-237) 
Sec. 16-290. - Same-Fee. 
    The fee for a license for operation as a junk dealer shall be $50.00 per year. The fee for operating of a junkyard shall be $150.00. 
(Code 1977, § 5.56.030; Code 1990, § 8-238; Ord. No. 2000-1939, § 8, 6-6-2000; Ord. No. 2003-2060, § 5, 9-2-2003) 
Sec. 16-291. - Receiving stolen or lost goods. 
    Every junk dealer or keeper of a junkyard who shall receive or be in possession of any goods, articles or things of value which may have been lost or stolen shall upon demand produce such article or thing to any member of the police service for examination. 
(Code 1977, § 5.56.040; Code 1990, § 8-239) 
Sec. 16-292. - Vehicles used in business. 
    Every vehicle used by a junk dealer in the conduct of his business shall bear thereon in legible characters the name and address of the owner and proprietor. 
(Code 1977, § 5.56.050; Code 1990, § 8-240) 
Sec. 16-293. - Fencing. 
    Except as otherwise provided by law, junkyards shall be required to maintain an opaque fence of not less than six feet in height surrounding the entire yard. This fence will keep from sight of passersby the materials enclosed within. Fence construction will comply with the building codes of the city. 
(Code 1977, § 5.56.060; Code 1990, § 8-241) 
Secs. 16-294-16-319. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - TOBACCO DEALERS 

Sec. 16-320. - License-Required. 
    It shall be unlawful to sell or offer for sale at retail, to give away, deliver or to keep with the intention of selling at retail, giving away or delivering tobacco products (as defined in section 22-128), cigarette papers or wrappers within the city without having first obtained a tobacco dealer's license therefor pursuant to this division. Such license shall be in addition to any other license required by this Code. A violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class B violation as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1990, § 8-245; Ord. No. 2000-1942, § 2, 7-5-2000; Ord. No. 2011-2458, § 16, 4-5-2011) 
Sec. 16-321. - Same-Application; fee. 
(a)  Application for a license under this division shall be made in writing to the city clerk and shall state the name and residence of the applicant, and the location at which sales are to be made. Such application shall be accompanied by evidence that the applicant is a person of good character and reputation, and shall be accompanied by the license fee provided in this division. All premises from which sales are to be made pursuant to a license issued under this division shall conform to all building and construction codes of the city. The application for license constitutes the granting of permission by the applicant for an inspection of the premises by the building official. 
(b)  The annual license fee under this division shall be $100.00. 
(Code 1990, § 8-246; Ord. No. 2000-1942, § 2, 7-5-2000; Ord. No. 2005-2116, § 1, 2-1-2005; Ord. No. 2010-2392, § 7, 3-16-2010) 
Sec. 16-322. - Responsibility for agents and employees. 
    Every act or omission of whatsoever nature, constituting a violation of any of the provisions of this division by any officer, director, manager or other agent or employee of any licensee shall be deemed and held to be the act of such licensee; and such licensee shall be punishable in the same manner as if such act or omission had been done or omitted by the licensee personally. 
(Code 1990, § 8-247; Ord. No. 2000-1942, § 2, 7-5-2000) 
Sec. 16-323. - Tobacco control commissioner. 
(a)  The mayor shall be the tobacco control commissioner and is charged with the administration of this division and such other provisions of this Code relating to tobacco as may be enacted. He may appoint persons to assist him in the exercise of powers and the performance of the duties provided in this division for the tobacco commissioner. 
(b)  The tobacco control commissioner, with the approval of a majority of the city council, may adopt rules and regulations for hearings to determine whether any license should be suspended, terminated or revoked. 
(Code 1990, § 8-248; Ord. No. 2000-1942, § 2, 7-5-2000) 
Sec. 16-324. - Suspension; revocation of license; fines, costs. 
(a)  The tobacco control commissioner may suspend or revoke any license issued under the provision of this division, if he determines that the licensee has violated any of the provisions of this division. The suspension of any license for failure to conform with the building or fire codes of the city shall continue so long as a violation of the building or fire code exists. 
(b)  In lieu of suspension or revocation of a license, the tobacco control commissioner may instead levy a fine on the licensee. The fine imposed shall not be less than $50.00 nor more than $500.00 for each violation. Each day that a violation continues shall constitute a separate violation. 
(c)  No such license shall be suspended or revoked and no licensee shall be fined except after a public hearing by the tobacco control commissioner affording an opportunity to the licensee to appear and defend against the charges. Written notice of the hearing location, date and time and a copy of the violation charge shall be given not less than seven days prior thereto. The hearing may be continued from time to time for reasonable cause. 
(d)  The tobacco control commissioner shall, within seven days after such hearing, if he determines after such hearing that the license should be revoked or suspended, or that the licensee should be fined, state the reason for such determination in a written order and either the amount of the fine, the period of suspension, or that the license has been revoked and serve a copy of such order upon the licensee. 
(e)  Any licensee determined by the tobacco control commissioner to have violated any of the provisions of this division shall pay to the city the costs of the hearing on such violation. The tobacco control commissioner shall determine the costs incurred by the city for such hearing, including, but not limited to, court reporter's fees, the costs of transcripts or records, attorneys' fees, the costs of preparing and mailing notices and orders and all other miscellaneous expenses incurred by the city or such lesser sum as the tobacco control commissioner may allow, and such costs assessed shall be in addition to the fine imposed. 
(f)  The licensee shall pay such costs and any fine to the city within 30 days of notification of the costs by the tobacco control commissioner. Failure to pay such costs within 30 days of notification is a violation this division and may be cause for license suspension or revocation, or the levy of an additional fine. 
(g)  When any license shall have been revoked for any cause, no license shall be granted to such licensee for the period of six months thereafter for the conduct of the business of selling any of the products or items listed in section 16-320 in the premises described in such revoked license. 
(Code 1990, § 8-249; Ord. No. 2000-1942, § 2, 7-5-2000) 
Sec. 16-325. - Penalty. 
    The penalty for a violation of section 16-320 shall be a fine of not less than $50.00 nor more than $750.00. Each day that the conduct continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1990, § 8-250; Ord. No. 2000-1942, § 2, 7-5-2000; Ord. No. 2007-2233, § 1, 6-19-2007) 
Secs. 16-326-16-353. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - ALCOHOLIC LIQUOR 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 16-354. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Alcoholic liquor means alcohol, spirits, wine and beer, and every liquid or solid, patented or not, containing alcohol, spirits, wine or beer, and capable of being consumed as a beverage by a human being. The provisions of this article shall not apply to alcohol used in the manufacture of denatured alcohol produced in accordance with Acts of Congress and regulations promulgated thereunder, nor to any liquid or solid containing one-half of one percent or less of alcohol by volume. 
    Banquet facility means a building used for the service of food and beverages to groups of persons attending for planned events or occasions, which building is not open for the general service of food and beverages to the public at large on a regular basis, and from which the service of food and beverages is to persons or groups who have a common, shared or affinitive relationship to the other members of the group for the planned event or occasion. 
    Beer means a beverage produced by the alcoholic fermentation of an infusion or concoction of barley or other grain, malt and hops in water, and includes, among other things, beer, ale, stout, lager beer, porter and the like. 
    Bowling alley means every establishment or building, or part of an establishment or building, as the case may be, wherein the game of bowling played with composition balls and ten wooden pins, is played, and consisting of at least eight full sized bowling lanes. 
    Campground means a parcel of land of at least ten acres upon which individual spaces are rented for short term periods (less than six months) to persons placing upon a rented individual space a motor home, camping trailer or tent for non-permanent use as a living unit, and to which the owner of the campground supplies electrical, water or sewage disposal connections for use by the renter of a space while occupying the space. 
    Club means a corporation organized under the laws of this state, not for pecuniary profit, solely for the promotion of some common object other than the sale or consumption of alcoholic liquors, kept, used and maintained by its members through the payment of annual dues, and owning, hiring or leasing a building or space in a building, or such extent and character as may be suitable and adequate for the reasonable and comfortable use and accommodation of its members and their guests and provided with suitable and adequate kitchen and dining room space and equipment and maintaining a sufficient number of servants and employees for cooking, preparing and serving food and meals for its members and their guests; provided that such club files with the local liquor control commissioner at the time of its application for a license under this Act and two copies of a list of names and residences of its members, and similarly files within ten days of the election of any additional member his name and address; and provided further, that its affairs and management are conducted by a board of directors, executive committee, or similar body chosen by the members at their annual meeting and that no member or any officer, agent or employee of the club is paid, or directly or indirectly receives, in the form of salary or other compensation any profits from the distribution or sale of alcoholic liquor to the club or the members of the club or its guests introduced by members beyond the amount of such salary as may be fixed and voted at any annual meeting by the members or by its board of directors or other governing body out of the general revenue of the club. 
    Convenience store means a retail outlet or store from which the sale of groceries, food, beverage and other sundry items is conducted, and which generally occupies a parcel of land of less than 20,000 square feet, with building or sales area comprising less than 5,000 square feet, and which may also include the sale of motor vehicle fuels and other petroleum products. 
    Drug store means a retail establishment which, together with other items, is duly authorized to sell at retail prescription drugs and which employs a registered pharmacist full time on the premises for the dispensing of prescription drugs. 
    Grocery store means a retail outlet or store: 
(1)  Whose principal business is the sale of groceries and food items for human consumption in packages for consumption off the premises; and 
(2)  Which maintains total grocery retail display and sales floor area of at least 10,000 square feet. 
    Hotel means every building or other structure kept, used, maintained, advertised and held out to the public to be a place where food is actually served and consumed and sleeping accommodations are offered for adequate pay to travelers and guests, whether transient, permanent or residential, in which (25 or more rooms are used for the sleeping accommodations of such guests and having one or more public dining rooms where meals are served to such guest, such sleeping accommodations and dining rooms being conducted in the same building or buildings in connection therewith and such building or buildings, structure or structures being provided with adequate and sanitary kitchen and dining room equipment and capacity. 
    Keg means a container designed and capable of holding beer or other fermented alcoholic liquor in a quantity of five or more gallons from which the beverage is dispensed by and through a separate device or apparatus, typically referred to as a "tap" or "tapper," attached to or inserted into the container. 
    Licensee means any person, firm, corporation, partnership or club holding a license under the provisions of this article. 
    Original package means any bottle, flask, jug, can, barrel, keg, hogshead or other receptacle or container whatsoever, used, corked, or capped, sealed and labeled by the manufacturer of alcoholic liquor, to contain and convey any alcoholic liquor. 
    Package store means a retail establishment the principal business of which is the sale of alcoholic beverages in the original packages for consumption off the premises, and for which sales of other products is ancillary to the sale of alcoholic beverages. 
    Restaurant means any public place kept, used, maintained, advertised and held out to the public as a place where meals are served, and where meals are actually and regularly served, without sleeping accommodations, such space being provided with adequate and sanitary kitchen and dining room equipment and capacity and having employed therein a sufficient number and kind of employees to prepare, cook and serve suitable food for its guests. 
    Wine means an alcoholic beverage obtained by the fermentation of the natural contents of fruits or vegetables, containing sugar, including such beverages when fortified by the addition of alcohol or spirits. 
(Code 1977, § 5.06.010; Code 1990, § 8-256; Ord. No. 86-1435, § 5.06.010, 1-6-1986; Ord. No. 91-1577, 3-4-1991; Ord. No. 98-1855, § 1, 11-20-1998; Ord. No. 2005-2126A, § 1, 3-15-2005; Ord. No. 2010-2438, § 1, 1-4-2011; Ord. No. 2013-2122, § 1, 9-17-2013; Ord. No. 2017-2323, § 1, 6-20-2017) 
Sec. 16-355. - Hours generally. 
(a)  No alcoholic liquor shall be sold, delivered, transferred, consumed, distributed or given away upon or about any licensed premises by anyone during the hours of 1:00 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. on any day. 
(b)  No person except a licensee, employee or agent of a licensee shall be or remain upon or within any licensed premises for more than 15 minutes past the required ending time for sales, and no person, including a licensee or an employee or agent of a licensee shall be or remain upon or within any licensed premises during the period more than 45 minutes past the time for ending of sales of alcoholic liquor; provided, however, that the restrictions upon persons being within or upon a licensed premises by this subsection shall not apply to a hotel, restaurant, bowling alley, grocery store, drug store or convenience store so long as the areas within and from which alcoholic liquor is sold and dispensed is closed in a manner to prohibit persons from entering into or upon said area except during times in compliance with this subsection. 
(c)  Nothing in this section shall prohibit licensees, their agents, employees or independent contractors hired by the licensee to render services to the licensee from being upon or within the licensed premises for the purpose of cleaning, redecorating or repairing the licensed premises during hours when otherwise prohibited, but provided that no sale, delivery, transfer, distribution, giving away or consumption of any alcoholic beverage shall occur upon the licensed premises during prohibited hours. 
(Code 1990, § 8-257; Ord. No. 86-1435, § 5.06.130, 1-6-1986; Ord. No. 91-1578, 3-4-1991; Ord. No. 2005-2126A, § 2, 3-15-2005; Ord. No. 2013-2135, § 1, 11-19-2013) 
Sec. 16-356. - Hours on New Year's Eve. 
    On the evening of December 31 of one year to January 1 of the following year (which period is commonly known as New Year's Eve) the hours during which alcoholic beverages may be sold, consumed, delivered, transferred, distributed or given away shall be from 6:00 a.m. on December 31 in one year until 1:30 a.m. on January 1 of the following year. 
(Code 1977, § 5.06.140; Code 1990, § 8-258; Ord. No. 2005-2126A, § 3, 3-15-2005; Ord. No. 2006-2204, § 1, 10-17-2006; Ord. No. 2013-2135, § 2, 11-19-2013) 
Sec. 16-357. - Sale, delivery or consumption; original package required. 
    No alcoholic liquors shall be sold, delivered, consumed or possessed except in the original package and with the seal unbroken in or on any property owned by or under the control of the city, including all streets and alleys, except for the specific premises licensed for a special event under the provisions of section 16-390. A violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class C violation as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1977, § 5.06.150; Code 1990, § 8-259; Ord. No. 2011-2458, § 17, 4-5-2011) 
Sec. 16-358. - Sanitary conditions. 
    All premises used for the sale of alcoholic liquor, or for the storage of such liquor for sale, shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition, and shall be kept in full compliance with the ordinances regulating the condition of premises used for the storage or sale of food for human consumption. 
(Code 1977, § 5.06.190; Code 1990, § 8-261) 
Sec. 16-359. - Purchase, possession or attendance at licensed premises by minors. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to sell, give or deliver alcoholic liquor to any person under the age of 21 years. 
(b)  Any person to whom the sale, gift or delivery of alcoholic liquor is prohibited because of age shall not purchase or accept a gift of alcoholic liquor nor have alcoholic 21 years to misrepresent his or her age for the purpose of purchasing or obtaining, or attempting to purchase or obtain, alcoholic liquor. 
(c)  In every place where alcoholic liquor is sold, there shall be displayed at all times in a prominent place a printed card which shall be supplied by the city clerk and which reads substantially as follows: 
"NOTICE TO ANY PERSON UNDER THE AGE OF 25: 
YOU ARE EXPECTED TO SHOW PROPER IDENTIFICATION AS PROOF OF AGE" 
"WARNING TO PERSONS UNDER THE AGE OF 21! 
YOU ARE SUBJECT TO A FINE UP TO $500.00 UNDER THE ORDINANCES OF THE CITY OF ROCK FALLS IF YOU PURCHASE ALCOHOLIC LIQUOR, OR MISREPRESENT YOUR AGE FOR THE PURPOSE OF PURCHASING OR OBTAINING ALCOHOLIC LIQUOR." 
(d)  It is unlawful for any person under the age of 21 years to attend any bar or to draw, pour or mix any alcoholic liquor in any licensed premises, but provided that a person 18 years of age or older, in connection with the employment of such person, may serve alcoholic beverages to booths or tables in a restaurant licensed under this article. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any licensee, or his agent or employee, to suffer or permit any person under the age of 21 years to be in or remain in any room or compartment adjoining or adjacent or situated in the room or place where such licensed premises is located; provided that this section shall not apply to any minor who is accompanied by his parent or guardian or to any licensed premises which derives its principal business from the sale of services or commodities other than alcoholic liquor or to any person 18 years of age or older employed in accordance with subsection (d) of this section. 
(f)  A violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class B violation as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1990, § 8-263; Ord. No. 88-1506, § 5.06.210, 4-18-1988; Ord. No. 91-1580, 3-4-1991; Ord. No. 99-1906, § 1, 11-16-1999; Ord. No. 2011-2458, § 18, 4-5-2011) 
Sec. 16-360. - Sale to certain persons prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any holder of an alcoholic liquor dealer's license to sell, deliver or give any alcoholic liquor to any intoxicated person or to any person known to him to be under legal disability or in need of mental treatment. 
(Code 1977, § 5.06.230; Code 1990, § 8-265) 
Sec. 16-361. - Gambling on premises. 
    There shall be no card games or gambling allowed on any premises licensed to sell alcoholic liquor, except for video gaming terminals licensed under the Illinois Video Gaming Act, and for which the licensed premises holds a permit issued by the city under the provisions of division 9 of article XIII of this chapter. No person under the age of 21 years shall be permitted to use or play a video gaming terminal, and any licensee who knowingly permits a person under the age of 21 years to use or play a video gaming terminal shall be subject to fine, suspension of license or revocation of license as provided in this Code. 
(Code 1977, § 5.06.240; Code 1990, § 8-266; Ord. No. 2012-2057, § 1, 6-19-2012) 
Sec. 16-362. - Removal, storage of alcoholic liquor after hours. 
    During the hours when alcoholic liquor is prohibited from being sold, the premises shall be closed to the public or all alcoholic liquor shall be removed from sight and placed in some room or locker which is securely locked, and the lock shall not be opened until the hour when alcoholic liquor may again be sold. 
(Code 1977, § 5.06.250; Code 1990, § 8-267) 
Sec. 16-363. - Tumultuous conduct. 
    No licensee or his agent or employee shall suffer or permit any person to disturb, tend to disturb or aid in disturbing the peace of others by violent, tumultuous, offensive or obstreperous conduct upon the licensed premises, and such conduct is hereby prohibited upon any premises for which a license to sell alcoholic liquor at retail has been issued pursuant to this article. Any licensee, or his agent or employee in charge of the licensed premises, shall, upon request of the police department, aid the police department in the quelling or elimination of any conduct or activity prohibited by this section and shall report such conduct to the police department as soon as possible following the initiation of such conduct, and shall cooperate fully with the police department in the investigation of such conduct and in the prosecution of the persons engaging in such conduct. 
(Code 1990, § 8-269; Ord. No. 91-1582, § 1, 3-4-1991) 
Secs. 16-364-16-384. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 16-385. - Required. 
    It is unlawful to sell or offer for sale in the city any alcoholic liquor without having a license, or in violation of the terms of such license. 
(Code 1977, § 5.06.020; Code 1990, § 8-285) 
Sec. 16-386. - Application. 
(a)  An application for a license for retail sale of alcoholic liquor shall be made to the local liquor control commission in writing and, if the applicant is an individual, shall be signed by the applicant, or if the applicant is a club, corporation for profit or partnership, shall be signed by a duly authorized agent or partner thereof. Applications for such license shall provide the following information: 
(1)  Where the applicant is an individual, the name, age, date of birth and residence address of the applicant. 
(2)  Where the applicant is a partnership, whether the partnership is a general or limited partnership, and the name, age, date of birth and residence address of each partner and whether such partner is a general or limited partner. 
(3)  Where the applicant is a corporation for profit, the following: 
a.  The date of incorporation; 
b.  State of incorporation; 
c.  Objects for which organized; 
d.  Name, date of birth and residence address of each officer and director; 
e.  Name, date of birth and residence address of each stockholder owning more than ten of the voting stock of the corporation; 
f.  The name, date of birth and residence address of the resident manager of the establishment and location for which the license is sought. 
(4)  If the applicant is a club or corporation not for profit, the date of organization or incorporation, object for which organized, name, date of birth and residence address of each officer and director of the club, and the name, date of birth and residence address of the resident manager of the location for which the license is sought as designated by corporation or club. 
(5)  If the applicant is a corporation, the application shall have attached to it a copy of the most recent annual report filed by the corporation with the Secretary of State of Illinois, or if the corporation shall have been organized for a period of time less than one year, a copy of the articles of incorporation. 
(6)  If the applicant is an individual, a statement as to the citizenship of the applicant, place of birth of the applicant, and if naturalized citizen, the time and place of naturalization. 
(7)  The amount of goods, wares and merchandise on hand at the time application is made. 
(8)  The location and description of the premises or place of business which is to be operated under such license. 
(9)  A statement as to whether the applicant has made a similar application for a similar license on premises other than described in this application, and the disposition of such application 
(10)  A statement that the applicant has never been convicted of a felony and is not disqualified to receive a license by reason of any matter or thing contained in this article under the laws of the state or ordinances of the city. 
(11)  Whether a previous license by any state or subdivision thereof or by the federal government has been revoked, and the reasons therefor. 
(12)  A statement that the applicant will not violate any of the laws of the state or of the United States, or any ordinance of the city in the conduct of business. 
(13)  Where the applicant is a corporation for profit, a corporation not for profit or a club, the application shall be signed by the chief executive officer and by the person designated as resident manager, and signature of the resident manager shall constitute an acknowledgement by the resident manager of the requirements for operation as a licensee under this article and of the laws of the state. 
(14)  Where the applicant is a partnership, the application shall be signed by all general partners. 
(b)  Application for a new license shall be submitted to the office of the city clerk for filing at least 30 days prior to the proposed effective date of the license. Applications for renewal licenses shall be submitted to the office of the city clerk for filing at least 30 days prior to the effective date of the renewed license.
