In addition to the other requirements for the obtaining of a business license as provided by this Code, the applicant for a license for sale of motorized or non-motorized vehicles must exhibit proof with the application for license that the applicant is in compliance with all regulations and requirements of the secretary of state of this state regulating the sale of motorized or non-motorized vehicles. 
(Code 1977, § 5.65.010; Code 1990, § 8-626; Ord. No. 2004-2106A, § 1, 9-21-2004) 
Sec. 16-828. - Same-Fee. 
    The annual fee for operation of a motorized and nonmotorized vehicle sales business shall be $35.00. 
(Code 1977, § 5.65.020; Code 1990, § 8-627) 
Sec. 16-829. - Space requirements on lot. 
    When vehicles for sale are parked in more than one row outside of a building, the operator of the business shall maintain a minimum of 15 feet between each row of vehicles to provide for the movement of fire or other emergency vehicles. In addition, the operator shall cause motor vehicles and recreational vehicles to be parked a in row so as to maintain a minimum distance of two feet between each two vehicles parked. 
(Code 1977, § 5.65.030; Code 1990, § 8-628) 
Secs. 16-830-16-851. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - SERVICE AND FILLING STATIONS 

Sec. 16-852. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Service station means any place of business where gasoline or any highly volatile fuels for motor vehicles or internal combustion engines are sold or offered for sale. 
(Code 1977, § 5.82.010; Code 1990, § 8-646) 
Sec. 16-853. - License required; fee. 
(a)  It is unlawful to conduct or operate a service station in the city without first having obtained a license therefor. The annual fee for such licenses shall be $5.00 for each pump operated at the location of the service station, except that if the service station is operated as a self-service station, the annual fee shall be $50.00 per station. 
(b)  No such license shall be issued unless the location and equipment used fully complies with the ordinances of the city. 
(c)  A violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class B violation as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1977, § 5.82.020; Code 1990, § 8-647; Ord. No. 2011-2458, § 26, 4-5-2011) 
Sec. 16-854. - Noncommercial filling stations. 
    Any person maintaining or operating any storage tank for gasoline for the use of the automobile for the owner, lessee, employees or agents of such person shall comply with all of the provisions of this division other than the requirement for the payment of a fee. 
(Code 1977, § 5.82.030; Code 1990, § 8-648) 
Sec. 16-855. - Bulk sales. 
    No motor fuels shall be dispensed at any service station except into the fuel tanks of motor vehicles, when such tanks are connected with the carburetion system of such vehicle; provided, however, that individual sales up to five gallons may be made in receptacles when painted red and labeled in full conformity with the state red can gasoline law. Such individual sales shall be limited to five gallons to any one person. 
(Code 1977, § 5.82.040; Code 1990, § 8-649) 
State Law reference- Gasoline receptacles, 430 ILCS 20/0.01 et seq. 
Sec. 16-856. - Fire and building codes. 
    Every person establishing, conducting or operating a service station shall comply with all applicable provisions of the fire and building codes of the city. 
(Code 1990, § 8-650) 
Sec. 16-857. - New construction; approval of plans. 
(a)  Drawings or blueprints made to scale shall be submitted in triplicate to the mayor and council and shall be approved by them before any new construction, addition or remodeling of a service station is undertaken. Drawings shall carry the name of the person proposing the installation and the location, and in addition shall show the following: 
(1)  The plot to be utilized and its immediate surroundings on all sides, all property lines to be designated and adjacent streets and highways to be named; 
(2)  The complete installation as proposed, including tanks and their capacity, pumps, buildings, drives and all equipment; 
(3)  Clearance from tanks to property lines; 
(4)  The type of construction of the service station building or buildings, with a clear showing that there will be no basement, cellar or excavation under any portion; 
(5)  Location of basements, cellars or pits of other buildings on the property or on adjacent property, and the location of tanks with reference thereto, as is provided in this division. If a building has no basement, cellar or pit make note to that effect; 
(6)  Location of sewers, manholes, catchbasins, cesspools, septic tanks, wells or cisterns, whether on the property or adjacent property or in adjoining streets, highways or alleys, and the location of tanks with reference thereto. If there is no sewer, manhole or catchbasin in a street or alley, or no sewer, manhole, cesspool, septic tank, well or cistern on property, make notation to that effect in the proper place; 
(7)  Location of vent pipe outlets and location of fill pipes; 
(8)  Ventilation of greasing pit, if greasing pit is located within a building or enclosure. 
(b)  Drawings shall be accompanied by an application for approval made out in triplicate on blanks furnished by the city clerk. 
(Code 1977, § 5.82.230; Code 1990, § 8-651) 
Secs. 16-858-16-877. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - PUBLIC GARAGES 

Sec. 16-878. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Public garage means any building or structure within the city where: 
(1)  Two or more motor vehicles are stored, housed or parked or where rent or compensation is paid to the owner, manager or lessee, for the housing, storing, sheltering, keeping or maintaining of such motor vehicle; 
(2)  The business of doing repair work on or for motor vehicles or any of the compound parts thereof, the replacing of or the adding of parts thereto or the polishing, washing, greasing, painting or refinishing of such vehicles is carried on; or 
(3)  Any building or structure is used as a motor transport terminal in which trucks, tractors and trailers are stored, housed, parked or sheltered, rented, hired, repaired, greased, painted and where such trucks, tractors and trailers are loaded or unloaded with freight and used for the transportation of goods, wares and merchandise for compensation. 
(Code 1977, § 5.76.010; Code 1990, § 8-671) 
Sec. 16-879. - License required; fee. 
    No person shall operate or maintain a public garage in the city without having first obtained a license therefor as required by this division. The annual fee for operation of a public garage shall be $50.00. 
(Code 1977, § 5.76.020; Code 1990, § 8-672; Ord. No. 2000-1939, § 14, 6-6-2000; Ord. No. 2010-2392, § 5, 3-16-2010; Ord. No. 2015-2242, § 1, 11-17-2015) 
Sec. 16-880. - Storage of junked, dismantled, nonoperating vehicles. 
    It is unlawful for any person owning, maintaining or operating a public garage to store, house, shelter or park any motor vehicle, truck, trailer or tractor that may be junked, partly dismantled or out of repair and not ready for use on any lot or parcel of land, except in a fully constructed building or structure. A violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class B violation as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1977, § 5.76.030; Code 1990, § 8-673; Ord. No. 2011-2458, § 27, 4-5-2011) 
Sec. 16-881. - Premises generally. 
    It is unlawful to maintain or operate any public garage in a frame building, or in any building or structure used for church, school or theater purposes, or in any building which does not conform to the requirements of the building code. The premises of every garage must be kept clean and free from inflammable waste materials. A violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class B violation as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1977, § 5.76.050; Code 1990, § 8-674; Ord. No. 2011-2458, § 28, 4-5-2011) 
Sec. 16-882. - Changing license tags. 
    It is unlawful for any person to change the license tags on any vehicle in a public garage, except in accordance with the register of motor vehicles kept by the secretary of state. A violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class B violation as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1977, § 5.76.060; Code 1990, § 8-675; Ord. No. 2011-2458, § 29, 4-5-2011) 
Sec. 16-883. - Inspections. 
    It shall be the duty of the chief of police and the fire marshal to make or cause to be made such inspections of public garages in the city as may be necessary to ensure compliance with the provisions of this division. Any police officer shall be permitted at any reasonable hour to view every car stored or kept in any public garage and it is unlawful to hinder any such inspection or to conceal any car or motor vehicle from such inspection. 
(Code 1977, § 5.76.070; Code 1990, § 8-676) 
Secs. 16-884-16-915. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - TAXICABS 

Sec. 16-916. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Taxicab means and includes any vehicle used to carry passengers for hire but not operating on a fixed route. 
(Code 1977, § 5.88.010; Code 1990, § 8-691) 
Sec. 16-917. - License-Required; application; expiration date. 
    It is unlawful to engage in the business of operating a taxicab in the city without first having secured a license therefor. Applications for such licenses shall be made in writing to the city clerk, and shall state thereon the name of the applicant, the intended place of business and the number of taxicabs to be operated. If the applicant is a corporation, the names and addresses of the president and secretary thereof shall be given. Such licenses shall expire April 30. A violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class B violation as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1977, § 5.88.020; Code 1990, § 8-692; Ord. No. 2011-2458, § 30, 4-5-2011) 
Sec. 16-918. - Same-Character of applicant. 
    No taxicab license shall be issued to or held by any person who is not a person of good character or who has been convicted of a felony; nor shall such license be issued to or held by any corporation if any officer thereof would be ineligible for a license under the foregoing conditions. 
(Code 1977, § 5.88.030; Code 1990, § 8-693) 
Sec. 16-919. - Same-Fee. 
    The license fee for each taxicab operated in the city shall be $25.00 for each vehicle. 
(Code 1977, § 5.88.040; Code 1990, § 8-694; Ord. No. 2000-1939, § 17, 6-6-2000; Ord. No. 2003-2060, § 13, 9-2-2003) 
Sec. 16-920. - Notification of identification numbers. 
    The licensee under this division shall notify the city clerk of the motor number and state license number of each taxicab operated. 
(Code 1977, § 5.88.060; Code 1990, § 8-696) 
Sec. 16-921. - State license and equipment requirements. 
    No taxicab shall be operated unless it bears a state license duly issued. No taxicab shall be operated unless it is equipped with proper brakes, lights, tires, horn, muffler, rear vision mirror and windshield wipers in good condition. It shall be the duty of the chief of police and or his designee to inspect every taxicab so often as may be necessary to see to the enforcement of the provisions of this section. 
(Code 1977, § 5.88.070; Code 1990, § 8-697; Ord. No. 2007-2238, § 1, 8-7-2007) 
Sec. 16-922. - Identification displayed on taxicabs. 
    Each taxicab, while operated, shall have on each side in letters readable from a distance of 20 feet, the name of the licensee operating it. If more than one taxicab is operated by a licensee, each taxicab shall be designated a different number, and such number shall also so appear on each side of such a taxicab. 
(Code 1977, § 5.88.080; Code 1990, § 8-698) 
Sec. 16-923. - Conduct of drivers. 
    It is unlawful for any driver of a taxicab while on duty to drink any intoxicating liquor, or to use any profane or obscene language, to shout or call to prospective passengers, or to disturb the peace in any way. A violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class B violation as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1977, § 5.88.100; Code 1990, § 8-699; Ord. No. 2011-2458, § 31, 4-5-2011) 
Sec. 16-924. - Driver's license-Required. 
    No person shall drive a taxicab unless he shall have secured a license therefor. 
(Code 1977, § 5.88.110; Code 1990, § 8-700) 
Sec. 16-925. - Same-Fee. 
    The annual fee for a taxicab driver's license shall be $10.00 for each person. 
(Code 1977, § 5.88.120; Code 1990, § 8-701; Ord. No. 2000-1939, § 18, 6-6-2000) 
Sec. 16-926. - Same-Qualifications. 
    No taxicab driver's license shall be issued to any person who is not competent to operate a motor vehicle or who is not familiar with the traffic laws and ordinances. The chief of police shall examine each applicant for a taxicab driver's license to determine the competency of the applicant. No such license shall be issued except on certificate of the chief that the applicant has demonstrated his ability to operate a motor vehicle as required herein. 
(Code 1977, § 5.88.130; Code 1990, § 8-702) 
Sec. 16-927. - Same-Revocation. 
    The mayor may revoke any taxicab driver's license for repeated violations of traffic laws or ordinances, or of any ordinance provision regulating the conduct of such drivers. 
(Code 1977, § 5.88.140; Code 1990, § 8-703) 
Sec. 16-928. - Determination of need. 
    No license to operate a taxicab in the city shall be issued unless and until the council determines that the public need for the taxicab service requires the additional service to be rendered by the applicant. In deciding this question, the council shall consider the need of the public for taxicab services, the number of taxicabs in operation, and the anticipated future needs and demands. 
(Code 1977, § 5.88.150; Code 1990, § 8-704) 
Sec. 16-929. - Bond, public liability policy. 
    No taxicab shall be operated unless it is covered by a bond or public liability policy as required by statute. 
(Code 1977, § 5.88.160; Code 1990, § 8-705) 
State Law reference- Safety and financial responsibility law, 625 ILCS 5/7-100 et seq. 
Sec. 16-930. - Passenger conduct; use of direct route. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the driver of any taxicab to accept as a passenger any person who seeks to so use the taxicab, provided such person is not intoxicated and conducts himself in an orderly manner. No person shall be admitted to a taxicab occupied by a passenger without the consent of the passenger. 
(b)  The driver shall take his passenger to his destination by the most direct available route from the place where the passenger enters the taxicab. 
(Code 1977, § 5.88.170; Code 1990, § 8-706) 
Secs. 16-931-16-948. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - HOUSE MOVERS 

Sec. 16-949. - License-Required; application. 
    It is unlawful to engage in the business of house moving, raising or shoring without first having a license therefor. Application for such license shall be made in writing to the building department. A violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class B violation as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1977, § 5.54.010; Code 1990, § 8-746; Ord. No. 2008-2267, § 4, 4-1-2008; Ord. No. 2011-2458, § 32, 4-5-2011) 
Sec. 16-950. - Same-Fee. 
    The fee for a house mover's license shall be $100.00 for each license requested under the provisions of this division. 
(Code 1977, § 5.54.020; Code 1990, § 8-747) 
Sec. 16-951. - Operation regulations. 
    Persons licensed under this division must comply with all of the ordinance provisions relating to the work being done, and must pay the permit fee required for moving buildings, and must keep lights and warnings maintained as is required by ordinance. 
(Code 1977, § 5.54.030; Code 1990, § 8-748) 
Secs. 16-952-16-975. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - PARKING LOTS 

Sec. 16-976. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Parking lot means and includes any place maintained for the outdoor parking of cars, except on a street, alley or other public place where such parking is permitted upon the payment of compensation. Such parking lots shall be subject to regulation of this division only if such lot provides a space for 15 or more vehicles excluding areas where stalls are leased by the week, month or year, and nothing within this division shall be deemed to provide for regulation of any areas provided as off-street parking which are required to be maintained in conformance with the city zoning ordinance. 
(Code 1977, § 5.70.010; Code 1990, § 8-766) 
Sec. 16-977. - Fee. 
    The annual fee for engaging in a parking lot business shall be $25.00. 
(Code 1977, § 5.70.020; Code 1990, § 8-767) 
Sec. 16-978. - Regulations generally. 
    No parking lot shall be established or operated in any place where such establishment or operation would be in violation of the zoning or any other ordinance. Not more than one car for each 200 square feet of area shall be accepted for parking in any such place. Each parking lot shall be so marked as to show the parking space allotted for each car, and shall have sufficient entrances and exits to permit the entrance and egress of cars without obstruction to traffic. 
(Code 1977, § 5.70.030; Code 1990, § 8-768) 
Sec. 16-979. - Hours and rates posted. 
    At the entrance of each parking lot there shall be posted in words and figures large enough to be read by prospective patrons a statement of the rates to be charged and the closing hours. 
(Code 1977, § 5.70.040; Code 1990, § 8-769) 
Sec. 16-980. - Cleanliness of premises; receptacles. 
    If a parking lot is maintained in connection with a licensed establishment serving food for consumption on the premises, and food or drinks are served to the occupants of cars, sufficient adequate containers must be maintained for all trash and refuse, and the refuse must be cleaned up and the premises must be kept thoroughly clean by the proprietor. 
(Code 1977, § 5.70.050; Code 1990, § 8-770) 
Sec. 16-981. - Other business conducted on parking lot premises. 
    If any business other than that of operating a parking lot is conducted on the same premises with a parking lot, such business shall be constructed in full compliance with all ordinances pertinent thereto, and any license required for the operation of such business must be procured and the fee required therefor must be paid. 
(Code 1977, § 5.70.060; Code 1990, § 8-771) 
Sec. 16-982. - Driveways. 
    No driveway to a parking lot shall be constructed except in full compliance with the ordinances relative to the issuance of permits for driveways. It shall be the duty of the operator of each parking lot to maintain the sidewalk and parkway over which such driveway passes in good condition. 
(Code 1977, § 5.70.070; Code 1990, § 8-772) 
Sec. 16-983. - Surface requirements. 
    It is unlawful to operate a parking lot unless the surface thereof is covered with concrete, asphalt, macadam or similar paving. Such parking lot shall at all times be kept clean and free from dust and refuse. 
(Code 1977, § 5.70.080; Code 1990, § 8-773) 
Sec. 16-984. - Buildings, structures on premises. 
    Any buildings constructed on a parking lot shall be constructed in full compliance with the ordinances pertaining thereto, and shall have exterior walls of nonflammable material. Any structure used or to be used for office purposes only may have less than the minimum area requirements prescribed for residences or commercial buildings. 
(Code 1977, § 5.70.100; Code 1990, § 8-775) 
Sec. 16-985. - Condition of vehicles; unlawful use of parking lot. 
    It is unlawful to park or store, in any parking lot, any vehicle which is not in a condition ready for use, or to permit the parking of any abandoned, junked or partially disabled vehicle in any such lot. It is unlawful to use any parking lot for storage or parking of any vehicle for the purpose of displaying the same for sale, or to use any parking lot or portion thereof as an automobile repair shop. 
(Code 1977, § 5.70.110; Code 1990, § 8-776) 
Sec. 16-986. - Use of intoxicating liquor on premises. 
    It is unlawful to serve intoxicating liquor for consumption in any vehicle parked in a parking lot or to drink any intoxicating liquor while therein. 
(Code 1977, § 5.70.120; Code 1990, § 8-777) 
Secs. 16-987-16-1015. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - PEDDLERS[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal powers as to hawkers, peddlers, etc., 65 ILCS 5/11-42-5; transient merchants, 225 ILCS 465/1 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 16-1016. - Exemptions. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to officers or employees of the city, county, state and federal governments or subdivisions thereof, when on official business or to persons engaged in soliciting for charitable or religious organizations. 
(Code 1977, § 5.50.060; Code 1990, § 8-801) 
Sec. 16-1017. - Inspection of books and records. 
    Every licensee under this article shall make available to authorized personnel of the city at reasonable times the books and records of such licensee in order to allow the personnel of the city to determine the amount of sales of merchandise being made by such licensee within the city limits of the city, and in order to determine that proper reporting of retailer's occupational taxes to the credit of the city is being made by such licensee. The council finds that because of the transitory nature of licensees under this article, such information will not be available to the personnel of the city on any permanent basis, and that no other adequate means, other than inspection of books and records, is open to the city to determine that sales are being properly recorded, and that after the transient or itinerant merchant has left the limits of the city, any methods of enforcement of tax ordinances will be limited. 
(Code 1977, § 5.50.070; Code 1990, § 8-802) 
Sec. 16-1018. - Hours and days of operation. 
    No hawker, itinerant merchant or peddler shall operate under the registration or license issued under this article on Sundays or holidays. The hawker, itinerant merchant or peddler shall not call at residences before 9:00 a.m. or after 9:00 p.m. except at the prior invitation or request of the occupant. 
(Code 1977, § 5.50.050; Code 1990, § 8-80) 
Secs. 16-1019-16-1049. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 16-1050. - Required. 
    It is unlawful for any person to engage in the business of hawker, peddler or itinerant merchant of merchandise, article or thing without first having obtained a license therefor from the city clerk. 
(Code 1977, § 5.50.010; Code 1990, § 8-796) 
Sec. 16-1051. - Application. 
    Applications for licenses under this article shall be made to the city clerk, and shall state thereon the number of vehicles, if any, intended to be used, the kind of article or merchandise to be peddled, and the permanent address of the peddler. 
(Code 1977, § 5.50.020; Code 1990, § 8-797) 
Sec. 16-1052. - Fee. 
    The fee for the issuance of any license under this division shall be $250.00 per year. 
(Code 1977, § 5.50.030; Code 1990, § 8-798; Ord. No. 2000-1939, § 20, 6-6-2000) 
Secs. 16-1053-16-1072. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - SOLICITORS AND CANVASSERS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 16-1073. - Exemptions. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to officers or employees of the city, county, state or federal governments, or any subdivisions thereof, when on official business, or to persons engaged in soliciting for charitable or religious organizations. 
(Code 1977, § 5.86.080; Code 1990, § 8-821) 
Sec. 16-1074. - Provisions not applicable to persons holding peddler's license. 
    The provisions of this article shall not apply to persons who have obtained a hawker's, itinerant merchant's or peddler's license as provided by article VIII of this chapter. 
(Code 1977, § 5.86.050; Code 1990, § 8-822) 
Sec. 16-1075. - Hours and days of operation. 
    No person shall operate under the registration certificate or license issued under this division on Sundays or holidays. Such person shall not call at residences before 9:00 a.m. or after 9:00 p.m. except at the prior invitation or request of the occupant. 
(Code 1977, § 5.86.070; Code 1990, § 8-828) 
Secs. 16-1076-16-1103. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - REGISTRATION 

Sec. 16-1104. - Certificate required; form. 
    It is unlawful for any solicitor, salesman or canvasser to call from home to home in the city without first registering and obtaining a registration certificate in the office of the city clerk. Such registration shall be on forms provided by the city and shall give the solicitor's identification, signature, name of his employer, and the nature of the products or services in which he is interested and the name of the manufacturer of such products and his proposed method of operation in the city. 
(Code 1977, § 5.86.010; Code 1990, § 8-823) 
Sec. 16-1105. - Fee. 
    The fee for issuance of the license required by this division, for each person, shall be as follows: 
(1)  Resident, $10.00 for one year; 
(2)  Non-resident, $50.00 for one week. 
(Code 1977, § 5.86.020; Code 1990, § 8-824; Ord. No. 2000-1939, § 16, 6-6-2000) 
Sec. 16-1106. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2015-2241, § 1, adopted November 3, 2015 repealed § 16-1106. Former § 16-1106 pertained to character of applicant and derived from the Code of 1977, § 5.86.030 and the Code of 1990, § 8-825. 
Sec. 16-1107. - Possession, exhibition of certificate. 
    Each solicitor shall at all times while soliciting or canvassing within the city carry upon his person the registration certificate required by this division, and shall exhibit the same upon request of any police officer or to any person upon whom he calls in the course of his business. 
(Code 1977, § 5.86.040; Code 1990, § 8-826) 
Secs. 16-1108-16-1137. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - FOOD AND BEVERAGE PEDDLER; DELIVERY VEHICLES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 16-1138-16-1167. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSES 

Sec. 16-1168. - Required for ce cream, candy, confection or beverage or other goods for human consumption. 
    It is unlawful to sell or offer for sale or to peddle any ice cream, candy, confection or beverage or other goods for human consumption from any vehicle, including motor vehicles and non-motorized vehicles on any public street, alley or parkway in the city without having obtained a license therefor. The annual license fee for a person engaged in a business subject to this section shall be $75.00 per year per licensee, regardless of the number of vehicles operated by such licensee. 
(Code 1977, §§ 5.44.010, 5.44.020; Code 1990, §§ 8-846, 8-847; Ord. No. 2003-2060, § 14, 9-2-2003; Ord. No. 2004-2107A, § 1, 9-21-2004; Ord. No. 2008-2276, § 1, 6-3-2008; Ord. No. 2010-2392, § 3, 3-16-2010) 
Sec. 16-1169. - Same-Exceptions. 
    The provisions of this section of the Municipal Code shall not apply to any vendor selling or offering for sale fruits, vegetables or other fresh produce, or any arts and craft projects from the location of the "farmer's market" sponsored by the chamber of commerce. On the days and during the hours of operations of the "farmer's market" at the location identified by the chamber of commerce, selling of such fresh produce for human consumption, or arts and craft projects, shall require no license for sale at such "farmer's market" as sponsored. 
(Code 1990, §§ 8-848-8-850; Ord. No. 96-1621, 7-30-1992; Ord. No. 2009-2345, § 1, 6-2-2009; Ord. No. 2015-2230, § 1, 8-18-2015) 
Secs. 16-1170-16-1186. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - SIDEWALK CAFES 

Sec. 16-1187. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Central business district means the area bounded by the Rock River on the north, by 5th Avenue on the west, by West 5th Street and East 6th Street on the south and by Avenue A and the northerly extension of the eastern right-of-way line of Avenue A on the east. 
    Sidewalk cafe means an outdoor dining area located on a public sidewalk where patrons may consume food and/or beverage provided by a food service establishment located within the building to which the sidewalk abuts. Such establishments may provide table service in the outdoor dining area or provide take-out items to be consumed in the outdoor dining area. This article shall not apply to outdoor dining on private property. 
(Ord. No. 2014-2158, § 1(8-860), 5-20-2014) 
Sec. 16-1188. - General provisions. 
(a)  License required. Outdoor dining on a public sidewalk shall be allowed only in the central business district, and only in compliance with the conditions of this article and after the issuance of a sidewalk cafe license. 
(b)  Permitted locations. Outdoor dining may be permitted on the public sidewalk immediately adjacent to the building occupied by the licensee, or immediately adjacent to the street curb fronting the building occupied by the licensee at the discretion of the licensee and upon the approval of the building official. An unobstructed continuous pedestrian pathway measuring no less than five feet in width shall be provided between the street curb and the dining area or, in the alternative, between the dining area and the licensee's building. 
(c)  Maintenance of sidewalk area. The licensee shall provide trash receptacles with covers for the deposit of waste paper and trash to prevent the littering of the public sidewalks and streets. Licensees shall not drill holes in the public sidewalk nor permanently affix any railing, fixture, partition or furniture to the public sidewalk, nor to any adjacent city railings or planters. All chairs, railings, partitions, trash receptacles, umbrellas, portable heaters and other equipment (except for tables) will be removed from the public sidewalk when the licensee is not open for business. No signs or other forms of advertising other than permitted by chapter 24 are permitted. 
(d)  Lighting restrictions. Lighting shall be restricted to illuminate the outdoor dining area only and be positioned so that it will not interfere with vision of pedestrians, motorists or other neighboring businesses. Lighting fixtures shall complement the established streetscape design and shall be approved by the building department. 
(Ord. No. 2014-2158, § 1(8-861), 5-20-2014) 
Sec. 16-1189. - Application process. 
(a)  Application. An application for a sidewalk cafe license shall be filed with the building department on a form provided by the building department. The application shall be signed by the owner of the property adjacent to the public sidewalk which is the site of the proposed sidewalk cafe or by his designated agent. The application shall include a site plan, drawn to scale and fully dimensioned, which accurately depicts the location, height, nature and extent of all proposed improvements and objects within the proposed sidewalk cafe area. All fixed features such as tree wells, sign posts, and fire hydrants located within 20 feet of the proposed sidewalk cafe area shall be depicted on the site plan. 
(b)  Review or denial. The building official shall review the application considering public safety issues unique to pedestrian and vehicular needs of the specific location for which the license is requested. The building official shall grant or deny the application within no more than 30 days of the filing of the application. The building official may deny a license or revoke an existing license if he determines that the use of the area proposed or being utilized is or has become detrimental to public health, safety or welfare. Any action by the building official to deny or revoke a license shall state, in writing, the reasons for such decision, and a copy of the decision shall be delivered to the applicant or licensee. The decision of the building official may be appealed to the city council by the applicant or licensee by filing a written appeal notice with the city clerk, such appeal to be filed within ten days of the service of the notice of denial or revocation on the applicant or licensee. the city council shall hear the appeal at the next regularly scheduled meeting occurring not less than five days after the filing of the appeal. At the hearing, the applicant or licensee may present such evidence as he deems appropriate to persuade the council that the decision of the building official is erroneous or without merit. The decision of the council shall be determined in open session at the meeting at which the appeal is heard, unless the applicant or licensee shall agree to an extension of time for announcement of the decision, and the decision of the council, when made, shall be final. 
(c)  Indemnification. The license shall not be issued until such time as the applicant has filed an indemnification agreement with the city agreeing to defend, indemnify, and hold the city and its employees harmless from and against any loss or damage arising from the use of the sidewalk or existence thereon of the improvements authorized by the license. 
(d)  Insurance. The applicant shall obtain and maintain in force a comprehensive general liability broad form property damage and personal liability insurance policy with blanket contractual single limit, per claim and aggregate, of not less than $1,000,000.00 insuring the licensee's operations on the sidewalk against loss or damages arising from claims asserted for damage to property or injury to persons. Such insurance shall name the city and its employees, elected officials and agents, on a special endorsement form, as additional insureds. A certificate of insurance shall be filed with the city and contain provisions that prohibit cancellations, modifications or lapses of the insurance without 30 days prior written notice to the city. 
(Ord. No. 2014-2158, § 1(8-862), 5-20-2014) 
Sec. 16-1190. - Development and design standards; fees; inspections. 
(a)  Horizontal clearance. A clear continuous pedestrian path of not less than five feet in width shall be required for pedestrian circulation outside of the dining area, but provided that the building official may require an area greater than five feet if necessary to protect the public safety. As used herein, the term "pedestrian path" means a continuous obstruction-free sidewalk area paved to city standards between the outside boundary of the dining area and any obstruction including, but not limited to, street trees, landscaping, street lights, benches, public art and curblines. These requirements may be modified at the discretion of the building official in locations where unusual circumstances exist and where public safety will not be jeopardized. 
(b)  Setbacks from corners, streets and alleys. When an outdoor dining area is located at a street corner, a ten-foot setback from the corner of the building shall be maintained along both frontages. When an outdoor area is located adjacent to a driveway or alley, a five-foot setback shall be maintained from the driveway or alley. These requirements may be modified at the discretion of the building official in locations where unusual circumstances exist and where public safety will not be jeopardized. 
(c)  Extension to adjacent properties. Subject to the approval of the building official, an outdoor dining area may extend onto the sidewalk in front of an adjacent business with the written consent of both the adjacent business owner and the adjacent property owner. 
(d)  Barriers. A licensee shall install a barrier between the dining tables and the pedestrian pathway, if the tables are located adjacent to the building, and between the tables and the curb, if the tables are located adjacent to the curb. No barrier shall be required if the applicant proposes to limit the outdoor dining area to one row of tables and chairs abutting the wall of the establishment, and if no alcohol will be served. Barriers shall complement the building facade as well as any street furniture and be somewhat transparent, and shall be able to withstand inclement weather. Barriers shall conform to the installation standards established by the building department and be removable. Barriers shall be capable of being removed through the use of wheels that can be locked into place or be attached to weighted bases that may be moved. The height of any barrier shall not exceed three feet six inches. 
(e)  Furniture; awnings and umbrellas. All furnishings and furniture utilized and placed within the outdoor seating area shall be of such material as to be capable of remaining upright in winds of up to 50 miles per hour, or, if not of such weight or material, shall be secured within the seating area by means of chains or cables so as to not be blown from the area if winds reach that speed. The use of awnings over outdoor dining areas and removable table umbrellas may be permitted provided they do not interfere with street trees. No portion of an awning shall be less than eight feet above the sidewalk, and no portion of an umbrella shall be less than seven feet above the sidewalk. Awnings may extend up to five feet from the building front or cover up to 50 percent of the outdoor dining area, whichever is less. Awnings shall have no support posts located within the public right-of-way. A building permit must be obtained prior to the installation of an awning. 
(f)  Lighting. Outdoor lighting fixtures shall complement the streetscape and the style of the building if consistent. The lighting fixtures shall not be glaring to motorists or pedestrians on the adjacent right-of-way, and shall illuminate only the outdoor dining area. Outdoor lighting may be installed on the facade of the building. Electrical wires shall not be permitted in the public right-of-way. Lighting shall be installed by a licensed electrician under an electrical permit from the building department. Battery operated lamps or candles will be permitted. 
(g)  Design. The design, material and colors used for chairs, tables, umbrellas, awnings, and other fixtures shall complement the architectural style and colors of the building facade and street furniture. 
(h)  Signs. Notwithstanding any other provision of this Code, signs and logos shall be permitted on umbrellas in outdoor dining areas. 
(i)  Heaters. Portable propane heaters shall be allowed within the outdoor dining area. 
(j)  Application fee. An application fee of $100.00 shall be paid at the time an application for a sidewalk cafe license is submitted to the building department. An annual use fee of $100.00 (sidewalk dining area of 100 square feet or less) or $200.00 (sidewalk dining area in excess of 100 square feet) shall be paid upon annual renewal of the sidewalk cafe license. 
(Ord. No. 2014-2158, § 1(8-863), 5-20-2014) 
Sec. 16-1191. - Violations; remedy; miscellaneous. 
(a)  Encroachment violation. In the event that a licensee violates the provisions of this article or the terms and conditions of a sidewalk cafe license by placing or installing an encroachment or item that obstructs the sidewalk or public way, the building official may order that such encroachment or obstruction be immediately removed, and upon failure of the licensee to comply with such order within 30 minutes of issuance, the building official may summarily abate such encroachment or obstruction that is in violation by physical removal. The removed encroaching or obstructing articles shall be placed on the property of the licensee. The licensee or property owner shall pay all costs incurred by the city in abating the encroachment or improvement. In addition to, or in lieu of, the issuance of an order to abate by the building official, the building official may issue a written notice of violation to the licensee. The building official may, at his discretion, order revocation of the license or may issue the notice of violation with notice to appear before the administrative hearing officer of the city, for adjudication in accord with the provisions of chapter 1, article II, division 3. Violations of the requirements of this division shall be a Class C violation, punishable as specified in section 1-41, and, the building official may order the revocation of the license for a third or subsequent violation of this division. 
(b)  Inspections. The building official may inspect improvements within the public right-of-way at any time without notice to the licensee. 
(c)  No alterations. The floor of the outdoor dining area shall be maintained at the same level as the sidewalk, and no alterations to the sidewalk, or coverings on the sidewalk such as borings for recessed sleeves shall be installed. 
(d)  Disabled access. The outdoor dining area shall be accessible to the disabled and buildings adjacent to these dining areas shall be maintained with building egress consistent with disabled access standards. 
(e)  Management. The sidewalk cafe management shall operate the outdoor dining area in compliance with the terms and conditions of this division and shall not delegate or assign that responsibility. The licensee shall ensure and be responsible to ensure that sidewalk cafe patrons do not disturb persons on the adjacent right-of-way by loud, boisterous and unreasonable noise, offensive, disruptive or threatening words or behavior. 
(f)  Maintenance. The restaurant management shall keep the outdoor dining area clear of litter, food scraps and soiled dishes and utensils at all times. At the end of each business day, sidewalk cafes shall be cleaned, swept and the entire sidewalk in and around the outdoor dining area shall be washed and the debris removed to a closed receptacle. No debris shall be swept or washed into the sidewalk gutter or street. If disposable materials are used, the establishment shall comply with all applicable city recycling programs. Awnings and umbrellas shall be washed whenever dirty but in any event not less than two times each outdoor dining season. Private trash receptacles shall be emptied daily. 
(g)  Furniture removal. When the establishment stops serving for the day and patrons already seated in it leave, further seating in the outdoor dining area shall be prohibited. Outdoor dining furniture shall be removed from the right-of-way at the conclusion of dining for the day by patrons. 
(h)  Plants. Plants shall be properly maintained, and stressed or dying plants shall be properly replaced. Because plant fertilizers contain material that can stain the pavement, water drainage from any plant onto the adjacent sidewalk shall not be allowed. Potted plants shall have saucers or other suitable systems to retain seepage and be elevated to allow for airflow of at least one inch between saucers and sidewalk. 
(i)  Termination. Upon termination of the sidewalk cafe license, the licensee shall immediately remove the barriers from around the outdoor dining area, return the sidewalk to its original condition, and remove all personal property, furnishings and equipment from the sidewalk. Any personal property remaining on the premises shall be removed pursuant to the laws of the state and this Code. 
(Ord. No. 2014-2158, § 1(8-864), 5-20-2014) 
Secs. 16-1192-16-1199. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI.5. - FOOD TRUCK VENDORS 

Sec. 16-1200. - Definitions. 
    Food truck vendor means a person engaged in the business of selling food or non-alcoholic beverages from a self- contained motorized vehicle or a self-contained enclosed trailer with valid license plates and registration. A food truck vendor does not include an ice cream truck operator. 
(Ord. No. 2017-2330, 8-15-2017; Ord. No. 2017-2334, 9-5-2017) 
Sec. 16-1201. - Annual license required. 
    No person shall operate as a food truck vendor without having first secured a valid annual license for each vehicle to be operated within the city, and to be displayed in or on each vehicle to be used in the operation of any such business. No licensed food truck vendor shall himself or through any employee while acting as a food truck vendor in this municipality barter, sell, or peddle any goods or merchandise or wares other than prepared food products for consumption by the customer as "take-out" from the premises. 
    Food truck vendors shall not be permitted to utilize amplified sound. Food truck vendors are not permitted to utilize city water, electric, or other utility to conduct business unless in the designated pads in the RB&W District. When operating as a transient merchant/itinerant vendor from privately owned property, electricity may be utilized with the permission of the property owner. 
    Sales occurring on public property by food truck vendors are permitted only from designated food truck vendor areas. If operating within a city owned parking lot, no more than two spaces may be utilized by any one vendor. Maps of these designated places of sales are available in the city clerk's office and on the city's website. The issuance of an annual food truck vendor license does not in any way reserve or designate space in the food truck vendor areas. 
    Availability will be on a first-come, first-serve basis. Food truck vendors may be required to obtain a permit to operate within the location of a city sponsored or sanctioned special event or festival, and the city council may limit the number of permits issued to allow food truck vendors to operate within the location of a city sponsored or sanctioned special event or festival, or may prohibit food truck vendors from operation therein entirely, so as to not provide unfair competition to vendors operating within or as a part of the event or festival. Operations within the RB & W district must be conducted in compliance with rules or regulations adopted or promulgated by the city tourism committee and/or the director of tourism. 
    Food truck vendors may operate from private property in the same manner as provided for itinerant vendors/transient merchants. 
(Ord. No. 2017-2330, 8-15-2017; Ord. No. 2017-2334, 9-5-2017) 
Sec. 16-1202. - Vehicle appearance and maintenance. 
    Vehicles utilized for food truck vending shall be kept in good mechanical and structural condition. Vehicles shall have a clean exterior and interior and shall be equipped with signs to alert traffic to proceed with caution past the truck while it is serving customers. Each vehicle shall have the company name affixed to it in a professional, workmanlike manner and in letters that are a minimum of six inches high. The company name shall be affixed to each side and rear of the vehicle. The city building department and city fire department will conduct annual inspections of food truck vendor vehicles to ensure compliance with health and safety issues. 
(Ord. No. 2017-2330, 8-15-2017; Ord. No. 2017-2334, 9-5-2017) 
Sec. 16-1203. - Licensing requirements. 
    In the event that the applicant will be operating more than one such motor vehicle or trailer in the city, the applicant must file separate applications and obtain separate food truck vendor's licenses for each such vehicle or trailer. A criminal background check is required for each employee authorized to conduct sales on behalf of the applicant. All food truck vendors shall be subject to and comply with all laws of the city. 
(1)  Application for a food truck vendor license shall be made at least ten days in advance of the intended date for beginning food sales upon a form provided by and filed with the office of the city clerk. The applicant shall truthfully state in full the information requested on the application, which shall include: 
a.  Individual applicant information. Name and address of present place of residence of the applicant, business address if other than residential address, social security number, and date of birth; 
b.  Identification. Copy of current, valid driver's license adequate to legally drive the food truck or vehicle hauling a food trailer; 
c.  Name of employer or representation. Name and address of the person, firm, or corporation or association by whom the applicant is employed or represents and the length of time of such employment or representation; 
d.  Description of food truck vendor service. Description sufficient for identification of the mobile food service provided by the merchant in which the applicant will engage, including a draft of the intended menu; 
e.  Vehicle description and licensing. A food truck shall be a single, self-contained motorized vehicle or self-contained enclosed trailer with valid license plates and registration. No external generators will be permitted. Make, model, and licensing information shall be included on the application and proof of licensing, auto insurance, and registration must be provided with application. 
f.  Time period. License year for which the certificate is being applied (license year runs May 1 through April 30); 
g.  Date of previous application. The date, or approximate date, of the latest previous application for certificate under this chapter, if any; 
h.  Revocation history. Whether a food truck vendor license issued to the applicant has ever been revoked; 
i.  Criminal history. Whether the applicant has ever been convicted of a felony or misdemeanor under the laws of the state of Illinois or any other state or federal law of the United States; 
j.  Tax identification number. Each applicant shall produce an Illinois Department of Revenue identification number for the retailers' occupation tax; 
k.  Health permit. Any food truck vendor shall be required to obtain an annual food service establishment permit from the county health department, and said certificate shall be required as a pre-condition to do business or be issued a license under this article in the city; 
l.  The addresses of the businesses or facilities at which any fat, oil or grease generated during the operation of the food truck or food trailer are or will be disposed of, including the contact information for the individual or business responsible for the operation of each such business or facility. Any change in the businesses or facilities used for the disposal of such fat, oil and grease shall be reported to the city clerk in writing by the food truck vendor within three business days of the first use of a the new business or facility; 
m.  Any application for a food truck vendor license requiring a vehicle shall be accompanied by proof of liability insurance with a minimum limit of $1,000,000.00 aggregate and issued by a company licensed to do business in the state of Illinois. Such insurance certificate shall contain an agreement signed by the insurance company that, prior to modification, cancellation or termination of the subject policy, written notice shall be sent to the city by said insurance company. If the vendor will be using public property the city shall be listed as an additional insured. 
(2)  All statements made by the applicant upon the application or in connection therewith shall be under oath. 
(3)  The office of the city clerk shall require every applicant to complete a release form authorizing the submission of a criminal history and motor vehicle report background check. The applicant shall be responsible for the payment of any background check fee in addition to any license fees. 
(4)  The office of the city clerk shall cause to be kept, in compliance with the Local Records Act, an accurate record of every application received and acted upon together with all other information and data pertaining thereto and all certificates of registration issued under the provisions of this chapter and of the denial of applications. 
(5)  Each applicant shall pay a $100.00 fee per application. Fees are not subject to proration. 
(Ord. No. 2017-2330, 8-15-2017; Ord. No. 2017-2334, 9-5-2017) 
Sec. 16-1204. - Regulation. 
    Compliance with State of Illinois and county health department rules: No food, food products, or beverages for public consumption shall be kept, offered for sale, transported, or handled except in accordance with the rules and regulations of the State of Illinois and the county health department. If the county health department suspends or revokes the food service establishment permit, then the food truck vendor license hereunder shall be suspended until the county health department reinstates the food service establishment permit. 
(Ord. No. 2017-2330, 8-15-2017; Ord. No. 2017-2334, 9-5-2017) 
Sec. 16-1205. - Health and safety standards. 
(a)  Each vehicle shall be operated in a sanitary manner and in such a manner as to provide no health hazards. Foods shall be kept under the conditions and at the temperatures required for food in restaurants. 
(b)  No fat, oil or grease or other waste product generated in the operation of the business conducted by or at the food truck may be disposed of on public property or deposited into either the sanitary sewer system or storm water drainage system of the city. 
(c)  No tents, tables, chairs, or other displays shall be placed at the designated vending area. Signage shall be limited to signs permanently or magnetically affixed to the vehicle. One A-frame sign shall also be permitted. This sign must be within ten feet of the vehicle and shall be limited to six square feet per side (two-sides permitted.) Food truck vendors are not permitted to utilize city water, electric, or other utility to conduct business unless under the rules of the RB&W district. 
(d)  Food truck vendors must provide for the sanitary collection of all refuse, litter, and garbage generated by patrons using the service and remove all such waste materials from the location before the vehicle departs. A motorized food truck shall not sit idle while serving food unless its operation is essential to producing the product sold. 
(e)  Food truck vendors shall only permit sales from the curb side of the vehicle when parked on a city street. No service area for the operation of a food truck or trailer shall block, obstruct, or interfere with vehicular, bicycle, or pedestrian traffic flow. Food truck vendors must maintain a minimum four foot wide clear walkway on all public sidewalks. 
(f)  Food truck vendors may operate at one location for a minimum of 30 minutes and a maximum of eight consecutive hours and may not return to that same location for a minimum of two hours after leaving. 
(g)  Food truck vendors may not operate between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 5:00 a.m. local time. 
(Ord. No. 2017-2330, 8-15-2017; Ord. No. 2017-2334, 9-5-2017) 
Sec. 16-1206. - Additional regulations. 
    The city council is hereby authorized to make such rules and regulations to implement the provisions of this chapter as are deemed necessary for the protection of the public health and safety. 
(Ord. No. 2017-2330, 8-15-2017; Ord. No. 2017-2334, 9-5-2017) 
Sec. 16-1207. - Denial of license. 
    If any of the following factors have been committed, the application for the license shall be denied: 
(1)  Any of the material statements made in the application to be false; 
(2)  Within five years of the date of application, the applicant has been convicted of or received a disposition of guilt through supervision, probation or conviction for any offense involving a forcible felony or an offense requiring the applicant to register as a sexual offender under the laws of the state of Illinois, of any other state, or of the United States. 
(3)  The applicant or his employer has had a previously issued license under this or a similar article revoked by the city or by any other municipality within one year of the date of the application; 
(4)  The applicant has not secured and maintained a valid health permit from the county health department; or, 
(5)  The applicant has outstanding debt with the city. 
    The city clerk shall deny the license application and shall provide written notification of such denial to the applicant in person or by first class mail. An applicant whose application has been denied shall have the appeal rights as afforded and set out in paragraphs (d) through (g) of section 16-36 of the City of Rock Falls Municipal Code, to the same extent as if the denial had been a suspension or revocation of license. 
(Ord. No. 2017-2330, 8-15-2017; Ord. No. 2017-2334, 9-5-2017) 
Sec. 16-1208. - Suspension of license; revocation and violations of vendor's license. 
(a)  A license may be suspended when a violation of this chapter is verified by the city and until such time as the violation is cured by the licensee and verified by the city. City staff or his designee shall be empowered to order a particular vehicle out of service for violations of this article without actually suspending the vendor license. 
(b)  The conviction of the applicant for a forcible felony, theft, burglary, fraud, bribery or moral turpitude shall result in the revocation of any and all food truck vendor's licenses issued hereunder. 
(c)  The city may revoke any food truck vendor's license if the driver of said vehicle is convicted of a moving traffic law violation occurring while operating a food truck or trailer under a license issued hereunder in the city. 
(d)  If the applicant or any driver of a subject vehicle is or shall become a registered sex offender under the Illinois sex offender registration act, the city shall refuse to issue a license hereunder or shall revoke any license already issued hereunder. 
(e)  A violation of any of the terms of this chapter or of the remainder of this Code may result in the revocation of any food truck vendor's license issued hereunder. 
(f)  Procedure for suspension or revocation of licenses and the appeal rights of licensees therefrom shall be governed by section 16-36 of the City of Rock Falls Municipal Code. 
(Ord. No. 2017-2330, 8-15-2017; Ord. No. 2017-2334, 9-5-2017) 
Sec. 16-1209. - License nontransferable. 
    The food truck vendor license issued hereunder shall not be transferable. 
(Ord. No. 2017-2330, 8-15-2017; Ord. No. 2017-2334, 9-5-2017) 
Sec. 16-1210. - Violations; penalties. 
(a)  Any person, partnership, firm, entity or corporation in violation of any provision of this article shall be fined as provided in section 1-41 (d) of this Code. 
(b)  The conviction or punishment of any person, partnership, firm, entity or corporation for violation of the provisions of this article shall not release such person from paying any fee due and unpaid at the time of such conviction, nor shall payment of any fee prevent prosecution for violation of any of the provisions of this article. 
(c)  The amount of any fee due hereunder shall be deemed a debt to the city. An action may be commenced in the name of the city in any court of competent jurisdiction for the amount of any delinquent fee. All unpaid fees shall be deemed delinquent after they are due and payable. 
(d)  All remedies shall be cumulative, and the use of one or more remedies by the city shall not bar the use of any other remedy. 
(Ord. No. 2017-2330, 8-15-2017; Ord. No. 2017-2334, 9-5-2017) 
Secs. 16-1211-16-1215. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XII. - CHARITABLE SOLICITATIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 16-1216. - Door-to-door solicitation; registration and license required. 
(a)  Definitions. As used in this article the following terms shall have the indicated meanings: 
    Charitable shall mean and include the words charitable, benevolent, philanthropic, patriotic, or eleemosynary. 
    Charitable organization means a charitable organization as that term is defined under 225 ILCS 460/1, or a not-for-profit organization incorporated under 805 ILCS 110/0.01 and/or 805 ILCS 110/35, or any other organization that has been granted tax exempt status from the state or from the Internal Revenue Service. 
    Charitable purpose means a charitable purpose as that term is defined in 225 ILCS 460/1. For purposes of this section, solicitation for a charitable purpose shall include a solicitation for or on behalf of a charitable organization, as that term is defined hereunder. 
    Commercial door-to-door solicitation means the sale, or seeking to obtain orders for the purchase of goods, wares, merchandise, foodstuffs, or services of any kind, character or description, for any kind of consideration whatsoever, either for immediate or future delivery, by means of in-person contact or attempted contact with city residents at their residences. 
    Door-to-door solicitation shall mean and include commercial door-to-door solicitation as defined herein, and door-to-door, in-person requests for money, credit, or any others item of value for a religious, charitable, or political purpose. 
    Residence shall mean and include every separate living unit occupied for residential purposes by one or more persons, contained within any type of building or structure and the yard, curtilage, or grounds upon which such structure is located. 
(b)  License required. It shall be unlawful for any person or organization to engage in commercial door-to-door solicitation in the city without first securing a license as herein provided. If an organization employs multiple individuals for such activities, each such individual and the organization shall be required to be licensed hereunder. 
(c)  Application for license: 
(1)  The application for a license under this section shall be made under oath upon a form provided by the city clerk. Each original application shall be completed in full by the applicant and shall set forth the following information: 
a.  The name, home and business address, date of birth, sex and a physical description of the applicant, including, but not limited to, height, weight, hair color, and eye color; 
b.  The name, address, and telephone number of the person, firm, corporation association or organization by whom the applicant is employed or represents, and the length of time of such employment or representation; 
c.  A description of the business, merchandise, wares, or services of the applicant; 
d.  The period of time/dates for which the license is applied for; 
e.  The date, or approximate date, of the latest previous application for license under this section; 
f.  Whether a license issued to the applicant under this section has ever been revoked; 
g.  Whether the applicant has ever been convicted of a violation of any provisions of this section, or the ordinance of any other municipality or any state statute regulating such activities; 
h.  Whether the applicant has ever been convicted of the commission of a felony or misdemeanor involving fraud, theft, false statements or a threat to public safety under the laws of any state or under federal law, and if so, the offense and date of conviction; 
i.  Whether the applicant has ever been convicted of the commission of a felony or misdemeanor for a crime involving a sex offense or an offense involving bodily harm against persons under the laws of this state or of any other state or federal law of the United States; 
j.  Whether the applicant has ever been registered as a sex offender or violent offender under the law of this state or of any other state or federal law of the United States; 
k.  Documentary evidence that the applicant is authorized to solicit for the organization represented; 
l.  The number and description of vehicles used, if any, including make, model, color, and license plate number of all such vehicles. 
(d)  Ineligible persons. No license shall be issued to any person: (i) who has been convicted of a felony or misdemeanor, involving dishonesty, theft, fraud, false statements, or a threat to public safety within five years prior to the date of application; (ii) who has been convicted of a felony or misdemeanor for a crime involving sex offenses or offenses involving bodily harm against persons under the law of this state or any other state or federal law within ten years prior to the date of application; (iii) who has been a registered sex offender or violent offender in any state; or (iv) who has been found liable of a violation of any of the provisions of this section; (v) whose license issued hereunder has previously been revoked; or (vi) who submits an incomplete or inaccurate application. 
(e)  Records retained. The city clerk shall cause to be kept in his or her office an accurate record of every application received and acted upon, together with all information and data pertaining thereto and all licenses issued under the provisions of this section, and of the denial of any applications. Such record shall contain the number of the license, the date of issuance, the nature of the business authorized to be carried on, the amount of the license fee paid, the expiration date of said license, and the name or names of the person or persons authorized to carry on such solicitation. 
(f)  Exceptions to license requirement. The provisions of this section shall not apply to the following: 
(1)  Solicitation by or on behalf of a charitable organization that is currently registered with the attorney general of the state and is in full compliance with the provisions of an Act to Regulate Solicitation and Collection of Funds for Charitable Purposes, 225 ILCS 460/1 et seq., or is exempt from registration with the attorney general pursuant to 225 ILCS 460/3(b); 
(2)  Any solicitation made on premises owned or occupied by the person or organization on behalf of whom the solicitation is made, or by permission of such owner or occupant. 
(g)  Right to free speech. The provisions contained in this section shall not be construed to prohibit or inhibit any activities or speech not involving any form of request for money or other article of value, including, but not limited to, speech of a political or religious nature. 
(h)  Issuance. The chief of police shall review any applications for licensure under this section and notify the city clerk if such license should be denied for the reason that the applicant has been convicted of a specific offense or other reason for which a license is to be denied under the Municipal Code of the city, within ten days of receipt of the application. 
    The city clerk shall issue a license upon receipt of approval of the application by the chief of police and payment of the prescribed license fee as provided in this division. Each license shall be for the term referred to in section 16-1217. 
(i)  Possession of license; renewal. All licenses issued under this section shall be upon the person of the licensee at all times during the operation of such solicitation, and shall, upon request of a law enforcement officer, display the license to said officer. All licenses are valid for the entire licensing period unless revoked or suspended prior to expiration, as provided in this section. An application to renew a license under this section shall be made not later than five days before the expiration of the current license. 
(j)  Restrictions applicable to all door-to-door solicitation. It shall be unlawful for any person: 
(1)  To engage in solicitation upon any premises or residence located thereon if such premises or residence is posted against solicitation by signage bearing the words "No Trespassing," "No Peddlers," "No Solicitors," or any other similar notice indicating that the occupant or occupants of such premises or residence desire not to be disturbed, unless such solicitation has been specifically requested by the owner or occupant of such premises. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful for any person to go in or about any residence or any non-residential premises for the purpose of conducting any form of solicitation at any time after 4:00 p.m. or before 9:00 a.m. on any Monday through Saturday, or at anytime on Sunday, or at anytime on any holiday recognized by the state unless such solicitation has been requested by the owner or occupant of such premises. 
(3)  It shall be unlawful for any person conducting any form of solicitation at any residence or non-residential premises to fail to immediately leave such premises, and/or to fail to immediately cease conducting such solicitation at such residence or non-residential premises upon receiving from any person in charge of said premises or an occupant thereof, a request to leave or cease solicitation. 
(Code 1990, § 8-866; Ord. No. 91-1609, § 1, 12-16-1991; Ord. No. 2011-2453, § 1, 4-5-2011; Ord. No. 2016-2247, § 1, 1-5-2016) 
Sec. 16-1217. - Rules for bucket brigades. 
(a)  No charitable organization or individual shall solicit funds from passing motorists on public roadways by having or allowing persons to stand or walk within the traveled portion of the roadway, in a manner commonly referred to as a "bucket brigade", unless all of the following conditions have been met and apply to such solicitation and bucket brigade: 
(1)  The charitable organization shall file an application with the office of the city clerk, and such application shall be filed so that at least ten business days occur between the filing of the application and a regularly scheduled meeting of the city council of the city at which notice of the application may be placed upon the agenda; 
(2)  The application shall specify the date or dates and times of day when the solicitation is to occur; 
(3)  The application shall state the manner and conditions under which the solicitation is to occur; 
(4)  The application shall state the name of the charitable organization sponsoring the solicitation; 
(5)  The application shall be accompanied by proof of the existence of a valid insurance policy insuring all of the charitable organization, any persons standing or walking along or upon the public roadway conducting the solicitation and the city against loss arising from bodily injury or property damage in connection with or as the result of such solicitation or actions of the persons conducting the solicitation; and 
(6)  The charitable organization certifies that the only persons who shall be standing or walking upon the public streets and making the solicitations are firefighters or police officers employed by the city, and provides the names of such persons. 
(b)  The city council shall consider the application at the regularly scheduled meeting thereof held not less than ten business days after the filing of the application, and the application shall be approved if all of the above and foregoing requirements have been met. 
(c)  In order to minimize the risk of injury to persons or damage to property based upon the reasons articulated and set forth in the preamble to the ordinance from which this section derives: 
(1)  Bucket brigade solicitation shall only be permitted to occur at the intersection of 1st Avenue and 3rd Street, or the intersection of 2nd Avenue and 3rd Street within the city, and at no other place; 
(2)  Shall occur only during the hours at least one hour after sunrise and one hour before sunset of the days on which the solicitation is to occur; 
(3)  All persons standing or walking upon the roadways conducting the solicitation shall wear protective vests, in highway safety orange or yellow, with reflecting material thereon; and 
(4)  Before beginning the solicitation, the organization shall place highway safety orange traffic cones on the dividing lines between traffic lanes extending at least 75 feet in each direction from the intersection where the solicitation is to occur. 
(d)  All terms and conditions utilized in this section shall have the meaning ascribed to them within the provisions of the Illinois Charitable Games Act (230 ILCS 30/1 et seq.) and 65 ILCS 5/11-80-9, unless otherwise described. 
(Code 1990, § 8-870; Ord. No. 91-1609, § 2, 12-16-1991; Ord. No. 2001-1968, § 1, 4-3-2001; Ord. No. 2013-2141, 12-17-2013) 
Secs. 16-1218-16-1237. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 16-1238. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person in the city to solicit contributions for any charitable purpose without first obtaining a permit from the council. The provisions of this section shall not apply to any established organization organized and operated exclusively for charitable purposes and not operated for pecuniary profit of any person if: 
(1)  The solicitations by such organization are conducted among the members thereof by other members or officers thereof, voluntarily and without remuneration for making such solicitation; or 
(2)  The solicitations are in the form of collections or contributions at the regular assemblies or services of any such organization. 
(Code 1990, § 8-867; Ord. No. 2011-2453, § 1, 4-5-2011) 
Sec. 16-1239. - Application. 
    An application for a permit to solicit shall be made to the city clerk's office upon forms provided by the city. Such application shall be sworn to and filed with the city clerk's office at least 15 days prior to the time at which the permit applied for shall become effective; provided, however, that the council may for good cause shown allow the filing of an application less than 15 days prior to the effective date of the permit applied for. The application shall contain the following information, or in lieu thereof, a detailed statement of the reason or reasons why such information cannot be furnished: 
(1)  The name, address or headquarters of the person applying for the permit; 
(2)  If applicant is not an individual, the names and addresses of the applicant's principal officers and managers and a copy of the resolution, if any, authorizing such solicitations, certified to as a true and correct copy of the original by the officer having charge of the applicant's records; 
(3)  The purpose for which such solicitations are to be made, the total amount of funds proposed to be raised thereby, and the use or disposition to be made of any receipts therefrom; 
(4)  A specific statement, supported by reason and, if available, figures, showing the need for the contributions to be solicited; 
(5)  The name and address of the person or persons who will be in direct charge of conducting the solicitations and the names of all promoters connected or to be connected with the proposed solicitations; 
(6)  An outline of the method or methods to be used in conducting the solicitations; 
(7)  The time when such solicitations shall be made, giving the preferred dates for the beginning and ending of such solicitations; 
(8)  The estimated cost of the solicitations; 
(9)  The amount of any wages, fees, commissions, expenses and emoluments to be expended or paid to any person in connection with such solicitations, and the names and addresses of all such persons; 
(10)  A financial statement of the last preceding fiscal year of any funds collected for charitable purposes within the city by the applicant, giving the amount of money so raised, together with the cost of raising it, and the final distribution thereof; 
(11)  A full statement of the character and extent of the charitable work being done by the applicant within the city; 
(12)  A statement that the actual cost of the solicitations will not exceed a stated percentage of the total amount to be raised; 
(13)  A statement to the effect that if a permit is granted, it will not be used or represented in any way as an endorsement by the city or by any department, officer or employee thereof; 
(14)  Such other information as may be reasonably required by the city attorney's office or the city clerk's office in order to determine the kind and character of the proposed solicitations and whether such solicitations are in the interest of, and not inimical to, the public welfare. 
If, while any application is pending, or during the term of any permit granted thereon, there is any change in fact, policy, or method that would alter the information given in the application, the applicant shall notify the city clerk's office in writing thereof within one business day after such change. 
(Code 1990, § 8-868; Ord. No. 2011-2453, § 1, 4-5-2011) 
Sec. 16-1240. - Issuance. 
(a)  The council shall issue a permit under this division whenever it shall find the following facts to exist: 
(1)  All of the statements made in the application are true. 
(2)  The applicant has a good character and reputation for honesty and integrity, or if the applicant is not an individual person, then every managing officer or agent of the applicant has a good character or reputation for honesty and integrity. 
(3)  The control and supervision of the solicitations will be under responsible and reliable persons. 
(4)  The applicant has not engaged in any fraudulent transaction or enterprise. 
(5)  The solicitations will not be a fraud on the public. 
(6)  The solicitations are prompted solely by a desire to finance a charitable cause described in the application, and will not be conducted for private profit or gain. 
(7)  The cost of raising the funds will be reasonable. 
(b)  The city clerk shall file in his office for public inspection, and shall serve upon the applicant by certified mail, a written statement of the council's finding of facts and its decision upon each application. 
(Code 1990, § 8-869; Ord. No. 2011-2453, § 1, 4-5-2011) 
Secs. 16-1241-16-1268. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIII. - AMUSEMENTS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 16-1269. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Carnival means an aggregation of attractions, whether shows, acts, games, vending devices or amusement devices, whether conducted under one or more managements or independently, which are temporarily set up or conducted in a public place or upon any private premises accessible to the public, with or without admission fee, and which, from the nature of the aggregation, attracts attendance and causes promiscuous intermingling of persons in the spirit of merrymaking and revelry. 
(Code 1990, § 8-886) 
Sec. 16-1270. - Applicability. 
    The provisions of this division except as to licensing and fees shall apply to all public shows, theatricals, circuses and other amusements in the city whether specifically licensed in another division or not. 
(Code 1977, § 5.10.010; Code 1990, § 8-887) 
Sec. 16-1271. - License required; application; fees. 
(a)  It is unlawful to conduct or operate any amusement which is open to the public and for admittance to which a fee is charged without having first secured a license therefor; provided that the provisions of this section shall not be held to apply to those amusements which are specifically licensed by any other ordinance of the city. 
(b)  Applications for such licenses shall be made to the city clerk in writing specifying the location of the proposed amusement and the dates the same is to be held.
