Such applications shall comply with all of the general provisions of the ordinances relating thereto. For such licenses the following fees shall be paid: 
(1)  Carnivals: $25.00 per day for one through five rides; $50.00 per day for six through ten rides; $75.00 per day for 11 through 15 rides; $100.00 per day for 16 or more rides. 
(2)  Other amusements: $10.00 per day. 
(Code 1977, §§ 5.10.020, 5.28.040; Code 1990, § 8-888; Ord. No. 2004-2087, § 1, 4-20-2004) 
State Law reference- Carnivals, 65 ILCS 5/11-54.1-1 et seq. 
Sec. 16-1272. - Carnival permit; consideration by council. 
    A carnival permit application shall be presented to the city council at a regular meeting, but shall not be acted upon until the next subsequent regular meeting of the council. No permit for a carnival shall be issued until the application shall have been laid over for consideration by the city council. 
(Code 1977, § 5.28.050; Code 1990, § 8-889; Ord. No. 94-1711, § 1, 6-20-1994) 
Sec. 16-1273. - Street shows. 
    No permit shall be granted or given for any carnival, exhibition, show or other amusement to be given on any public street or sidewalk or in such place that the only main accommodation for the public or the audience will be in a public place, except on the order of the council. 
(Code 1977, § 5.10.030; Code 1990, § 8-891) 
Sec. 16-1274. - Athletic exhibitions-License required; exemptions. 
    It is unlawful to conduct, operate or exhibit any race between persons, animals or vehicles, or any baseball games, boxing or wrestling matches or any other athletic contest or exhibition for admission to which a fee is charged without first having procured a license therefor; provided, however, that this section shall not apply to athletic exhibitions sponsored by any educational, religious or charitable organizations. 
(Code 1977, § 5.10.040; Code 1990, § 8-892) 
Sec. 16-1275. - Same-Declaration of gross receipts; payment of fee. 
    The proprietor of an athletic exhibition shall submit to the city clerk a statement, verified under oath, of the gross receipts of each such game, contest or race, within one week after an athletic exhibition. At the same time, the proprietor or person exhibiting or operating such exhibition shall pay to the clerk a sum equal to three percent of the gross receipts. 
(Code 1977, § 5.10.050; Code 1990, § 8-893) 
Sec. 16-1276. - Same-Police admitted free to maintain order. 
    Sufficient members of the police service shall be admitted free of charge to all athletic exhibitions for the purpose of preserving and maintaining order. The city clerk may post any number of persons at the box office of each such performance, and may examine all the books pertaining to such performance showing or tending to show the gross receipts. 
(Code 1977, § 5.10.060; Code 1990, § 8-894) 
Sec. 16-1277. - Inspections. 
    It shall be the duty of the chief of police and the fire marshal to see that every exhibition, amusement, theatrical or other public show or amusement is inspected by a member of the police and fire services, and to ensure conformity with the provisions concerning such amusements. 
(Code 1977, § 5.10.100; Code 1990, § 8-895) 
Sec. 16-1278. - Obscene shows unlawful. 
    It is unlawful for any person to present, exhibit, conduct or take part in any obscene show, theatrical, play, motion picture, exhibition or other form of public amusement or show. 
(Code 1977, § 5.10.110; Code 1990, § 8-896) 
Sec. 16-1279. - Conduct of audience; fire risks, other risks. 
(a)  The audience of any amusement, show or theatrical must be orderly and quiet at all times. It is unlawful for any person attending such amusement, show or theatrical to create a disturbance in the audience. 
(b)  It is unlawful to permit or gather such a crowd to witness any such amusement or show as to create a dangerous condition because of fire or other risk. 
(Code 1977, § 5.10.120; Code 1990, § 8-897) 
Sec. 16-1280. - Promotion of riot or disturbance. 
    It is unlawful to present any public amusement or show of any kind which tends to or is calculated to cause or promote any riot or disturbance. 
(Code 1977, § 5.10.140; Code 1990, § 8-898) 
Sec. 16-1281. - Exit lights. 
    It shall be the duty of the owner or occupant in charge of any building or hall used as an assembly hall with accommodations for 100 persons or more in which theatricals, shows, amusements, lectures and other entertainment is offered, operated or presented to provide and place a sign on which the word "EXIT" appears in letters at least six inches high over every door or other opening from such hall to every means of egress therefrom, and a light shall be provided with a red globe and placed at or over such sign, which light shall be kept burning during the entire period that the hall is open to the public and until the audience has left the hall. 
(Code 1977, § 5.10.170; Code 1990, § 8-899) 
Secs. 16-1282-16-1305. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - MOTION PICTURES AND THEATRICALS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal regulation of theatricals and shows, 65 ILCS 5/11-42-5. 

Sec. 16-1306. - License-Required. 
    It is unlawful to give, present or conduct any motion picture or theatrical, for admission to which a fee is charged, excepting performances given solely for the benefit of and under the supervision of a religious, educational or charitable organization, without having first secured a license therefor. 
(Code 1977, § 5.64.010; Code 1990, § 8-916) 
Sec. 16-1307. - Same-Application. 
    Applications for licenses under this division shall be made in conformance with the general provisions relating to such applications, and shall state in addition to the other information required, the place of the intended performance and the seating capacity thereof. 
(Code 1977, § 5.64.020; Code 1990, § 8-917) 
Sec. 16-1308. - Same-Fee. 
(a)  Any person securing an annual license for motion pictures or theatricals, naming a specific place or building where the performances are to be presented, may present therein any number of performances, including theatricals, during the year for which the license was secured without having to pay any additional fee. 
(b)  The license fee for such licenses shall be $150.00 for an annual license, $75.00 for a license for six months, and $10.00 for a license for one day. 
(Code 1977, § 5.64.030; Code 1990, § 8-918; Ord. No. 2000-1939, § 11, 6-6-2000) 
Sec. 16-1309. - Use of unlicensed premises; fee. 
    For motion pictures or theatricals which are presented in premises which are not covered by the license fee, the fee to be paid shall be $5.00 per day. No such motion picture or theatrical shall be presented in or on any premises or building which does not fully comply with the requirements of the ordinances for the construction and maintenance of buildings for this purpose. 
(Code 1977, § 5.64.040; Code 1990, § 8-919) 
Sec. 16-1310. - Standing during performance; limit on number of persons admitted. 
    It is unlawful to permit any person, excepting ushers or other theater employees, to remain standing in a hall or room in which a motion picture is presented during the time of such performance. It is unlawful to admit to any such hall more persons than can be accommodated by the seating arrangements of the premises. 
(Code 1977, § 5.64.060; Code 1990, § 8-920) 
Secs. 16-1311-16-1333. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - COIN-OPERATED AMUSEMENT DEVICES 

Sec. 16-1334. - License-Required. 
    No person shall place, install, maintain or operate in any building or place within the city any mechanical coin-operated amusement device, including coin-operated mechanical musical devices for use by the public and for which a fee is charged, without first having obtained a license for each place or location where such mechanical coin-operated amusement device is installed, maintained or operated. 
(Code 1977, § 5.32.010; Code 1990, § 8-936) 
Sec. 16-1335. - Same-Application. 
    Any person desiring a license required by this division shall make application for that purpose to the city clerk. Such application shall set forth the full name of the applicant and his address; the location and character of the building or place where such mechanical coin-operated amusement device is to be located, maintained and operated; the number of such devices to be located, maintained or operated in such building or place; the type of machine to be located, maintained and operated; and the charge to be made to the customer for operating each such device. 
(Code 1977, § 5.32.020; Code 1990, § 8-937) 
Sec. 16-1336. - Same-Fees; transfer. 
(a)  No coin-operated amusement device shall be placed for use within the city until the owner thereof shall have purchased an annual license for such device, and shall have paid an annual license fee equal to $40.00 for each such device. Also, the owner or lessee in possession of any premises where is located at any time more than four such coin-operated amusement devices shall apply for and obtain an arcade operator's license and shall pay an annual license fee for such license equal to $100.00. Also, any person owning more than four such coin-operated amusement devices, whether located at the same or at more than one location or premises within the city, shall be deemed a coin-operated amusement device operator and shall obtain coin-operated amusement device operator's license and pay therefor an annual license fee equal to $750.00. 
(b)  None of the fees and license permits provided for in subsection (a) of this section shall be prorated if the license is issued for less than a full fiscal year. 
(c)  A license issued for a device located at a designated location within the city may be transferred to another device which replaces the original at such location without charge or additional fee. 
(d)  An application for any license under this section shall specify the number and type of devices to be located at a premises within the city, the name and address of the owner of the device, and shall specify the address and location of the device. 
(e)  The requirements of subsection (a) of this section shall not apply to any not-for-profit organization exempt from tax under Internal Revenue Code section 501(c)(3), and in lieu of any fees required by the provisions of subsection (a) of this section, said not-for-profit organizations shall be issued a license to operate any number of devices, an arcade operators license and/or coin operated amusement device operators license upon payment of an annual license fee of $10.00. 
(Code 1990, § 8-938; Ord. No. 88-1507, § 5.32.030, 4-18-1988; Ord. No. 2005-2121, § 1, 2-1-2005; Ord. No. 2010-2392, § 2, 3-16-2010) 
Secs. 16-1337-16-1355. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - PUBLIC DANCES 

Sec. 16-1356. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Public dance means any dance which is made open to the general public and for which admissions are solicited from the public at large and for which admission is charged or donations for the conduct thereof are sought, but public dances regulated by this division do not include any dances conducted by any civic or social club open to members only, or any dance conducted by any educational institution or students or faculty thereof. 
(Code 1977, § 5.74.070; Code 1990, § 8-956) 
Sec. 16-1357. - License-Required. 
    It is unlawful to operate or conduct a public dance in the city without having first obtained a license therefor. 
(Code 1977, § 5.74.010; Code 1990, § 8-957) 
Sec. 16-1358. - Same-Application. 
(a)  Applications for public dance licenses shall be made in conformance with the provisions of division 1 of this article and article II of this chapter and shall specify the location of the proposed dances and the person or organization sponsoring the same. 
(b)  No such license shall be issued to a person who is not a person of good moral character, nor to a corporation or organization which is not represented in the city by a person of good moral character. 
(Code 1977, § 5.74.020; Code 1990, § 8-958) 
Sec. 16-1359. - Same-Investigation of applicant. 
    It shall be the duty of the chief of police to make or cause to be made an investigation into the character of each applicant for a public dance license and report the results of such investigation to the council. 
(Code 1977, § 5.74.030; Code 1990, § 8-959) 
Sec. 16-1360. - Same-fees. 
    The fees for public dances shall be as follows: 
(1)  Annual license, $40.00; 
(2)  License for one day, $20.00. 
(Code 1977, § 5.74.040; Code 1990, § 8-960; Ord. No. 2000-1939, § 13, 6-6-2000) 
Secs. 16-1361-16-1388. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - CIRCUSES 

Sec. 16-1389. - License-Required; application. 
(a)  No person shall conduct or operate a circus in the city without having first obtained a license as is provided in this division. 
(b)  Application for such licenses shall be made to the city clerk and shall specify the place in or on which the circus is to be conducted. 
(Code 1977, § 5.28.010; Code 1990, § 8-976) 
Sec. 16-1390. - Same-Fee. 
    The fee for a circus license under this division shall be $100.00 per day. The fee for street parades or circuses shall be $20.00 per day. 
(Code 1977, § 5.28.020; Code 1990, § 8-977) 
Sec. 16-1391. - Sideshows and concessions. 
    The license fee for each sideshow and concession operated in connection with a circus shall be $10.00 per day. 
(Code 1977, § 5.28.030; Code 1990, § 8-978; Ord. No. 2000-1939, § 3, 6-6-2000) 
Sec. 16-1392. - Permit application. 
    All applications for permits for the operation of a circus within the city limits shall be made in writing specifying the location of the proposed circus and the dates the same is to be held. 
(Code 1977, § 5.28.040; Code 1990, § 8-979) 
Sec. 16-1393. - Consideration by council. 
    Circus permit applications shall be presented to the council at a regular meeting and shall not be acted upon until the next subsequent regular meeting, and no permit shall be issued until the next regular meeting after the application has been presented. 
(Code 1977, § 5.28.050; Code 1990, § 8-980; Ord. No. 94-1714, § 1, 7-5-1994) 
Sec. 16-1394. - Mandatory compliance with provisions. 
    It shall be the duty of every person licensed under this division to obey the provisions of division 1 of this article and all other ordinance provisions relating to circuses or the premises occupied. 
(Code 1977, § 5.28.070; Code 1990, § 8-982) 
Sec. 16-1395. - Inspections. 
    It shall be the duty of the chief of police and the fire marshal to see that inspections as provided for in section 16-1277 shall be made of all circuses and circus performances and of the premises used. 
(Code 1977, § 5.28.080; Code 1990, § 8-983) 
Sec. 16-1396. - Cheating, short changing, defrauding. 
    It is unlawful for any person to cheat, short change or otherwise defraud any person attending or about to attend a circus performance within the city. 
(Code 1977, § 5.28.090; Code 1990, § 8-984) 
Sec. 16-1397. - Parade; permit, bond. 
    It is unlawful to conduct any parade connected with a circus on any public street, alley or other public way or place in the city unless a permit therefor is first obtained from the mayor and council. Such permit shall specify the route to be followed, and shall be accompanied by a bond in the sum of $10,000.00, conditioned to indemnify the city for any loss, damage or liability incurred or caused by the conduct of such exhibition or such parade. 
(Code 1977, § 5.28.100; Code 1990, § 8-985) 
Secs. 16-1398-16-1417. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - RODEOS 

Sec. 16-1418. - License-Required. 
    It is unlawful for any person to engage in, present or operate a rodeo within the city without having first obtained a license therefor from the city clerk. 
(Code 1977, § 5.77.010; Code 1990, § 8-1001) 
Sec. 16-1419. - Same-Fee. 
    The fee for engaging in, presenting or operating a rodeo shall be $10.00 per day. 
(Code 1977, § 5.77.020; Code 1990, § 8-1002) 
Sec. 16-1420. - Sanitary facilities. 
    A person engaging in or presenting or operating a rodeo shall provide sanitary facilities or restrooms for the benefit of the members of the public viewing such rodeo and for the participants equivalent to one restroom for each 100 persons of that sex of anticipated attendance to a maximum of seven restrooms for each sex. 
(Code 1977, § 5.77.030; Code 1990, § 8-1003) 
Secs. 16-1421-16-1448. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 7. - HORSE OR DOG SHOWS 

Sec. 16-1449. - License-Required. 
    No person shall present, operate or exhibit any horse or dog show within the city without having first obtained a license therefor issued by the city clerk. 
(Code 1977, § 5.51.010; Code 1990, § 8-1021) 
Sec. 16-1450. - Same-Fee. 
    The fee for the issuance of a license for the operation or presentation of a horse or dog show shall be $10.00 per day. 
(Code 1977, § 5.51.020; Code 1990, § 8-1022) 
Secs. 16-1451-16-1478. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 8. - RAFFLES[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Raffles, 230 ILCS 15/0.01 et seq. 

Sec. 16-1479. - Title. 
    This division shall be known, cited and referred to as the raffle ordinance of the city. 
(Code 1977, § 5.76A.010; Code 1990, § 8-1041) 
Sec. 16-1480. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Business organization means a voluntary organization composed of individuals and businesses who have joined together to advance the commercial financial, industrial and civic interest of a community. 
    Charitable organization means an organization or institution organized and operated to benefit an indefinite number of the public. The service rendered to those eligible for benefits must also confer some benefit on the public. 
    Educational organization means an organization or institution organized and operated to provide systematic instruction in useful branches of learning by methods common to schools and institutions of learning which compare favorably in their scope and intensity with the course of study presented in tax-supported schools. 
    Fraternal organization means an organization of persons having a common interest, the primary interest of which is to both promote the welfare of its members and to provide assistance to the general public in such a way as to lessen the burdens of government by caring for those who otherwise would be cared for by the government. 
    Labor organization means an organization composed of workers organized with the objective of betterment of the conditions of those engaged in such pursuit and the development of a higher degree of efficiency in their respective occupations. 
    Licensee means an organization which has been issued a license to operate a raffle. 
    Net proceeds means the gross receipts from the conduct of raffles, less sums expended for prizes, local license fees and other reasonable operating expenses incurred as a result of operating a raffle. 
    Nonprofit means organized, operated and conducted on a not-for-profit basis with no personal profit inuring to anyone as a result of the operation. 
    Person means an individual, firm, organization, public or private corporation, government, partnership or unincorporated association. 
    Raffle means a form of lottery, as defined in 2012 (720 ILCS 5/28-2), conducted by an organization licensed under this division in which: 
(1)  The player pays or agrees to pay something of value for a chance, represented and differentiated by a number or by a combination of numbers or by some other means, one or more of which chances is to be designated the winning chance; and 
(2)  The winning chance is to be determined through a drawing or by some other method based on an element of chance by an act or set of acts on the part of persons conducting or connected with the lottery, except that the winning chance shall not be determined by the outcome of a publicly exhibited sporting contest. 
    Religious organization means any church, congregation, society or organization founded for the purpose of religious worship. 
    Veterans organization means an organization or association comprised of members of which substantially all are individuals who are veterans or spouses, widows or widowers of veterans, the primary purpose of which is to promote the welfare of its members and to provide assistance to the general public in such a way as to confer a public benefit. 
(Code 1977, § 5.76A.040; Code 1990, § 8-1043; Ord. No. 2015-2201, § 1, 3-17-2015) 
Sec. 16-1481. - Enforcement. 
(a)  Violations. A violation of this division shall be punishable as a Class B violation as provided in section 1-41. 
(b)  Abatement. The imposition of the penalties prescribed in this section shall not preclude the city attorney from instituting appropriate action to prevent unlawful raffles or to restrain, correct or abate a violation of this division or of the conditions of a raffle license issued pursuant hereto. 
(Code 1977, § 5.76A.160; Code 1990, § 8-1044; Ord. No. 2011-2458, § 33, 4-5-2011) 
Sec. 16-1482. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this division is to regulate and control the conduct of raffles within the city. 
(Code 1977, § 5.76A.020; Code 1990, § 8-1045) 
Sec. 16-1483. - License requirements. 
    It is unlawful for any person to conduct or operate a raffle or to sell, offer for sale, convey, issue or otherwise transfer for value a chance on a raffle unless done in accordance with this division. 
(Code 1977, § 5.76A.050; Code 1990, § 8-1046) 
Sec. 16-1484. - Application. 
(a)  Any person seeking to conduct or operate a raffle shall file an application therefor with the city clerk on forms provided by the city clerk. Such application shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The name, address and type of organization; 
(2)  The length of existence of the organization and, if incorporated, the date and state of incorporation; 
(3)  The name, address, telephone number, social security number and date of birth of the organization's presiding officer, secretary, raffles manager and any other members responsible for the conduct and operation of the raffle; 
(4)  The aggregate retail value of all prizes to be awarded in the raffle; 
(5)  The maximum retail value of each prize to be awarded in the raffle; 
(6)  The maximum price charged for each raffle chance issued or sold; 
(7)  The maximum number of raffle chances to be issued; 
(8)  The area or areas in which raffle chances will be sold or issued; 
(9)  The time period during which raffle chances will be issued or sold; 
(10)  The date, time and location at which winning chances will be determined; 
(11)  A sworn statement attesting to the not-for-profit character of the applicant organization, signed by its presiding officer and secretary; 
(12)  A certificate signed by the presiding officer of the applicant organization attesting to the fact that the information contained in the application is true and correct. 
(b)  A fidelity bond in the name of the raffles manager in an amount equal to the aggregate retail value of all prizes to be awarded shall accompany the application. The city may waive this bond requirement and include a waiver provision in the license issued, provided that proof of a unanimous vote of the members of the licensed organization is provided with the application. 
(Code 1977, § 5.76A.060; Code 1990, § 8-1047; Ord. No. 2015-2201, § 2, 3-17-2015) 
Sec. 16-1485. - Licensee qualifications. 
    Raffle licenses shall be issued only to a bona fide charitable, business, educational, fraternal, labor, religious and veterans' organizations that operate without profit to their members and which have been in existence continuously for a period of five years or more immediately before making application for a license and which have had during that entire five-year period a bona fide membership engaged in carrying out their objectives, or to a non-profit fundraising organization that the licensing authority determines is organized for the sole purpose of providing financial assistance to an identified individual or group of individuals suffering extreme financial hardship as the result of an illness, disability, accident or disaster. 
(Code 1977, § 5.76A.070; Code 1990, § 8-1048; Ord. No. 2015-2201, § 3, 3-17-2015) 
Sec. 16-1486. - Issuance, contents of license. 
(a)  The city clerk shall review all raffle license applications for completeness and shall submit completed applications to the city council at the next regularly scheduled council meeting after the date of application. The city council shall, within 30 days from the date of application, accept or reject a raffle license application. If an application is accepted, the city clerk shall forthwith issue a raffle license to the applicant. A raffle license shall be valid for the time period specified on the application or until the last day of the fiscal year during which the license was issued. 
(b)  A raffle license shall show the following: 
(1)  The area or areas in which raffle chances may be sold or issued; 
(2)  The period of time during which raffle chances may be sold or issued; and 
(3)  The date, time and location on or at which winning chances will be determined. 
(c)  The license shall be prominently displayed at the time and location of the determination of the winning chances. 
(d)  A license shall be valid for multiple raffles within the time period for which application is made but shall be valid only for those raffles identified upon the application. 
(Code 1977, § 5.76A.080; Code 1990, § 8-1049; Ord. No. 2015-2201, § 4, 3-17-2015) 
Sec. 16-1487. - Conduct of raffles. 
(a)  The operation and conduct of raffles are subject to the following restrictions: 
(1)  The entire net proceeds of any raffle must be exclusively devoted to the lawful purpose of the licensee. 
(2)  No person except a bona fide member of the licensee may participate in the management or operation of the raffle. 
(3)  No person may receive remuneration or profit for participating in the management or operation of the raffle. 
(4)  A licensee may rent a premises on which to determine the winning chance or chances in a raffle only from an organization which is also licensed under this division. 
(5)  Raffle chances may be sold, offered for sale, conveyed, issued or otherwise transferred for value only within the area specified on the license; and the winning chances may be determined only at the location specified on the license. 
(6)  No person under the age of 18 years may participate in the operation or conduct of raffles. A person under the age of 18 years may be within the area where winning chances are being determined only when accompanied by his parent or guardian. 
(b)  If a lessor rents premises where a winning chance or chances on a raffle are determined, the lessor shall not be criminally liable if the person who uses the premises for the determining of winning chances does not hold a license issued by the city under this division. 
(Code 1977, § 5.76A.090; Code 1990, § 8-1050) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 230 ILCS 15/4. 
Sec. 16-1488. - Raffles manager. 
    All operation and conduct of a raffle shall be under the supervision of a single raffles manager designated by the licensee. The manager shall give a fidelity bond equal in amount to the aggregate retail value of all prizes to be awarded in favor of the organization conditioned upon its honesty in the performance of its duties. The terms of the bond shall provide that notice shall be given in writing to the city not less than 30 days prior to its cancellation. The city may waive this bond requirement and include a waiver provision in the license issued, provided that proof of a unanimous vote of the members of the licensed organization is provided with the application. 
(Code 1977, § 5.76A.100; Code 1990, § 8-1051; Ord. No. 2015-2201, § 5, 3-17-2015) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 230 ILCS 15/5. 
Sec. 16-1489. - Records. 
(a)  Each licensee shall keep records of its gross receipts, expenses and net proceeds for each single gathering or occasion at which winning chances are determined. All deductions from gross receipts for each single gathering or occasion shall be documented with receipts or other records indicating the amount, a description of the purchased item or service or other reason for the deduction, and the recipient. The distribution of net proceeds shall be itemized as to payee, purpose, amount and date of payment. 
(b)  Gross receipts from the operation of raffles shall be segregated from other revenues of the licensee, including bingo gross receipts, if bingo games are also conducted by the same nonprofit organization pursuant to license therefor issued by the department of revenue of the state, and placed in a separate account. Each licensee shall keep separate records of its raffles. The person who accounts for gross receipts, expenses and net proceeds from the operation of raffles shall not be the same person who accounts for other revenues of the licensee. 
(c)  Each licensee shall report to its membership and to the city its gross receipts, expenses and net proceeds from the raffle, and the distribution of net proceeds itemized as required in this division. 
(d)  Raffle records shall be preserved for three years, and organizations shall make available their records relating to the operation of raffles for public inspection at reasonable times and places. 
(Code 1977, § 5.76A.110; Code 1990, § 8-1052) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 230 ILCS 15/5. 
Sec. 16-1490. - Fee schedule. 
(a)  A fee of $60.00 shall be paid to the city clerk when an application for a raffle license is filed. A raffle license shall permit the conduct of a raffle with a maximum single cash prize or the maximum retail value of a single non-cash prize not exceeding $100,000.00. Multiple drawings may be held to award the prizes but all drawings must occur on the same day and at the same location. If within 30 days of the raffle the city receives the report from the licensee of the gross receipts, expenses and net proceeds from the raffle, and the distribution of net proceeds from the raffle, a refund of $20.00 will be returned to the licensee. 
(b)  A fee of $80.00 shall be paid to the city clerk when an application for a 12-month raffle license is filed. A 12-month raffle license permits an organization to regularly conduct raffles among its own membership at a regularly scheduled organizational meeting. Chances for these raffles may only be sold, and the drawings held, on the day of the meetings. A schedule of drawings must be filed with the application. If within 30 days of the end of the fiscal year the city receives the report from the licensee of the gross receipts, expenses and net proceeds from the raffle, and the distribution of net proceeds from the raffle a refund of $20.00 will be returned to the licensee. 
(Code 1977, § 5.76A.120; Code 1990, § 8-1053; Ord. No. 2000-1940, § 1, 6-6-2000; Ord. No. 2008-2271, § 1, 4-15-2008; Ord. No. 2015-2201, § 6, 3-17-2015) 
Sec. 16-1491. - Prize limitations. 
    The aggregate retail value of all prizes awarded in a single raffle shall not exceed $100,000.00, and the retail value of any one prize awarded in a single raffle shall not exceed $100,000.00. 
(Code 1977, § 5.76A.130; Code 1990, § 8-1054; Ord. No. 2015-2201, § 7, 3-17-2015) 
Sec. 16-1492. - Chance limitation. 
    The price which may be charged for each raffle chance sold, offered for sale, conveyed, issued or otherwise transferred for value shall not exceed the following schedule: 
Aggregate Retail Value of Prizes Maximum Price Less than $1,000.00 $10.00 $1,000.00-$100.000.00 $500.00  
(Code 1977, § 5.76A.140; Code 1990, § 8-1055; Ord. No. 2015-2201, § 8, 3-17-2015) 
Sec. 16-1493. - Reciprocity. 
    If the county or any city located in the county should adopt an ordinance regulating the operation of raffles, licensees who have obtained licenses from such city or county are hereby authorized and allowed to sell, offer for sale, convey, issue or otherwise transfer for value raffle chances within the corporate limits of the city without first obtaining a license pursuant to this division, provided that such city or county has adopted an ordinance, or part thereof, granting reciprocity to the licensee who has been licensed by the city. 
(Code 1977, § 5.76A.150; Code 1990, § 8-1056) 
Secs. 16-1494-16-1519. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 9. - VIDEO GAMING TERMINALS 

Sec. 16-1520. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Licensee means and includes all of the establishments defined in the following definition. 
    Video gaming terminal, licensed establishment, licensed fraternal establishment, licensed veterans establishment, and licensed truck stop establishment shall have the meanings set forth in the Illinois Video Gaming Act (230 ILCS 40/1 et seq.). 
(Code 1990, § 8-1000; Ord. No. 2012-2054, § 2, 5-15-2012) 
Sec. 16-1521. - Imposition of annual fee. 
    Commencing upon adoption of the ordinance from which this division is derived, an annual fee of $25.00, is hereby imposed upon each video gaming terminal operated by a licensed establishment, licensed fraternal establishment, licensed veterans establishment or licensed truck stop establishment within the city in accordance with the provisions of the Illinois Video Gaming Act, 230 ILCS 40/1 et seq. (the "Act"). The fee paid for each video gaming terminal shall be for the fiscal year May 1 through April 30, and any fee paid during a fiscal year shall apply until the end of the fiscal year in which paid. Any continuing operation of a video gaming terminal shall require the payment of a new annual fee on or before May 1 of each year for the ensuing fiscal year. 
(Code 1990, § 8-1101; Ord. No. 2012-2054, § 2, 5-15-2012) 
Sec. 16-1522. - Application for permit. 
    Every licensee shall make application to the city clerk's office for a permit, and shall pay the annual fee for each video gaming terminal operated. The application shall designate the name of the licensee, the location of the licensed establishment operating the video gaming terminal, the number of video gaming terminals operated at that location, and shall include a copy of the license issued by the state for the operation of the video gaming terminal. No permit shall be issued to any person whose video gaming terminal is not licensed by the state for the location for which the permit is sought. 
(Code 1990, § 8-1102; Ord. No. 2012-2054, § 2, 5-15-2012) 
Sec. 16-1523. - Limitations upon placement. 
    No video gaming terminal permit shall be issued to, and no video gaming terminal shall be placed or operated from within, a location that does not also have issued to it a license for the sale of alcoholic beverages at retail by the drink for consumption on the premises. Notwithstanding any greater limit which may from time to time be established by the state legislature, no more than five video gaming terminals shall be allowed, nor permits be issued therefor, under this division for each licensee at any one location. 
(Code 1990, § 8-1103) 
Sec. 16-1524. - Play by minors prohibited; penalties. 
    No person under the age of 21 years shall be permitted to use or play a video gaming terminal, and any licensee who shall suffer or permit a person under the age of 21 years to use or play a video gaming terminal shall be subject to fine or have his or her licenses issued under this division suspended or revoked, after hearing before the mayor acting pursuant to the procedures applicable to hearings held pursuant to the provisions of chapter 1, article II, division 3. 
(Code 1990, § 8-1104; Ord. No. 2012-2054, § 2, 5-15-2012) 
Sec. 16-1525. - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating the provisions of this division by operation of a video gaming terminal without having obtained the permit and paid the annual fee therefor, or by operating a video gaming terminal in violation of any provision of this division, shall be guilty of a petty offense, and shall be fined an amount not to exceed $500.00 for each such offense, and the license or licenses shall be subject to suspension or revocation as herein provided. Each day that a video gaming terminal is operated in violation of this division shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1990, § 8-1105; Ord. No. 2012-2054, § 2, 5-15-2012) 
Sec. 16-1526. - Inspection of records. 
    Each licensee shall permit the inspection of the books and records of the licensee pertaining to and reflecting operation of each video gaming terminal of the licensee at the request of any law enforcement officer of the city or the state at all reasonable times. 
(Code 1990, § 8-1106; Ord. No. 2012-2054, § 2, 5-15-2012)

(c)  Rocket Drive (formerly Grace Avenue) from West 2nd Street to a point of intersection with 11th Avenue shall be closed to all vehicular traffic except school bus traffic for a period of 15 minutes immediately following the close of school on each school day, and such school bus traffic shall be permitted to travel south and west upon Rocket Drive and exit onto West 2nd Street.

Sec. 18-122. - Avenue E at Ada Street-Yield right-of-way.

(Code 1990, § 9-130; Ord. No. 97-1825, § 1, 11-18-1997) 
Sec. 18-123. - Same-Stop intersection. 
    All vehicular traffic entering the intersection of Ada Street and Avenue E at the intersection where Avenue E lies only southward from Ada Street, shall stop before entering the intersection. Appropriate signs shall be erected designating the stop intersection. 
(Code 1990, § 9-131; Ord. No. 97-1825, § 2, 11-18-1997)

ARTICLE VI. - PARKING 

Sec. 18-145. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Compact car means a motor vehicle with a total length of not more than 182 inches, said length measurement to include any and all attachments or appendages to the motor vehicle. 
    Municipal parking lot means an area or real estate, regardless of size, located within the city, fee title to which is owned by the city, or in which the city owns or controls by easement, license or lease the exclusive right to possession, and which is or has been set aside and designated by the city council as an area for the parking or storing of motor vehicles. The term "municipal parking lot" shall not include any street, highway or alley. 
    Municipal parking lot (1) means the parking lot located between 1st Avenue and 2nd Avenue and lying north of the alley dissecting said block, adjacent to the Love light tree. 
    Municipal parking lot (2) means the parking lot located between 2nd Avenue and 3rd Avenue and lying south of the alley dissecting said block, directly behind the post office. 
    Municipal parking lot (3) means the parking lot between 4th Avenue and 5th Avenue and lying south of the right-of-way of West 2nd Street, on the site of the old city complex. 
    Municipal parking lot (4) means the parking lot located between East 2nd Street and East 3rd Street and lying east of the alley bisecting said block. 
    Municipal parking lot (5) means the parking lot located between East 3rd Street and East 4th Street and lying east of the alley bisecting said block off of Avenue A. 
    Municipal parking lot (6) means the parking lot located north of West 1st Street and located south of the Rock River and also known as the Lower Dam Park. 
    Municipal parking lot (7) means the parking lot north of East 2nd Street and located west of the Hennepin Canal and adjacent to the Rock Falls Hydro Electric Plant. 
    Municipal parking lot (8) means the parking lot located on the corner of East 2nd Street and Emmons Avenue and adjacent to the Hennepin Canal at the Arduini Boat Ramp. 
    Municipal parking lot (9) means the parking lot located on the north side of the community youth building and south of West 10th Street at the Public Library. 
    Municipal parking lot (10) means the parking lot located on the south side of the community youth building near city hall and police-fire building and north of West 12th Street. 
(Code 1977, § 10.24.010; Code 1990, § 9-141; Ord. No. 2003-2050, § 1, 6-3-2003; Ord. No. 2009-2320, § 2, 3-3-2009; Ord. No. 2010-2411, § 1, 8-3-2010) 
Sec. 18-146. - Time limits; penalties. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to park any vehicle for a longer period than that designated by the city council by ordinance between the hours designated in such ordinance. Appropriate signs shall be posted. 
(b)  A violation of this article shall be punishable as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1990, § 9-142; Ord. No. 88-1520, 11-7-1988; Ord. No. 98-1838, § I, 4-1-1998; Ord. No. 2001-1982, § 1, 8-8-2001; Ord. No. 2001-1980, § 3, 8-8-2001; Ord. No. 2003-2052, § 1, 6-3-2003; Ord. No. 2010-2421, § 17, 10-5-2010; Ord. No. 2011-2458, § 34, 4-5-2011) 
Sec. 18-147. - Place of payment of penalty. 
    The penalty for any parking violation specified by this article shall be made at the office of the police service, until a criminal complaint shall have been filed with the circuit court of the county, charging a violation of an ordinance of the city. Fines and penalties collected by the police service shall be remitted to the general fund of the city upon collection. 
(Code 1990, § 9-143; Ord. No. 88-1518, 11-7-1988) 
Sec. 18-148. - Parking longer than 48 hours. 
(a)  It is unlawful to park any motor vehicle for a consecutive period of time longer than 48 hours on any street, highway, alley or municipal parking lot within the city. 
(b)  A violation of this section shall be punishable as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1977, § 10.24.020; Code 1990, § 9-144; Ord. No. 2003-2051, § 1, 6-3-2003; Ord. No. 2010-2421, § 18, 10-5-2010) 
Sec. 18-149. - 30-minute areas. 
(a)  Parking on the north side of West 2nd Street from 12th Avenue west for a distance of 110 feet shall be restricted to a period of 30 minutes. 
(b)  A violation of this section shall be punishable as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1977, § 10.24.050; Code 1990, § 9-145; Ord. No. 2010-2421, § 19, 10-5-2010) 
Sec. 18-150. - Three-hour areas. 
(a)  It is unlawful to park any vehicle, whether motor-driven or otherwise, at any time for a period of more than three hours on the following described streets and avenues: 
(1)  The east side of 2nd Avenue from West 2nd Street to 1st Street; 
(2)  The west side of 2nd Avenue from 2nd Street north to 1st Street; 
(3)  The north side of West 2nd Street from the westerly line of 4th Avenue to the easterly line of 5th Avenue; 
(4)  The north side of West 2nd Street from a point 850 feet west of 5th Avenue West to 8th Avenue; 
(5)  Easterly line of 4th Avenue eastward to the easterly line of 3rd Avenue; 
(6)  The North side of West 2nd Street from 1st Avenue to 2nd Avenue; 
(7)  On each side of East 4th Street between the intersection with 1st Avenue and the intersection with Avenue A. 
(b)  Appropriate signs shall be erected designating 90-minute parking areas. 
(Code 1977, § 10.24.110; Code 1990, § 9-147; Ord. No. 85-1433, 12-16-1985; Ord. No. 87-1486, 7-20-1987; Ord. No. 90-1554, 5-21-1990; Ord. No. 92-1620, 7-20-1992; Ord. No. 96-1782, § 1, 7-2-1996; Ord. No. 2003-2049, 6-3-2003; Ord. No. 2010-2421, § 21, 10-5-2010; Ord. No. 2011-2447, § 1, 2-15-2011; Ord. No. 2013-2134, §§ 1, 2, 11-19-2013) 
Sec. 18-151. - Three-hour areas between 8:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. 
    It is unlawful to park any vehicle, whether motor-driven or otherwise, between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. for a period of more than three hours, except on Sundays and holidays, on the following streets: 
(1)  5th Avenue from West 2nd Street southerly to West 3rd Street; 
(2)  The east side of 1st Avenue from the intersection with East 2nd Street southerly to the intersection with East 4th Street; 
(3)  2nd Avenue from West 2nd Street southerly to West 3rd Street; 
(4)  The south side of West 2nd Street from 1st Avenue to 4th Avenue; 
(5)  The south or southerly side of West 2nd Street in the city from the westerly line of the alley running south from West 2nd Street in the block between 6th Avenue and 7th Avenue in the city, westerly to 7th Avenue; 
(6)  The north side of West 2nd Street from 1st Avenue to the easterly line of 4th Avenue except for a space commencing with the extended centerline of 3rd Avenue and thence running eastward a distance of 112 feet for which space there shall be no time limit upon parking, and also except for a space commencing with the east line of 4th Avenue and running thence easterly for four diagonal parking spaces for which there shall be no time limit upon parking; 
(7)  The north side of West 2nd Street from the easterly line of 4th Avenue easterly to the easterly line of 3rd Avenue; 
(8)  On each side of East 3rd Street from Avenue A westward to the point of intersection of the alley running in north-south direction between 1st Avenue and Avenue A; 
(9)  On each side of the center of the southerly most line of parking spaces located within the municipal parking lot (A), which lies between 1st Avenue and 2nd Avenue and is bounded on the north by West 1st Street. 
(Code 1977, § 10.24.120; Code 1990, § 9-148; Ord. No. 85-1434, 12-16-1985; Ord. No. 86-1440, 4-7-1986; Ord. No. 87-1486, 7-20-1987; Ord. No. 96-1781, § 1, 7-2-1996; Ord. No. 98-1857, § 1, 10-20-1998; Ord. No. 2006-2211, § 1, 12-19-2006; Ord. No. 2008-2275, § 1, 6-3-2008; Ord. No. 2010-2421, § 22, 10-5-2010; Ord. No. 2011-2447, § 1, 2-15-2011) 
Sec. 18-152. - Prohibited areas. 
(a)  Generally. At any time it is unlawful to permit any vehicle to stand in any of the following places, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the directions of a police officer or traffic signal: 
(1)  At any place where the standing of a vehicle will reduce the usable width of the roadway for moving traffic to less than 18 feet; 
(2)  On any parkway. 
(b)  Specific locations. Parking is prohibited on the following named streets: 
(1)  The west side of Avenue D from Dixon Avenue south for a distance of 100 feet; 
(2)  The east side of Circle Drive from a point 221.4 feet north of the north line of Dixon Road north for a distance of 25 feet; 
(3)  The south side of Dixon Avenue from a point 106 feet west of the center of Avenue A easterly to the intersection of Avenue A; 
(4)  The north side of East 3rd Street from Wood Avenue east for a distance of 200 feet; 
(5)  The north side of East 3rd Street in the city from 1st Avenue easterly to the alley running northwesterly and southeasterly through Block 11 in the original town (now city); 
(6)  The east side of 11th Avenue between West 2nd Street and LeRoy Avenue; 
(7)  The east side of 5th Avenue from West 6th Street south to West 10th Street; 
(8)  The west side of 5th Avenue from the Intersection of West 7th Street to a point 50 feet north thereof; 
(9)  Along both sides of 1st Avenue (Illinois Route 40) from the intersection with 4th Street southward to the south edge of the bridge across the Illinois-Mississippi Feeder Canal; 
(10)  The west side of 4th Avenue between West 2nd Street and West 1st Street in the city;

Sec. 18-155. - Parking and standing; prohibited and restricted areas between 8:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m.

Parking therein during the hours and times specified in this subsection by any person other than as authorized by the board of education of the Rock Falls Elementary School District shall be prohibited.

(2)  Along each side of Leroy Avenue from the intersection with 11 th Avenue east to the intersection with 10 th Avenue. 
(3)  Along both sides of West 2 nd Street from the intersection with Rocket Drive (formerly Grace Avenue) to the intersection with 11 th Avenue. 
(c)  Violation of this section shall be punishable as provided in Section 1-41. 
(Code 1977, §§ 10.24.155, 10.24.157; Code 1990, § 9-152; Ord. No. 89-1535, 9-18-1989; Ord. No. 90-1564, 9-4-1990; Ord. No. 96-1778, § 2, 5-21-1996; Ord. No. 2009-2318, § 1, 2-3-2009; Ord. Sec. 18-156. - Alleys. 
(a)  No person shall park a vehicle within an alley in such a manner or under such conditions as to leave available less than ten feet of the width of the roadway for the free movement of vehicular traffic and no person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle within an alley in such position as to block the driveway entrance to any abutting property. 
(b)  It is unlawful to park any automobile, truck or other vehicle upon any of the following alleys in the city, with the exception; for purposes of loading or unloading, and shall at no time leave available less than ten feet of the width of the roadway for the free movement of vehicular traffic; and shall at no time exceed a period of 45 minutes. 
(Code 1977, § 10.24.170; Code 1990, § 9-154; Ord. No. 2010-2421, § 27, 10-5-2010; Ord. No. 2014-2170, § 1, 7-15-2014) 
Sec. 18-157. - Rock River Bridge. 
(a)  Automobiles, trucks and other vehicles shall be prohibited from parking along either side of 1st Avenue (Illinois Route 40) between the Rock River Bridge and 2nd Street. 
(b)  A violation of this section shall be punishable as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1977, § 10.24.185; Code 1990, § 9-156; Ord. No. 96-1784, § 1, 7-2-1996; Ord. No. 2010-2421, § 29, 10-5-2010) 
Sec. 18-158. - Snow emergency parking. 
    Following any snowfall of at least two inches and the declaration of a snow emergency by the superintendent of streets, or in his absence from the department, the assistant superintendent, and before the snow emergency is lifted by such individual, it shall be unlawful for any person to obstruct the orderly removal of snow from the city's streets by parking or otherwise leaving unattended any motor vehicle upon: 
(1)  Snow routes. Any street which has been designated as a snow route. The parking restrictions of this subsection shall terminate block by block along such snow route once the accumulated snow has been removed from the full width of the corresponding street. 
(2)  Downtown business parking area. Any street in the downtown business area (as that term is defined in section 18-159) between 2:00 a.m. and 5:00 a.m. 
(3)  Other streets. 
a.  Once a snow emergency has been declared, and until such snow emergency has been lifted, no person shall leave parked or standing any motor vehicle on an even-numbered side of the street in the city on an odd-numbered day of the month, nor shall any such vehicle be parked or standing on an odd-numbered side of the street in the city on an even-numbered day of the month. For purposes of this subsection, the term "day" shall be defined as the hours between 6:00 a.m. and 8:00 p.m. The parking restrictions of this subsection shall terminate block by block along such streets once the accumulated snow has been removed from the full width of the corresponding street. Nothing contained in this subsection shall be construed to permit parking on any streets where parking is otherwise restricted or prohibited. 
1.  West 2nd Street from 5th Avenue to 14th Avenue; 
2.  14th Avenue from West 2nd Street to the township line south of West 21st; 
3.  West 5th Street from 1st Avenue to 15th Avenue; 
4.  West 10th Street from 1st Avenue to 14th Avenue; 
5.  Prophetstown Road from 12th Avenue to Route 30; 
6.  West 19th Street from Route 40 to 14th Avenue; 
7.  12th Avenue from the bridge south to West 24th Street; 
8.  8th Avenue from West 2nd Street south to the end; 
9.  5th Avenue from West 2nd Street south to Route 30; 
10.  Dixon Avenue from 1st Avenue to the city limits; 
11.  East 2nd Street from Emmons to Avenue B; 
12.  Avenue B between East 2nd Street and East 3rd Street; 
13.  East 3rd Street from Avenue E to 1st Avenue; 
14.  Industrial Park Road from U.S. Route 30 to East 10th Street; 
15.  East 10th Street from Industrial Park Road to 1st Avenue; 
16.  Martin to Minkel and over to Lincoln and back; 
17.  Avenue D from Dixon Avenue to East 10th Street; 
18.  Avenue E from Dixon Avenue to East 2nd Street. 
b.  Signs shall be posted on such city streets at or near their points of intersection within the corporate boundaries of the city stating: "Restricted Parking during Snow Emergencies." Calendar parking in effect until snow has been removed from the full width of the street. 
(Code 1977, § 10.24.190; Code 1990, § 9-157; Ord. No. 96-1786, § 1, 7-16-1996; Ord. No. 2009-2324, § 1, 3-17-2009; Ord. No. 2010-2421, § 30, 10-5-2010; Ord. No. 2011-2446(A), 2-15-2011) 
State Law reference- Authority to prohibit parking during snow removal, 65 ILCS 5/11-208(a)(13). 
Sec. 18-159. - Downtown business area parking during snow emergency. 
(a)  Following any snowfall of at least two inches and the declaration of a snow emergency by the superintendent of streets, or in his absence from the department, the assistant superintendent, and before the snow emergency is lifted by such individual, no parking shall be permitted on the following described streets (the "downtown business area") after 2:00 a.m. and before 5:00 a.m.: 
(1)  1st Avenue from the Rock River Bridge south to Dixon Avenue; 
(2)  2nd Avenue from West 1st Street south to the east west alley; 
(3)  3rd Avenue from West 2nd Street south to the east west alley; 
(4)  4th Avenue from West 1st Street south to the east west alley; 
(5)  West 2nd Street from 1st Avenue west to 5th Avenue; 
(6)  East 2nd Street from 1st Avenue east to Avenue A; 
(7)  West 3rd Street from 1st Avenue west to 4th Avenue; 
(8)  East 3rd Street from 1st Avenue east to Avenue A; 
(9)  Avenue A from East 2nd Street to East 3rd Street. 
(b)  Any motor vehicle parked in violation of this section may be towed under order by the police department, and, in addition to payment of the fine defined in subsection (d) of this section, the owner of the vehicle shall pay to the towing agency the towing and storage charges reasonably incurred by such agency before he may regain possession of the vehicle. 
(c)  The police department or the code enforcement officer may issue tickets to the owner of any vehicle parked in violation of this section. 
(d)  A violation of this section shall be punishable as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1977, § 10.24.191; Code 1990, § 9-158; Ord. No. 94-1698, § 1, 1-17-1994; Ord. No. 2007-2222, § 1, 2-20-2007; Ord. No. 2009-2324, § 1, 3-17-2009; Ord. No. 2010-2421, § 31, 10-5-2010) 
Sec. 18-160. - Parallel parking. 
(a)  Autos, trucks and other vehicles on the north side of East 4th Street in the city from 1st Avenue to the alley running northwesterly and southeasterly through Block 14 of the original town (now city), shall be parked only by parallel parking and for a period not to exceed 90 minutes. 
(b)  Autos, trucks and other vehicles on the south side of East 3rd Street from 1st Avenue to the alley running northwesterly and southeasterly through Block 14 of the original town (now city), shall be parked only by parallel parking and for a period of not to exceed two hours. 
(c)  A violation of this section shall be punishable as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1977, § 10.24.220; Code 1990, § 9-159; Ord. No. 96-1783, § 1, 7-2-1996; Ord. No. 2010-2421, § 32, 10-5-2010) 
Sec. 18-161. - Taxicab stands, bus stands. 
(a)  No vehicle other than a licensed taxicab shall be parked in any area designated by ordinance as a cabstand. No vehicle other than a bus shall be parked in an area so designated as a bus-loading zone. 
(b)  A violation of this section shall be punishable as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1977, § 10.24.230; Code 1990, § 9-160; Ord. No. 99-1883, § 1, 5-18-1999; Ord. No. 2001-1990, § 1, 12-4-2001; Ord. No. 2002-2019, § 1, 10-1-2002; Ord. No. 2010-2421, § 33, 10-5-2010) 
Sec. 18-162. - Parking for certain purposes prohibited. 
(a)  It is unlawful to park any vehicle upon any street for the purpose of displaying it for sale, or to park any vehicle upon any business street from which vehicle merchandise is peddled. 
(b)  A violation of this section shall be punishable as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1977, § 10.24.240; Code 1990, § 9-161; Ord. No. 2010-2421, § 34, 10-5-2010) 
Sec. 18-163. - Handicapped parking. 
(a)  A motor vehicle bearing registration plates issued to a person with disabilities or bearing the special decal issued by the secretary of state or other special device, as recognized by section 11-1301.1 of the state vehicle code (625 ILCS 5/11-1301.1), is exempt from any ordinance imposing time limitations on parking, except limitations of one-half-hour or less, but otherwise is subject to the laws which prohibit parking in no-stopping and no-standing zones, in front of or near fire hydrants, driveways, public building entrances and exits, bus stops and loading areas, and is prohibited from parking where the motor vehicle constitutes a traffic hazard, and the motor vehicle shall be moved at the instruction and request of a law enforcement officer to a location designated by the officer. Any motor vehicle bearing registration plates specified in section 11-1301.1 of the state vehicle code (625 ILCS 5/11-1301.1), may park, in addition to any other lawful place, in any parking place specifically reserved by posting of an official sign for such vehicles. Parking privileges granted by this section are strictly limited to the persons to whom the special registration plates or decals were issued, and to qualified operators acting under the express direction of the person with disabilities while that person is present. 
(b)  No person, except those permitted by subsection (a) of this section, shall use any area for the parking of any motor vehicle where such area has been designated as a parking space for persons with disabilities or where an official sign controlling such area expressly prohibits parking at any time or during certain hours. It is the policy of the city that the person in whose name a vehicle is registered with the secretary of state shall be accountable and responsible for the parking of that vehicle in compliance with the ordinances of the city. If any vehicle is determined to be parked in violation of the provisions of this section regulating parking privileges for persons with disabilities, then the police service shall attach to the vehicle a parking ticket, in a form to be established by the chief of police, but which shall contain at least the date and time of violation. The person to whom the vehicle is then registered shall pay a fine as provided in section 1-41. 
(c)  Any motor vehicle not bearing the registration plate, decal or device specified in section 11-1301 of the state vehicle code (625 ILCS 5/11-1301.1) and parked in a designated parking area for persons with disabilities on either private land or public land, shall be subject to being towed and impounded by the police service. Upon the police service receiving notice of such violation of disabilities parking areas, a police officer shall cause any towing service to remove the vehicle to the place of impoundment of vehicles within the city. Thereafter, the vehicle shall be released to the owner only upon payment by the owner of all towing charges, reasonable storage charges and any fine or penalty which may be due as a result of the violation. 
(d)  The following locations are hereby designated as reserved for parking privileges for persons with disabilities and appropriate signs shall be erected designating that the space is restricted to parking for motor vehicles bearing registration plates, decals or devices issued to persons with disabilities pursuant to the provisions of this section: 
(1)  Beginning at the east edge of the driveway serving the residence known as 509 East 4th Street, and extending westerly for a distance of 50 feet. 
(2)  One line adjacent to and on each side of the center of the southerly most line of parking spaces located within the municipal parking lot which lies between 1st Avenue and 2nd Avenue and is bounded on the north by West 1st Street. 
(3)  Upon the east side of 8th Avenue from a point 76 feet south of the intersection of 8th Avenue with West 5th Street to a point 140 feet south of the intersection of 8th Avenue and West 5th Street. 
(4)  Upon the east side of 9th Avenue from a point 142 feet south of the crosswalk at 19th Street in a southerly direction for 40 feet to a point 182 feet south of such crosswalk. 
(5)  Upon the east side of 1st Avenue, North of East 3rd Street, the tenth and eleventh parking spaces. 
(6)  Upon the east side of Galt Avenue from a point 82 feet north of the intersection of Galt Avenue and West 5th Street to a point 167 feet north of the intersection of Galt Avenue and West 5th Street. 
(7)  Upon the East side of 9th Avenue from a point 245 feet south of the intersection of 9th Avenue and Route 30 West to a point 270 feet south of the intersection of 9th Avenue and West Route 30. 
(8)  Upon the East side of Ada Street from a point 65 feet south of the intersection of East 2nd Street and Ada Street to a point 102 feet south of the intersection of East 2nd Street and Ada Street. 
(9)  Upon the south side of West 2nd Street from the intersection with 4th Avenue to a point 95 feet east of the center of the intersection of 4th Avenue and West 2nd Street. 
(10)  Upon the south side of West 2nd Street from the intersection with 2nd Avenue to a point 99 feet west of the center of the intersection of West 2nd Street and 2nd Avenue. 
(Code 1977, § 10.24.260; Code 1990, § 9-163; Ord. No. 86-1454, 9-15-1986; Ord. No. 87-1487, 7-20-1987; Ord. No. 88-1519, 11-7-1988; Ord. No. 89-1522, 1-17-1989; Ord. No. 90-1554, 5-21-1990; Ord. No. 92-1632, 11-16-1992; Ord. No. 96-1801, § 1, 11-5-1996; Ord. No. 2007-2240, § 2, 8-7-2007; Ord. No. 2008-2260, § 1, 1-15-2008; Ord. No. 2008-2282, § 1, 7-1-2008; Ord. No. 2010-2393, § 1, 3-16-2010; Ord. No. 2010-2421, § 35, 10-5-2010; Ord. No. 2015-2192, § 1, 3-3-2015; Ord. No. 2016-2269, § 1, 7-19-2016) 
Sec. 18-164. - Loading zones. 
(a)  During the time specified in this section it is unlawful for the driver of any vehicle to stand a passenger vehicle for a period of time longer than is necessary for the loading or unloading of passengers, not to exceed three minutes and for the driver of any freight-carrying vehicle for a period of time longer than is necessary to load, unload and deliver materials, not to exceed 30 minutes, in any of the following places: 
(1)  In any public alley, during any hour of the day or night; 
(2)  At any place not to exceed 75 feet along the curb before the entrance to any hospital or hotel at any time; 
(3)  At any place not to exceed 75 feet along the curb before the entrance to a public building between 8:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. except on Sunday; 
(4)  Directly in front of the entrance of any theater at any time the theater is open for business. 
(b)  A violation of this section shall be punishable as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1977, § 10.28.010; Code 1990, § 9-164; Ord. No. 2010-2421, § 36, 10-5-2010) 
Sec. 18-165. - Semitrailers; trucks. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Semi-trailer shall have the meaning as set forth in the state vehicle code. 
    Truck shall have the meaning as set forth in the state vehicle code but for purposes of this section, shall exclude trucks with a load capacity of two tons or less. 
(b)  Truck parking prohibited. Trucks and semi-trailers shall not be parked on any street or alley of the city within any zoning district of the city which is zoned for residential use, business or commercial use, or M-1 use, for any period longer than one hour except for the purpose of loading or unloading or for making a delivery or for picking up goods or materials. In addition, no truck or semi-trailer, as defined within this section, shall be parked or stored upon any parcel of real estate zoned for residential, business or commercial or M-1 use within the city for a period of more than 48 consecutive hours, unless the same shall be parked or stored entirely within an enclosed structure or building. Within any B-1, B-2 or M-1 zoning district, a truck or semi-trailer, as defined within this section, may be parked for no more than 12 consecutive hours for loading and unloading or for making a delivery or picking up of goods and materials, unless the truck or semi-trailer shall be owned and operated by the owner or tenant in possession of the parcel of real estate upon which the truck or semi-trailer is located. 
(c)  Penalty. A violation of this section shall be punishable as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1977, § 10.32.010; Code 1990, § 9-165; Ord. No. 92-1613, § 1, 2-3-1992; Ord. No. 2008-2301, § 1, 11-18-2008; Ord. No. 2010-2421, § 37, 10-5-2010) 
Sec. 18-166. - Fire lanes. 
(a)  Parking is hereby prohibited in the following described areas designated as fire zones; but this prohibition shall not apply to the vehicle of any firefighter or volunteer firefighter of the city while such firefighter or volunteer firefighter is responding to and assisting in any emergency fire or rescue call: 
(1)  Within 15 feet of any fire hydrant; 
(2)  On the east side of 7th Avenue from its intersection with West 12th Street northward to the intersection with West 10th Street; 
(b)  Signs shall be erected at the fire lane zones (except fire hydrant locations) designated in this section indicating "NO PARKING-FIRE LANE" and all fire lane zones shall be designated by yellow-painted curbs. 
(c)  A violation of this section shall be punishable as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1990, § 9-166; Ord. No. 90-1561, §§ 1, 2, 7-2-1990; Ord. No. 2001-1980, § 1, 8-8-2001; Ord. No. 2010-2421, § 38, 10-5-2010) 
Sec. 18-167. - Fire lanes on private property. 
(a)  The chief of the fire department of the city shall inspect and examine parking lots of private retail, commercial and industrial facilities within the city, from time to time, and upon such inspection and examination, shall have authority to designate and declare that a portion of such parking lot be a fire lane, as defined within the fire prevention code of the city. 
(b)  When the chief of the fire department determines that it is necessary or appropriate for designation of a fire lane on private property pursuant to this section, he shall prepare a drawing designating the location and dimensions of the fire lane, and shall prepare an order declaring the establishment of the fire lane. A copy of the drawing and order shall be delivered to the owner or person or firm in possession of the real estate where the fire lane is to be located, and a copy of the drawing and order shall be delivered and filed with the office of the clerk and with the office of the director of economic development and administration. A copy of each shall also be delivered to the mayor. 
(c)  Upon establishment of a fire lane on private property pursuant to this section, the owner or person or firm in possession of the real estate shall make the lane in accordance with the fire prevention code of the city, and the director of economic development and administration of the city shall cause to be erected as soon as practicable upon the fire lane a sign denoting the lane and the penalty for parking in violation of the fire lane. 
(d)  Parking shall be prohibited within the dimensions of any fire lane located upon private property, except for parking of the vehicle of any firefighter or volunteer firefighter of the city while such firefighter or volunteer firefighter is responding to an emergency fire or rescue call. 
(e)  A violation of this section shall be punishable as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1990, § 9-167; Ord. No. 93-1646, 2-16-1993; Ord. No. 2010-2421, § 39, 10-5-2010) 
Sec. 18-168. - Resident parking. 
(a)  The following areas and locations are designated and reserved only for parking of vehicles owned by or guests of residents whose homes are located within the designated areas, during the hours as specified; 
(1)  Along both sides of Leroy Avenue between the intersection of 10 th Avenue and 11 th Avenue between the hours of 7:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. Monday through Friday on days when Rock Falls Township High School is in session. 
(2)  Along both sides of West 2 nd Street between the intersection of 11 th Avenue and 12 th Avenue during the hours from 7:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. Monday through Friday on days when Rock Falls Township High School is in session. 
(3)  Along both sides of West 2 nd Street between the intersection of 12 th Avenue and 13 th Avenue during the hours from 7:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. Monday through Friday on days when Rock Falls Township High School is in session. 
(4)  Along both sides of 12 th Avenue between the intersection of West 2 nd Street and West 5 th Street during the hours from 7:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m., Monday through Friday on days when Rock Falls Township High School is in session. 
(5)  Along both sides of 8 th Avenue south of West 19 th Street between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 4:00 p.m. local time Monday through Friday on days when Rock Falls Elementary School District is in session. 
(b)  All persons residing within a resident parking area as delineated within this section shall, in order to be permitted to park during the times and hours as specified, obtain from the police department a decal, tag or sticker, in such form as may be designated by the chief of police, and such decal, tag or sticker shall be affixed or placed within any vehicle for which resident parking privileges are sought so that the same shall be visible through the windows to the outside at all times when the vehicle is to be parked within the resident parking area during the times as restricted. It shall be unlawful for any vehicle other than a vehicle bearing or containing a resident parking decal, tag or sticker to be parked within any resident parking area during the hours and days as restricted by this section. 
(c)  The penalty for violation of this section shall be in accordance with the provisions of subsection 1-41. 
(Code 1990, § 9-168; Ord. No. 2009-2358, § 1, 9-1-2009; Ord. No. 2014-2181, § 1, 11-4-2014; Ord. No. 2017-2332, § 2, 8-16-2017) 
Sec. 18-169. - Construction permit parking areas; designated. 
(a)  The following areas and locations are designated as construction permit parking areas in which vehicles may be parked in accordance with this section, subject to the conditions set forth herein: 
(1)  On both sides of West 2nd Street between the intersection of 5th Avenue and 1st Avenue during the hours from 7:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m., Monday through Friday; 
(2)  On both sides of East 2nd Street between the intersection of 1st Avenue and Wood Avenue during the hours of 7:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m., Monday through Friday; 
(3)  On the East side of 1st Avenue between the intersection of East 2nd Street and East 4th Street during the hours of 7:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m., Monday through Friday. 
(b)  Any contractor or subcontractor performing construction work, for which a building permit has been issued, on a building located adjacent to the areas designated in subsection (a) of this section may apply for and be granted a permit to park during the times and hours specified, said permit being entitled a construction parking permit. Applications shall be made to the building official for the construction parking permit, and shall be granted only to those contractors designated as a contractor or subcontractor employed to perform construction services on the premises where construction is taking place that created the eligibility for the permit. The permit, when issued, shall consist of a decal, tag or sticker, in such form as may from time to time be designated by the chief of the police department. Upon issuance, such decal, tag or sticker shall be affixed or placed within any vehicle while parked within the construction permit parking area in a manner so that it is visible from the outside of the vehicle through the glass. A vehicle, with the construction parking permit displayed, shall be exempt, during the times parked within the construction parking permit area, from the usual and customary time limitations on parking as otherwise applicable by this Code to vehicles while parked within the construction permit parking area. 
(c)  Nothing herein shall be construed or interpreted to grant exemption from the parking time limitations to any vehicle which does not display the proper and duly issued construction parking permit, decal, tag or sticker as otherwise may be applicable in any of the areas designated in subsection (a) of this section. 
(Ord. No. 2014-2151, § 1, 4-1-2014) 
Sec. 18-170. - Fifteen-minute areas. 
(a)  It is unlawful to park any motor vehicle at any time for a period of more than 15 minutes on the following described streets and avenues: 
(1)  On the south side of East 3rd Street between the point of intersection with Avenue A and the alley (running in a north-south direction between 1st Avenue and Avenue A); 
(2)  Along the south side of West 10th Street between a point which is 178 feet east of the centerline of 7th Avenue, and a point which is 214 feet east of the centerline line of 7th Avenue. 
(b)  A violation of this section shall be punishable as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1990, § 9-170; Ord. No. 96-1795, § 1, 9-16-1996; Ord. No. 2001-1976, § 1, 7-3-2001; Ord. No. 2010-2421, § 40, 10-5-2010) 
Sec. 18-171. - Recreational vehicle parking restricted or prohibited. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Recreational vehicle means a recreational vehicle as defined within the state vehicle code, and in addition, the term "recreational vehicle" includes boats, boats with trailers, motor homes, motor coaches, pick-up campers, camping trailers, travel trailers, fifth-wheel trailers, utility trailers, race cars and race car trailers, canoes or kayaks and trailers therefor, tent campers, folding campers, utility trailers, carnival equipment and associated trailers, and all cases, boxes or other containers used to transport or store recreational vehicles or recreational vehicle equipment. 
(b)  Recreational vehicle parking restrictions. No recreational vehicle shall be parked upon any street in a residentially zoned district within the city and shall not be parked or stored off-street within any residentially zoned district unless parked or stored in conformance with one or more of the following: 
(1)  Upon any street for a period not exceeding 24 consecutive hours; 
(2)  Within a fully enclosed structure or building; 
(3)  Outside a fully enclosed structure or building and in a front or side yard of the lot, only upon a paved surface, not parallel to the front property line of the residentially zoned property or lot, and at least ten feet from the front property line of the residentially zoned property, measured from the front property line to the nearest point on the recreational vehicle; 
(4)  Outside a fully enclosed structure or building and in a rear yard, no nearer to the rear lot line than five feet. 
(c)  Requirements applicable to recreational vehicles parked or located within residential areas. Recreational vehicles parked or stored outside an enclosed structure or building shall: 
(1)  Be maintained in good and safe condition at all times so that the same shall be operable in the manner in which it was intended; 
(2)  At all times have the exterior of the recreational vehicle intact and maintained in good order, condition and repair; 
(3)  If such recreational vehicle requires registration and licensing with the state, be so properly registered and licensed and bear license plates that are at all times current; 
(4)  Be owned by the permanent resident of the residence where parked, stored or located; and, 
(5)  At no time be used for permanent residence quarters or for permanent materials storage, except that use for temporary occupancy by a visitor at a residence with the permission of the owner or lawful tenant thereof for a period of no more than 14 consecutive days shall be permitted. 
No recreational vehicle located, parked or stored within a residentially zoned district shall be permanently connected to water, natural gas, electric or sanitary sewer service. The area around and surrounding any parked or stored recreational vehicle within a residentially zoned district shall be kept weed free and free of accumulation of rubbish, garbage or trash. 
(d)  Penalty. A violation of this section shall be punishable as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1990, § 9-175; Ord. No. 2008-2300, § 1, 11-18-2008; Ord. No. 2010-2421, § 41, 10-5-2010) 
Secs. 18-172-18-195. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - TRUCKS GENERALLY 

Sec. 18-196. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Truck means a motor vehicle designed, used or maintained primarily for the transportation of property, but excluding: 
(1)  Those motor vehicles licensed by the state for a gross weight in pounds, including vehicle and maximum load, of 8,000 pounds or less, and bearing a state class B license plate or similar size vehicle as licensed by other states; 
(2)  Motorhomes and mini motor homes; 
(3)  Truck campers; 
(4)  Van campers. 
(Code 1990, § 9-181; Ord. No. 87-1473, § 10.36.010, 6-15-1987) 
State Law reference- Registration of vehicles, 625 ILCS 5/3-400 et seq. 
Sec. 18-197. - Operation on city streets; deliveries, pickups. 
(a)  No person shall drive or operate any truck upon any street in the city where truck traffic is prohibited as defined in this article. Trucks may be operated for the purpose of making a delivery or pickup of property only, provided that such pickup or delivery of property shall be only from the nearest unrestricted street intersecting the point of pickup or delivery. 
(b)  Appropriate signs shall be erected upon streets upon which truck traffic is prohibited to advise drivers or operators of trucks of such restrictions. 
(Code 1990, § 9-182; Ord. No. 87-1473, § 10.36.020, 6-15-1987) 
Sec. 18-198. - Prohibited on certain streets. 
    The operation or driving of any truck is prohibited upon the following streets or locations within the city: 
(1)  East 5th Street; 
(2)  East 6th Street; 
(3)  East 7th Street; 
(4)  East 8th Street; 
(5)  East 9th Street; 
(6)  13th Avenue from U.S. Route 30 South to the city limits;
