(7)  8th Avenue between West 2nd Street and U.S. Route 30; 
(8)  4th Avenue between West 2nd Street and 1st Avenue; 
(9)  11th Street between Avenue A and Avenue D; 
(10)  LeRoy Avenue between Rocket Drive (formerly Grace Avenue) and 8th Avenue; 
(11)  5th Avenue between West 5th Street and West 2nd Street; 
(12)  10th Avenue between West 2nd Street and LeRoy Avenue; 
(13)  7th Avenue South from West 2nd Street to the city limits; 
(14)  10th Street from 1st Avenue west to the city limits; 
(15)  East 2nd Street. 
(Code 1990, § 9-183; Ord. No. 87-1473, § 10.36.030, 6-15-1987; Ord. No. 2011-2484, § 3, 12-6-2011) 
Secs. 18-199-18-219. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - OFF HIGHWAY VEHICLES 

Sec. 18-220. - Low speed vehicles and non-highway vehicles on roadway. 
(a)  Low speed vehicles, as defined in section 1-140.7 of the state vehicle code (625 ILCS 5/1-140.7), and non-highway vehicles, as defined in section 11-1426.1 of the state vehicle code (625 ILCS 5/11-1426.1) shall not be operated upon streets or roadways within the city except in compliance with this article. 
(b)  Signs shall be posted at the point of entry of all roadways and highways entering into the city to read as follows: 
USE OF STREETS PROHIBITED BY LOW SPEED AND 
NON-HIGHWAY VEHICLES WITHOUT CITY PERMIT. 
(c)  When authorized by and pursuant to the provisions of this article, low speed and non-highway vehicles may be operated within the city only in compliance with all traffic rules and regulations established by the state vehicle code or city ordinance, and only those vehicles that comply with the equipment requirements of the state vehicle code may be operated when otherwise authorized pursuant to this article. Nothing herein shall be interpreted or construed to permit a person who does not possess a valid driver's license to operate a low speed or non-highway vehicle. A valid driver's license means a license issued in the name of the operator by the state or a foreign jurisdiction and in force at the time of operation of the vehicle. 
(Code 1990, § 9-200; Ord. No. 2008-2287, § 1, 8-5-2008; Ord. No. 2010-2439, § 1, 1-4-2011; Ord. No. 2014-2149, § 1(9-200), 4-1-2014) 
Sec. 18-221. - Permit for use; authorized applicants. 
(a)  Any governmental unit, governmental agency or organization, not for profit charitable, civic or religious corporation or organization, or fraternal organization, said entities referred to herein as a "qualified applicant", may make application pursuant to the provisions of this section for authority to operate low speed and or non-highway vehicles within the city. 
(b)  Applications for a permit to operate low speed and or non-highway vehicles shall be submitted by a qualified applicant to the office of the city clerk. Each application shall include the following information: 
(1)  The name of the organization and the type of entity (that is, governmental, corporation, charitable, religious, fraternal or other form). 
(2)  Address within the city of the organization and the purpose for which the organization or entity was formed. 
(3)  Name and residence address of the chief administrative officer or official of the organization. 
(4)  Type of vehicle for which a permit is sought. 
(5)  Locations within the city and/or streets or roadways within the city upon which the vehicle is to be operated, and the time period during which the vehicles will be operated. 
(6)  Location at which the vehicles may be inspected. 
(c)  Within two days of submission, each application submitted to the city clerk shall be delivered to the chief of the police department, who shall conduct an investigation into the application, and who shall cause an inspection of the vehicle or vehicles for which permit is sought to be conducted. The inspection conducted by the chief or his designee shall be to ascertain: 
(1)  That the vehicle or vehicles comply with all applicable laws and regulations concerning equipment required to be installed; 
(2)  The name or names of the persons who shall be the operators of the vehicles; 
(3)  That said persons possess the required driver's license; and 
(4)  That the vehicle or vehicles are insured to meet or exceed the requirements of the state vehicle code. 
(d)  The chief, upon completion of the inspection and investigation of proposed drivers shall report his findings to the mayor and city clerk. If the chief of police, following the inspection and investigation, determines that: 
(1)  The vehicle or vehicles possess required equipment; 
(2)  The operator or operators possess the required license; and 
(3)  The locations proposed for operation will not be in violation of any provision of the state vehicle code and will not create a safety hazard to persons within the city; 
the mayor shall direct the city clerk to issue the permit. 
(e)  The mayor may deny issuance of a permit to any organization: 
(1)  If the inspection by the chief of the police department reveals that any required equipment does not exist; 
(2)  That the operators do not possess the required license; 
(3)  That the proposed locations will create a safety hazard or be in violation of the state vehicle code; or 
(4)  That the organization or any of the proposed operators of the vehicles have previously been found to be in violation of the provisions of this article or have previously had a permit issued pursuant to this article revoked. 
(f)  Notice of the denial of an application shall be given in writing by the mayor to the applicant within 30 days of the date of application. A refusal to issue a permit may be appealed by the applicant by filing a request for hearing, to be held pursuant to the provisions of section 18-223. 
(g)  Each permit issued pursuant to this section shall be for a period not to exceed one year, and shall be for a period of less than one year, if the application discloses that the permit is sought for a limited purpose and not for continuous use. Any permit issued for a period of one year shall terminate on April 30 of each year, but may be renewed upon submission by the qualified applicant of certification that he continues to be qualified to receive the permit. Upon any application for renewal, notice shall be given thereof by the city clerk to the chief of police, and the chief, or his designee, may, at the discretion of the chief, inspect the vehicles or investigate the proposed drivers, to the same extent as a new application. 
(h)  No permit shall be issued authorizing the operation of a low speed or non-highway vehicle upon all city streets of the city, but each permit shall specify, with clarity, the exact location or locations within the city where the vehicles may be operated, the time or times of day when the vehicles may be operated (if the chief of police determines that limits should be fixed thereon) and may specify the exact intersection at which the crossing of a state highway is permitted. 
(i)  The inspections to be performed by the chief of the police department shall be completed and report thereon made to the mayor within 14 days of the date when the application is delivered to the chief by the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 2014-2149, § 1(9-201), 4-1-2014) 
Sec. 18-222. - Violations; penalties; revocation. 
(a)  Any person who shall operate, or organization that shall permit the operation of, a low speed or non-highway vehicle in violation of any of the provisions of this article shall be guilty of a Class C violation. 
(b)  A permit issued pursuant to this article may be revoked by the mayor, after notice and a hearing as provided for in section 18-223, for any of the following causes: 
(1)  Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement contained in the application for the permit; 
(2)  Violation by the holder of the permit of provisions of this article or other ordinances of the city relating to the permit, the subject matter of the permit or the operator of the vehicle; 
(3)  Violation by the holder of the permit, or the operator of the vehicle of any provision of this article. 
(Ord. No. 2014-2149, § 1(9-202), 4-1-2014) 
Sec. 18-223. - Appeals procedure. 
(a)  As used herein, the term "appellant" shall refer to the person or organization seeking to appeal a denial of a permit, or to the person or organization seeking to appeal a proposed revocation of a permit. 
(b)  An appeal for refusal to grant a permit must be submitted, in writing, to the mayor, and filed in the office of the city clerk, within ten days following the issuance of the written denial of the application by the mayor. Notice of the date and time of the hearing shall be given in writing by the mayor to the appellant at least five days prior to the scheduled hearing. 
(c)  For any proposed revocation of a permit issued pursuant to this article, notice of hearing on such proposed revocation shall be given, in writing, by the mayor setting forth the grounds for the proposed revocation, and the time and place of the hearing. Such notice shall be sent to the appellant by certified mail, return receipt requested, at the address of the applicant set forth in the application for the permit, and shall be sent at least five days prior to the date set for the hearing. If the appellant requests a continuance of the date of the hearing, the mayor may impose a suspension of the permit pending the final hearing, and the final hearing shall be rescheduled for a date not later than 14 days after the request for continuance. 
(d)  Hearings shall be conducted by the mayor, acting in a judicial manner. At the hearing on a proposed revocation, the city attorney shall present the complaint and shall represent the city to produce evidence sufficient to justify the revocation. On appeal of a denial of a permit, the appellant shall be required to produce evidence to rebut the basis for denial. The appellant in either case shall be allowed counsel and shall have the right to submit evidence and cross examine witnesses. The mayor shall preside and shall render the decision. 
(e)  Within a period not later than 30 days after the conclusion of the hearing, the mayor shall file a written decision, and provide a copy thereof to the appellant, in which he summarizes the evidence and states the reasons for the decision. 
(f)  A person aggrieved by the decision of the mayor in regard to the denial of an application for permit, or in connection with the revocation of a permit, shall have the right to appeal to the ordinance and license committee of the city council. Such appeal shall be taken by filing with the city clerk, within ten days after notice of the denial of the application or revocation of the permit has been issued, a written statement, under oath, setting forth specifically the grounds for appeal. The committee shall thereupon set the time and place for a hearing on such appeal, and notice of such hearing shall be given to the appellant in the same manner as provided in this section. The hearing shall be held at a date not earlier than five days after the notice is given, and may be held at a regularly scheduled meeting of the committee. The decision of the committee on such appeal shall be final. 
(g)  An electronically recorded record of the appeal hearing shall be made by the city. If the appellant requests a transcript of the hearing, the cost of transcription thereof shall be paid for by the appellant. 
(h)  The decision of the committee on any appeal shall be a final administrative ruling, subject to review under the provisions of the state administrative review law (735 ILCS 5/3-101 et seq.), and the time limits for notice of appeal and procedures and standards of review as set forth therein. 
(Ord. No. 2014-2149, § 1(9-230), 4-1-2014) 
Secs. 18-224-18-254. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - VEHICLE IMPOUNDMENT; FEES; BAIL FEE 

Sec. 18-255. - Vehicles subject to seizure and impoundment. 
    A vehicle may be seized and impounded by the city when an arrest of a person is made by a member of the police department and the motor vehicle was used at the time of the arrest for the commission of any of the following violations or offenses: 
(1)  Operation or use of a motor vehicle in the commission of, or in the attempt to commit, an offense for which a motor vehicle may be seized and forfeited pursuant to article 36 of the Criminal Code of 2012 (720 ILCS 5/36-1 et seq.); 
(2)  Driving under the influence of alcohol, another drug or drugs, an intoxicating compound or compounds, or any combination thereof, in violation of 625 ILCS 5/11-501; 
(3)  Operation or use of a motor vehicle in the commission of, or in the attempt to commit, a felony or in violation of the Cannabis Control Act (720 ILCS 550/1 et seq.); 
(4)  Operation or use of a motor vehicle in the commission of, or in the attempt to commit, an offense in violation of the Illinois Controlled Substances Act (720 ILCS 570/100 et seq.); 
(5)  Operation or use of a motor vehicle in the commission of, or in the attempt to commit, an offense in violation of 625 ILCS 5/24-1, 5/24-1.5 or 5/24.3.1; 
(6)  Driving while a driver's license, permit, or privilege to operate a motor vehicle is suspended or revoked pursuant to 625 ILCS 5/6-101; except that vehicles shall not be subjected to seizure or impoundment if the suspension is for an unpaid citation (parking or moving) or due to failure to comply with emission testing; 
(7)  Operation or use of a motor vehicle while soliciting, possessing, or attempting to solicit or possess cannabis or a controlled substance, as defined by the Cannabis Control Act (720 ILCS 550/1 et seq.) or the Illinois Controlled Substances Act (720 ILCS 570/100 et seq.); 
(8)  Operation or use of a motor vehicle with an expired driver's license, in violation of section 6-101 of the state vehicle code, if the period of expiration is greater than one year; 
(9)  Operation or use of a motor vehicle without ever having been issued a driver's license or permit, in violation of 625 ILCS 5/6-101, or operating a motor vehicle without ever having been issued a driver's license or permit due to a person's age; 
(10)  Operation or use of a motor vehicle by a person against whom a warrant has been issued by a circuit clerk in the state for failing to answer charges that the driver violated 625 ILCS 5/6-101, 5/6-303 or 5/11-501; 
(11)  Operation or use of a motor vehicle in the commission of, or in the attempt to commit, an offense in violation of article 16 of the Criminal Code of 2012 (720 ILCS 5/16-1 et seq.); or 
(12)  Operation or use of a motor vehicle in the commission of, or in the attempt to commit, any other felony offense in violation of the Criminal Code of 2012 (720 ILCS 5/1-1 et seq.). 
(Code 1990, § 9-300; Ord. No. 2012-2058, § 1, 6-19-2012) 
Sec. 18-256. - Towing and storage fees. 
    When a vehicle has been seized and/or impounded pursuant to the preceding section or any other law or statute, the owner thereof or the agent of the owner shall be liable to and shall pay and reimburse the city or other person who shall have towed said vehicle for the reasonable fees for such towing, and shall be liable to and pay and reimburse the city or other person for all storage fees for the period of time that said vehicle remains in storage following the seizure and impoundment. 
(Code 1990, § 9-301; Ord. No. 2012-2058, § 1, 6-19-2012) 
Sec. 18-257. - Administrative fee for towed and impounded vehicles; storage fees. 
(a)  The registered owner or the agent or agents of the owner shall be liable to the city for an administrative fee of $100.00 in addition to any and all applicable fines, costs, towing, and storage fees. The administrative fee shall be collected by and paid to the city. Additional towing or storage fees, or both, shall be collected by and paid to the person, firm, or entity that tows or stores the vehicle impounded under this article, or to the city for payment to the appropriate person or entity. The administrative fee provided for in this section shall be waived by the city upon submission of verifiable proof that the vehicle was stolen at the time that the vehicle was impounded. 
(b)  The fee to be paid to the city for storage of an impounded vehicle shall be $20.00 per day (or part thereof). 
(Code 1990, § 9-302; Ord. No. 2012-2058, § 1, 6-19-2012) 
Sec. 18-258. - Procedure for seizure and impoundment of vehicles. 
    Whenever a city police officer reasonably believes that the driver of a motor vehicle has committed an offense as enumerated in section 18-256, the officer may provide for the towing of the motor vehicle to the city impound lot or a city-approved private lot. 
(Code 1990, § 9-303; Ord. No. 2012-2058, § 1, 6-19-2012) 
Sec. 18-259. - Notice and opportunity for hearing. 
(a)  At the time that a motor vehicle is towed pursuant to the provisions of this article, the city shall notify or make a reasonable attempt to notify the owner, lessee, agent or agents, or person identifying himself or herself as the owner or lessee of the vehicle, or any person who is found to be in control of the vehicle at the time of the alleged offense, of the following: 
(1)  The fact of the seizure and of the right of the vehicle owner or the lessee to an administrative hearing. 
(2)  That the seized motor vehicle will remain impounded pending the completion of an administrative hearing, unless the owner or lessee of the vehicle, or a lienholder, posts with the city a bond equal to the administrative fee as set forth in this article and pays all towing and storage charges. 
(b)  The registered owner or lessee of the vehicle and any lienholder of record shall also be provided with a written notice of administrative hearing. The notice shall: 
(1)  Be served upon the owner, lessee, and any lienholder of record either by personal service or by first class mail to the interested party's address as registered with the Secretary of State; 
(2)  Be served upon such interested parties within ten days after impoundment of a vehicle by the city; and 
(3)  Contain a date, time and location of the administrative hearing. 
An initial hearing shall be scheduled and convened no later than 45 days after the date of the mailing of the notice of hearing. 
(c)  All administrative hearings conducted pursuant to this article shall be conducted by a hearing officer who is an attorney and who has been licensed to practice law in the state for a minimum of three years, and may be conducted in accord with the procedures outlined and set forth in article II, division 3 of chapter 1. At the conclusion of the administrative hearing, the hearing officer shall issue a written decision either sustaining or overruling the vehicle impoundment. 
(1)  If the basis for the vehicle impoundment is sustained by the administrative hearing officer, any bond for administrative fee posted to secure the release of the vehicle as set forth below shall be forfeited to the city. 
(2)  Unless the administrative hearing officer overturns the basis for the vehicle impoundment, no vehicle shall be released to the owner, lessee, or lienholder of record until all administrative fees and towing and storage charges are paid. 
(3)  Vehicles not retrieved from the towing facility or storage facility within 35 days after the administrative hearing officer issues a written decision shall be deemed abandoned and may be disposed of in accordance with the provisions of the state vehicle code chapter 4, article II (625 ILCS 5/4-201 et seq.), or as elsewhere provided for in this Code. 
(4)  Unless stayed by a court of competent jurisdiction, any fee imposed under this article which remains unpaid in whole or in part after the expiration of the deadline for seeking judicial review under the administrative review law (735 ILCS 5/3-101 et seq.) may be enforced in the same manner as a judgment entered by a court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Code 1990, § 9-304) 
Sec. 18-260. - Release of vehicle. 
(a)  Motor vehicles seized and impounded under this article shall remain impounded until all costs associated with the towing and storage of the motor vehicle are paid to the police department, and the registered owner, lessee, or lienholder of the vehicle remits the administrative fee to the city police department. The city police department shall have the right to hold the vehicle until the costs associated with towing, storage, and the administrative fee have been paid in full or until the motor vehicle is released as a result of the administrative review process, or as otherwise provided in this article. 
(b)  All fees and costs collected by the police department pursuant to this article shall be promptly remitted to the city treasurer for deposit into a fund specifically identified as to the source thereof, to be utilized in accord with the direction and appropriation by the city council in accordance with law. 
(Code 1990, § 9-305; Ord. No. 2012-2058, § 1, 6-19-2012) 
Sec. 18-261. - Administrative review. 
    All final decisions of the administrative hearing officer under section 18-259 shall be subject to review under the provisions of the administrative review law (735 ILCS 5/3-101 et seq.). 
(Code 1990, § 9-306; Ord. No. 2012-2058, § 1, 6-19-2012) 
Sec. 18-262. - Bail processing fee. 
    Any person arrested by a member of the police department for any violation of a bailable municipal ordinance or state or federal law shall be liable to and shall pay a bail processing fee to the city, through the police department, in the amount of $20.00 at the time of posting the bail, in addition to any amount of bail required for release following the arrest. 
(Code 1990, § 9-307; Ord. No. 2012-2058, § 1, 6-19-2012) 
Secs. 18-263-18-269. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - TOW ROTATION LIST 

Sec. 18-270. - Tow rotation list. 
    The chief of police is and shall be authorized to maintain a tow rotation list for towing services to be used by the police department and other city departments, when necessary to tow any vehicle within the city or within the jurisdictional area covered by the city police department or any other city department. 
(Ord. No. 2016-2250, § 1, 3-15-2016) 
Sec. 18-271. - Qualifications for tow rotation list. 
(a)  Any towing service provider operating within the city may submit an application for inclusion on the city tow rotation list on an application form prescribed by the chief of police, for review and consideration by the chief of police. The application shall be accompanied by a $75.00 non-refundable application fee, to defray the city's costs in processing the application and conducting all necessary investigations and verifications to determine the suitability of the applicant for inclusion on the tow rotation list. Applicants shall be required to comply with the following requirements: 
(1)  All towing service providers listed on the tow rotation list shall be required to maintain the following insurance; 
a.  Comprehensive automobile liability insurance with a minimum combined single limit coverage of $1,000,000.00; 
b.  Commercial general liability insurance with limits of not less than $1,000,000.00 per occurrence, $100,000.00 minimum garage keeper's legal liability insurance, and $100,000.00 minimum on-hook coverage or cargo insurance; and 
c.  A workers compensation policy covering every person operating a tow truck on behalf of the towing service provider, if required under current law. 
(2)  The towing service provider may utilize only vehicles, that possess a valid vehicle registration, display valid Illinois license plates, and that comply with the weight requirements of the Illinois Vehicle Code; 
(3)  All persons operating a towing or recovery vehicle on behalf of the towing service provider must have completed a traffic incident management training program approved by the state department of transportation; 
(4)  Every towing service provider must hold a valid authority issued to it by the state commerce commission; 
(5)  Every person operating a vehicle on behalf of the towing service provider must be licensed for the type of towing operation he or she shall be performing and the vehicle he or she shall be operating; 
(6)  Every owner of a towing service provider and each person operating a vehicle on behalf of the towing service shall submit his or her fingerprints to the department of state police in the form and manner prescribed by the department of state police for purposes of conducting a criminal history record check; 
(7)  The following persons are disqualified from owning a towing service provider or operating a vehicle on behalf of a towing service provider included on the city's tow rotation list, if such owner or operator has been convicted, during the five years preceding the application, of a criminal offense involving one or more of the following: 
a.  Bodily injury or attempted to inflict bodily injury to another person; 
b.  Theft of property or attempted theft of property; or 
c.  Sexual assault or attempted sexual assault of any kind. 
(8)  The towing service provider shall possess a secure parking lot used for short-term vehicle storage after a vehicle is towed that is open during business hours and is equipped with security features as required by the police department; 
(9)  The towing service provider shall otherwise comply with all other applicable federal, state, and local laws. 
(Ord. No. 2016-2250, § 1, 3-15-2016) 
Sec. 18-272. - Review of tow rotation. 
    The chief of police shall review the tow rotation list on an annual basis. The chief of police may suspend or remove any company from the tow rotation list in his or her sole discretion based upon the performance of the company, compliance with the qualifications set forth in section 18-271, or other factors he or she deems appropriate. Complaints regarding the process for inclusion on or exclusion from the city's tow rotation list shall be submitted in writing to the chief of police. The chief of police shall make the final determination as to which towing service provides shall be included or excluded, and shall not be held liable for the exclusion of any towing service provider from the tow rotation list. 
(Ord. No. 2016-2250, § 1, 3-15-2016) 
Sec. 18-273. - Update of documentation. 
    Towing service providers listed on the tow rotation list shall periodically, upon request by the chief of police, provide updated documentation to demonstrate compliance with the qualifications required under section 18-271. 
(Ord. No. 2016-2250, § 1, 3-15-2016) 
Sec. 18-274. - Fees for city-owned vehicle towing services. 
    For tows of city vehicles, the charge to the city shall not exceed $50.00 per such tow. 
(Ord. No. 2016-2250, § 1, 3-15-2016) 
Sec. 18-275. - Fees for unclaimed vehicles. 
    With respect to unclaimed vehicles which are sold, and the towing service provider is unpaid for such tow, payment to the towing service provider shall be governed by 625 ILCS 5/4-204(c). 
(Ord. No. 2016-2250, § 1, 3-15-2016) 
Chapter 19 - RESERVED 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 20-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Nuisance means any person doing an unlawful act, or omitting to perform a duty, or suffering or permitting any condition or thing to be or exist, which act, omission, condition or thing: 
(1)  Injures or endangers the comfort, repose, health or safety of others; 
(2)  Offends decency; 
(3)  Is offensive to the senses; 
(4)  Unlawfully interferes with, obstructs or tends to obstruct or renders dangerous for passage any public or private street, highway, sidewalk, stream, ditch or drainage; 
(5)  In any way renders other persons insecure in life or the use of property; or 
(6)  Essentially interferes with the comfortable enjoyment of life and property, or tends to depreciate the value of the property of others. 
(Code 1990, § 10-86; Ord. No. 88-1509, § 8.56.010, 7-5-1988) 
Sec. 20-2. - Illustrative enumeration. 
(a)  The maintaining, using, placing, depositing, leaving or permitting to be or remain on any public or private property of any of the following items, conditions or actions is hereby declared to be and constitute a nuisance; provided, however, this enumeration shall not be deemed or construed to be conclusive, limiting or restrictive: 
(1)  Any accumulation of rubbish, trash, refuse, junk and other abandoned materials, metals, lumber or other things; 
(2)  Any condition which provides harborage for rats, mice, snakes and other vermin; 
(3)  Any building or other structure which is in such a dilapidated condition that it is unfit for human habitation, or kept in such an unsanitary condition that it is a menace to the health of people residing in the vicinity thereof, or presents a more than ordinarily dangerous fire hazard in the vicinity where it is located; 
(4)  All unnecessary or unauthorized noises and annoying vibrations, including animal noises; 
(5)  All disagreeable or obnoxious odors and stenches, as well as the conditions, substances or other causes which give rise to the emission or generation of such odors and stenches, which shall include, without limitation, the emission or generation of such odors and stenches as a result of the running of an engine on a parked or stationary motor vehicle (while not located within the traveled vein of any public street or roadway) for a period of time in excess of ten minutes during the period from April 1 to October 1 of any year; 
(6)  The carcasses of animals or fowl not disposed of within a reasonable time after death; 
(7)  The pollution of any public well or cistern, stream, lake, canal or body of water by any sewage, dead animal, creamery, industrial waste or other substances; 
(8)  Any building, structure or other place or location where any activity in violation of local, state or federal law is conducted, performed or maintained; 
(9)  Any accumulation of stagnant water permitted or maintained on any lot or piece of ground; 
(10)  Dense smoke, noxious fumes, gas, soot or cinders, in unreasonable quantities; 
(11)  A motor vehicle not currently licensed by this state or any other state or country exposed to the view of the general public and not either enclosed in a building or structure or located on a sales lot of a licensed automobile dealer; 
(12)  Any pickup truck bed topper, structure designed as camper top to be placed on a pickup truck bed, tool chests or other equipment designed to be attached to the bed of any pickup truck exposed to the view of the general public and not either enclosed in a building or structure or located or stored within a front yard of the premises (as the term "front yard" is defined within chapter 34). 
(b)  A violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class C violation as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1990, § 10-87; Ord. No. 88-1509, § 8.56.020, 7-5-1988; Ord. No. 93-1687, § 1, 11-1-1993; Ord. No. 2010-2421, § 43, 10-5-2010) 
Sec. 20-3. - Prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to cause, permit, maintain or allow the creation or maintenance of a nuisance. 
(Code 1990, § 10-88; Ord. No. 88-1509, § 8.56.070, 7-5-1988) 
Sec. 20-4. - Notice to abate. 
    Whenever a nuisance is found to exist within the city, the mayor or some other duly designated official of the city shall give five days' written notice to the owner or occupant of the property upon which such nuisance exists or to the person causing or maintaining the nuisance. 
(Code 1990, § 10-93; Ord. No. 88-1509, § 8.56.080, 7-5-1988) 
Sec. 20-5. - Contents of notice. 
    The notice to abate a nuisance issued under the provisions of this article shall contain: 
(1)  An order to abate the nuisance or to request a hearing within a stated time, which shall be reasonable under the circumstances; 
(2)  The location of the nuisance, if the same is stationary; 
(3)  A description of what constitutes the nuisance; 
(4)  A statement of acts necessary to abate the nuisance; 
(5)  A statement that if the nuisance is not abated as directed and no request for hearing is made within the prescribed time, the city will abate such nuisance and assess the cost thereof against such person. 
(Code 1990, § 10-94; Ord. No. 88-1509, § 8.56.090, 7-5-1988) 
Sec. 20-6. - Service of notice. 
    The notice to abate a nuisance shall be served by the chief of police, by the building official or by any agent duly authorized or appointed by either of such persons. 
(Code 1990, § 10-95; Ord. No. 88-1509, § 8.56.100, 7-5-1988) 
Sec. 20-7. - Abatement by city-Generally. 
    Upon the failure of the person upon whom notice to abate a nuisance was served pursuant to the provisions of this article to abate the same, the chief of police or the building official with concurrence of the mayor shall proceed to abate such nuisance and shall prepare a statement of costs incurred in the abatement thereof. 
(Code 1990, § 10-96; Ord. No. 88-1509, § 8.56.110, 7-5-1988) 
Sec. 20-8. - Same-Emergency. 
    When, in the opinion of the chief of police, building official or other duly designated official, there is an actual and immediate danger to the public or occupants of particular premises caused by a nuisance on such premises, the chief of police or building official, with concurrence of the mayor, without any notice or hearing, may order and require such premises to be vacated. The chief of police, building official or other duly designated official shall immediately post the premises, warning of the dangerous condition, and shall then abate such nuisance and prepare a statement of costs incurred in the abatement thereof. 
(Code 1990, § 10-97; Ord. No. 88-1509, § 8.56.120, 7-5-1988) 
Sec. 20-9. - City's costs declared lien; collection as taxes. 
(a)  Any and all costs incurred by the city in the abatement of a nuisance under the provisions of this article shall constitute a lien against the property upon which such nuisance existed and for the abatement or removal for which the city incurred costs or expenses for such abatement or removal, and such lien shall be perfected pursuant to the provisions of section 20-11. 
(b)  The owner or party in interest in whose name the property appears upon the last local tax assessment records shall be notified of the amount of such cost by first-class mail at the address shown on the records. If such owner or party in interest fails to pay the same within 30 days after such mailing, the assessor shall add such cost to the next tax roll of the city and the same shall be collected in the same manner in all respects as provided by law for the collection of taxes. 
(Code 1990, § 10-98; Ord. No. 88-1509, § 8.56.130, 7-5-1988; Ord. No. 2013-2103, § 2, 5-7-2013) 
Sec. 20-10. - Refuse collection in certain areas; hours restricted. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person engaged in the business of or providing the service of collecting refuse, trash or garbage to collect or pick up refuse, trash or garbage in any residentially zoned district within the city or any commercially zoned district that lies within one-half block of any residentially zoned district of the city, between the hours of 8:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. 
(Code 1990, § 10-99; Ord. No. 88-1509, § 8.56.140, 7-5-1988; Ord. No. 2013-2123, § 1, 10-1-2013) 
Sec. 20-11. - Costs of removal of nuisances; lien; notice to property owners. 
    In any case where the city incurs a removal cost for the removal or abatement of a nuisance under this chapter, for which the city is entitled to claim a lien for that removal or abatement cost pursuant to the provisions of 65 ILCS 5/11-20-15, then the following procedure shall apply: 
(1)  As soon as practicable following completion of the abatement or removal activities, the city administrator shall cause notice of the removal costs to be served upon the person to whom was sent the tax bill for general taxes on the property at which the removal activity occurred for the taxable year immediately preceding the removal activities. The notice shall be delivered personally, or sent by certified mail to the address of whom the general taxes were mailed for the taxable year immediately preceding the removal activities, and the notice shall state: 
a.  The substance of section 11-20-15 of the Illinois Municipal Code; 
b.  The substance of this article; 
c.  Identification of the underlying parcel upon which the removal activities occurred, by common description and street address, if known; and 
d.  The removal or abatement activity conducted and the costs incurred thereby. 
(2)  Within one year after the removal or abatement cost has been incurred, and after service of the notice referred to in subsection (1) of this section, the city administrator shall cause a notice of lien to be filed in the county office of the recorder, said notice to consist of a sworn statement setting out: 
a.  A description of the underlying parcel that sufficiently identifies the parcel upon which the removal or abatement activity occurred to qualify the notice for recording; 
b.  The amount of the removal or abatement cost incurred; and 
c.  The date or dates when the removal abatement cost was incurred by the municipality. 
If more than one removal or abatement activity or on more than one occasion removal or abatement activity was undertaken during the course of a one-year period, the notice of lien to be filed pursuant to this section for the total costs of all such activities may be combined into a single notice. 
(Code 1990, § 10-100; Ord. No. 2013-2103, § 1, 5-7-2013) 
Secs. 20-12-20-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - WEEDS, ETC.[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Weed abatement, 65 ILCS 5/11-20-6 et seq. 

Sec. 20-41. - Penalties. 
    In addition to other costs or other penalties, any person violating any provision of this article shall be fined not less than $50.00 nor more than $100.00 for each such violation. Each separate day on which a violation occurs shall be deemed a separate offense under this article. 
(Code 1977, § 8.64.060; Code 1990, § 10-116; Ord. No. 2004-2102A, § 1, 8-17-2001) 
Sec. 20-42. - Weeds, trees and bushes declared a nuisance. 
(a)  The following are hereby declared to be a nuisance within the city: 
(1)  Any weeds such as jimson, burdock, ragweed, thistle, cocklebur or other weeds of a like kind, growing in or on any lot or tract of land in the city; 
(2)  Trees, bushes or shrubs involuntarily growing within or along a property line dividing two separate lots or tracts of land in the city. For purposes of this subsection (2), the term "involuntary" means a tree, bush or shrub which was not intentionally planted by the owner of one of the lots adjoining the property line for use as ornament or shade. 
(b)  Any of the nuisances as enumerated in this section, shall be abated by the owner of the lots upon which such nuisance exists, and upon failure of the owner or owners to so abate, the provisions of section 20-46 or 20-47 shall apply. Any costs incurred by the city in the trimming or removal of any nuisance plant may be the subject of a lien upon the property of the owner of the lot upon which the nuisance plant existed, pursuant to the provisions of section 11-20-7 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/11-20-7). 
(c)  A violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class C violation as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1977, § 8.64.010; Code 1990, § 10-117; Ord. No. 2009-2322, § 1, 3-17-2009; Ord. No. 2010-2421, § 44, 10-5-2010) 
Sec. 20-43. - Barberry bushes declared a nuisance. 
    It shall be a nuisance and unlawful to plant or permit the growth of the bush of the species of tall, common or European barberry, further known as Berberis vulgaris, or its horticultural varieties within the city. 
(Code 1977, § 8.64.020; Code 1990, § 10-118) 
Sec. 20-44. - Prohibition. 
    No owner of or other person occupying any lot, place or area within the city, and including the parkway located between the sidewalk or property line and the improved and traveled portion of the public way adjacent to any lot, place or area within the city, shall permit any grass, weeds or other unhealthful or noxious growth to grow or stand to a height exceeding eight inches anywhere on such lot, place area or parkway. 
(Code 1990, § 10-119; Ord. No. 88-1509, § 8.56.210, 7-5-1988) 
Sec. 20-45. - Additional height restrictions. 
    It is unlawful for anyone to permit any weeds, grass or plants, other than trees, bushes, flowers or other ornamental plants, to grow to a height exceeding eight inches within the city, except as permitted by the provisions of section 20-48. Any such plants or weeds exceeding such height are hereby declared to be a nuisance. 
(Code 1977, § 8.64.030; Code 1990, § 10-120; Ord. No. 2011-2465, § 1, 6-21-2011) 
Sec. 20-46. - Notice to destroy. 
(a)  The chief of police or the building official is hereby authorized and empowered to notify, in writing, the owner of any lot, place or area within the city, or the agent of such owner, to cut or destroy any weeds or unhealthful or noxious growths found growing or standing on such owner's property. Such notice may be delivered to such owner or agent personally or such notice may be mailed to such owner or agent at his last known address. 
(b)  The person so served with a notice shall abate the nuisance within five days after service of the notice. 
(Code 1977, § 8.64.050; Code 1990, § 10-121; Ord. No. 88-1509, 7-5-1988) 
Sec. 20-47. - Failure to comply with notice. 
(a)  Upon the failure, neglect or refusal of any owner or the agent of any owner of any such lot who has been notified under section 20-46(a) to cut or destroy such weeds or unhealthful or noxious growths growing or standing upon such owner's property within five days after service of such notice, the city administrator or building official is directed to employ the necessary persons to cut or destroy such weeds or unhealthful or noxious growths. The costs of the cutting, destruction or removal of such weeds, or unhealthful or noxious growths shall be and constitute a lien against the property upon which such weeds or noxious growths occurred, and the city administrator shall perfect the lien in accordance with the requirements of section 20-11. 
(b)  Annually, at least 30 days prior to the end of each fiscal year of the city, the city clerk shall compile a list of all liens filed pursuant to subsection (a) of this section, and present such list to the finance committee of the city council for review. The finance committee shall review the liens which have been filed during the preceding year, and which remain unpaid. The finance committee shall then recommend whether any such liens previously filed be renewed by refiling, or be permitted to terminate, and shall direct the city clerk to refile for renewal those liens which the finance committee determines to be viable for collection. 
(Code 1990, § 10-122; Ord. No. 88-1509, § 8.56.230, 7-5-1988; Ord. No. 2007-2247, § 1, 8-21-2007; Ord. No. 2013-2103, § 3, 5-7-2013) 
Sec. 20-48. - Prairie grass plots; authorization; regulation thereof. 
(a)  Purpose. This section is enacted in order to encourage the regulated development of prairie grass plots within the corporate limits of the city while ensuring the aesthetic, safety, and environmental integrity of adjoining properties. 
(b)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Burning means reduction by fire of prairie grass in a manner wholly consistent with the terms of the IDNR Acres for Wildlife Program. 
    IDNR means the Illinois Department of Natural Resources. 
    Noxious weeds means plants such as jimson, burdock, ragweed, thistle, cocklebur, milkweed or other similar plants involuntarily growing. 
    Prairie grass means any of four species of grasses identified by the state department of natural resources Acres for Wildlife Program as follows: 
(1)  Big bluestem (Andropogon gerardii); 
(2)  Little bluestem (Schizachyrium scoparius); 
(3)  Sideoats grama (Bouteloua curtipendula); 
(4)  Indiangrass (Sorghastrum nutans). 
    Setback means a space between prairie grass plots and adjoining land or properties intended to reduce the impact of a prairie grass plot on the adjacent properties. 
(c)  Development permits. 
(1)  Persons wishing to establish prairie grass plots within the corporate limits of the city shall submit to the building department, at least 30 days in advance of conditional approval, a written plan including drawings, illustrations, grass seed mix, flower seed mix and maps showing the proposed prairie grass plot in relation to adjoining properties and structures. 
(2)  Upon approval of a submitted plan, the city will issue conditional permission to proceed with planning to the proposing property owner. The proposing property owner shall then be required to seek and gain acceptance into the state department of natural resources Acres for Wildlife program. Upon submission to the city of a copy of the letter of acceptance into that program, final permission will be granted by issuance of a permit by the building official. Neither construction, tillage, nor any other physical amendment to the property proposed for development of the prairie grass plot shall occur before issuance of a permit. 
(3)  Upon issuance of final approval, only the property involved in the prairie grass plot shall be exempt from those municipal ordinances regulating the height of grasses. All setback areas shall remain subject to and comply with those municipal ordinances regulating the height of grasses. 
(d)  Composition. Prairie grass plots shall be planted only with the four species of grasses described in subsection (b) of this section. Efforts toward maintenance, care, and propagation of vegetation in the designated plot areas shall be directed toward the successful growth of those species only. A minimum prairie grass mix of five pounds per acre to include a mix of prairie flowers as identified by the state department of natural resources shall be sowed as the initial planting within the plot. 
(e)  Setbacks. Any lot or parcel for which a permit is granted must have a buffer setback area, within which the grass and vegetative material are maintained to a height of eight inches or less. The buffer setback areas shall be: 
(1)  40 feet from any building structure; 
(2)  20 feet from the front property line; 
(3)  20 feet from any side property line; 
(4)  Ten feet from rear property lines and from all driveways and entrances to the property; 
(5)  20 feet from all utility poles, utility boxes, fire hydrants or other utility or service facilities or equipment. 
(f)  Minimum plot size. Prairie grass plots within the corporate limits of the city shall be no less than one acre in size in M-1 and M-2 zoning districts, and three acres in R-2, R-3, R-4 districts. Those areas of a property included in setbacks shall not be included in the calculation of the minimum plot size. Prairie grass plots shall not be permitted in any R-1, B-1 or B-2 district. 
(g)  Burning. Burning of prairie grass plots shall be as deemed necessary for the health of the prairie and shall be in accordance with the following regulations: 
(1)  Adjoining neighbors within 300 feet of the plot should be notified in writing at least seven days in advance of the intent to burn; 
(2)  Burning shall commence only with approval for the day of burning by a full time member of the fire department, with consideration given to atmospheric, environmental and climatic conditions such as wind, wind direction, proximity of adjoining structures and other conditions that might unreasonably increase the hazard from plot burning. 
(h)  Liability. The property owner shall bear full liability and responsibility for any damage, losses, or other burdens as a result of the prairie grass burning. 
(i)  Maintenance. All plots of prairie grass permitted by the city council shall remain enrolled in and in good standing with the Acres for Wildlife program with the state department of natural resources, and must comply with all guidelines established by that program, all of which guidelines are hereby adopted by reference into this section. All plots of prairie grass shall be kept free of involuntary or voluntary trees and shrubs, and of all weeds, including noxious weeds. Notwithstanding other provisions hereof, ornamental grasses shall be permitted to be grown within 20 feet of the perimeter of any water retention or detention facility in any zoning classification. 
(Code 1990, § 10-123; Ord. No. 2011-2465, § 2, 6-21-2011; Ord. No. 2013-2127, § 1, 9-17-2013; Ord. No. 2016-2248, § 2, 1-5-2016) 
Secs. 20-49-20-69. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - GARBAGE; DEBRIS; GRAFFITI 

Sec. 20-70. - Garbage, debris and graffiti; nuisance declared. 
(a)  The accumulation of garbage and debris, or the allowance of graffiti to be sprayed or painted upon any parcel of private property within the city, outside of any building thereon, is hereby declared to be a nuisance. The city administrator or his designee shall cause notice of the accumulation of garbage or debris, or the allowance of graffiti upon any parcel of private property to be given, by personal delivery, or by certified mail addressed to the person to whom was sent the tax bill for the general taxes on the property for the taxable year immediately preceding the notice, and such notice shall include a demand that the garbage and debris, or graffiti, be removed from the parcel of property, shall contain a common description of the property, or the street address, if known and shall state that unless the garbage or debris or graffiti is removed within ten days following receipt of the notice, that the city shall enter upon the property for the purpose of removal of such garbage, debris or graffiti. If the owner fails or refuses to remove the garbage, debris or graffiti within ten days following receipt of the notice, then the city administrator may cause entry upon the property to be made for the removal of such garbage, debris or graffiti. 
(b)  The owner of the parcel from which the garbage or debris was removed shall pay to the city the cost incurred by the city for the removal of the garbage or debris from the parcel, but not for the removal of graffiti. Upon failure of the owner to make payment for the cost of such removal, the city administrator shall cause a lien to be filed against the parcel, such lien to be perfected pursuant to the provisions of section 20-11. 
(Code 1990, § 10-130; Ord. No. 2013-2101, § 1, 5-7-2013) 
Secs. 20-71-20-98. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - DUTCH ELM DISEASE; EMERALD ASH BORER; ELM BARK BEETLES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Dutch elm disease, 65 ILCS 5/11-20-11 et seq. 

Sec. 20-99. - Removal of infected trees-Owners' responsibilities. 
(a)  All species and varieties of elm trees (trees of genus ulums) infected with the fungus known as "Dutch Elm Disease" (Ceratostomella ulmi), or any ash tree infected with emerald ash borer (Argrilus planipennis Fairmaire), as determined by the city administrator or his designee, are hereby declared to be a public nuisance. Upon a determination of the infection of any such trees by the city administrator, notice shall be given to the owner of the parcel of real estate upon which such tree or trees are located, with such notice to advise the owner that the owner is required, pursuant to this article, to cause said trees to be removed within 30 days. Notice shall be given by personal delivery to the owner of the parcel of real estate, or by mailing to the person to whom was sent the tax bill for the general taxes on the property for the taxable year immediately preceding the notice and to the owner to the address of the parcel of real estate. It is unlawful for any person, being the owner of the parcel of real estate upon which an infected tree is located, to possess or keep such a tree after the expiration of the 30-day period following the notification pursuant to this section. 
(b)  All species and varieties of ash or elm trees that are dead or substantially dead, or which contain parts thereof which, because of the condition or location, may serve as a breeding place for the European elm bark beetle (Scolytus multistriatus), the native elm bark beetle (Hylurgopinus rufipes) and the emerald ash borer (Argrilus planipennis Fairmaire) are hereby declared to be public nuisances, subject to abatement as provided for within this article. 
(Code 1977, § 8.68.010; Code 1990, § 10-141; Ord. No. 2013-2102, § 2, 5-7-2013) 
Sec. 20-100. - Same-Performed by city upon failure of owner; creation of lien. 
    Upon the failure of any owner or owners of property referred to in section 20-99 to remove an infected tree or trees following notice given as required therein, and after the expiration of 30 days following the giving of such notice, the city may enter upon the property or premises of the owner and remove the infected tree or trees, or cause the same to be removed, and the reasonable cost incurred or expended by the city for such removal shall be paid and reimbursed to the city by the owner of the parcel or property from which the infected tree was removed. Upon failure of the owner to reimburse, the reasonable cost incurred or paid by the city for such removal shall be and constitute a lien upon the parcel of real estate upon which the tree was removed, and such lien shall be perfected in accordance with the provisions of section 20-11. 
(Code 1977, § 8.68.020; Code 1990, § 10-142; Ord. No. 2013-2102, § 3, 5-7-2013) 
Sec. 20-101. - Contents of notice of lien. 
    The notice of lien referred to in section 20-100 shall consist of a sworn statement setting out a description of the real estate sufficient for identification thereof; the amount of money representing the cost and expense incurred or payable for the service; and the date or dates when such cost and expense was incurred by the city. 
(Code 1977, § 8.68.030; Code 1990, § 10-143) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/11-20-12. 
Secs. 20-102-20-130. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - INOPERABLE MOTOR VEHICLES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Abandoned, lost, stolen or unclaimed vehicles, 625 ILCS 5/4-201 et seq., 65 ILCS 5/11-40-3. 

Sec. 20-131. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Inoperable motor vehicle means: 
(1)  Any motor vehicle from which, for a period of at least seven days, the engine, wheels or other parts have been removed, or on which the engine, wheels or other parts have been altered, damaged or otherwise so treated or are in a condition that the vehicle is incapable of being driven under its own motor power; or 
(2)  Which is not currently registered or licensed by this state or another state or country so that it may be lawfully operated on a highway. 
(Code 1977, § 8.40.010; Code 1990, § 10-161; Ord. No. 2015-2216, § 1, 7-7-2015) 
Sec. 20-132. - Violation; penalty. 
    Any person who fails to comply with a notice to dispose of or remove inoperable motor vehicle, as described in this article, shall be guilty of a Class C offense punishable as provided in section 1-41, or, if charged with an ordinance violation in the county circuit court, shall be adjudged guilty of a petty offense, and may be fined upon conviction thereof an amount not less than $50.00 nor more than $750.00. Each separate day on which a violation occurs shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Code 1977, § 8.40.050; Code 1990, § 10-162; Ord. No. 2015-2216, § 2, 7-7-2015) 
Sec. 20-133. - Applicability. 
    Nothing in this article shall apply to any motor vehicle which: 
(1)  Is kept within a building when not in use; 
(2)  Which is an operable historic motor vehicle over 25 years of age; 
(3)  On the premises of a place of business which is a conforming use within the zoning district where located, and which business is engaged in the wrecking or junking of motor vehicles; or, 
(4)  Has been rendered temporarily incapable of being driven under its own motor power in order to perform ordinary service or repair operations. 
(Code 1977, § 8.40; Code 1990, § 10-163; Ord. No. 2008-2307, § 1, 12-16-2008) 
Sec. 20-134. - Declaration of nuisance; abatement notice. 
    All inoperable motor vehicles, whether on public or private property and in view of the general public, either from ground level or from the second story window of an adjacent property are declared to be a nuisance. The owner of any inoperable motor vehicle or the owner of, or person in possession of, private property upon which any inoperable motor vehicle is located shall cause such inoperable motor vehicle to be disposed of and removed within 24 hours following receipt by such person of a notice instructing the disposal or removal. Such notice shall be delivered by the police service to the owner of the motor vehicle or to the owner or possessor of the real property upon which any inoperable motor vehicle shall be parked. 
(Code 1977, § 8.40.030; Code 1990, § 10-164; Ord. No. 2004-2081, § 1, 1-20-2004) 
Sec. 20-135. - Elimination of nuisance. 
    It shall be sufficient in order for any person to eliminate a nuisance as declared by this article to cause any such inoperable motor vehicle to be placed in a building or otherwise out of the view of the general public from public property or streets. 
(Code 1977, § 8.40.040; Code 1990, § 10-165) 
Sec. 20-136. - Condition of vehicles; unlawful use of parking lot. 
(a)  It is unlawful to park or store, in any public parking lot, any inoperable motor vehicle, or to permit the parking of any abandoned, junked or partially disabled vehicle in any such parking lot, whether public or private, in such a location as to be visible from a public highway, street or alley, or from the premises of another person who is not the owner of the parking lot. 
(b)  It is unlawful to use any parking lot for storage or parking of any vehicle for the purpose of displaying the same for sale, unless the lot or parking lot is the location of a business licensed for vehicle sales under the provisions of chapter 16, article VII of division 2. 
(c)  It is unlawful for any person to use any parking lot or portion thereof as a location upon which repairs are performed upon motor vehicles, or to use the same as the location of an automobile or motor vehicle repair shop. 
(d)  A violation of any of the provisions of this section shall be punishable as a Class C violation as provided in section 1-41. 
(Ord. No. 2015-2216, § 3, 7-7-2015) 
Secs. 20-137-20-149. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - OPEN BURNING 

Sec. 20-150. - Open burning prohibited. 
(a)  Definitions. For purposes of this article, the following terms are defined, and terms not otherwise defined shall carry the ordinary and customary definition thereof. 
    Landscape waste means dry leaves, trimmings and shrubs, tree limbs and branches, vines, grass clippings, green trimmings or branches, wet leaves or grass, and other materials having been derived from growing plants. 
    Smolder means to burn sluggishly and slowly without open flame but producing smoke. 
    Recreational fire means a fire created outside of buildings for the purpose of entertainment or cooking. 
(b)  Open burning of any material, including but not limited to landscape waste, except as otherwise permitted or allowed by the Municipal Code of the City of Rock Falls, is hereby declared to be a nuisance and is prohibited within the city limits. Violation of this section is a Class C violation punishable as set forth in section 1-41 of the Municipal Code. 
(c)  Notwithstanding the prohibition against open burning, recreational fires shall be permitted subject to the following conditions and restrictions: 
(1)  Recreational fires may be created using small dry sticks, dry limbs, logs, charcoal, propane or other cooking or camping fuel only. 
(2)  Recreational fires shall not be created or burned between the periods of 1:00 a.m. and 7:00 a.m. on any day, and any fire created prior to 1:00 a.m. on any day shall be extinguished at or prior to 1:00 a.m. 
(3)  Recreational fires shall not be created nor allowed to continue burning during periods when winds exceed a constant speed of ten mph or greater, or during periods of extreme drought, as determined by the chief of the Twin Cities Joint Fire Command. When extreme drought conditions have been determined to exist, public notice will be made through newspaper and by posting on the website of the city. 
(4)  Recreational fires shall be created and burned only in an enclosed vessel, fire pit or fireplace (for example, a Chiminea designed for burning of organic materials). No such vessel, fire pit or fireplace shall be greater than six feet measured in any dimension. 
(5)  Garbage, trash, refuse, lumber building materials, tires, and landscape waste, (except as otherwise permitted in subparagraph (1) hereof) shall not be used as the source of fuel for a recreational fire. 
(6)  Upon the direction of police or fire personnel, a recreational fire shall be extinguished immediately. 
(7)  Recreational fires shall not be created nor allowed to burn unless a responsible adult is within the immediate vicinity of that fire at all times while burning is occurring to supervise and assure that the fire exists in accordance with the requirements of this section. For purposes of this paragraph, "immediate vicinity" means within an area no greater than 25 feet from the recreational fire. 
(d)  In the event that personnel of the fire department of the city are dispatched to extinguish any open burning existing or being conducted in violation of the provisions of this section, then the person having created or being in charge of or conducting such unlawful open burning shall be required to pay and reimburse directly to the city, in addition to any fine or penalty that may be levied for violation, the sum of $150.00 as reimbursement for costs incurred by the city in the dispatch of the fire department. The amounts due shall be billed by the city to the responsible person, and shall be due and payable within 30 days of said billing. The city shall be entitled to any legal remedy available to it for collection of the amounts not paid as required by this paragraph. 
(e)  Violation of the provisions of this section shall be subject to issuance of an ordinance violation ticket and punishable as a Class C violation as set forth in Section 1-41 of the Municipal Code of the city. In the absence of any ability of the city to determine one specific person who may be the violator of a provision of this Section, the occupant of the residence at which is located the illegal open burning shall be the party responsible for any penalties or expenses set forth herein. 
(Ord. No. 2017-2317, § 1, 7-5-2017; Ord. No. 2017-2333, §§ 1, 2, 9-19-2017) 
Chapter 21 - RESERVED 
Chapter 22 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 22-1. - Posting bills. 
    It is unlawful for any person to post any bills or advertisements on any public property or on any utility or traffic sign poles in the street or right-of-way without the authority of the council. It is unlawful to post any bill or advertisement on any property without written consent of the owner thereof. A violation of any of the provisions of this subsection shall be punishable as a Class C violation as provides in section 1-41. 
(Code 1977, § 8.52.010; Code 1990, § 10-1; Ord. No. 2015-2218, § 1, 7-7-2015) 
Sec. 22-3. - Shooting arrows prohibited; exceptions. 
(a)  No person shall shoot any arrow from a bow or crossbow, within the city limits, except as provided in this section. 
(b)  The above and foregoing prohibition shall not apply to any discharge or shooting in the following circumstances or conditions: 
(1)  The shooting of any arrow from a bow or crossbow within a building constructed and maintained as an indoor archery range; and 
(2)  The shooting of any arrow from a bow or crossbow upon real estate zoned under the Municipal Code as A-1 and which real estate was zoned A-1 upon its annexation to the city, when the shooting of any arrow is in the course of the hunting of any animal pursuant to and in accordance with the laws of the state allowing and regulating hunting, and when the hunting is conducted by the owner, lawful occupant or the guests of either upon such real estate. 
(c)  Nothing herein shall be deemed, interpreted or construed to any way limit or eliminate any common law liability of any person arising from damage to property or injury to persons as the result of or arising from the shooting of any arrow from a bow or cross bow. 
(Code 1977, § 9.78.010; Code 1990, § 10-5; Ord. No. 98-1847, § 1, 7-21-1998; Ord. No. 2190(B), § 1, 8-2-2006) 
Sec. 22-4. - Cemeteries. 
    It is unlawful for any person to bury any person within the city limits or within a mile thereof, except in an established cemetery. 
(Code 1990, § 10-89; Ord. No. 88-1509, § 8.56.030, 7-5-1988) 
Sec. 22-5. - Serving utensils sterilized. 
    Utensils for personal use in all places serving food or drink to the public shall be thoroughly cleaned and sterilized after each such usage. 
(Code 1990, § 10-90; Ord. No. 88-1509, § 8.56.040, 7-5-1988) 
Sec. 22-6. - Spitting. 
    It is unlawful for any person to spit or expectorate on any public sidewalk or street or other public place, or on the floor or walls of any store, theater, hall, public vehicle, or other place frequented by the public or to which the public is invited. 
(Code 1990, § 10-91; Ord. No. 88-1509, § 8.56.050, 7-5-1988) 
Sec. 22-7. - Smoke emissions unlawful; measurements. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to cause or permit any emission of dense smoke from any fire chimney, engine, oil burner or any other agency in the city so as to cause annoyance or discomfort to the residents thereof. 
(b)  For the purpose of testing and grading the density of smoke, the Ringelmann Smoke Chart, as published and used by the United States Geological Survey, is adopted as a standard for such grading; and smoke is defined as and declared to be "dense" when it is of a degree of density of number three on the Ringelmann chart or greater for more than six minutes in any one hour, whether such period of time is consecutive or not. 
(Code 1990, § 10-92; Ord. No. 88-1509, § 8.56.060, 7-5-1988) 
Secs. 22-8-22-32. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CONDUCT AT FAST FOOD RESTAURANTS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Contracts for regulation of traffic in shopping centers, 65 ILCS 5/1-1-7 and 625 ILCS 5/11-209. 

Sec. 22-33. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Cruising means entering the parking area or drive-up food lane of a fast food restaurant in a motor vehicle, and driving a circuit of the parking area more than one time, or driving more than one trip through the parking area in a motor vehicle in close time proximity, without making or attempting to make a purchase from such restaurant. 
    Fast food restaurant means a restaurant specializing in the rapid preparation and service of foods such as sandwiches, hamburgers, chicken, beverages, ice cream or similar types of foods. 
(Code 1990, § 10-26; Ord. No. 87-1479, § 10.50.010, 7-20-1987) 
Sec. 22-34. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any provision of this article shall be deemed to be guilty of a petty offense and shall be fined an amount not to exceed $500.00. 
(Code 1990, § 10-27; Ord. No. 87-1479, § 10.50.070, 7-20-1987) 
Sec. 22-35. - Entire premises deemed public place. 
    In order to preserve the public peace, health and safety, the entire premises of any fast food restaurant operating within the city, including the inside area used for the service and consumption of food by customers, and including any parking area for motor vehicles and any means of ingress or egress to the parking area or restaurant, are hereby declared to be a public place. 
(Code 1990, § 10-28; Ord. No. 87-1479, § 10.50.020, 7-20-1987) 
Sec. 22-36. - Creating loud noise, other disturbance. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person while on the premises of a fast food restaurant to race the engine of any motor vehicle, blow the horn of a motor vehicle, or create any loud noise, nuisance or disturbance where the quiet and good order of the premises or the neighborhood are disturbed. 
(Code 1990, § 10-29; Ord. No. 87-1479, § 10.50.030, 7-20-1987) 
Sec. 22-37. - Unlawful parking, leaving of vehicles; operation of vehicle on the premises; using abusive language. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, while on the premises of a fast food restaurant, to engage in any of the following acts or conduct: 
(1)  Parking a motor vehicle upon the premises and leaving the motor vehicle parked and unoccupied without the consent of the operator of such restaurant. For this purpose, a person entering upon the premises for the purpose of making a purchase from the restaurant shall be deemed to have the consent of the operator to leave the motor vehicle unoccupied and parked. Upon complaint of the operator of a fast food restaurant, any vehicle parked in violation of this subsection shall be subject to a parking citation as in other cases of unlawful parking within the city, and, further, upon complaint of the operator of the restaurant, such vehicle may be impounded by the police service and removed from the premises to a place of safekeeping, in which event the owner or operator of the motor vehicle shall be responsible for and reimburse the city for any towing charges incurred in such impoundment, and shall pay such charges before the vehicle shall be released to the owner. 
(2)  Entering upon the premises in or upon a motor vehicle and using such premises for cruising, racing, as a shortcut to another street or premises, or to operate the vehicle in such a manner as to endanger the safety of any other person or vehicle lawfully on the premises. 
(3)  While on the premises of a fast food restaurant, and in the presence or hearing of another person, cursing or abusing such person or using any violently abusive language under circumstances which are reasonably calculated to provoke a breach of the peace. 
(Code 1990, § 10-30; Ord. No. 87-1479, § 10.50.040, 7-20-1987) 
Sec. 22-38. - Unlawful congregating. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for four or more persons to congregate on the premises of any fast food restaurant and linger or loiter at any location either inside or outside the building or inside or outside a motor vehicle while not actually consuming purchases made on the premises. 
(b)  A violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class C violation as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1990, § 10-31; Ord. No. 87-1479, § 10.50.050, 7-20-1987; Ord. No. 2010-2421, § 42, 10-5-2010) 
Sec. 22-39. - Signs required for enforcement. 
    The provisions of this article shall not be enforced and applied to any party on the premises of a fast food restaurant unless the operator of such restaurant has posted and affixed in at least two conspicuous locations on such fast food restaurant premises signs with letters a minimum of two inches high which provide the following or closely similar language: 
"CRUISING IN OR CONGREGATING AND LOITERING ON THE PREMISES EITHER INSIDE OR OUTSIDE AN AUTOMOBILE IS UNLAWFUL. NO UNOCCUPIED VEHICLE MAY BE LEFT ON THE RESTAURANT PROPERTY WITHOUT THE CONSENT OF THE OWNER. PERSONS VIOLATING THESE PROVISIONS ARE SUBJECT TO ARREST AND UNOCCUPIED VEHICLES MAY BE TOWED AT THE OWNERS' EXPENSE." 
(Code 1990, § 10-32; Ord. No. 87-1479, § 10.50.060, 7-20-1987) 
Secs. 22-40-22-66. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - TRESPASS 

Sec. 22-67. - Trespass-Generally. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to commit a trespass within the city, upon either public or private property. 
(Ord. No. 2014-2159, § 2(10-33), 5-20-2014) 
Sec. 22-68. - Same-Enumerated offenses. 
    Without constituting any limitation upon the provisions of section 22-67, any of the following acts by any persons shall be deemed included among those that constitute trespasses in violation of the provisions of section 22-67, and appropriate action may be taken under this section at any time to prevent or suppress any violation of this section: 
(1)  An entry upon the premises, or any part thereof, of another, including any public property, in violation of a notice posted or exhibited at the main entrance to such premises or at any point of approach or entry, or in violation of any notice, warning or protest given orally or in writing by any owner or occupant of such premises; 
(2)  The pursuit of a course of conduct or action incidental to the making of an entry upon the land of another in violation of a notice posted or exhibited at the main entrance to such premises or at any approach or entry, or in violation of any notice, warning, or protest given orally or in writing by any owner or occupant thereof; 
(3)  A failure or refusal to depart from the premises of another when requested, either orally or in writing, to leave by any owner or occupant thereof; 
(4)  An entry into or upon any vehicle or watercraft made without the consent of the person having the right to the possession or control thereof, or any failure or refusal to leave any such vehicle, or watercraft after being requested to leave by the person having such right; 
(5)  Depositing, abandoning or dumping any waste material, garbage, refuse or other offensive substance upon the premises, or any part thereof, of another, including any public property, without the prior consent of the owner of said property. 
(Ord. No. 2014-2159, § 2(10-34), 5-20-2014) 
Sec. 22-69. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating this article shall be subject to a fine of not less than $50.00 nor more than $750.00, plus court costs. 
(Ord. No. 2014-2159, § 2(10-35), 5-20-2014) 
Sec. 22-70. - Enforcement. 
    Proceedings to enforce any violation of this article may be initiated and conducted in accordance with and pursuant to the provisions of chapter 1 providing for administrative adjudication of code violations, or by any other means provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 2014-2159, § 2(10-36), 5-20-2014) 
Secs. 22-71-22-98. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - EMERGENCY 911 TELEPHONE SYSTEM 

Sec. 22-99. - Misuses and abuses. 
(a)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    911, E9-1-1 or 911 line means the emergency reporting system available for use within the city by placing a call to telephone number 911. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly: 
(1)  Transmit in any manner to the fire department of any city, town, village or fire protection district a false alarm of fire, knowing at the time of such transmission that there is no reasonable grounds for believing that such fire exists; 
(2)  Transmit in any manner to another a false alarm to the effect that a bomb or other explosive of any nature is concealed in such place that its explosion would endanger human life, knowing at the time of such transmission that there is no reasonable grounds for believing that such bomb or explosive is concealed in such place; 
(3)  Transmit in any manner to any peace officer, public officer or public employee a report to the effect that an offense has been committed, knowing at the time of such transmission that there is no reasonable grounds for believing that such an offense has been committed; 
(4)  Call by telephone the number 911 for the purpose of making a false alarm or complaint, or for the purpose of reporting false information, knowing at the time of such call that the alarm, complaint or information is false; or 
(5)  Call by telephone the number 911 for any nonemergency purpose or reason, after having been notified, prior to such call, either verbally or in writing by any peace officer, public officer or public employee, that the placing of nonemergency calls to the 911 line is prohibited. 
(c)  Any person found to have violated any provision of this section shall be fined an amount not less than $50.00 nor more than $500.00 for each such offense. 
(Code 1990, § 10-200; Ord. No. 92-1630, 10-5-1992) 
Secs. 22-100-22-126. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - COMPREHENSIVE REGULATION OF TOBACCO PRODUCTS 

Sec. 22-127. - Legislative finding and declaration. 
(a)  The mayor and council expressly find and declare that: 
(1)  Cigarette smoking has been determined to be dangerous to human health; 
(2)  There exists substantial scientific evidence that the use of tobacco products causes cancer, heart disease and various other medical disorders; 
(3)  The Surgeon General of the United States has declared that nicotine addiction from tobacco is similar to addiction to cocaine, and is the most widespread example of drug dependence in this country; 
(4)  The director of the National Institute of Drug Abuse concluded that the majority of the 320,000 Americans who die each year from cigarette smoking became addicted to nicotine as adolescents before the age of legal consent; 
(5)  The National Institute on Drug Abuse found that cigarette smoking precedes and may be predictive of adolescent illicit drug use; and 
(6)  The present legislative scheme of prohibiting sales of tobacco products to persons under the age of 18 has proven ineffective in preventing such persons from using tobacco products. 
(b)  The enactment of the ordinance from which this article is derived directly pertains to and is in furtherance of the health, welfare and safety of the residents of the city, particularly those residents under 18 years of age. 
(Code 1990, § 12-100; Ord. No. 2000-1942, § 1, 7-5-2000) 
Sec. 22-128. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Licensee means a holder of a license to sell tobacco products issued pursuant to chapter 16, article IV, division 7. 
    Smoking herbs means all substances of plant origin and their derivatives, including, but not limited to, broom, calea, California poppy, damiana, hops, ginseng, lobelia, jimson weed and other members of the Datura genus, passion flower and wild lettuce, which are processed or sold primarily for use as smoking materials. 
    Tobacco accessories shall mean cigarette papers, pipes, holders of smoking materials of all types, cigarette rolling machines, and other items, designed primarily for the smoking or ingestion of tobacco products or of substances made illegal under any statute or of substances whose sale, gift, barter, or exchange is made unlawful under this article.
