    Tobacco products means any substance containing tobacco leaf, including, but not limited to, cigarettes, cigars, pipe tobacco, snuff, chewing tobacco or dipping tobacco. 
    Vending machine means any mechanical, electric or electronic, self-service device which, upon insertion of money, tokens or any other form of payment, dispenses tobacco products. 
(Code 1990, § 12-101; Ord. No. 2000-1942, § 1, 7-5-2000) 
Sec. 22-129. - Prohibited sales, delivery, signs. 
(a)  No person shall knowingly sell, barter, exchange, deliver or give away or cause or permit or procure to be sold, bartered, exchanged, delivered, or given away tobacco accessories or smoking herbs to any person under 18 years of age. 
(b)  No person shall knowingly sell, barter, exchange, deliver, or give away a bidi cigarette to another person, nor shall a person cause or permit or procure a bidi cigarette to be sold, bartered, exchanged, delivered, or given away to another person. 
(c)  No person shall knowingly offer, sell, barter, exchange, deliver or give away cigarette paper or cause, permit, or procure cigarette paper to be sold, offered, bartered, exchanged, delivered, or given away except from premises or an establishment where other tobacco products are sold. 
(d)  A person shall not knowingly sell, give away, barter, exchange, or otherwise furnish to any person any wrapping paper or wrapping leaf, however characterized, including, without limitation, cigarette papers, blunt wraps, cigar wraps, or tubes of paper or leaf, or any similar device, for the purpose of making a roll of tobacco or herbs for smoking, that is or is held out to be, impregnated, scented, or imbibed with, or aged or dipped in, a characterizing flavor, other than tobacco or menthol, including, without limitation, alcoholic or liquor flavor, or both, chocolate, fruit flavoring, vanilla, peanut butter, jelly, or any combination of those flavors or similar child attractive scent or flavor. 
(e)  No person shall knowingly offer, sell, barter, exchange, deliver or give away cigarette paper or cause, permit, or procure cigarette paper to be sold, offered, bartered, exchanged, delivered, or given away by use of a vending or coin-operated machine or device. For purposes of this section, the term "cigarette paper" shall not include any paper that is incorporated into a product to which a tax stamp must be affixed under the Cigarette Tax Act (35 ILCS 130/1 et seq.) or the Cigarette Use Tax Act 35 ILCS 135/1 et seq. 
(f)  No person in the furtherance or facilitation of obtaining smoking accessories and smoking herbs shall display or use a false or forged identification card or transfer, alter, or deface an identification card. 
(g)  Any person, firm, partnership, company or corporation operating a place of business where tobacco accessories and smoking herbs are sold or offered for sale shall post in a conspicuous place upon the premises a sign upon which there shall be imprinted the following statement: 
"SALE OF TOBACCO ACCESSORIES AND SMOKING HERBS TO PERSONS UNDER EIGHTEEN YEARS OF AGE OR THE MISREPRESENTATION OF AGE TO PROCURE SUCH A SALE IS PROHIBITED BY LAW". 
The sign shall be printed on a white card in red letters at least one-half-inch in height. 
(h)  A violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class C violation as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1990, § 12-102; Ord. No. 2000-1942, § 1, 7-5-2000; Ord. No. 2010-2421, § 48, 10-5-2010) 
Sec. 22-130. - Purchase by minors prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of 18 years to purchase tobacco products, or to misrepresent his identity or age, or use any false or altered identification for the purpose of purchasing tobacco products. 
(b)  A violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class C violation as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1990, § 12-103; Ord. No. 2000-1942, § 1, 7-5-2000; Ord. No. 2010-2421, § 49, 10-5-2010) 
Sec. 22-131. - Possession by minors prohibited. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of 18 years to possess any tobacco products; provided that the possession by a person under the age of 18 years under the direct supervision of the parent or guardian of such person in the privacy of the parent's or guardian's home shall not be prohibited. 
(b)  A violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class C violation as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1990, § 12-104; Ord. No. 2000-1942, § 1, 7-5-2000; Ord. No. 2010-2421, § 50, 10-5-2010) 
Sec. 22-132. - Proximity to certain institutions. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, offer for sale, give away or deliver tobacco products within 100 feet of any school premises, child care facility or other building used for education or recreational programs for persons under the age of 18 years. 
(Code 1990, § 12-105; Ord. No. 2000-1942, § 1, 7-5-2000) 
Sec. 22-133. - Certain free distributions prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any licensee or any person in the business of selling or otherwise distributing, promoting or advertising tobacco products, or any employee or agent of any such licensee or person, in the course of such licensee's or person's business, to distribute, give away or deliver tobacco products free of charge to any person on any right-of-way, park, playground or other property owned by the city, any school district, any park district or any public library. 
(Code 1990, § 12-106; Ord. No. 2000-1942, § 1, 7-5-2000) 
Sec. 22-134. - Vending machines; locking devices. 
    It shall be unlawful for any licensee to sell or offer for sale, give away, deliver or to keep with the intention of selling, giving away or delivering tobacco products by use of a vending machine, unless such vending machine is equipped with a manual, electric or electronic locking device controlled by the licensee so as to prevent its operation by persons under the age of 18 years; provided, however, a vending machine located at any premises from which persons under the age of 18 years are prohibited by law, or premises where the public is generally not permitted and where vending machines are strictly for the use of employees of the business located at such premises, shall be exempt from the requirements of this section. 
(Code 1990, § 12-107; Ord. No. 2000-1942, § 1, 7-5-2000) 
Sec. 22-135. - Penalty. 
(a)  The penalty for violation of sections 22-129(a), 22-132, 22-133, and 22-134 shall be a fine of not less than $50.00 nor more than $500.00. Each day that a violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(b)  Violations of section 22-130 or section 22-131 with respect to purchase of tobacco products and/or possession of tobacco products by a person under 18 years of age shall be punishable by the penalty as follows: 
(1)  Violation of section 22-130: $50.00 fine. 
(2)  Violation of section 22-131: $25.00 fine. 
(c)  First-time offenders shall have the option of attending a free smokers' education class presented by the county health department in lieu of paying a fine, at such hours and for such duration as may be established by the health department. Proof of attendance shall be exhibited, as may be required by the enforcing authority. 
(Code 1990, § 12-108; Ord. No. 2000-1942, § 1, 7-5-2000) 
Secs. 22-136-22-153. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - MINORS 

Sec. 22-154. - Curfew. 
(a)  No person less than 17 years of age shall be present at or upon any public assembly, building, place, street or highway at the times as specified herein unless accompanied and supervised by: 
(1)  A parent; 
(2)  A legal guardian; or 
(3)  Other responsible companion at least 18 years of age who has been approved by a parent or guardian, or unless the person is engaged in a business or occupation which the laws of the state authorize to be performed by a person less than 17 years of age. 
(b)  The hours during which a person under 17 years of age shall be prohibited from being present at or upon any public assembly, building, place, street or highway, as provided herein, shall be: 
(1)  Between 12:01 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. on Saturday; 
(2)  Between 12:01 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. Sunday; and 
(3)  Between 11:00 p.m. on Sunday to Thursday, inclusive, and 6:00 a.m. on the following day. 
(c)  It is unlawful for a parent, legal guardian or other person to knowingly permit a person less than 17 years of age under the custody or control of the parent, legal guardian or other person to violate the provisions of this section. 
(d)  It is a defense to prosecution under this section that the minor was: 
(1)  Accompanied by the minor's parent or guardian or other person in custody or control of the minor; 
(2)  On an errand on the direction of the minor's parent or guardian, without any detour or stops; 
(3)  In a motor vehicle involved in interstate travel; 
(4)  Engaged in an employment activity or going to or returning home from an employment activity, without any detour or stops; 
(5)  Involved in an emergency; 
(6)  On the sidewalk abutting the minor's residence or abutting the residence of a next-door neighbor if the neighbor did not complain to the police department about the minor's presence; 
(7)  Attending an official school, religious, or other recreational activities supervised by adults and sponsored by a government or governmental agency, a civic organization, or other similar entity that takes responsibility for the minor, or going to or returning home from, without any detour or stop, an official school, religious, or other recreational activity supervised by adults and sponsored by a government or governmental agency, a civic organization, or other similar entity that takes responsibility for the minor; 
(8)  Exercising First Amendment rights protected by the United States Constitution and/or rights protected by article 1, sections 3, 4, and/or 5 of the state constitution, such as the free exercise of religion, freedom of speech, and the right of assembly; or 
(9)  Married or had been married or is an emancipated minor under the Emancipation of Minors Act (750 ILCS 30/1 et seq.). 
(e)  Violation of the provisions of this section shall be a Class C violation punishable as provided by section 1-41. 
(Code 1990, § 10-201; Ord. No. 2011-2456, § 1, 4-5-2011) 
Sec. 22-155. - Truancy. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Community service means a penalty requiring that an offender found in violation of this section perform unpaid work or services beneficial to the community. 
    Custodian means: 
(1)  A person who, under court order, is the custodian of the person of the minor; 
(2)  A public or private agency with which a court has placed a minor; or 
(3)  A person acting in the role of a parent by reason of a private agreement, arrangement, custom, or habit. 
    Guardian means: 
(1)  A parent; 
(2)  A parent who under court order is a guardian of the person of the minor; or 
(3)  A public or private agency with which a court has placed a minor. 
    Minor means a person who is under 18 years of age. 
    Parent means a person who is a natural parent, adoptive parent, or step parent of another person. 
    Responsible adult means the parent, guardian, or custodian having the care and custody of a minor. 
    Truant means a child subject to compulsory school attendance and who is absent without valid cause from such attendance of a school day or a portion thereof, as defined in the state school code, 105 ILCS 5/26-2a. 
(b)  Truancy restrictions. 
(1)  It is unlawful for any minor who is subject to compulsory education or to compulsory continuation education by statute or court order to be absent without valid cause from such attendance for a school day or any portion thereof. 
(2)  It is unlawful for any responsible adult to knowingly permit a minor under the age of 13 years to be absent without valid cause from such attendance for a school day or a portion thereof. 
(c)  Defenses. It is defense to a violation under this section that the child was absent from such attendance as a consequence of any of the following: 
(1)  Observance of a religious holiday or being otherwise forbidden from attendance on a particular day or days or a particular time of day because of such religion. For purposes of this section, the term "religion" includes all aspects of religious observance and practice, as well as belief; 
(2)  Illness; 
(3)  Death in the immediate family; 
(4)  Family emergency; 
(5)  Other situations beyond the control of the student as determined by the board of education, or such circumstances which cause such reasonable concern of the parent for the safety or health of the student; 
(6)  Participating in, going to, or returning from lawful employment or a school-sanctioned activity. 
(d)  Penalty. Any child subject to compulsory school attendance who is absent without valid cause from such attendance for a school day or a portion thereof shall be a truant and shall be guilty of the offense of truancy, and, if of the age of 13 years or older, such a violator will be subject to following penalties: 
(1)  Upon the first conviction, the payment of a fine in an amount not to exceed $50.00, in addition to court costs; 
(2)  Upon the second conviction within a one year period, the payment of a fine of in excess of $75.00 but not to exceed $100.00, in addition to costs; 
(3)  In lieu of or in addition to any penalty imposed pursuant to subsections (c)(1) or (2) of this section, the violator may be ordered to perform community service; 
(4)  The fine for any conviction for a violation of this section shall not exceed $100.00, as established by the Illinois Municipal Code, 65 ILCS 5/11-5-9; and 
(5)  If the child found to be truant is under the age of 13 years, the parent or custodian of the child is subject to the foregoing fines, or community service, or both. 
(6)  Each day upon which a violation occurs constitutes a separate offense under this section. 
(Code 1990, § 10-202; Ord. No. 2011-2457, § 1, 4-5-2011) 
Sec. 22-156. - Sex offender registration act fees. 
(a)  Any and all persons required to register with the chief of police pursuant to the Sex Offender Registration Act (730 ILCS 150/1 et seq.) (the "Act") shall pay to the city a $100.00 initial registration fee and a $100.00 annual renewal fee or such other or additional fees as may be prescribed or required under the Act as the same may be amended from time to time. The police department may waive the registration fee if it is determined that the person is indigent and unable to pay the registration fee. 
(b)  The city shall be entitled to retain that portion of the initial registration fee and that portion of the annual renewal fee as specified under the Sex Offender Registration Act, as may be amended from time to time, and shall remit the remainder of the described fees to the state agencies set forth in the Sex Offender Registration Act within 30 days of receipt. 
(c)  In addition to other remedies available to the city for enforcement of the payment obligations of this section, proceedings may be instituted by the police chief utilizing the administrative code enforcement procedures as are set forth in chapter 1, article II. 
(Ord. No. 2014-2186, § 1, 12-2-2014) 
Secs. 22-157-22-180. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - SKATEBOARDS AND IN-LINE SKATES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 22-181-22-198. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - SKATEBOARDS 

Sec. 22-199. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Skateboard means a single platform mounted on wheels which is propelled solely by human power. 
    Skateboard ramp means any outdoor structure or structures designed and principally intended to permit persons on skateboards to move continuously and from one side to the other, and commonly known as ramps or pipes. 
    Skateboarding means the use of a skateboard by any person as a means of transporting or propelling that person from one point to another. 
(Code 1990, § 12-50; Ord. No. 91-1598, 5-20-1991) 
Sec. 22-200. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any of the provisions of this division shall be issued a city ordinance citation and shall be subject to a minimum penalty of $5.00 and a maximum penalty of $50.00 for each such violation. 
(Code 1990, § 12-59; Ord. No. 91-1598, 5-20-1991) 
Sec. 22-201. - Preexisting conditions. 
    The owner of any parcel of real estate upon which is located a skateboard ramp as of May 20, 1991, shall cause the ramp to comply with the terms and provisions of this article on or before January 1, 1992, or if he shall fail to make the ramp comply with the provisions of this article, he shall remove the ramp on or before January 1, 1992. 
(Code 1990, § 12-58; Ord. No. 91-1598, 5-20-1991) 
Sec. 22-202. - Skateboarding prohibited. 
(a)  Skateboarding shall be prohibited at the following points or locations within the city: 
(1)  On any public street, roadway or highway, except within the lines of a designated crosswalk. 
(2)  On any sidewalk located adjacent to and upon any real estate within the city which carries a zoning classification of B-1, B-2, MU-1, M-l or M-2, but skateboarding shall be permitted on all other sidewalks, and designated skate parks. 
(3)  In or upon private property without the consent or knowledge of the owner of such private property. 
(4)  In or upon public or private parking lots within the city without the consent in writing or knowledge of the owner thereof. 
(b)  A violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class C violation as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1990, § 12-51; Ord. No. 91-1598, 5-20-1991; Ord. No. 2010-2421, § 46, 10-5-2010; Ord. No. 2015-2235, § 1, 9-15-2015) 
Sec. 22-203. - Right-of-way. 
    The operator of a skateboard shall be imbued with the status of a pedestrian, but the operator shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicular and to all other pedestrian (nonskateboard) traffic. 
(Code 1990, § 12-52; Ord. No. 91-1598, 5-20-1991) 
Sec. 22-204. - One operator only. 
    No more than one person shall operate or ride upon a skateboard at the same time. 
(Code 1990, § 12-53; Ord. No. 91-1598, 5-20-1991) 
Sec. 22-205. - Skateboard ramps. 
    Skateboard ramps shall be prohibited within the city except that one skateboard ramp may be located on each parcel of real estate bearing classification R-l, R-2 or R-3, and any such ramp shall comply with all of the following conditions: 
(1)  The ramp shall be located within the rear yard, and no more than one ramp shall be permitted on a single zoning lot; 
(2)  The ramp shall not occupy no more than 30 percent of the rear yard area; 
(3)  The minimum rear yard setback for the ramp shall be five feet, the minimum side yard setback for the ramp shall be five feet, and no ramp shall be located upon any drainage or utility easement; 
(4)  No ramp shall be located nearer than 30 feet to a principal building or structure on an adjoining parcel; 
(5)  No skateboard ramp constructed under the provisions of this article may be used for commercial purposes. 
(Code 1990, § 12-54; Ord. No. 91-1598, 5-20-1991) 
Sec. 22-206. - Building permit. 
    No skateboard ramp which exceeds 36 inches in height shall be located or constructed within the city unless a building permit shall first be issued for such ramp by the building official in accordance with the building codes and ordinances of the city. Any skateboard ramp to be constructed pursuant to this section shall comply with the following conditions in addition to any other conditions which may be imposed by the building codes or ordinances of the city: 
(1)  The owner of the premises shall submit plans for the proposed ramp, identifying the design, materials, methods of construction and dimensions; 
(2)  The plans submitted to the building official shall include details as to proposed location, fencing required, berms or landscaping utilized to screen the ramp; 
(3)  No skateboard ramp shall be constructed which exceeds six feet in height, exclusive of any guardrail; 
(4)  Any ramp to be constructed of a height greater than 36 inches shall have a guardrail located on the ramp platform, which guardrail shall be not less than 36 inches in height and not more than 48 inches in height; 
(5)  Any ramp to be constructed of plywood shall utilize exterior grade plywood; 
(6)  All ramps constructed of wood shall utilize wood which has been smooth-finished to prevent injury and shall be properly surface-coated to prevent deterioration and unsightliness; 
(7)  All ramps shall be constructed soundproof by insulating the underside of the riding surface and by enclosing the ends of the ramp with plywood or some other suitable all-weather material. 
(Code 1990, § 12-55; Ord. No. 91-1598, 5-20-1991) 
Sec. 22-207. - Screening. 
    No skateboard ramp shall be located or constructed unless it is screened from view from adjacent properties and from public rights-of-way. The screening from view may be by fence, berm, landscaping or a combination. 
(Code 1990, § 12-56; Ord. No. 91-1598, 5-20-1991) 
Sec. 22-208. - Hours. 
    No skateboard ramp may be utilized for skateboarding between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 9:00 a.m. of any day. 
(Code 1990, § 12-57; Ord. No. 91-1598, 5-20-1991) 
Secs. 22-209-22-239. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - IN-LINE SKATES 

Sec. 22-240. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    In-line skater means one who glides along or otherwise propels himself on in-line skates. 
    In-line skates (a/k/a: roller blades) means a pair of shoes with a single line of wheels attached to the bottom of each shoe, utilized for skating by the wearer over a flat surface. 
(Code 1990, § 12-60; Ord. No. 92-1629, § 1, 9-21-1992) 
Sec. 22-241. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any provision of this division shall be subject to the penalty as provided by section 22-200. 
(Code 1990, § 12-65; Ord. No. 92-1629, § 1, 9-21-1992) 
Sec. 22-242. - Prohibited. 
(a)  In-line skating shall be prohibited at the following points or locations within the city: 
(1)  On any state highway south of 2nd Street; 
(2)  On West 2nd Street between 1st Avenue and 4th Avenue; 
(3)  On any sidewalk or alley within the following area: 
a.  Within one-half block of West 2nd Street between 1st Avenue and 4th Avenue; 
b.  Within one-half block of 1st Avenue between 4th Street and 2nd Street; 
(4)  On or upon private property without the consent or knowledge of the owner of such private property; 
(5)  On or upon public or private parking lots within the city without the consent in writing and knowledge of the owner thereof. 
(b)  A violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class C violation as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1990, § 12-61; Ord. No. 92-1629, § 1, 9-21-1992; Ord. No. 2010-2421, § 47, 10-5-2010) 
Sec. 22-243. - Traffic laws applied. 
    Laws and ordinances regulating motorized and nonmotorized traffic shall apply to in-line skaters. In-line skaters shall be granted all rights and shall be subject to all the duties applicable to pedestrians by this Code and by state law except as to special regulations in this article. 
(Code 1990, § 12-62; Ord. No. 92-1629, § 1, 9-21-1992) 
Sec. 22-244. - On public/private roadways and sidewalks. 
    The following additional requirements shall be observed by all in-line skaters: 
(1)  All in-line skaters shall exercise due caution; 
(2)  All in-line skaters shall yield the right-of-way to pedestrians, bicycles and other vehicles which are utilizing the same roadway or sidewalk or an intersecting roadway or sidewalk; 
(3)  All in-line skaters shall, when skating on a roadway, skate as nearly as possible to the left-hand side of the roadway, and shall yield the right-of-way to vehicles moving upon the roadway when passing a standing or parked vehicle; 
(4)  In-line skaters shall not skate in a reckless manner; 
(5)  In-line skaters shall skate in a single file upon sidewalks or roadways, and shall not race upon any sidewalk or roadway; 
(6)  In-line skaters shall not skate after dusk nor before dawn. 
(Code 1990, § 12-63; Ord. No. 92-1629, § 1, 9-21-1992) 
Sec. 22-245. - One operator only. 
    No in-line skater shall carry any other person while skating. 
(Code 1990, § 12-64; Ord. No. 92-1629, § 1, 9-21-1992) 
Chapter 23 - RESERVED 
Chapter 24 - SIGNS 

Sec. 24-1. - Building permit required. 
    No sign shall be located, erected, moved, reconstructed, extended, enlarged, converted or structurally altered without a building permit and without being in conformity with the provisions of this chapter. The sign shall also meet all the structural requirements of the city building code. 
(Code 1977, § 17.52.010; Code 1990, § 12.5-1; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 3(16-431), 4-19-1993) 
Sec. 24-2. - Imitation of traffic or railroad signs; obstruction of ingress, egress; obstruction of visibility. 
    No sign shall be erected, relocated or maintained so as to prevent free ingress to or egress from any door, window or fire escape and no sign shall be attached to a standpipe or fire escape. No sign shall be placed so as to obstruct or interfere with traffic visibility. 
(Code 1977, § 17.52.020; Code 1990, § 12.5-2; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 3(16-432), 4-19-1993) 
Sec. 24-4. - Prohibited in residential districts; exceptions. 
    All signs are prohibited in all residential districts except the following: 
(1)  Signs over show windows or doors of a nonconforming business or a business in the RO district without display or elaboration, with only the name and occupation of the proprietor and not to exceed two feet in height and ten feet in length; 
(2)  Real estate signs not to exceed 24 square feet in area which advertise the sale, rental or lease of the premises upon which the signs are located for a period not to exceed six months, which period may be extended for six-month intervals by the council; 
(3)  Name, occupation and warning signs not to exceed one square foot located on the premises; 
(4)  Bulletin boards for public, charitable or religious institutions not to exceed 20 square feet in area located on the premises; 
(5)  Memorial signs, tables, names of buildings and date of erection when cut into any masonry surface or when constructed of metal and affixed flat against a structure; 
(6)  Official signs, such as traffic-control, parking restrictions, information and notices; 
(7)  Temporary signs in favor of or opposing any political party, any candidate for political office, or any proposition to be decided by election but provided that no such sign shall be placed on public property, and provided that no such sign shall be placed on private property without the consent of the owner. All such temporary signs shall be posted for a period not to exceed 75 days, and all such temporary signs shall be removed within ten days following the election to which the sign is applicable. 
(Code 1977, § 17.52.040; Code 1990, § 12.5-4; Ord. No. 93-1649, § 1, 3-1-1993; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 3(16-434), 4-19-1993; Ord. No. 2010-2417, § 1, 9-7-2010) 
Sec. 24-5. - Commercial and industrial districts. 
    Signs are permitted in all commercial and industrial districts subject to the restrictions set forth in sections 24-6 through 24-13. 
(Code 1977, § 17.52.052; Code 1990, § 12.5-5; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 3(16-435), 4-19-1993; Ord. No. 2010-2417, § 2, 9-7-2010) 
Sec. 24-6. - Wall signs. 
    Wall signs placed against the exterior walls of a building shall not extend more than 24 inches into a public way, shall not exceed 900 square feet in area for any one public entrance and one sign face, shall provide a minimum of eight feet of clearance beneath the sign and shall not exceed 20 feet in height above the mean centerline street grade. 
(Code 1977, § 17.52.060; Code 1990, § 12.5-6; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 3(16-436), 4-19-1993) 
Sec. 24-7. - Ground signs. 
    Ground signs shall not extend beyond property lines, shall be allowed to exceed 20 feet height limitation at a ratio of two feet of height for each one foot set back from the property line, shall meet all yard requirements for the district in which they are located, and shall not exceed 300 square feet per facing in B-l, B-2 and MU-1 zoned districts, and shall not exceed 600 square feet per facing in M-l and M-2 zoned districts. 
(Code 1990, § 12.5-7; Ord. No. 85-1418, § 17.52.070, 8-19-1985; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 3(16-437), 4-19-1993; Ord. No. 2015-2234, § 1, 9-15-2015) 
Sec. 24-8. - Roof signs. 
    Roof signs shall not exceed ten feet in height above the roof, shall meet all the yard and height requirements for the district in which they are located, and shall not exceed 300 square feet per face for any one building. All such roof signs must be so constructed that there is at least four feet of space between the billboard or sign board and the edge of the roof at all sides and ends. It is unlawful to construct any roof sign or billboard on the roof of any building which is unable to withstand the additional weight and wind pressure imposed by such construction. 
(Code 1990, § 12.5-8; Ord. No. 85-1418, § 17.52.080, 8-19-1985; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 3(16-438), 4-19-1993) 
Sec. 24-9. - Outdoor advertising signs. 
    Outdoor advertising signs, in addition to other applicable regulations, shall not be erected closer than 40 feet to a residence, nor more than 75 feet from a business or industry. 
(Code 1977, § 17.52.090; Code 1990, § 12.5-9; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 3(16-439), 4-19-1993) 
Sec. 24-10. - Obstruction of or attachment to fire escapes. 
    It is unlawful to erect or maintain any advertising sign in such a position as to obstruct any fire escape or any window or door leading thereto; no advertising sign shall be fastened to any fire escape. 
(Code 1990, § 12.5-10; Ord. No. 85-1418, § 17.52.100, 8-19-1985; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 3(16-440), 4-19-1993) 
Sec. 24-11. - Illumination. 
    The wiring of illuminated signs must comply with the provisions of all ordinances of the city relating to electrical wiring, and of all electrical codes of the city. 
(Code 1990, § 12.5-11; Ord. No. 85-1418, § 17.52.110, 8-19-1985; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 3(16-441), 4-19-1993) 
Sec. 24-12. - Nuisances. 
    Any billboard or sign board which is dangerous because of insecure construction or fastening with the result and danger of falling, or because it is an extreme fire hazard and in fact a nuisance, is declared to be a nuisance and may be abated as such. 
(Code 1990, § 12.5-12; Ord. No. 85-1418, § 17.52.120, 8-19-1985; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 3(16-442), 4-19-1993) 
Sec. 24-13. - Temporary signs. 
(a)  A temporary sign is any sign made of any material, being more than four square feet in area, and which is not securely and permanently attached to any building, pole, standard, or otherwise firmly anchored to the ground, and which can be easily moved or replaced. Flags and banners are not classified as temporary signs. 
(b)  No temporary signs shall be placed within a commercial or manufacturing district unless a permit for the placement thereof shall first have been issued by the building official. Applications for a permit for placement of a temporary sign shall be submitted to the building official and shall specify the location, size, whether illuminated, and whether the location has been previously granted a permit for temporary sign within the preceding 12 months. Applications for permit for temporary signs and shall be accompanied by payment of a fee in the amount of $25.00, except that not for profit organizations shall be exempt from payment of the fee. Each permit issued shall allow the placement of a temporary sign for no longer than 30 consecutive days. No more than three permits shall be issued for temporary sign placement for the same location within any calendar year, but nothing herein shall prohibit the application at the same time for issuance of permits for up to three temporary sign placements at the same location, so long as the permit fees for all placements are paid with the multiple applications. 
(c)  Temporary signs shall comply with all of the following restrictions or requirements: 
(1)  Shall not exceed 50 square feet in area; 
(2)  Shall be placed at least five feet from the property line, and shall be placed in a manner so that visibility for vehicular traffic is not obstructed; 
(3)  Shall be secured to prevent movement or overturning in a manner as approved by the building official; 
(4)  Shall not exceed five feet in height and ten feet in length; 
(5)  If placed upon a corner lot, shall not be placed within the area of a 20-foot radius of the corner thereof; 
(6)  Shall not be placed within 40 feet of a parcel zoned for residential use; 
(7)  If the sign is illuminated or has other electrical connection, all electrical wiring shall comply with the electric code in effect within the city. 
(d)  Except as otherwise allowed by section 12.5-4, temporary signs shall be permitted only in zoning districts B-l, B-2, M-l, MU-1 and M-2. 
(e)  Any temporary sign which does not comply with the requirements of this section is hereby declared to be a nuisance subject to abatement as provided within the Municipal Code. In addition, the owner or occupant of any parcel upon which it is placed a temporary sign that does not conform to the requirements of this section commits a violation punishable as a Class B violation as provided in section l-41. 
(Code 1990, § 12.5-13; Ord. No. 2010-2417, § 3, 9-7-2010; Ord. No. 2011-2458, § 35, 4-5-2011; Ord. No. 2015-2233, § 1, 9-15-2015) 
Chapter 25 - RESERVED 
Chapter 26 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- General powers over streets and public ways, 65 ILCS 5/11-80-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 26-1. - Supervision and enforcement authority. 
    All public streets, alleys, sidewalks and other public ways in the city shall be under the supervision of the street superintendent. He shall be charged with the enforcement of all ordinance provisions relating to such public places, except traffic ordinances, and is authorized to enforce such ordinances. 
(Code 1977, § 12.04.010; Code 1990, § 13-1) 
Sec. 26-3. - Construction-Permit required; application; issuance. 
    It is unlawful to construct or lay any pavement on any public street, sidewalk, alley or other public way, or to repair the same, without first having secured a permit therefor. Applications for such permits shall be made to the building department and shall state the location of the intended pavement or repair, the extent thereof, and the person or firm who is to do the actual construction work. No such permits shall be issued except on order of the council. 
(Code 1977, § 12.04.020; Code 1990, § 13-2) 
Sec. 26-4. - Same-Bond; amount. 
    Each applicant pursuant to section 26-3 shall file a bond in the amount of $50,000.00 with surety to be approved by the council, conditioned to indemnify the city for any loss or damage resulting from the work undertaken or the manner of doing the same. 
(Code 1977, § 12.04.030; Code 1990, § 13-3) 
Sec. 26-5. - Pavement specifications. 
    All street and sidewalk pavements shall be made in conformity with specifications laid down or approved from time to time by the council. 
(Code 1977, § 12.04.040; Code 1990, § 13-4) 
Sec. 26-6. - Injuring pavement. 
    It is unlawful to injure any sidewalk, street or alley pavement. A violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class B violation as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1977, § 12.04.050; Code 1990, § 13-5; Ord. No. 2011-2458, § 36, 4-5-2011) 
Sec. 26-7. - Walking, driving on newly laid pavement. 
    It is unlawful to walk upon or drive any vehicle or animal upon, or injure any newly laid street or sidewalk pavement while the same is guarded by a warning sign or barricade, or to knowingly injure any soft, newly laid pavement. A violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class B violation as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1977, § 12.04.060; Code 1990, § 13-6; Ord. No. 2011-2458, § 37, 4-5-2011) 
Sec. 26-8. - Repairs. 
    All public streets, alleys and sidewalk pavements shall be kept in good repair. Such repair work, whether done by the city or by the abutting owner, shall be under the supervision of the street superintendent. 
(Code 1977, § 12.04.070; Code 1990, § 13-7) 
Sec. 26-9. - Defects or obstructions to be reported. 
    It shall be the duty of every city officer or employee becoming cognizant of any defect in any street, alley or sidewalk, or any obstruction thereof, to report the same to the street superintendent as soon as possible. 
(Code 1977, § 12.04.080; Code 1990, § 13-8) 
Sec. 26-10. - Encroachments. 
(a)  As used in this section, the term "encroachment" means any building, fence, sign or any other structure or object of any kind (with the exception of utilities and public road signs) which is placed, located or maintained in, on, under or over any portion of any street, highway, or other public property. 
(b)  It is unlawful for any person to erect or cause to be erected, or to retain or cause to be retained, an encroachment. A violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class C violation as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1977, §§ 12.04.130, 12.32.010, 12.32.020; Code 1990, § 13-9; Ord. No. 2011-2458, § 38, 4-5-2011) 
Sec. 26-11. - Obstructions. 
    It is unlawful for any person to cause, create or maintain any obstruction of any street, alley, sidewalk or other public way, except as may be specifically authorized by ordinance or by the street superintendent when necessary in an emergency or in connection with any lawful construction, repair or removal work. A violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class C violation as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1977, § 12.04.090; Code 1990, § 13-10; Ord. No. 2011-2458, § 39, 4-5-2011) 
Sec. 26-12. - Obstruction of drains. 
    It is unlawful to obstruct any drain in any public street or alley. A violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class B violation as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1977, § 12.04.100; Code 1990, § 13-11; Ord. No. 2011-2458, § 40, 4-5-2011) 
Sec. 26-13. - Barricades-When required; lights. 
(a)  Any person laying or repairing any pavement on a street, sidewalk or other public place, or making an excavation in any such place, shall maintain suitable barricades to prevent injury to any person or vehicle by reason of the work. Such barricades shall be protected by lights at nighttime. 
(b)  Any defect in any such pavement shall be barricaded to prevent injury. 
(Code 1977, § 12.04.110; Code 1990, § 13-12) 
Sec. 26-14. - Same-Disturbing. 
    It is unlawful to disturb or interfere with any barricade or light lawfully placed to protect or mark any new pavement or excavation or opening in any public street, alley or sidewalk. A violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class B violation as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1977, § 12.04.120; Code 1990, § 13-13; Ord. No. 2011-2458, § 41, 4-5-2011) 
Sec. 26-15. - Construction, maintenance of openings, stairways. 
    It is unlawful to construct or maintain any opening or stairway in any public street or sidewalk or alley without a permit from the council. All such lawfully maintained openings shall be guarded by a suitable strong cover or a railing, to the approval of the street superintendent. A violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class B violation as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1977, § 12.04.140; Code 1990, § 13-14; Ord. No. 2011-2458, § 42, 4-5-2011) 
Sec. 26-16. - Erection, maintenance of poles and wires. 
    It is unlawful to erect any poles or wires or to maintain any poles or wires over any public street, alley or other public way without having first secured permission from the council. A violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class B violation as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1977, § 12.04.150; Code 1990, § 13-15; Ord. No. 2011-2458, § 43, 4-5-2011) 
Sec. 26-17. - Erection, maintenance of gasoline pumps or tanks. 
    It is unlawful to maintain or erect any gasoline pump or tank in any public street, alley or sidewalk. A violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class B violation as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1977, § 12.04.160; Code 1990, § 13-16; Ord. No. 2011-2458, § 44, 4-5-2011) 
Sec. 26-18. - Deposits of materials on streets. 
    It is unlawful to deposit on any street any material which may be harmful to the pavement thereof, or any waste material or any glass or other articles which may do injury to any person, animal or property. A violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class C violation as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1977, § 12.04.170; Code 1990, § 13-17; Ord. No. 2011-2458, § 45, 4-5-2011) 
Sec. 26-19. - Depositing injurious material on sidewalk. 
    It is unlawful to deposit on any public sidewalk any material which may be harmful to the pavement thereof, or any waste material or any glass or other articles which might cause injury to persons, animals or property. A violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class C violation as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1977, § 12.04.180; Code 1990, § 13-18; Ord. No. 2011-2458, § 46, 4-5-2011) 
Sec. 26-20. - Merchandise deposited on sidewalk. 
    Merchandise or other articles may be deposited on sidewalks preparatory to delivery, provided that the usable width is not thereby reduced to less than four feet. No such article shall remain on such walk for more than one-half hour. A violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class B violation as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1977, § 12.04.190; Code 1990, § 13-19; Ord. No. 2011-2458, § 47, 4-5-2011) 
Sec. 26-21. - Articles on window ledges, other places abutting public ways. 
    It is unlawful to place any movable article on any window ledge, or other place abutting on a public street, alley or other place at a height above four feet from the ground in such a manner that the same can be or is in danger of falling onto any such street, sidewalk, alley or other public place. 
(Code 1977, § 8.28.020; Code 1990, § 12-26) 
Sec. 26-22. - Scaffolds and ladders. 
    Any scaffold or ladder placed in such a way that it overhangs or can fall into any public street, alley or other public place in the city shall be firmly constructed and safeguarded. It is unlawful to place or leave any tool or article on any such place in a manner that the same can fall onto any street, sidewalk, alley or other public place from a height greater than four feet. 
(Code 1977, § 8.28.030; Code 1990, § 12-27) 
Sec. 26-23. - Depositing material in streets. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to dump, deposit, bulldoze or plow or cause to be dumped, deposited, bulldozed or plowed any grass, leaves, branches, snow, ice or any other things in the roadway or gutter of any public street in the city. 
(b)  A violation of this section shall be punishable as a class C violation as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1977, § 8.28.040; Code 1990, § 12-28; Ord. No. 2010-2421, § 45, 10-5-2010) 
Sec. 26-24. - Playing games on streets and sidewalks. 
    It is unlawful to play any games upon any street, alley, sidewalk or other public place where such games cause unnecessary noise or interfere with traffic or pedestrians. A violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class C violation as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1977, § 12.04.200; Code 1990, § 13-20; Ord. No. 2011-2458, § 48, 4-5-2011) 
Secs. 26-25-26-51. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - EXCAVATIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 26-52. - Manner of excavating. 
(a)  It is unlawful to make any excavation or tunnel in any way contrary to or at variance with the terms of a permit issued under this article. Proper bracing shall be maintained to prevent the collapse of adjoining ground. An excavation shall not have anywhere below the surface any portion which extends beyond the opening at the surface. 
(b)  No injury shall be done to any pipes, cables or conduits in making excavations or tunnels; and notice shall be given to the city department or officer charged with the care thereof, which are or may be endangered or affected by the making of any such excavation or tunnel before such pipes, cables or conduits shall be disturbed. 
(c)  No unnecessary damage or injury shall be done to any tree or shrub or the roots thereof. 
(d)  A violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class B violation as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1977, § 12.08.070; Code 1990, § 13-36; Ord. No. 2011-2458, § 49, 4-5-2011) 
Sec. 26-53. - Surface restoration. 
(a)  Any person making any excavation or tunnel in or under any public street, alley, sidewalk or other public place in the city shall restore the surface thereof to the original condition as existed prior to the excavation. Refills shall be properly tamped down and backfilled and any bracing in such tunnels shall be left in place. 
(b)  Any opening in a paved or improved portion of a street, sidewalk, alley or other public place shall be prepared and the surface re-laid by the applicant in compliance with city ordinances and subject to the supervision of the street superintendent. If such work is not done within ten days after restoration is possible, the city may restore the surface and charge the cost thereof to the person doing such excavation. 
(c)  If piping is laid or repaired it shall immediately have the space between the pipe and the bottom and sides of the trench packed full with wet sand or other approved material by hand, as fast as placed, up to the top level of pipe. The filling shall be carried up evenly on both sides of the pipe. Care shall be taken that no rock or other hard substances are placed in contact with the pipe. 
(d)  If any piping is installed or replaced such pipe shall be covered by hand to a depth of at least 12 inches with wet sand or other approved material. Material used for backfilling to the depth of 12 inches shall be wet sand or other approved material, free from stones larger than two inches in diameter, frozen material or other hard substance. 
(e)  Unless pipe is installed or repaired, in which event subsection (d) of this section shall apply, the person doing any such excavation shall fill the entire excavation or tunnel with flowable fill (city specifications) in accordance with specifications set forth in table A below. It shall be the duty of the person to complete the resurfacing of any street, sidewalk or alley and to repair any right-of-way in compliance with this article. 
(f)  Backfilling to the base of the street shall comply with city specifications. Material topped with two inches of cold patch may be used only as a temporary street surface. Temporary surfaces may remain for no more than 30 calendar days after the completion of the work performed, at which time permanent surface material shall be installed in compliance with city specifications. If excavations are commenced after November 15 and before May 15, the permittee may use the temporary patch described in this section as a winter patch. Winter patches must be replaced by a permanent patch at the later of May 15 or 30 calendar days after the completion of the work performed. 
(g)  Replacement surfaces for excavations shall be as follows: 
(1)  Concrete with hot mix overlay: Match existing concrete topped with two inches of hot mix compacted to road surface; 
(2)  Compacted bituminous hot mix matched to existing street surface; or 
(3)  Bituminous surface treatment: Compacted two inches of cold patch material leveled to road surface for temporary patches outlined in subsection (c) of this section. 
Table A: Flowable fill specification: Guidance on materials, quantities for mixtures. 
Type I. Recommended trial mixture for use on city right-of-way only (city specifications):

200 (Class C) Course aggregate Fine aggregate 2,900 lbs. Approximate water content 375-540 lbs. Compressive strength at 28 days  
Flowable fill shall be created utilizing the following procedure: 
Load truck mixer at standard charging speed in the following sequence: 
(1)  Add 70 to 80 percent of water required. 
(2)  Add 50 percent of the aggregate filler. 
(3)  Add all cement and fly ash required. 
(4)  Add balance of aggregate filler. 
(5)  Add balance of water. 
Component Quantity Sand 1 ton Water 55 gallons  
(h)  As used herein, the term "wet sand" means sand which has been mixed with water before installation in a mixer or by hand so that the sand is wetted thoroughly and flows in the same manner as flowable fill. 
(Code 1977, § 12.08.080; Code 1990, § 13-37; Ord. No. 2006-2202, § 1, 10-3-2006; Ord. No. 2007-2237, § 1, 6-19-2007; Ord. No. 2010-2410, § 1, 7-20-2010; Ord. No. 2013-2137, § 1, 11-19-2013) 
Sec. 26-54. - Temporary sidewalk; when required. 
    If any sidewalk is blocked by any excavation work, a temporary sidewalk shall be constructed or provided which shall be safe for travel and convenient for users. 
(Code 1977, § 12.08.090; Code 1990, § 13-38) 
Sec. 26-55. - Inspection. 
    The street superintendent shall from time to time inspect all excavations and tunnels being made in or under any public street, alley or other public place in the city to see to the enforcement of the provisions of this article. Notice shall be given to him at least ten hours before the work of refilling any such excavation or tunnel commences. 
(Code 1977, § 12.08.110; Code 1990, § 13-39) 
Secs. 26-56-26-83. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 26-84. - Exemptions. 
    The provisions of this division relative to securing permits shall not apply to officers or employees of the city engaged in doing work for the city; nor to persons or corporations which are operating under a franchise or grant from the city if such franchise provides for the making of excavations and tunnels without securing a permit therefor. 
(Code 1977, § 12.08.120; Code 1990, § 13-56) 
Sec. 26-85. - Required. 
    It is unlawful for any person to tunnel under or to make any excavation in any street, alley or other public place in the city without having obtained a permit therefor as provided in this division, or without complying with the provisions of this division or in violation of or variance from the terms of any such permit. A violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class B violation as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1977, § 12.08.010; Code 1990, § 13-57; Ord. No. 2011-2458, § 50, 4-5-2011) 
Sec. 26-86. - Application. 
    Applications for excavation permits shall be made to the building department and shall describe the location of the intended excavation or tunnel, the size thereof, the purpose thereof, the person doing the actual excavating work and the name of the person for whom the work is being done. Such applications shall contain an agreement that the applicant will comply with all ordinances relating to the work being done. 
(Code 1977, § 12.08.020; Code 1990, § 13-58; Ord. No. 2008-2267, § 5, 4-1-2008) 
Sec. 26-87. - Estimated time for completion stated on application. 
    Each application for a permit under this division shall state the length of time it is estimated will elapse from the commencement of the work until the restoration of the surface of the ground, or until the refill is made ready for the pavement to be put on by the city, if the city restores such surface pavement. It is unlawful to fail to comply with this time limitation unless permission for an extension of time is granted by the council. 
(Code 1977, § 12.08.040; Code 1990, § 13-59) 
Sec. 26-88. - Issuance. 
    No permit under this division shall be issued except on order of the street superintendent or his designee. 
(Code 1977, § 12.08.030; Code 1990, § 13-60; Ord. No. 2008-2267, § 6, 4-1-2008) 
Sec. 26-89. - Bond. 
    No permit under this division shall be issued unless and until the applicant therefor has filed with the building department a bond in the sum of $50,000.00, conditioned to indemnify the city for any loss, liability or damage that may result or accrue because of the making or existence of such excavation. 
(Code 1977, § 12.08.060; Code 1990, § 13-61; Ord. No. 2008-2267, § 7, 4-1-2008) 
Secs. 26-90-26-106. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CONSTRUCTION OF DRIVEWAYS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 26-107. - Grade surface requirements. 
    No driveway shall be so constructed or graded as to leave a step, sharp depression or other obstruction in the sidewalk. It is unlawful to have the surface finish of any driveway, where the same crosses the sidewalk, constructed of such materials as to render it slippery and hazardous to pedestrians or to have the grade of such portion vary from the grade of the sidewalk or be other than level. 
(Code 1977, § 12.16.060; Code 1990, § 13-76) 
Sec. 26-108. - Materials. 
    Driveways across sidewalks shall be constructed of concrete or of such other materials as may be approved by the council. 
(Code 1977, § 12.16.070; Code 1990, § 13-77) 
Sec. 26-109. - Maintenance. 
    It shall be the duty of the person maintaining a driveway to keep the same in good repair where it crosses the sidewalk and free from obstructions and openings. 
(Code 1977, § 12.16.080; Code 1990, § 13-78) 
Secs. 26-110-26-131. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 26-132. - Required. 
    No person shall construct a driveway across any sidewalk in the city without having first obtained a permit therefor. 
(Code 1977, § 12.16.010; Code 1990, § 13-96) 
Sec. 26-133. - Application. 
    Applications for permits under this division shall be made to the building department and shall be accompanied by the required fee. 
(Code 1977, § 12.16.020; Code 1990, § 13-97; Ord. No. 2008-2767, § 8, 4-1-2008) 
Sec. 26-134. - Commercial or habitual use; council approval required. 
    No permit for construction of a driveway for commercial use or for the habitual use of other than the owner or occupant of the premises served shall be issued except upon the order of the council. 
(Code 1977, § 12.16.030; Code 1990, § 13-98) 
Secs. 26-135-26-151. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - HOUSE NUMBERING 

Sec. 26-152. - Thoroughfare naming and property numbering system. 
(a)  Thoroughfare names. Thoroughfare names shall be chosen that relate to the scale and location of the subdivision or local history. 
(1)  Objectives. Names should be pleasant sounding, appropriate, easy to read (so the public, children in particular, can handle the name in an emergency situation), and should add to the pride of home ownership and entrepreneurial activity. 
(2)  Categories. Wherever possible, street names in the same section of a neighborhood or subdivision in the city shall be related to identifiable local landmarks, historic events, or themes. 
(3)  Unacceptable thoroughfare names. Numerical names, e.g., First or 1st, which do not correspond with address numbers in hundred blocks; alphabetical letters, e.g., A, B, C, etc.; frivolous, complicated or undesirable names; unconventional spelling; compound names (unless used sparingly and not on short streets); words in a foreign language; proper names, e.g., Carol, Ellen, George, etc., shall not be permitted. 
(4)  Affixes. Unnecessary affixes are to be avoided. The only terms which may be used as prefixes are: East, West, North and South which shall indicate direction from the base lines. The only terms which may be used as suffixes are: 
a.  "Alley" or "Lane" to describe a secondary access drive to property, generally in the rear of the property. 
b.  "Boulevard" to describe a thoroughfare divided by a landscaped center island, or a major thoroughfare running in a diagonal direction, rather than east-west or north-south, which connects at least two arterial or collector thoroughfares. 
c.  "Close" to describe an open space having property frontage, but no public right-of-way, along its perimeter and having one side fronting a public thoroughfare. 
d.  "Court" to describe a permanently closed thoroughfare ending in a turnaround such as a cul-de-sac. 
e.  "Drive" "Trail" or "Way" to describe a winding or curvilinear thoroughfare that meanders about and continues through to other rights-of-way, generally discontinuous thoroughfares. 
f.  "Highway" to describe a designated state or federal highway. 
g.  "Circle" to describe short thoroughfares that return to themselves or begin and circle back to terminate on the same thoroughfare. 
h.  "Parkway" to describe a special scenic route or park drive or thoroughfare having an unusual amount of landscaping. 
i.  "Place" to describe any private street, usually a private cul-de-sac or permanent dead-end thoroughfare. 
j.  "Road" to describe any thoroughfare located on a section line, having heavy traffic volume, and running in any direction. 
k.  "Square" to describe any thoroughfare that forms one or more sides of an attached or detached square. 
l.  "Street" or "Avenue" to describe thoroughfares generally parallel to the base lines and having continuity; streets run east-west; avenues run north-south. 
(5)  Name duplication. Similar sounding names are considered to be duplication, regardless of spelling. No duplication of names is permitted in the city, and no duplication of names is permitted within the service area of a fire protection district regardless whether the duplicate name is located in or outside the city corporate limits. 
(6)  Continuity. A continuous thoroughfare, or a thoroughfare proposed to be a continuous thoroughfare, shall bear the same name throughout, even if it changes direction or if interim gaps prevent the thoroughfare from being continuous. No separate name is to be used for a cul-de-sac that provides street frontage for three or less lots or dwelling units. The name shall be the same as that of the intersecting thoroughfare. However, where there is a series of long and short culs-de-sac along a thoroughfare, each shall have a separate name. 
(b)  Property numbering. 
(1)  Vanity addresses. Vanity addresses are prohibited. The term "vanity address" means one in which the name or number have no relationship to the city's street naming and property numbering system. 
(2)  Reference point. The reference point, or point of origin, for the city property numbering system shall be the intersection of 1st Avenue and 1st Street. 
(3)  Base lines. The base lines from which measurements used to assign property numbers are taken for the city property numbering system shall be 1st Avenue and 1st Street. 
(4)  Grid lines. The grid lines indicating where block numbers change from 100 to the next higher hundred for the city property numbering system shall be at an interval of 2,000 feet on the east-west axis, and at an interval of 2,000 feet on the north-south axis. 
(5)  Frontage unit. The standard interval in frontage to assign consecutive property numbers on any thoroughfare in the city shall be ten feet. 
(6)  Countywide numbering system. A property numbering system shall be developed and maintained for each new development in the city without necessary regard for the existing countywide numbering system. 
(c)  Assigning numbers to individual parcels. 
(1)  General. When assigning numbers, start at the grid or base line and allow hypothetical numbers for each frontage interval. Do not skip across streets, utility easements, railroads, streams, etc., because if time brings change, there will be numbers available to assign to new parcels. Vacant property is not to be assigned a number until something is built thereon it. The interval closest to a line perpendicular to the front building entrance shall be the one assigned. 
(2)  West of 1st Avenue. Odd numbers shall be assigned to buildings on the southerly and easterly sides of the thoroughfare west of 1st Avenue. Even numbers shall be assigned to the opposite side. 
(3)  East of 1st Avenue. Odd numbers shall be assigned to buildings on the northerly and easterly sides of the thoroughfare east of 1st Avenue. Even numbers shall be assigned to the opposite side. 
(4)  Apartments and condominiums. Separate units of condominium and apartment buildings having internal entrances shall be designated with sub-numbers and letters (e.g., Apt. A, Apt. 310), but not individual property numbers. 
(5)  Business districts. In a commercial, office, or industrial district, each external door shall have its own number. Businesses with an internal entrance shall be designated by suite numbers or letters (e.g., Suite 206). 
(6)  Numbering when a thoroughfare changes direction. As a general rule, if a thoroughfare changes direction drastically and for a substantial length, the numbering should be changed to reflect the orientation with a different base line. The same criteria used to determine when to change a thoroughfare name shall be used to decide whether to use numbering from the east-west axis or the north-south axis. 
(7)  Thoroughfares starting from different points on the same cross street. When a thoroughfare does not begin at the same location as a parallel thoroughfare, the numbers shall begin with the same number measured from the base line as on the parallel thoroughfare. Likewise, buildings facing thoroughfares that do not extend to the base line at present are assigned numbers as if they were extended to the base line. 
(8)  Diagonal thoroughfares. The general principle to apply when numbering diagonal thoroughfares is to treat the thoroughfare as either a north-south or an east-west thoroughfare if it is not a perfect diagonal. If the thoroughfare is a perfect diagonal, an arbitrary decision is made to treat it is a north-south or an east-west thoroughfare. 
(9)  Corner lots. When assigning a number to a building on a corner lot, assign a number from the thoroughfare upon which the front entrance faces. Dual addresses shall be avoided if at all possible. 
(10)  Group housing projects/private drives. Because of private drives and interior parking bays, group housing developments present unique problems to the assignment of property numbers. A number shall be assigned to the property where the driveway joins the thoroughfare and shall become the street address of all units which face upon that interior court or parking lot. The separate apartments or stores shall have a sub-number, for example, 630 Dixon Avenue Building D. This method shall also be utilized for assigning numbers in crowded, disorganized, or haphazard development where there are rear dwellings. 
(11)  Duplex buildings, multiple buildings on a lot, and buildings with multiple entrances. 
a.  Separate numbers shall be assigned to each entrance of a duplex house, for an upstairs apartment which has an outside entrance, for separate buildings in the rear of other buildings, and for separate entrances in an apartment or commercial building. If a commercial enterprise that is part of a residence has a separate entrance from a thoroughfare, it shall also be assigned a separate number. 
b.  If there is a rear entrance or a hidden structure, a post shall display the number on the path leading to the entrance, even if it is reached through another structure. For units on alleys or interior malls where there is no access to a thoroughfare parallel to the alley, a name shall be given to the alley and property numbers are assigned accordingly. If there is access from a parallel thoroughfare, numbers shall be assigned from the series on that thoroughfare. 
c.  In the case of commercial or industrial facilities, auxiliary buildings will not be assigned separate numbers, but the main building (where business is transacted) will receive a property number. 
(12)  Numbering on circle and loop thoroughfares. Circle thoroughfares begin and end touching the same thoroughfare. It is advisable in such cases to ignore compass directions and to give numbers on such thoroughfares to correspond with the numbering on the street where the circle is originated. There will be more properties on the outside of the circle than on the inside of the circle. In such cases, numbers shall be assigned in the regular manner to the side of the circle thoroughfare having the greatest property frontage along the thoroughfare, using consecutive odd or even numbers. Numbers shall then be assigned to the side having the shorter frontage such that numbers correspond with property on the opposite side of the thoroughfare. It is wise to avoid duplication of numbers if an auxiliary thoroughfare using a different thoroughfare designation carries the same name as the main thoroughfare. 
(Code 1977, § 12.24.010; Code 1990, § 13-116; Ord. No. 92-1638, § 1, 12-21-1992; Ord. No. 2013-2121, 9-3-2013) 
Sec. 26-153. - Street number chart. 
    The building official shall maintain a chart and provide a copy of such chart to the city clerk, showing the proper street number of every lot within the city, and such chart shall be opened to inspection by all interested persons. 
(Code 1977, § 12.24.020; Code 1990, § 13-117; Ord. No. 92-1638, § 1, 12-21-1992) 
Sec. 26-154. - Placement and visibility of house numbers. 
    It shall be the duty of the owner and occupant of every commercial and residential building within the city to place thereon, in a place visible from the street, in figures at least four inches in height, the street number of the building, as assigned by the building official. It shall be unlawful for any person to fail to so number any commercial or residential building owned or occupied by him after receipt of notice to so number from the proper authority of the city. 
(Code 1977, § 12.24.030; Code 1990, § 13-118; Ord. No. 92-1638, § 1, 12-21-1992; Ord. No. 2000-1936, § 1, 5-16-2000) 
Secs. 26-155-26-176. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - TREES, HEDGES AND SHRUBS 

Sec. 26-177. - Permit required for planting in public place. 
    It is unlawful to plant any tree or bush in any public street or parkway or other public place without having first secured a permit therefor. Applications for such permits shall be made to the city clerk and shall be referred by him to the street superintendent. All trees and shrubs so planted shall be placed subject to the direction and approval of the street superintendent. A violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class B violation as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1977, § 12.28.010; Code 1990, § 13-136; Ord. No. 2011-2458, § 51, 4-5-2011) 
Sec. 26-178. - Trees; prohibited locations. 
    No trees or shrubs shall be planted nearer than 20 feet, as measured horizontally from any overhead electrical utility lines or wires, nor nearer than ten feet to any underground (buried) electrical utility line. If any trees or shrubs are planted in violation of the provisions of this section, the city utility department shall give notice to the owner of the real estate upon which the trees or shrubs are planted or growing to remove the same. Upon failure of the owner to remove the trees or shrubs within ten days following the delivery of the notice referred to in the preceding sentence, the city utility crew shall be authorized to cause the trees or shrubs to be removed, and the owner of the real estate upon which the trees or shrubs are growing shall reimburse to the city the cost of such removal. 
(Code 1977, § 12.28.020; Code 1990, § 13-137; Ord. No. 93-1650, 3-1-1993) 
Sec. 26-179. - Removal permit. 
    It is unlawful to remove or cut down any tree or shrub or portion thereof in any street, parkway or other public place without having first secured a permit therefor. Applications for such permits shall be made to the city clerk and shall be referred by him to the street superintendent before permission shall be granted. A violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class B violation as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1977, § 12.28.030; Code 1990, § 13-138; Ord. No. 2011-2458, § 52, 4-5-2011) 
Sec. 26-180. - Injuring. 
    It is unlawful to injure any tree or shrub planted in any public place. A violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class B violation as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1977, § 12.28.040; Code 1990, § 13-139; Ord. No. 2011-2458, § 53, 4-5-2011) 
Sec. 26-181. - Gas pipe leaks. 
    Any person or company maintaining any gas pipe in the city shall, in the absence of provisions in the franchise concerning the subject, keep such pipes free from leaks so that no injury shall be done to any tree or shrub. 
(Code 1977, § 12.28.060; Code 1990, § 13-140) 
Sec. 26-182. - Attachment of wires or ropes; trimming near wires, poles. 
(a)  It is unlawful to attach any wire or rope to any tree or shrub in any public street, parkway or other public place without the permission of the street superintendent. 
(b)  Any person or company given the right to maintain the poles and wires in the streets, alleys or other public places in the city shall, in the absence of provision in the franchise concerning the subject, keep such wires and poles free from and away from any trees or shrubs in such places so far as may be possible and shall keep all such trees and shrubs properly trimmed, subject to the supervision of the street superintendent so that no injury shall be done either to the poles or wires or the shrubs and trees by their contact. 
(c)  A violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class B violation as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1977, § 12.28.070; Code 1990, § 13-141; Ord. No. 2011-2458, § 54, 4-5-2011) 
Sec. 26-183. - Trimming or removal. 
(a)  The owner of real estate upon which any tree or shrub is growing, which overhangs any sidewalk, street, or other public place is responsible for and shall cause such tree or shrub to be trimmed in such a way that it does not impede or interfere with traffic or travel on such public place, in accordance with the requirements of this section. Any tree or shrub overhanging a sidewalk or other pedestrian way shall be trimmed so that the minimum height above the walk surface is eight feet. Any tree or shrub overhanging a street, alley or other highway for the use of motor vehicles shall be trimmed, or removed as necessary, so that the minimum height above the surface of the traveled way is 16 feet. 
(b)  In addition to the minimum clearance heights specified in subsection (a) of this section, the owner of any premises upon which any tree or shrub is growing shall cause said tree or shrub to be trimmed, as necessary, so that such tree or shrub does not constitute an obstruction to the view of a driver of a motor vehicle traveling upon any public street, alley or other highway, nor impede the safe movement of motor vehicles along or upon any street, alley, or other highway adjoining the premises upon which the tree or shrub is growing. 
(c)  The owner of any premises upon which is growing a tree, any portion of which has become in danger of falling on or across any public sidewalk, street, alley or highway shall cause that part of the tree or shrub to be removed before the same shall have fallen. 
(d)  The street superintendent, the police chief or the building official, or any agent or employee authorized and directed by them, are authorized and directed to give notice to the owner of any premises within the city of the requirement that such owner comply with the provisions of this section. If the owner shall fail, within 14 days following the issuance of such notice, to comply with this section, then the street superintendent is authorized to direct the trimming or removal of any tree or shrub or portion thereof so that the same shall comply with the requirements of this section, and the owner of the premises upon which the tree or shrub is growing shall be responsible for and shall pay and reimburse the city for the reasonable cost and expense incurred in such trimming or removal. 
(e)  A violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class C violation as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1977, § 12.28.080; Code 1990, § 13-142; Ord. No. 2001-1975, § 1, 7-3-2000; Ord. No. 2010-2431, § 1, 12-7-2010; Ord. No. 2011-2458, § 55, 4-5-2011) 
Sec. 26-184. - Attachment of advertisements or notices. 
    It is unlawful to attach any sign, advertisement or notice to any tree or shrub in any street, parkway or other public place. A violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class B violation as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1977, § 12.28.090; Code 1990, § 13-143; Ord. No. 2011-2458, § 56, 4-5-2011) 
Secs. 26-185-26-206. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - LAND USE PERMIT; EXCAVATIONS 

Sec. 26-207. - Land use permit-Required; exceptions. 
    The excavations from or deposits on the earth of rock, stone, gravel, sand, earth, minerals or building or construction materials shall not be construed to be a permitted use in any district established by this chapter unless and until a land use (building) permit has first been secured therefor, except for the following defined extractions and deposits: 
(1)  Excavations for the foundation or basement of any building or for a swimming pool for which a land use permit or a building permit has been issued, or deposits on the earth of any building or construction materials to be used in a structure for which such zoning permit and building permit has been issued; 
(2)  Grading of any parcel of land for a permitted use where no bank is left standing and exposed of more than ten feet in vertical height, or when less than 1,000 cubic yards of earth is removed from the premises; 
(3)  Grading in a subdivision which has been approved by the city in accordance with the city subdivision regulations and any amendments thereto; 
(4)  Excavations by any public agency or public utility for the installation, operation, inspection, repair or replacement of any of its facilities; 
(5)  Any quarry or gravel pit existing as such on the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived shall obtain a new use permit and conform with the provisions of this article within one year of the adoption of the ordinance from which this article is derived. 
(Code 1977, § 17.48.010; Code 1990, § 13-161; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 3(16-411), 4-19-1993) 
Sec. 26-208. - Same-Issuing authority; validity. 
    The council shall have the power to grant special land use permits, revocable and valid for specified periods of time, to permit extractions from or deposits on the earth of rock, stone, gravel, sand, earth, minerals or building or construction materials as set forth in this article. 
(Code 1977, § 17.48.010; Code 1990, § 13-162; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 3(16-412), 4-19-1993) 
Sec. 26-209. - Same-Conditions for issuance. 
    The conditions under which a use permit for excavation from or depositing on the earth of such materials may be issued, may include, but are not limited to, any requirements deemed necessary to protect the public health, safety, comfort, convenience or general welfare including insurance against liability arising from production or activities or operations incident thereto; completion of the work and cleaning up and planting in accordance with approved plans; designation of area in which work may be done; designation of the slope to which excavation may be made or the grade of filling; provisions for controlling dust; hours during which operations may proceed; precautions which must be taken to guide safe traffic movements in and around and by such operation; enclosure by fences of exterior boundaries of property to be used; posting of a good and sufficient bond to ensure compliance with the use permit and any other conditions deemed necessary by the zoning board of appeals. 
(Code 1977, § 17.48.010; Code 1990, § 13-163; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 3(16-413), 4-19-1993) 
Sec. 26-210. - Inspections. 
    The building official shall make such inspections as he deems necessary or as are required by the zoning board of appeals to ensure that all work is in accordance with the use permit issued under this article. All inspection services shall be paid for by the applicant at the actual cost to the city. 
(Code 1977, § 17.48.010; Code 1990, § 13-164; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 3(16-414), 4-19-1993) 
Secs. 26-211-26-228. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - CONSTRUCTION OF UTILITY FACILITIES IN THE RIGHTS-OF-WAY 

Sec. 26-229. - Purpose and scope. 
(a)  Purpose. The purpose of this article is to establish policies and procedures for constructing facilities on rights-of-way within the city's jurisdiction, which will provide public benefit consistent with the preservation of the integrity, safe usage, and visual qualities of the city rights-of-way and the city as a whole. 
(b)  Intent. In enacting this article, the city intends to exercise its authority over the rights-of-way in the city and, in particular, the use of the public ways and property by utilities, by establishing uniform standards to address issues presented by utility facilities, including without limitation: 
(1)  Prevent interference with the use of streets, sidewalks, alleys, parkways and other public ways and places; 
(2)  Prevent the creation of visual and physical obstructions and other conditions that are hazardous to vehicular and pedestrian traffic; 
(3)  Prevent interference with the facilities and operations of the city's utilities and of other utilities lawfully located in rights-of-way or public property; 
(4)  Protect against environmental damage, including damage to trees, from the installation of utility facilities; 
(5)  Protect against increased stormwater run-off due to structures and materials that increase impermeable surfaces; 
(6)  Preserve the character of the neighborhoods in which facilities are installed; 
(7)  Preserve open space, particularly the tree-lined parkways that characterize the city's residential neighborhoods; 
(8)  Prevent visual blight from the proliferation of facilities in the rights-of-way; and 
(9)  Ensure the continued safe use and enjoyment of private properties adjacent to utility facilities locations. 
(c)  Facilities subject to this article. This article applies to all facilities on, over, above, along, upon, under, across, or within the rights-of-way within the jurisdiction of the city. A facility lawfully established prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived may continue to be maintained, repaired and operated by the utility as presently constructed and located, except as may be otherwise provided in any applicable franchise, license or similar agreement. 
(d)  Franchises, licenses, or similar agreements. The city, in its discretion and as limited by law, may require utilities to enter into a franchise, license or similar agreement for the privilege of locating their facilities on, over, above, along, upon, under, across, or within the city rights-of-way. Utilities that are not required by law to enter into such an agreement may request that the city enter into such an agreement. In such an agreement, the city may provide for terms and conditions inconsistent with this article.
