State Law reference- Municipal Automobile Renting Occupation Tax, 65 ILCS 5/8-11-7. 

Sec. 30-88. - Imposed; amount. 
    A tax is imposed upon all persons engaged in the business of renting automobiles in this city at the rate of one percent of the gross receipts from such sales made in the course of such business, in accordance with the provisions of 65 ILCS 5/8-11-7. 
(Code 1977, § 3.28.010; Code 1990, § 6-101) 
Secs. 30-89-30-108. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - HOTEL TAX[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to adopt hotel tax, 5 ILCS 5/8-3-14. 

Sec. 30-109. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Bureau means the city convention and visitors bureau, as the same is established and existing pursuant to this article or any other ordinance of the city modifying or amending the provisions or establishing any of the duties or responsibilities of such bureau. 
    Department means the state department of revenue. 
    Hotel means any building or buildings in which the public may, for a consideration, obtain living quarters, sleeping or housekeeping accommodations. The term "hotel" includes inns, motels, tourist homes or courts, lodginghouses, roominghouses, apartment houses and bed-and-breakfast houses. 
    Occupancy means the use or possession, or the right to the use or possession, of any room or rooms in a hotel for any purpose, or the right to the use or possession of the furnishings or to the services and accommodations accompanying the use and possession of the room or rooms. 
    Permanent resident means any person who occupies or has the right to occupy any room or rooms in a hotel for at least 30 consecutive days for his or her own personal use unrelated to the conducting of any business or occupation. 
    Rent or rental means the consideration received for occupancy, valued in money, whether received in money or otherwise, including all receipts, cash, credits and property or services of any kind or nature. 
    Renter means any person who pays for the privilege of using or occupying a hotel room for the period for which payment is made. 
    Room or rooms means any living quarters, sleeping or housekeeping accommodations. 
(Code 1990, § 6-122; Ord. No. 91-1602, § 1, 10-29-1991) 
Sec. 30-110. - Tax imposed. 
(a)  There is hereby levied and imposed a tax upon all persons, firms or corporations engaged in the business of renting, leasing or letting rooms in a hotel which is located within the corporate limits of the city, at a rate of five percent of the gross rental receipts from such renting, leasing or letting for any purpose for each 24-hour period or portion thereof, excluding, however, from the gross rental receipts the proceeds of such rents, leasing or letting to permanent residents. The tax imposed herein shall be in addition to any and all other taxes and charges applicable to such hotels, but such other taxes and charges shall not be construed to be a part of the gross rental receipts upon which this tax is levied. 
(b)  The ultimate incidents of and liability for payment of the tax levied herein is upon the person engaged in the business of leasing, renting or letting such rooms. Such hotel owners and operators may reimburse themselves for their tax liability for this tax by separately stating such tax as an additional charge to the lessee or renter, which charge may be stated in combination as a single amount, with the state tax imposed under the hotel operator's occupation tax (35 ILCS 145/1 et seq.). No tax is imposed based upon receipts from any permanent residents of any hotel. 
(c)  No person engaged in the business of renting, leasing or letting rooms in a hotel shall reimburse himself or charge for the imposition of this tax at a rate higher than the tax imposed by this article. 
(d)  Except as otherwise provided in this subsection (d), on or before the last day of each calendar month, every person engaged in the business of renting, leasing or letting rooms in a hotel within the city during the preceding calendar month shall file a return with the treasurer, on forms to be supplied by the treasurer, stating: 
(1)  The name of the operator; 
(2)  His residence address and the address of the principal place of business from which he engages in the business of renting, leasing or letting rooms in a hotel in the city; 
(3)  Total amount of rental receipts received by him during the preceding calendar month from renting, leasing or letting rooms during such preceding calendar month; 
(4)  Total amount of rental receipts received by him during the preceding calendar month from renting, leasing or letting rooms to permanent residents during such preceding calendar months; 
(5)  Total amount of other exclusions from gross rental receipts as allowed by this article; 
(6)  Gross rental receipts which were received by him during the preceding calendar month and upon the basis of which the tax is imposed; 
(7)  The amount of the tax due; 
(8)  The amount of the penalty due, if any; 
(9)  Such other reasonable information as may from time to time be required by the treasurer. 
The person subject to tax shall also transmit to the treasurer with the return required by this subsection (d), the amount of the tax and penalties, if any, due as shown by such return. Such person shall also file with the treasurer, not later than five business days after such documents are transmitted to the state, copies of all hotel operator's occupation tax returns as are required by the provisions of the hotel operator's occupation tax (35 ILCS 145/1 et seq.). 
(e)  Any person engaged in the business of renting, leasing or letting of hotel rooms shall maintain complete and accurate books and records, including a daily sheet showing the gross receipts for the hotel rentals for the day reported. 
(f)  For the purposes of enforcing and administering this article, the treasurer or such agents as are designated by the treasurer shall, after providing reasonable notice, have access during normal business hours to the books and records of persons and businesses subject to this article. The treasurer or such agents as are designated by the treasurer shall at least annually inspect such books and records and shall file a written report of his or her findings with the city council no later than April 1 of each year. 
(g)  Any person who violates any provision of this article, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine of not less than $200.00 nor more than $500.00 for the first offense, and not less than $300.00 and not more than $750.00 for the second and each subsequent offense during any 180-day period. A separate and distinct offense shall be regarded as having been committed each day upon which such person shall continue any such violation. 
(h)  There is hereby created a city tourism promotion fund into which the treasurer shall, by the twentieth day of each month, place the proceeds resulting from the previous month's collection of this hotel tax. The moneys in this fund shall be utilized solely and exclusively for the purpose of promoting tourism and to attract overnight visitors in the city and county. 
(i)  This tax shall not in any manner constitute an indebtedness by the city subject to any limitation imposed by statute or otherwise. 
(j)  Nothing herein adopted shall be construed to affect any suit now pending in any court or any rights accrued or liability incurred or any cause or causes of action accrued or existing under any prior resolution or ordinance; nor shall any right or remedy of any character be lost, impaired or affected by this article. 
(k)  Every person required by this section to file a return and pay a tax hereunder shall pay a penalty for late filing of the return or for late payment of the tax, and such penalty shall be equal to five percent for each month, or part of month, in which the return shall be filed late, and five percent for each month, or part of month, in which the tax is paid late. 
(Code 1990, § 6-123; Ord. No. 91-1602, § 1, 10-29-1991; Ord. No. 91-1603, 11-4-1991; Ord. No. 2004-2089, § 1, 5-18-2004) 
Sec. 30-111. - Use of funds generated. 
    The moneys generated from the imposition of the tax authorized by this article shall be expended in such manner as the city council shall, from time to time, determine necessary and expedient in order to accomplish the goals of promotion of tourism and attraction of overnight visitors to the city. For that purpose, the city council may, from time to time enter into contracts or agreements with other persons, organizations or agencies to provide services or products intended and designed to promote such tourism and overnight visitor attraction, and upon such terms and conditions as the city council shall determine necessary; provided, however, that every such contract or agreement so authorized shall include a prohibition against use of any of the moneys generated from the tax imposed by this article for advertisement for or otherwise promotion of new competition in the hotel business. 
(Code 1990, § 6-124; Ord. No. 91-1602, § 1, 10-29-1991; Ord. No. 2003-2043, § 1, 5-20-2003; Ord. No. 2005-2135, § 1, 5-17-2005; Ord. No. 2008-2269, § 1, 2, 5-20-2008) 
Secs. 30-112-30-135. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - TAX ON SUPPLYING, FURNISHING, OR SELLING GAS 

Sec. 30-136. - Tax imposed. 
    A tax is hereby imposed on all persons engaged in the business of distributing, supplying, furnishing or selling gas for use or consumption within the corporate limits of the city, and not for resale at the rate of five per cent of the gross receipts therefrom actually paid to the taxpayer for services billed. 
(Code 1990, § 6-230; Ord. No. 2003-2068, § 1, 10-21-2003; Ord. No. 2010-2383, § 1, 3-2-2010) 
Sec. 30-137. - Exceptions. 
(a)  The tax authorized by this article shall not be imposed with respect to any transaction in interstate commerce or otherwise to the extent to which the business or privilege may not, under the constitution and statutes of the United States, be made the subject of taxation by the state or any political subdivision thereof; nor shall the tax imposed by this article be imposed upon or applicable to any person engaged in the business of distributing, supplying, furnishing, selling or transmitting gas for any transaction that is or may become subject to taxation under the provisions of the Non-Home Rule Municipal Retailers' Occupation Tax Act 965 ILCS 5/8-11-1.3). 
(b)  The tax imposed by this article shall be imposed in like manner and at the same rate upon all persons engaged in businesses of the same class within the city, whether privately or municipally owned or operated, or exercising the same privilege within the municipality. 
(c)  The tax imposed and enumerated in this article shall be in addition to the payment of any money, or value of products or services furnished to the city by any tax payer upon whom the tax is imposed as compensation for the use of the streets, alleys, or other public places of the city, or for installation or maintenance therein, as used in the operation of the taxpayer's business. 
(Code 1990, § 6-231; Ord. No. 2003-2068, § 1, 10-21-2003) 
Sec. 30-138. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Gross receipts means the consideration received for distributing, supplying, furnishing or selling gas for use or consumption and not for resale, and for all services rendered in connection therewith valued in money, whether received in money or otherwise, including cash, credit, services and property of every kind and material and for all services rendered therewith, and shall be determined without any deduction on account of the cost of the service, product or commodity supplied, the cost of materials used, labor or service cost, or any other expenses whatsoever. The term "gross receipts" does not include any amounts specifically excluded from the definition of gross receipts as enumerated within 65 ILCS 5/8-11-2. The term "gross receipts" shall not include that portion of the consideration received for distributing, supplying, furnishing, or selling gas to school districts or units of local government. 
(Code 1990, § 6-232; Ord. No. 2003-2068, § 1, 10-21-2003) 
Sec. 30-139. - Effective date. 
    The tax levied herein at the rate of three percent shall be based on the gross receipts, as herein defined, actually paid to the taxpayer for services billed on or after November 1, 2003, through and including April 30, 2010. The tax levied herein at the rate of five percent shall be based on the gross receipts, as herein defined, actually paid to the taxpayer for services billed on or after May 1, 2010. 
(Code 1990, § 6-234; Ord. No. 2003-2068, § 1, 10-21-2003; Ord. No. 2010-2383, § 2, 3-2-2010) 
Sec. 30-140. - Tax return required. 
(a)  On or before December 31, 2003, each taxpayer shall make a return to the city treasurer for the month of November, stating: 
(1)  His name; 
(2)  His principal place of business; 
(3)  His gross receipts during those months upon the basis of which the tax is imposed; 
(4)  Amount of tax; 
(5)  Such other reasonable and related information as the corporate authorities may require. 
(b)  On or before the last day of every month thereafter, each taxpayer shall make a like return to the city treasurer for a corresponding one month period. 
(c)  The taxpayer making the return herein provided for shall, at the time of making such return, pay to the city treasurer, the amount of tax herein imposed; provided that in connection with any return the taxpayer may, if he so elects, report and pay an amount based upon his total billings of business subject to the tax during the period for which the return is made (exclusive of any amounts previously billed) with prompt adjustments of later payments based upon any differences between such billings and the taxable gross receipts. 
(Code 1990, § 6-235; Ord. No. 2003-2068, § 1, 10-21-2003) 
Sec. 30-141. - Erroneous payment. 
    If it shall appear that an amount of tax has been paid which was not due under the provisions of this article, whether as the result of a mistake of fact or an error of law, then such amount shall be credited against any tax due, or to become due, under this article from the taxpayer who made the erroneous payment. 
(Code 1990, § 6-236; Ord. No. 2003-2068, § 1, 10-21-2003) 
Sec. 30-142. - Penalty. 
    Any taxpayer who fails to make a return, or who makes a fraudulent return, or who willfully violates any other provision of this article is guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be fined not less than $100.00 nor more than $750.00 and in addition shall be liable in a civil action for the amount of tax due. 
(Code 1990, § 6-238; Ord. No. 2003-2068, § 1, 10-21-2003) 
Chapter 31 - RESERVED 
Chapter 32 - UTILITIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Municipal utilities, 65 ILCS 5/11-117-1 et seq.; water supply system, 65 ILCS 5/11-124-11 et seq.; construction and purchase of waterworks, 5 ILCS 5/11-130-1 et seq.; Public Utilities Act, 220 ILCS 5/1-101 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 32-1. - Creation of utility office. 
    It is hereby created a utility office to be located within the municipal building. Said utility office shall have, among its duties, the preparation of and mailing of invoices and bills to customers of the various utility services of the city, and the receipt and collection of amounts due for utility services provided to customers of the city. The utility office shall be under the day to day supervision of a crew leader, to be designated and named by the electric superintendent with the advice and consent of the mayor and city council. The crew leader of the utility office shall be charged with the carrying out of the duties assigned by this section and by the city council from time to time, and the crew leader shall provide reports of the activities of said office to the electric superintendent, city council and mayor and to the superintendent of each utility department of the city. The utility office shall also perform such other duties as may from time to time be assigned by the electric superintendent, mayor and city council. 
(Code 1990, § 15-1; Ord. No. 2000-1922, § 1, 2-3-2000; Ord. No. 2008-2262, § 1, 1-15-2008; Ord. No. 2013-2111, § 1, 6-18-2013) 
Secs. 32-2-32-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - BILLS 

Sec. 32-21. - No new service to persons owing charges in arrears. 
    No person owing utility charges and removing to other premises where there are city utility connections or where connections shall afterwards be made shall be served until such charges in arrears are paid in full. 
(Code 1977, § 13.12.140; Code 1990, § 15-27) 
Sec. 32-22. - Bills generally; delayed payment. 
(a)  The rates specified within this Code for electrical, water, sanitary sewer and garbage collection services shall be applied to the service utilized by each customer of a utility department, and a written bill shall be prepared by the city's customer service office. Each bill prepared shall be mailed to the customer at the address provided therefor by the customer to the customer service office. Each bill shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The time period and number of days of utility services provided for each service; 
(2)  The amount owed for each utility service supplied; 
(3)  The date when complete payment is due, which date shall be not less than 15 days after the date the bill is prepared; 
(4)  Notice whether the bill for each service is based upon actual or estimated measurement of the amount of utility services supplied; and 
(5)  Notice that residential customers may call the customer service office, city hall, at the telephone number listed on the bill, in order to: 
a.  Dispute the amount of any utility charge; 
b.  Avoid termination of utility services for non-payment in accordance with the provisions of this article; or 
c.  Request the restoration of any utility service previously terminated. 
(b)  The customer service office shall upon request by any customer provide information as to the following: 
(1)  The procedure to dispute any charge for utility services; 
(2)  The procedure to avoid termination of any utility service due to non-payment of charges; 
(3)  The procedure for a tenant of any residential property to avoid termination of utility services due to failure by the landlord to pay the utility charges; and 
(4)  The procedure to obtain reinstatement of utility services. 
(c)  Any time before the date specified within any notice to a customer as the date of termination of utility services for non-payment of a bill, or for violation of any provision of this Code, or within ten days following the giving of a notice of rejection for utility services, the customer may dispute the basis for the proposed termination of services or the basis for the rejection; provided, however, that the customer shall not be entitled to dispute the basis of termination or rejection for services if the basis was the subject of a previous dispute which was either: 
(1)  Adjudicated pursuant to this section; or 
(2)  Not properly challenged by the customer's failure to follow the procedure set out in this section. 
(d)  The procedure to dispute termination of services or rejection for services shall be as follows: 
(1)  Before the date specified in the notice for termination of services or within ten days following receipt of notice of rejection for services, the customer shall notify the supervisor of the customer service office of the city, in writing, that the customer disputes all or part of the amounts shown on the bill, or disputes the basis for rejection of services, or that the customer claims other reasons for disputing the right of the city to terminate services or the right of the city to reject the customer for services. Such writing shall state as completely as possible the basis and nature of the dispute. 
(2)  If the supervisor of the customer service office determines that the dispute is untimely, or that the customer previously disputed the termination or the rejection upon the same basis, the supervisor shall mail to the customer a notice stating that the present dispute is untimely or invalid for prior adjudication. A dispute is untimely if filed after service has been terminated. 
(3)  If the supervisor of the customer service office determines that the dispute is not untimely or invalid under this section, the supervisor shall, within three days after receipt of the customer's notice, arrange an informal meeting between the customer and the superintendent of each affected utility department. 
(4)  The superintendent of each affected utility department shall attempt to resolve the dispute in a manner satisfactory to the department and the customer, based upon the department's records, the customer's allegations and other relevant materials available to the superintendent, at such meeting. The superintendent of each affected utility department shall, within five days after the meeting with the customer, mail to the customer a copy of the superintendent's decision resolving the dispute. 
(5)  If the decision of the superintendent is unsatisfactory to the customer, the customer, within five days of mailing of the decision by the superintendent of the affected department, may file in writing with the supervisor of the customer service office a request for a formal hearing before the utilities committee of the city council. Upon filing of the request by the customer, a formal hearing shall be held by the utilities committee within ten days following receipt of the customer's request for such hearing. 
(6)  At the hearing before the utilities committee, the superintendent of the affected utility department and the customer shall be entitled to present all evidence that, in the view of the utilities committee, is relevant and material to the dispute, and the committee shall be entitled to examine and cross examine witnesses. A record of the hearing shall be maintained. 
(7)  At the conclusion of the hearing, the utilities committee shall render a decision on the dispute. Such decision shall be reduced to writing and a copy thereof shall be mailed to the customer within five days of the hearing. The decision shall be final and binding on the affected utility department, and on the customer. 
(e)  Utilization of the dispute procedure provided for in this section shall not relieve a customer of the obligation to timely and completely pay all other undisputed utility charges for services supplied by the city or to timely and completely pay undisputed portions of amounts which are subject to the instant dispute, or to otherwise comply with the requirements of this Code. Failure by the customer to timely and completely pay all such undisputed amounts or to otherwise comply with requirements of this Code shall be cause for termination of the utility service in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(f)  Until the date of the decision of the affected utility department superintendent becomes final, or until the date of the decision of the utilities committee (if the customer shall have appealed the superintendent's decision) the utility service which has been the subject of the dispute shall not be terminated based solely upon the matters in dispute; provided, however, that nothing shall prohibit termination of the utility service for other cause which is undisputed by the customer. If the decision of the superintendent or the utilities committee, as applicable, is unfavorable to the customer disputing the charge, the notice to the customer of such unfavorable decision shall specify a date not less than five days after such notice within which all disputed amounts must be paid or within which other such corrective action must be taken by the customer in order to avoid termination of the utility services. Failure by the customer to pay or take such other action within the time specified in such notice shall then be cause for termination of the utility services at the expiration of the time period. 
(g)  Except as otherwise provided in subsection (f) of this section, the provisions of this subsection shall govern all termination of utility service for non-payment of utility charges or for failure to comply with other requirements of this Code. 
(1)  If, by the payment date shown on any bill for utility services, the city shall not have received complete payment of the amounts shown on the bill or if the violations alleged within any notice of violation of provisions of this Code shall have not been corrected by the date specified in such violation notice, the customer service office shall mail to or personally serve upon the customer a notice of termination of utility services. 
(2)  The notice of termination shall contain the following information: 
a.  The amount to be paid or the nature of the violation to be corrected; 
b.  The date of the notice of termination; 
c.  The date after which termination of utility services shall be made, which date shall be at least eight days from the date of the notice of termination; 
d.  Notice that unless the payment of the amounts specified or that the affected utility department superintendent has certified that the violation has been corrected prior to the date of termination, that the utility service shall be terminated under this subsection (g); 
e.  Notice that in lieu of paying the entire amount shown, a customer, prior to the date of termination, may notify the customer service office that he disputes the correctness of all or part of the amount shown or that he disputes that he is in violation of provisions of this Code cited as authority for the termination notice, provided that the basis of the dispute shall not have been the subject of a previous dispute either waived or adjudicated. 
(3)  If, prior to the date specified within the notice after which utility services will be terminated, the city shall not have received complete payment of the amounts shown on the notice of termination and if no notice of dispute under subsection (f) of this section shall have been received by the city, or if the customer shall not have corrected any violation of provisions of this Code as shown on the notice of termination, then the utility services which are the subject of the notice of termination shall be terminated and disconnected. If, however, the customer pays the entire amount shown on the notice of termination, or if the superintendent of the affected utility department certifies that the violations of this Code serving as the basis for the notice of termination have been corrected, then such payment or correction shall be considered timely, and the notice of termination shall be ineffective. 
(h)  (1)  Utility services shall be terminated for non-payment only during the hours of 8:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. Monday through Thursday; and on Friday during the hours of 8:00 a.m. to 12:00 p.m. 
(2)  No terminations shall be permitted on a legal holiday or on the day before a legal holiday, and a federal holiday or on the day before a federal holiday. 
(3)  No terminations of utility services shall be permitted on a day when the low temperature forecast for the following 24 hours, as reported by the National Weather Service at its first order station nearest the residence, includes a forecast that the temperature will be below 20 degrees Fahrenheit. If the utility service to a residential customer has been terminated and not reinstated by 5:00 p.m. on the day of termination, when the low temperature within the previous 24 hours, as reported by the National Weather Service at its first order station nearest residence, was below 32 degrees Fahrenheit, the customer service office shall notify the police department of the city on the day of termination of the following: 
a.  The name of the customer; 
b.  The address and location of the residence no longer receiving such utility services; 
c.  The possible threat to the health and life of all persons residing at the residence. 
(i)  In the event of termination of utility services in accordance with the provisions of this section, such utility services shall be reinstated to the customer within one full working day of receipt by the customer service office of complete payment of the amount prompting the termination (including required deposits) and any reconnection charges, or receipt of notice from the superintendent of the affected utility department that the violation of the provision of this Code giving rise to the termination has been corrected. Such payment or correction of violations shall not be considered timely for purposes of this article. 
(j)  In computing any period of time prescribed by this section, the day of the act or event from which the designated period of time begins to run shall not be included. The last day of the period so completed shall be included, unless it is a Saturday, Sunday or a legal holiday, in which event the period runs until the next day which is not a Saturday, Sunday or legal holiday. When the period of time prescribed is less than seven days, intermediate Saturdays, Sundays, and legal holidays shall be excluded in the computation. 
(k)  In addition to being subject to a termination of service pursuant to this section, each bill for utility services which shall not have been paid by the customer on or prior to the due date shown on the monthly bill, shall have added to the bill the amount of five percent of the monthly bill as a late payment penalty, unless the customer listed on the bill is 65 years or older before the time listed as the due date, or if the customer is receiving federal Social Security Disability and can provide proof of coverage to city staff. 
(Code 1990, § 15-29; Ord. No. 87-1469, § 13.28.070, 6-1-1987; Ord. No. 89-1528, 6-19-1989; Ord. No. 2000-1950, § 2, 9-5-2000; Ord. No. 2009-2341, § 1, 5-19-2009; Ord. No. 2011-2472, § 1, 7-19-2011; Ord. No. 2011-2481, § 1, 9-20-2011; Ord. No. 2017-2331, § 1, 8-15-2017) 
Sec. 32-23. - Delinquent payment constitutes lien upon real estate; statements filed. 
    If the charges for utility services for water or for sanitary sewer services shall not have been paid within 40 days after mailing of the bill for such water or sewer services, such charges shall be deemed to be delinquent and thereafter such delinquencies shall constitute a lien upon the real estate for which such utility services are supplied. The city clerk is authorized and directed to prepare and file with the county recorder of deeds a statement of lien claim for the amount of delinquency and lien in the form as required by statute authorizing the filing of such lien statement. If the user whose bill is unpaid is not the owner of the premises and the city clerk has notice of this fact, notice of the claiming of lien shall also be mailed to the owner of the premises, if the owner's address is known to the city clerk, whenever such bill remains unpaid; provided, however, that the failure of the city clerk to record such lien notice or to mail such notice or the failure of the owner to receive such notice shall not affect the right of the city to foreclose upon the lien for unpaid utility services of water and sewerage charges. Any property subject to a lien for unpaid charges shall be subject to foreclosure of such lien by bill in equity in the name of the city, in accordance with procedures under the statute providing for such liens. Upon authorization by the city council, the city attorney will be authorized and directed to institute such proceedings in the name of the city in any court having jurisdiction over such matters against any property for which the city is entitled to a lien under this provision or any provision of any statute of the state. 
(Code 1977, § 13.04.070; Code 1990, § 15-30; Ord. No. 2000-1950, § 3, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 32-24. - Service discontinuance-Water. 
    When water service to a customer has been discontinued for non-payment of charges, a reconnection charge of $50.00 shall be made if such reconnection is made during normal working hours and a charge of $100.00 shall be made if such reconnection is made after normal working hours. 
(Code 1977, § 13.08.040; Code 1990, § 15-31; Ord. No. 92-1614, § 1, 3-2-1992; Ord. No. 2006-2176, § 1, 4-18-2006) 
Sec. 32-25. - Same-Electrical. 
    When electrical service to a customer has been discontinued for non-payment of charges, a reconnection charge of $50.00 shall be made if such reconnection is made during normal working hours, and a reconnection charge of $100.00 shall be made if such reconnection is made after normal working hours. 
(Code 1977, § 13.32.040; Code 1990, § 15-32; Ord. No. 92-1615, § 1, 3-2-1992; Ord. No. 2006-2176, § 2, 4-18-2006) 
Sec. 32-26. - Tampering with meters. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to tamper with, alter, reverse or disconnect any municipally owned meter regulating or measuring the flow of water, sewage or electricity to or from any building or structure served by the utility departments of the city. 
(b)  Tampering, altering, reversing or disconnecting any such meter shall be punishable as a Class B violation as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1977, § 13.32.080; Code 1990, § 15-33; Ord. No. 92-1617, 5-18-1992; Ord. No. 2010-2421, § 51, 10-5-2010) 
Sec. 32-27. - Additional charges; payment; addition to bill. 
(a)  In addition to rates and charges for utility services as provided for within this Code, any additional or supplemental charges due and owing from a customer for additional services, including costs for repair of lines or facilities when such repairs are occasioned by the act or neglect of the customer, costs for additional or supplemental service or services not included with the usual and customary service, shall be billed to the customer and added to the next bill and statement due following the date of completion of the service, and shall be payable as a part of the statement to which the service is added. 
(b)  A customer from whom supplemental or additional charges under this section are due may make request to the superintendent of the utility department from which the supplemental or additional service was obtained, that such additional or supplemental charges be payable in installments by addition of equal amounts to multiple monthly bills, not exceeding 12 months, unless the superintendent of the utility department, with the advice and consent of the public works committee, grants a request from the customer for additional time for payment of the additional or supplemental charges. The granting of additional time to complete repayment under an installment agreement shall be based on the total additional charges subject to repayment, in light of the customer's financial circumstances. The obligation for initiating the request for installment payment option shall be that of the customer, and the utility superintendent shall, in determining whether to grant the request for installment payment, ensure that the city obtains from the customer adequate assurance and security for payment of the amounts due. The agreement for installment payments shall be reduced to writing, and shall be signed by the customer. The director is authorized to accept from the customer a grant of lien against the real estate to which the additional or supplemental service was supplied, and for which the utility service is supplied, as security and guarantee of payment of the amounts due and owing under the installment agreement. The lien upon real estate shall be in such form as may be approved by the city attorney and shall continue and exist as a lien upon the real estate until the supplemental or additional charges due under the installment agreement have been paid in full. Any cost of recording the lien claim or of the release of lien claim upon payment in full shall be paid by the customer. 
(c)  The right to request installment payment of additional or supplemental charges, and the obligation to provide collateral and security for such installment payments, shall exist as to all real estate served by the utility service of the city, whether within or without the limits of the city. 
(d)  Prior to acceptance of a lien as security for payment of installments, the superintendent of the utility department shall ensure that the customer has lawful authority to grant the lien upon real estate. 
(Code 1990, § 15-34; Ord. No. 2002-2030, § 1, 11-19-2002; Ord. No. 2017-2328, § 1, 7-18-2017) 
Secs. 32-28-32-57. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 32-58. - Water utility department created. 
(a)  There is hereby created the water utility department of the city to be owned, maintained and operated as a separate utility, and to be referred to in this article as the water utility or water department. 
(b)  The water utility department, under the direction of the council and such other officers and employees designated by it, shall have the supervision, management and control, subject to the city council, of the maintenance, enlargement and operation of the water utility department owned and controlled by the city and all matters and things connected with the operation, maintenance and extension of the water utility department and preserving the property belonging thereto. The water utility department shall be charged with the production and distribution of a potable drinking water supply to the residents, citizens and users within the city, subject to the rates and charges, rules and regulations as specified within this article. 
(c)  There shall be a superintendent of the water utility department, to be appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the city council, who shall have supervision over all buildings and equipment used and the furnishing of water utility service in the city, and who shall see that the objectives and purposes of the water utility department are carried out and that the water utility department is conducted on an economical, business-like basis, and for this purpose, it shall be the duty of the superintendent and all of the officers, employees and servants of the department to enforce all of the provisions of this article and to observe, obey and carry out the orders and directions of the city council. The superintendent shall prepare and keep in his office a complete map or atlas of the water utility distribution system, together with all connections and other appurtenances distinctly recorded therein, and such other books, records and materials as is necessary to properly maintain and operate the water utility system. 
(Code 1990, § 15-50; Ord. No. 2004-2110, § 1, 12-21-2004) 
Sec. 32-59. - Meter installation; bypass prohibited. 
(a)  No water shall be supplied to any customer or premises except through a metering device installed in accordance with the requirements of the state plumbing code and in accordance with such other requirements as may from time to time be adopted and published and in effect by the superintendent of the water utility department of the city. Meters shall be installed to protect them from freezing, shall be installed in order to be readily accessible to service and meter reading personnel of the city, and an outside reader device, to be visible from the outside of the building on the premises, shall be installed and connected to the water meter. No meter or metering device in place and existing as of the effective date of the ordinance from which this section is derived (July 17, 2002) shall be replaced or repaired unless the same shall be replaced or repaired in accordance with the provisions of this section. 
(b)  A stop box shall be installed and in place at all times for any water service, and the stop box shall be placed in accordance with requirements established from time to time by the superintendent of the water utility, shall be located on public right-of-way (or as near public right-of-way as is physically practicable) and shall provide a means whereby service to the premises may be disconnected by the city when disconnection is required for any reason. 
(c)  It is unlawful for any person, including a licensed plumber, to: 
(1)  Tamper with, alter, reverse or remove any municipally owned water valve or service valve box to or from any building or distribution line served by the municipal water supply system, except with the permission of the superintendent of the water utility; 
(2)  Install any pipe or other device to replace or bypass a meter so as to prevent the meter from accurately measuring water being used and supplied by the city; 
(3)  Connect to the municipal water supply any building or other water usage device in such a manner that the quantity of water utilized at the building or other water using device will not be accurately measured by a meter installed in accordance with subsection (a) of this section. 
(d)  City water utility personnel shall make all taps onto water mains and will install connecting lines from the main to a service valve box to be located on public right-of-way near the property line. The customer shall be responsible for installation of all other conduits, piping, meters, valves and other apparatus or equipment, and the cost thereof, necessary to provide service to the location, but all installations, replacements or repairs from the service valve box to and including the meter shall: 
(1)  Be performed only by a licensed plumber; 
(2)  Be performed only after application to the city by the customer for and issuance of a construction permit for such work; and 
(3)  Meet and comply with the requirements of the state plumbing code and any additional requirements as may from time to time be adopted by the superintendent of the water utility. 
No water shall be supplied or taken by any customer unless the meter for the premises shall have first been installed. 
(e)  A violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class B violation as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1990, § 15-51; Ord. No. 2001-1966, § 2, 3-20-2001; Ord. No. 2002-2018, § 2, 7-17-2002; Ord. No. 2006-2210, 12-19-2006; Ord. No. 2010-2404, § 1, 6-15-2010; Ord. No. 2010-2421, § 52, 10-5-2010) 
Sec. 32-60. - Meter damage. 
(a)  The owner of each parcel of real estate served by the municipal water supply system of the city, and the customer responsible for payment for charges for water consumption and use at each location (if different from the owner) shall be jointly and severally liable for and responsible to the city for payment of the cost of repair or replacement of any damaged meter at said real estate. The term "damaged meter" means any water meter or water consumption reading device used in the determination of the amount of water consumed or used at the premises and which is made inaccurate or which is caused to leak for any reason other than manufacturing defects or ordinary wear and tear, and shall include, but not be limited to, damage caused as the result of water freezing within the measuring device. It shall not be a defense to the liability under this section that any damage may have been the result of causes, persons or agencies not related or connected to the owner or customer. 
(b)  The amount to be paid by any owner or customer for repair or replacement of any damaged meter shall be determined from time to time by the superintendent of the water distribution system of the city, but the amount shall not exceed the then replacement cost for the meter or other device, including the reasonable expense incurred by the city for labor to repair, remove and/or replace the meter or other device. Charges for repair or replacement of damaged meters shall be added to the invoice for water service to be issued next following the date of the repair or replacement, and shall constitute a part of the rates and charges payable to the city by the owner or customer. 
(c)  Employees and agents of the city shall be entitled, at all reasonable times, to go upon the premises of any customer of the water distribution system of the city for the purpose of testing, inspecting, repairing or replacing any water meter or water meter reading device located thereon. 
(d)  When a premises served by the waterworks system of the city shall be unoccupied for 30 or more consecutive days, the owner or customer of that location shall request of the waterworks utility department that water service at such premises be discontinued during the period of non-occupancy. Failure by an owner or customer to comply with this requirement shall cause that owner and the customer, if other than the owner, to be responsible to the city for and to pay and reimburse the city for any amount of water estimated to be utilized at the premises during such period of non-occupancy, if the meter shall have been damaged because of lack of heat or other causes during the period of non-occupancy, and in addition, the customer, and the owner, if other than the customer, shall be responsible to and shall reimburse the city for any and all costs to repair or replace any meter or other materials or devices of the city which may have been damaged due to freezing or other cause during such period of non-occupancy. 
(e)  A violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class B violation as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1990, § 15-52; Ord. No. 2001-1966, § 3, 3-20-2001; Ord. No. 2002-2018, § 3, 7-17-2002; Ord. No. 2005-2117, § 1, 2-1-2005; Ord. No. 2010-2421, § 52, 10-5-2010) 
Sec. 32-61. - Minimum charge for non-functioning meter. 
(a)  When it is determined that a water meter shall have been malfunctioning or non-functioning, the customer shall be required to pay a minimum amount for each billing period during which the meter has been non-functioning or malfunctioning. Such minimum amount shall be equal to: 
(1)  The debt service charge applicable to the class of service; plus 
(2)  The monthly customer service charge applicable to the class of service; plus 
(3)  User charges equal to the monthly average user charges for the four-month period immediately preceding the period when the meter was malfunctioning or non-functioning. 
(b)  If the amount so determined is greater than three times the customer's average monthly bill for the four-month period immediately preceding the period when the meter was malfunctioning or non-functioning, then the manager may, upon application of the customer, allow payment of the minimum amount so determined, in installments, each to be added to the next three succeeding monthly bills of the customer. 
(c)  Nothing in this section shall be deemed to eliminate or to operate as a waiver of the lien for non-payment set forth in section 32-23. 
(Code 1990, § 15-53; Ord. No. 2001-1966, § 4, 3-20-2001; Ord. No. 2002-2018, § 4, 7-17-2002) 
Sec. 32-62. - Use of groundwater as a potable water supply prohibited. 
(a)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Person means any individual, partnership, co-partnership, firm, company, limited liability company, corporation, association, joint stock company, trust, estate, political subdivision or any other legal entity or its legal representatives, agents or assigns. 
    Potable water means any water used for human or domestic consumption, including, but not limited to, water used for drinking, bathing, swimming, washing dishes or preparing foods. 
(b)  The use of, or attempt to use, groundwater from within the corporate limits of the city, as a potable water supply, by the installation or drilling of wells or by any other method is hereby prohibited within the city. This prohibition expressly does not include the city, as the operator of the public water supply system for residents of the city, and the city shall be entitled to continue and expand use of wells as a source for the potable water supply for the municipal water supply system of the city. Any private water well being used as the supply or source of potable water for any person on the date of adoption of the amendment from which this article is derived shall be discontinued and be brought into compliance with the requirements of this article on or before October 1, 2014. Any private water well used as the source or supply of potable water for any person shall, until eliminated and removed as the source of potable water, be tested at least annually for the presence of contaminants or chemical constituents by a licensed and reputable water testing laboratory or health department, and if such water test reveals the presence of contaminants or other chemical constituents in levels greater than is deemed or considered by applicable law or regulation to be safe for human consumption, then such private water well shall be immediately discontinued as the source or supply of potable water, and the requirements of this article shall be immediately complied with by the owner of that private water well. For purposes of compliance with this section, the superintendent of the municipal water utility system is empowered to require that the owners and users of all private water wells as a source or supply of potable water provide to the superintendent copies of all annual or more frequent water tests conducted upon the water drawn from such well. All such water tests shall be conducted in accordance with the requirements and protocol of the county health department. Any private water supply existing on the date of passage of this amendment shall at all times be operated in a sanitary manner, comply with all requirements of any health department rule or regulation applicable thereto, shall not be connected in any manner to the city's public water supply system, and shall be operated in a manner to avoid contamination of underground water and aquifer. 
(c)  Whenever an industrial user requires water for industrial purposes (and not as a source of potable water) and the superintendent of the water utility of the city determines that the city's water facilities have inadequate capacity to provide the pressure, volume or rate of flow required by that industry, the user may be required to install a private water supply meeting such requirements as may from time to time be in force and effect governing such industrial water supply uses; provided, however, that any private water supply shall not be used for any purpose other than industrial use by the user, the prohibitions against cross connections as contained within this Code shall be observed and followed, and the private water well shall be installed and operated so that underground water and aquifer are not and will not be contaminated. 
(d)  A violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class A violation as provided in section 1-41, and in addition thereto, the city shall be entitled to seek injunctive relief to prevent and prohibit a violation of the provisions of this section by any person. For purposes of determining a monetary penalty, each day that a violation continues shall be deemed to be a separate violation of this section. 
(Code 1990, § 15-54; Ord. No. 2004-2091, § 1, 6-1-2004; Ord. No. 2007-2239, § 1, 8-7-2007; Ord. No. 2010-2421, § 53, 10-5-2010; Ord. No. 2011-2454, § 1, 4-5-2011; Ord. No. 2013-2115, § 1, 7-2-2013; Ord. No. 2014-2152, § 1, 4-1-2014) 
Sec. 32-63. - Private water supply systems. 
(a)  Whenever a public water main is not available under the provisions of section 32-62, the plumbing system of any house, building or other property upon which is constructed as an improvement utilized for any human activity and situated within the city shall be connected to a private water supply complying with the provisions of this section. 
(b)  Whenever an industrial user requires water for industrial purposes and the superintendent of the water utility of the city determines that the city's water facilities have inadequate capacity to provide the pressure, volume or rate flow required by that industry, the user may be required to install a private water supply complying with the provisions of this section; provided, however, that the private water supply shall not be used for any purpose except for industrial purposes, and the prohibitions against cross connection as contained within this Code shall be followed. 
(c)  A private water supply shall not be used for any residence building except for a single-family residence. 
(d)  Before commencement of construction or reconstruction of a private water supply, the owner shall first obtain a permit therefor from the building department of the city. Applications for permits shall be made on a form supplied by the city. The applicant shall provide and supply, prior to issuance of the permit, any plans, specifications and other information as required by the city, including the name and license or registration number of the plumber contracted to perform the work. No permit shall be issued until the plans and specifications for the private water supply have been approved in writing by the superintendent of the water utility of the city, and until all permits required by any other agency with jurisdiction over private water supplies shall have been issued, with copies thereof supplied to the building department at the time of application for the permit. The applicant shall pay a fee to the building department for issuance of the permit, in accordance with schedules adopted from time to time by the city council, and in addition, shall pay an inspection fee in the amount of $50.00. The plumber installing the private water supply shall be required to notify the superintendent of the water utility of the city of the date and time when the water supply is to be installed, or the date and time when completion of the installation is scheduled so that the superintendent may inspect the installation to ensure compliance with applicable requirements. The superintendent of the water utility shall not give his approval of issuance of the permit if the installation would be a threat to contamination of the recharge area or the city's water supply wells, or if the installation would in any other manner be in violation of rules or regulations governing public or private water supplies within the state or the city. 
(e)  Any private water supply existing or heretofore constructed within the city shall at all times be operated in a sanitary manner, comply with all requirements of any health department rule or regulation applicable thereto, shall not be connected in any manner to the city's public water supply system, and shall be constructed and operated in a manner to avoid contamination of underground water and aquifer. 
(Code 1990, § 15-55; Ord. No. 2004-2091, § 2, 6-1-2004; Ord. No. 2005-2151, § 1, 11-15-2005) 
Sec. 32-64. - Lawn irrigation wells. 
(a)  The owner or occupant of a residence, building or other property which is otherwise required to connect to the public water supply of the city may obtain a permit to install a sandpoint well for use as a source of water for irrigation of lawn or landscaping for such residence, building or other property, and for no other purpose, provided that the following conditions apply and have been met: 
(1)  Prior to issuance of a permit by the city, the applicant shall obtain a written permit from the county health department for installation of such sandpoint irrigation well. 
(2)  The application to the city for permit for installation of such irrigation sandpoint well shall include a copy of the permit issued by the county health department, and a copy of the application submitted to the health department, including any plans, specifications and other information required by the county health department as a precondition to issuance of the county permit. 
(3)  The application for permit from the city shall be accompanied by an inspection fee of $50.00. 
(4)  If, at any time, additional rules or regulations, statutes or laws shall be adopted by any agency by which any additional permits for installation of an irrigation sandpoint well are required to be issued by any agency other than the county health department, such additional permits shall also be exhibited at the time of application to the city. 
(b)  All irrigation sandpoint wells, whether heretofore constructed or to be constructed pursuant to application made after adoption of the ordinance from which this article is derived, shall be installed and constructed to comply with all requirements of the county health department rules and regulations applicable thereto, shall at all times be operated in a sanitary manner, shall not be connected in any manner to the public water supply system of the city, and shall be constructed and operated in a manner to prevent and avoid contamination of any underground water or aquifer. 
(c)  For purposes of this section, no sandpoint irrigation wells shall be installed so that the tip of the sandpoint is more than 25 feet below the surface of the ground. 
(Code 1990, § 15-56; Ord. No. 2007-2246, § 1, 8-21-2007) 
Sec. 32-65. - Service outside city limits; requirements. 
    Connection to the public water supply system of the city shall not be made to any property that is not within the corporate limits of the city until there shall have been filed: (i) an irrevocable petition to annex seeking to have the property annexed to the city upon approval of the city council, meeting the requirements of division 1 of article 7 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/7-1-1 et seq.) and, (ii) an application for service, and until permit and connection fees have been paid. If the property is contiguous to the city, the property shall be annexed when all action by the city council required for annexation has been completed and taken. If the property is not contiguous to the boundary of the city at the time of filing, so to permit the immediate annexation thereof by action of the city council, the petition shall also be in a form meeting the requirements for recording within the office of the county recorder. The petition for annexation shall require that the property be annexed to the city immediately upon its becoming contiguous to the limits of the city. The legal description of the property shall be sufficient to allow the recording of the document, and shall include the property identification number assigned thereto by the county supervisor of assessments. An annexation plat, as required by law, shall also be supplied. 
(Ord. No. 2015-2223, § 1, 7-21-2015) 
Secs. 32-66-32-86. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - RATES 

Sec. 32-87. - Single-family residential dwellings, commercial and industrial users. 
(a)  Single-family residential dwellings shall be served by one five-eighths-inch meter. Any metering device installed at such a dwelling which is not of this size shall be changed to conform with this subsection. 
(b)  There shall be and there is hereby established monthly rates and charges for the use of and for service supplied by the water works system of the city to residential single-family dwellings in accordance with the tables set forth in this subsection. Meter readings shall be taken monthly, to determine usage, and bills shall be rendered for all water used and consumed as determined by the meter reading monthly. As set forth in the table, the basic user charge shall include the use of up to 300 cubic feet of water per month. As set forth in the tables, the "basic user rate" shall apply to each 100 cubic feet (or part thereof) of water used and consumed per month as determined by the meter reading for all consumption in excess of 300 cubic feet per month. 
(1)  The following table specifies the rates and components of rates and charges applicable for all meter readings taken and billings rendered on or after May 1, 2015, and through April 30, 2016:

Sec. 32-88. - Municipal and school water service. 
    Service shall be available to all schools served by the waterworks system and to municipal facilities of the city and other municipal governments, and there shall be and there is hereby established rates and charges for the use of and for the service supplied by the waterworks system of the city to such services as follows: 
(1)  A facilities charge of $2.00 per month shall be applied, which shall also serve as the minimum monthly charge. 
(2)  Consumption and usage charge at the rate of $1.00 per 100 cubic feet of water used as established by the meter reading for the first 300 cubic feet per month. 
(3)  Consumption and usage charge at the rate of $1.20 per 100 cubic feet of water used as established by the water meter reading for all usage in excess of 300 cubic feet per month. 
(Code 1990, § 15-77; Ord. No. 85-1412, 7-15-1985) 
Sec. 32-89. - Fire service. 
(a)  Every commercial or industrial customer of the municipal water service possessing, a connection to the municipal water utility for fire suppression equipment installed within the premises of the commercial or industrial customer shall pay, in addition to the fees, rates and charges applicable for any water usage measured through a meter, a charge per month in accord with the following table: 
Meter Size Monthly Rate 2 inches $8.05 4 inches $10.05 6 inches $12.05 8 inches $14.55  
(b)  The rates specified in this section shall be applicable to and charged for all meter readings taken or for bills rendered after August 1, 2006. 
(Code 1977, § 13.04.030; Code 1990, § 15-78; Ord. No. 2002-2002, § 1, 4-2-2002; Ord. No. 2006-2189, § 1, 7-18-2006; Ord. No. 2016-2273, § 1, 7-19-2016) 
Sec. 32-90. - Users outside corporate limits. 
    Each user of the waterworks system of the city located outside the corporate limits shall have 50 percent added to the bill rendered for the type of service as set out above. 
(Code 1977, § 13.04.050; Code 1990, § 15-80) 
Sec. 32-91. - Waterworks revenues to be kept separate; timely delivery to city treasurer; periodic revenue. 
(a)  All revenues and moneys derived from the operation of the waterworks system shall be held by the city clerk separate and apart from all other funds of the city. All of such sums, without any deductions, shall be delivered to the city treasurer not more than ten days after receipt of the same, or at more frequent intervals as may from time to time be directed by the city council. 
(b)  The city council shall cause the certified public accountant hired and engaged by the city to conduct each annual audit of the city's financial affairs, to review, not less often than annually, and as a part of said audit procedure, the water rates and charges to determine whether said charges are adequate to pay and discharge the operation, maintenance, repair and replacement expenses of the waterworks system, to meet capital needs of the system and to meet debt service requirements of the system. The city council shall cause water service charges to be revised periodically to reflect any change in the adequacy of the charges to meet the expenses and costs referred to herein, and to reflect changes in capital needs and requirements of the system and operation, maintenance and repair costs. 
(Code 1977, § 13.04.100; Code 1990, § 15-81; Ord. No. 2000-1950, § 1, 9-5-2000) 
Sec. 32-92. - Administration of water fund. 
    The city treasurer shall receive all such revenues from the waterworks system and all other funds and moneys incident to the operation of such system, as the same may be delivered to him and deposit the same in a separate fund designated as the water fund of the city. The treasurer shall administer such fund in every respect in the manner provided by the provisions of the Illinois Municipal Code. 
(Code 1977, § 13.04.110; Code 1990, § 15-82) 
Sec. 32-93. - Maintenance of books, records, accounts. 
    The city treasurer shall establish a proper system of accounts and shall keep proper books, records and accounts in which complete and correct entries shall be made of all transactions relative to the waterworks system. At regular annual intervals, the city treasurer shall cause to be made an audit by an independent auditing concern of the books to show the receipts and disbursements of the waterworks system. 
(Code 1977, § 13.04.120; Code 1990, § 15-83) 
Sec. 32-94. - Notice of liability. 
    A copy of the ordinances codified in this division, properly certified by the city clerk, shall be filed in the office of the recorder of deeds and shall be deemed notice to all owners of real estate of their liability for service supplied to any user of the service of the waterworks system of the city on their properties. 
(Code 1977, § 13.04.130; Code 1990, § 15-84) 
Secs. 32-95-32-116. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - CONNECTION FEES, DEPOSITS, AND METER FEES 

Sec. 32-117. - Deposit of residential customers. 
    No water shall be furnished to new residential customers until the customer shall have first deposited with the city a sum of $15.00. Upon termination of water service to any customer, the deposit shall be returned without interest after deducting any charges due the city for water service provided. 
(Code 1990, § 15-101; Ord. No. 87-1471, 6-15-1987; Ord. No. 96-1770, 4-2-1996; Ord. No. 2005-2140, § 1, 8-2-2005) 
Sec. 32-118. - Deposit for business or manufacturing user. 
    Deposits shall be made for water service by each new or transferred business or manufacturing user equal to one month's average bill, determined as follows: 
(1)  When an existing business or manufacturing establishment is transferred and the new owner intends to carry on business substantially as in the past, an average of the bills for the past 12 months shall be used. 
(2)  Where a new business or manufacturing operation is started, the superintendent of the water department shall make a survey and estimate the amount of one month's bill. 
(Code 1977, § 13.08.020; Code 1990, § 15-102) 
Sec. 32-119. - Residential hookup charges. 
(a)  An applicant for water service to be provided to any residential structure shall pay to the city all costs incurred by the city for labor and materials for the installation of water connection, tap into the main, excavation and other services necessary to provide and supply water service to said residential structure. No installation shall be completed or made and no connection to the water supply system of the city shall be made until a permit for the installation shall have been issued by the building official of the city. No such permit shall be issued except after receipt of approval of the superintendent of the water utility department following review of plans and specifications therefor. Application for the permit shall be made on forms supplied by the city. Such application and installation shall constitute the agreement of the owner of the residential structure to pay the usual and customary charges made by the city for the provision of water service and the furnishing of water. Such charges shall commence no later than 30 days after installation of the tap-in for service to the residential structure, notwithstanding that the owner thereof shall not have made a physical connection to the water system. 
(b)  Each applicant shall pay a fee for issuance of the permit for water connection in accordance with the schedule of fees maintained from time to time and adopted by the city council. Such fees shall be based upon the labor charges and material costs incurred by the city in the installation, the rate of which shall be fixed and determined from time to time by the city council, but in no event shall the permit fee be less than $100.00. 
(c)  Notwithstanding the other provisions of this section, the following terms, conditions, standards and requirements shall apply to any residential property located within the city where required to connect to the public water supply system of the city as a result of and because of the passage of Ordinance No. 2011-2454 (prohibits use of groundwater as a potable water supply) and the requirements contained therein: 
(1)  If a stop box or control valve/connector to service the residence exists at a location within five feet of the property line of the residence that is required to connect to the city public water supply system, no charge shall be made by the city for labor and materials for connection of the residence water supply to the public water supply system through the "stop box," and the only fee applicable to be paid by the owner of the residence shall be the normal hook-up fee of $100.00. 
(2)  If, in order to connect the residence to the city's public water supply, a water line must be installed to run from the main and to a stop box to be placed within five feet of the property line, no payment shall be required by the city from the owner of the residence for labor and materials necessary to perform the connection and installation of the line and "stop box," but in lieu thereof, the connection shall be made by the city for a charge of $500.00, inclusive of any connection or hook-up fee. 
(3)  Upon the request by the owner of any residence submitted to the public works committee of the city council, together with reasonable supporting documentation and information to establish justification, the payments to the city required for connection to the public water supply under this subsection (c) may be allowed by the committee to be paid in 12 equal monthly installments, but provided that any installment not paid on the due date thereof shall be subject to a lien claim as a delinquent water charge, as in other cases provided. 
(4)  The special fee and payment arrangements provided for in this subsection (c) shall expire at the end of the 36th month following the date of adoption of the Ord. No. 2011-2471 (adopted on July 5, 2011). 
(Code 1977, § 13.08.030; Code 1990, § 15-103; Ord. No. 85-1423, § 13.16.050, 9-16-1985; Ord. No. 2004-2088, § 1, 5-18-2004; Ord. No. 2011-2471, § 1, 7-5-2011) 
Sec. 32-120. - Commercial hookup charge. 
(a)  An applicant for water service to be provided to any commercial purpose structure shall pay to the city all costs incurred by the city for labor and materials for the installation of water connection, tap into the main excavation and other services necessary to provide and supply water service to said commercial purpose structure. No installation shall be completed or made and no connection to the water supply system of the city shall be made until a permit for the installation shall have been issued by the building official of the city. No such permit shall be issued except after receipt of approval of the superintendent of the water utility department following review of plans and specifications therefor. Application for the permit shall be made on forms supplied by the city. Such application and installation shall constitute the agreement of the owner of the commercial purpose structure to pay the usual and customary charges made by the city for the provision of water service and the furnishing of water. Such charges shall commence no later than 30 days after installation of the tap-in for service to the commercial purpose structure, notwithstanding that the owner thereof shall not have made a physical connection to the water system. 
(b)  Each applicant shall pay a fee for issuance of the permit for water connection in accordance with the schedule of fees maintained from time to time and adopted by the city council. Such fees shall be based upon the labor charges and material costs incurred by the city in the installation, the rate of which shall be fixed and determined from time to time by the city council, but in no event shall the permit fee be less than $300.00. 
(Code 1990, § 15-104; Ord. No. 85-1423, § 13.16.060, 9-16-1985; Ord. No. 95-1759, § 3, 12-18-1995; Ord. No. 2004-2088, § 2, 5-18-2004) 
Sec. 32-121. - Industrial hookup charges. 
(a)  An applicant for water service to be provided to any industrial purpose structure shall pay to the city all costs incurred by the city for labor and materials for the installation of water connection, tap into the main, excavation and other services necessary to provide and supply water service to said industrial purpose structure. No installation shall be completed or made and no connection to the water supply system of the city shall be made until a permit for the installation shall have been issued by the building official of the city. No such permit shall be issued except after receipt of approval of the superintendent of the water utility department following review of plans and specifications therefor. Application for the permit shall be made on forms supplied by the city. Such application and installation shall constitute the agreement of the owner of the industrial purpose structure to pay the usual and customary charges made by the city for the provision of water service and the furnishing of water. Such charges shall commence no later than 30 days after installation of the tap-in for service to the industrial purpose structure, notwithstanding that the owner thereof shall not have made a physical connection to the water system. 
(b)  Each applicant shall pay a fee for issuance of the permit for water connection in accordance with the schedule of fees maintained from time to time and adopted by the city council. Such fees shall be based upon the labor charges and material costs incurred by the city in the installation, the rate of which shall be fixed and determined from time to time by the city council, but in no event shall the permit fee be less than $500.00 for a main of less than six inches nor less than $1,000.00 for a main six inches or larger. 
(Code 1990, § 15-105; Ord. No. 85-1423, § 13.16.070, 9-16-1985; Ord. No. 2004-2088, § 3, 5-18-2004; Ord. No. 2004-2088, § 3, 5-18-2004) 
Sec. 32-122. - Bulk purchasers of water; rates. 
(a)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Bulk purchaser means a purchaser of water drawing 50 gallons or more per draw from a hydrant or water supply outlet owned or maintained by the city and which is not connected by any permanent device to equipment or premises of the purchaser. 
(b)  There is hereby established as rates and charges to those persons, firms or corporations making bulk purchases of water, as defined herein, from the waterworks supply system of the city as follows: 
(1)  A debt service charge of $4.85 per purchaser for each month when purchases are made, but provided that the debt service charge shall not be charged to any purchaser who, at the time of the purchase, is a residential water customer of the city waterworks supply system; plus 
(2)  A charge of $4.15, per unit of purchase or part thereof, per purchase, where a unit equals 750 gallons of water; plus 
(3)  A customer service charge for facilities and capital improvements of $2.40 for each purchase made. 
(c)  All amounts due from any bulk purchases under this section shall be payable in advance by drawing of any water from city hydrants, unless the purchaser shall have previously established a credit account with the utility collection office of the city, and all such amounts shall be payable to the utility collection of the city. 
(d)  The superintendent of the water department of the city, subject to approval of the public works committee of the city council, shall make and establish reasonable rules and regulations governing and controlling the bulk sale of water and credit and payment rules therefor. 
(e)  The rates specified in this division shall be applicable to and charged for all meter readings taken or for bills rendered after July 1, 2017. 
(Code 1990, § 15-107; Ord. No. 95-1746, § 1, 5-15-1995; Ord. No. 2005-2130, § 1, 4-19-2005; Ord. No. 2005-2133, § 1, 5-17-2005; Ord. No. 2006-2187, § 1, 7-5-2006; Ord. No. 2017-2315, § 1, 6-6-2017) 
Sec. 32-123. - Presence of owner at initial supply of service. 
    At any service location within the city where the waterworks department has been authorized to supply service, no such service shall be supplied through opening of the valves to permit the pressurization of the water supply lines at that location unless there shall be present at the time of opening of the valves the property owner or his duly authorized representative or agent, for the purpose of visual inspection of the supply lines at that location and for detection of any leaks or unintended usage. 
(Code 1990, § 15-108; Ord. No. 2005-2118, § 1, 2-1-2005) 
Sec. 32-124. - Emergency disconnection or discontinuance of supply; exoneration of city. 
    Whenever maintenance requirements of the waterworks utility system of the city require that service to a customer or user be interrupted, discontinued temporarily or disconnected temporarily, the superintendent of the waterworks utility shall give to any affected customer advance notice of the time and date of the discontinuance, interruption or disconnection, and in the event of any emergency situation requiring discontinuance, interruption or disconnection of service shall attempt to notify affected customers in advance of the discontinuance, interruption or disconnection; provided, however, that in any emergency matter which requires the discontinuance, interruption or disconnection of service, the city nor its agents or employees shall be liable nor responsible to any customer affected thereby for any damages, costs or expenses as a result of the discontinuance, interruption or disconnection without notice, and service may be discontinued, interrupted or disconnected as necessary in order to meet the needs of the emergency, without notice. No person shall be entitled to maintain or state a claim or cause of action against the city arising from damages alleged to have been suffered arising from or as the result of the discontinuation, interruption or disconnection of water service, if such discontinuation, interruption or disconnection was made necessary in order to protect the integrity of the public water supply system or in order to make repairs to the system due to an unforeseen emergency event or occurrence. If the discontinuation, interruption or disconnection is due to a leak or rupture in piping or lines between the city stop box and the meter at the location, then service will not be reconnected until such time as the line or piping is repaired or replaced so that no leak exists. 
(Code 1990, § 15-109; Ord. No. 2005-2119, § 1, 2-1-2005; Ord. No. 2015-2207, § 1, 2-21-2015) 
Secs. 32-125-32-146. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - CROSS CONNECTION CONTROL 

Sec. 32-147. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:
