(2)  The capital improvement charge (CI) shall apply to all users of the wastewater treatment facilities of the city, shall be for the purpose of creating a financial reserve from which can be paid the cost of replacement of capital items of the system, and shall be calculated by estimating the amount needed annually for capital improvements or replacements within the wastewater treatment system, divided by the estimated number of users. The amount so determined shall be divided by 12 to determine the periodic monthly amount. 
(3)  The basic usage charge (BC) shall apply to all users of the wastewater treatment system and shall allow the user to discharge up to 300 cubic feet of water or wastewater per month. 
(4)  The basic usage rate (R) shall be applied to each 100 cubic feet or portion thereof of water usage or discharge per billing period and shall be based on water usage and/or discharge into the wastewater facilities of the city as recorded by water meters and/or sewerage meters, and shall be determined by computing the amount necessary to pay and cover all fixed and variable costs associated with operation, non-capital maintenance and repair of the wastewater collection and treatment system of the city. The basic usage rate will be applicable to average or below average strength sewage, which is defined as follows: 
a.  Average strength sewage shall be determined to have the following characteristics: 
1.  A five-day, 20-degree Celsius biochemical oxygen demand (BOD5) of 200 milligrams per liter; and 
2.  A suspended solids (SS) content of 240 milligrams per liter. 
b.  The basic usage rate shall be fixed to ensure adequate receipts to cover and defray administrative, operation and maintenance costs, including routine replacement items, and shall be computed by estimating projected annual revenues required to operate and maintain the wastewater collection and treatment facilities, estimating the billable wastewater volume to be treated, and computing the cost per 100 cubic feet of billable volume. 
c.  The basic usage rate shall be applied to all water usage and/or discharge in excess of 300 cubic feet, per billing period. 
(5)  The replacement treatment plant charge (RC) shall apply to all users, and shall be for the purpose of creating a financial reserve and for payment of a portion or all of the costs incurred by the city in planning, design, development, permitting and construction of a replacement for the wastewater treatment plant currently operated by the city, and shall be calculated by estimating the amount needed to create such reserve fund and to pay the costs, including land acquisition and engineering, legal and administrative fees and expenses, for the specific purpose of replacement of the wastewater treatment plant. The replacement treatment plant charge shall allow the discharge of up to 300 cubic feet of waste per billing period. 
(6)  The replacement wastewater treatment plant usage rate (P) shall be applied to each 100 cubic feet or portion thereof of water usage or discharge in excess of 300 cubic feet per billing period, and based on water usage and/or wastewater discharge as recorded by water meters and/or sewerage meters, and shall be calculated in the same manner and with the same assumptions of strength of discharge as applicable to the basic usage rate, and shall be for the purpose of establishing a reserve for and to pay and defray any costs associated with or arising from, or increased by, the replacement wastewater treatment plant to be constructed by the city for the fixed and variable expenses and costs of operation, maintenance and repairs of said replacement wastewater treatment plant. 
(7)  A surcharge (S), to be levied in addition to the other portions of the rates and charges as set forth in subsections (b)(1) through (6) of this section will be levied upon all users of the wastewater treatment facilities and plant of the city whose discharges exceed the average strength sewage BOD5 of 200 milligrams per liter or whose discharges exceed the average strength sewage concentrations for suspended solids (SS) of 240 milligrams per liter. The surcharge shall be based on metered sewage flow for all wastes which exceed these concentrations and shall be applied to each 100 cubic feet or portion thereof of discharge. The procedure for computation of a surcharge shall be in accordance with this subsection (b)(7). The unit rates for BOD5 and SS surcharge calculation shall be determined as follows: 
a.  The estimated annual revenue required for operating and maintaining the wastewater treatment facilities, and for the replacement wastewater treatment plant charge shall be proportioned; 
b.  The costs for major plant categories relative to BOD5 and SS shall be proportioned; 
c.  The total wastewater volume, pounds of BOD5 and pounds of SS shall be estimated; and 
d.  The unit cost per pound of BOD5 and SS shall be computed. 
Each user of the wastewater treatment facilities, by taking service and discharging waste into the wastewater treatment system of the city, shall be deemed to have consented for the city, from time to time, and as frequently as determined necessary in the discretion of the superintendent of wastewater treatment department, to go upon the property of the user and take such samples as are deemed appropriate and necessary in order to determine the levels of BOD5 and SS as are existent in the waste discharge by the user into the wastewater treatment facilities, for purposes of determining the applicability of the surcharge. 
(c)  Wastewater service rates and charges. 
(1)  The rates and charges in this subsection are hereby established as the monthly rates and charges for the use of and for service supplied by the wastewater system of the city. In the table which follows, the amount set forth in each column b though g shall be the amount for each component of the rate, and shall be computed in accordance with the formula specified in subsection (d) of this section, and column a of the table shall specify the date when each rate so calculated shall become effective, and shall be effective for all meter readings and/or billings issued for wastewater treatment services rendered on and after the effective date specified therein. The rates set opposite the line of the table labeled "preexisting" are those rates applicable at time of adoption of the ordinance from which this division is derived and until November 1, 2008.

(2)  Provided, however, that any user operating a pre-treatment facility by which waste which is discharged into the wastewater treatment facilities of the city is pretreated by the user to reduce the BOD5 and SS shall pay, in lieu of the basic usage rate (R), as set forth in the above and foregoing table, an amount in accordance with the following table, for all waste discharged, per month, in excess of 300 cubic feet, and such pre-treating user shall not be required to pay the debt service (DS) charge.

(d)  Surcharge rates and charges. The rates of surcharge (S) for BOD5 and SS shall be as follows: 
(1)  For biochemical oxygen demand (BOD5), $0.80 per pound of BOD5. 
(2)  For suspended solids (SS), $0.60 per pound of SS. 
(3)  The surcharge per user shall be computed by the following formula: 
S = V (0.006238 [A (BOD5 - 200) + B (SS - 240)] 
where: 
S = Amount of surcharge in dollars. 
V = Wastewater volume in 100 cubic feet per billing. 
(0.006238) = Unit weight of water × 106 per 100 cubic feet. 
A = Unit charge for BOD5 per pound. 
BOD5 = Five-day biochemical oxygen demand in milligrams per liter. 
200 = Allowable average BOD5 concentration in milligrams per liter. 
B = Unit charge for SS per pound. 
SS = Suspended solids in milligrams per liter. 
240 = Allowable average SS concentration in milligrams per liter. 
(e)  Computation of wastewater service charge. Following is the formula for calculating wastewater service charges for users located within the corporate limits: 
(1)  Metered users. 
MC = DS + CI + B + (V - 300) R + RC + (V - 300) P + S 
where: 
MC = Amount of wastewater service charge per billing period; 
DS = Debt service for principal and interest in dollars per billing period; 
CI = Capital improvement charge in dollars per billing period; 
B = Basic usage charge in dollars for use of up to 300 cubic feet of waste discharge per billing period; 
V = Wastewater volume in cubic feet per billing period rounded to the next highest increment of 100 cubic feet. For wastewater volumes of 300 or less cubic feet per billing period, V shall equal 300; 
R = Basic usage rate in dollars per 100 cubic feet of waste discharge per billing; 
RC = Replacement wastewater plant charge in dollars for use of up to 300 cubic feet of waste discharge per billing period; 
P = Replacement plant usage rate in dollars per 100 cubic feet of waste discharge per billing period; and 
S = Amount of wastewater surcharge in dollars as computed by the surcharge formula specified in subsection (d)(2) of this section. 
(2)  Non-metered users. All non-metered users of the wastewater facilities of the city shall pay a minimum flat rate charge, in lieu of calculation by formula, as the wastewater service charge per billing period. The term "non-metered user" means a user not connected to the public water supply system, and whose water consumption is not measured by an installed water usage recordation device. The flat rate charge applied to non-metered users assumes a maximum use of 1,000 cubic feet per billing period, and assumes more than two individuals residing in a residential user unit. Any non-metered residential user may request a reduction in the flat rate charge to be applied per billing period for the reason that the residential unit is occupied on a permanent resident basis by one or two persons. The rate to be applied to non-metered users shall be as set forth in the table in this subsection (e)(2). In order to establish eligibility for a reduced minimum flat rate charge based upon residency by one or two persons, the resident shall be required to provide and exhibit to the utility collection office of the city, each year: 
a.  A copy of that portion of page one of the resident's income tax return showing the number of exemptions claimed upon the return and the number of dependents claimed upon the return; and 
b.  A statement in writing, verified under penalty of perjury, to the supervisor of the utility collection department that the non-metered residential user unit is occupied on a permanent resident basis by only one or two persons, as applicable. 
Any person making a false application for reduced flat rate charge, or a false statement in support of the application for reduced flat rate charge, shall be guilty of a petty offense and upon a finding of guilty, shall be fined an amount not to exceed $500.00. In addition to any fine levied as punishment for violation of this subsection (e)(2), any user making a false application or a false statement in support of an application for reduced flat rate charge shall be required to pay to the city all amounts that would have otherwise been due and owing had the user not been granted the reduced flat rate charge. Each non-metered user requesting flat rate charge shall be required to exhibit annually the proof required by this subsection (e)(2) and to make the verified statement annually as required by this subsection (e)(2) in order to be eligible for continuation of the reduced flat rate charge. If a user fails to supply the annual proof or statement in support of application for reduced flat rate charge, the flat rate charge shall be increased to the amount then in effect for non-metered users, without reduction.

(3)  A metering device for measuring the volume of waste discharged may be required by the superintendent of the wastewater treatment department if volumes cannot otherwise be determined from metered water consumption records, such device to be installed and maintained at the expense of the user. Following installation, such meter may not be removed, unless service is canceled, without the written consent of the superintendent of the wastewater treatment department.

Sec. 32-305. - Sewerage use deposits. 
(a)  No sewerage service shall be supplied to any user of the sewerage system of the city until the user has paid a deposit to the city in amounts as follows: 
(1)  For deposits on residential property, $10.00. 
(2)  For deposits on commercial property, $20.00. 
Such deposits shall be paid by the proposed user at the time of application for sewerage service to the city. 
(b)  Upon termination of the sewerage service to any customer, the deposit as listed in subsection (a) of this section, after deduction therefrom for any charges remaining due to the city for sewerage services, shall be returned to the customer. No interest shall be paid to a customer upon refund of any part of a security deposit. 
(Code 1977, § 13.20.015; Code 1990, § 15-267; Ord. No. 87-1470, 6-15-1987; Ord. No. 96-1771, 4-2-1996) 
Sec. 32-306. - Administration of sewerage fund. 
    The city treasurer shall receive all such revenues from the sewerage system and all other funds and moneys incident to the operation of such system, as the same may be delivered to him, and deposit the same in a separate fund designated as the sewerage fund of the city. The treasurer shall administer such fund in every respect in the manner provided by the provisions of the Illinois Municipal Code and all laws amendatory thereof and supplementary thereto. 
(Code 1977, § 13.20.060; Code 1990, § 15-269) 
Sec. 32-307. - System of accounts; books; audit. 
(a)  The city treasurer shall establish a proper system of accounts and shall keep proper books, records and accounts in which complete and correct entries shall be made of all transactions relative to the sewerage system, and at regular annual intervals he shall cause to be made an audit by an independent auditing concern of the books to show the receipts and disbursements of the sewerage system. 
(b)  In addition to the customary operating statements, the annual audit report shall also reflect the revenues and operating expenses of the wastewater facilities, including a replacement cost. In this regard, the financial information to be shown in the audit report shall include the following: 
(1)  Flow data showing total gallons received at the wastewater plant for the current fiscal year; 
(2)  Billing data to show total volume of wastewater billed; 
(3)  Debt service for the next succeeding fiscal year; 
(4)  Number of users connected to the system; 
(5)  Number of nonmetered users; 
(6)  A list of users discharging nondomestic wastes (industrial users) and volume of waste discharged. 
(Code 1977, § 13.20.070; Code 1990, § 15-270) 
Sec. 32-308. - Notice of liability. 
    A copy of the ordinances codified in this division, properly certified by the city clerk, shall be filed in the office of the recorder of deeds of the county and shall be deemed notice to all owners of real estate of their liability for service supplied to any user of the city on their properties. 
(Code 1977, § 13.20.080; Code 1990, § 15-271) 
Sec. 32-309. - Access to records. 
    The state environmental protection agency or its authorized representative shall have access to any books, documents, papers and records of the city which are applicable to the city system of user charges for the purpose of making audit, examination, excerpts and transcriptions thereof to ensure compliance with the terms of the special and general conditions to any state grant (Access To Records General Condition No. 19 of state grants for sewage treatment works under the Anti-Pollution Bond Act of 1970). 
(Code 1977, § 13.20.090; Code 1990, § 15-272) 
Sec. 32-310. - Notice of rates. 
    Each user will be notified annually by the city in conjunction with a regular bill, of the rate and that portion of the user charges which are attributable to the wastewater treatment services, including the financial information of section 32-307(b). 
(Code 1977, § 13.20.100; Code 1990, § 15-273) 
Sec. 32-311. - Appeals. 
    The method of computation of rates and service charges established for user charges in section 32-304(c) shall be made available to a user within 30 days of receipt of a written request for such. Any disagreement over the method used in the computations thereof shall be remedied by a committee within 60 days after notification of a formal written appeal outlining the discrepancies. The committee shall consist of a user, a member appointed by the city, and a third member appointed by the two other members. Except where council approval is needed, the decision of the committee shall be final. 
(Code 1977, § 13.20.110; Code 1990, § 15-274) 
Sec. 32-312. - Dumping contents of private septic system. 
(a)  The superintendent of the wastewater treatments facility shall be permitted to accept, from time to time, the dumping of contents of private septic systems or sewage disposal systems into the wastewater treatment facility of the city. The following conditions shall apply prior to acceptance of any materials for dumping into the wastewater treatment facility from a private septic system or sewage disposal system: 
(1)  The waste shall be accepted at the discretion of the wastewater superintendent, and with a pre-arranged appointment. 
(2)  A wastewater treatment facility attendant shall be on duty and in attendance at the time the dumping occurs. 
(3)  The person requesting authority to dump shall execute an affidavit stating that the material to be dumped consists solely of residential septic or sewage disposal system waste. 
(4)  The attendant of the wastewater treatment plant facility will conduct sampling and such tests of the contents to be dumped as may be from time to time determined by the superintendent of the wastewater treatment plant, but shall include at least a test for the pH value of the material to be dumped. 
(5)  Prior to the dumping of any substance or material, the party shall execute an agreement in a form approved and provided by the city whereby the party agrees to indemnify and hold harmless the city from any loss or damage arising from the introduction into the wastewater treatment facility of the city of the materials or substances for which permission to dump is sought. 
(b)  No waste from grease traps or any other substance or materials which will be harmful to the wastewater treatment facilities of the city shall be accepted for dumping into the facility and no substances or materials shall be accepted if the same would violate any provisions of the NPDES permit issued to the city for operation of the wastewater treatment facility. 
(c)  A fee shall be paid by each person, prior to the dumping of any materials or substance into the wastewater treatment facility of the city from private septic system or private sewage disposal system, in the amount of $50.00 for up to 2,000 gallons of materials, and the additional sum of $25.00 for each additional 1,000 gallons of material or substance or part thereof. 
(d)  A violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class B violation as provided in section 1-41. 
(e)  The city may prohibit any party or person from utilizing the wastewater treatment facility of the city from the dumping of any waste material if the party has violated any provision of this section, or if any damage has occurred to the wastewater treatment facility of the city as the result of any substance or material dumped into the system by the party. 
(Code 1990, § 15-275; Ord. No. 94-1718, § 1, 8-15-1994; Ord. No. 2004-2105A, § 1, 9-21-2004; Ord. No. 2010-2421, § 56, 10-5-2010; Ord. No. 2011-2458, § 58, 4-5-2011; Ord. No. 2016-2283, § 1, 9-20-2016) 
Sec. 32-313. - Service outside city limits: requirements; rates. 
(a)  Connection to the wastewater treatment and disposal system of the city shall not be made to any property that is not within the corporate limits of the city until there shall have been filed: (i) an irrevocable petition to annex seeking to have the property annexed to the city upon approval of the city council, meeting the requirements of division 1 of article 7 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/7-1-1 et seq.) and, (ii) an application for service, and until permit and connection fees have been paid. If the property is contiguous to the city, the property shall be annexed when all action by the city council required for annexation has been completed and taken. If the property is not contiguous to the boundary of the city at the time of filing, so to permit the immediate annexation thereof by action of the city council, the petition shall also be in a form meeting the requirements for recording within the office of the county recorder. The petition for annexation shall require that the property be annexed to the city immediately upon its becoming contiguous to the limits of the city. The legal description of the property shall be sufficient to allow the recording of the document, and shall include the property identification number assigned thereto by the county supervisor of assessments. An annexation plat, as required by law, shall also be supplied. 
(b)  For residential customers located outside the limits of the city, the rates and charges shall be as follows, unless otherwise modified or provided for in an annexation agreement that has been duly approved by the city council:

Sec. 32-314. - Regulation of portable toilets. 
(a)  This section is to preserve and protect the health, safety and general welfare of persons and the property in the city by regulating the location and maintenance of portable toilets and requiring a permit for their use and placement. 
(b)  Definitions. For the purpose of this section, the following definitions shall apply. 
(1)  Portable toilet means a free standing, movable toilet structure equipped with a water-tight impervious container which receives waste discharged through a hopper, seat, urinal or similar device and into which container may be placed disinfecting or deodorizing chemicals. For the purposes of this section, portable toilet and chemical toilet shall have the same meaning. 
(2)  Parks/open space means public passive or active recreation areas including but not limited to parks, hiking/bike trails, natural areas, wild life areas, open grass area and baseball diamonds, tennis courts, basketball courts, play fields and playgrounds owned by the municipality and/or local park district. 
(c)  Allowable use of portable toilets. Portable toilets may only be used to provide temporary bathroom facilities for special events, seasonal bathroom facilities on public and private parks and open recreational spaces, or as part of construction projects. In no case shall portable toilets be used as permanent sanitary facilities for residential, commercial or industrial uses or as a secondary sanitary facility on existing developed properties. Provided, however, that portable toilets may be utilized or provided by the city for use in case of emergency where permanent sanitary facilities are not available for use, or are inoperable or the use thereof has been prohibited by action of the city, and the provisions of this section shall not apply to such emergency use or provision by the city. 
(d)  Permit required. No person, firm, partnership, non-profit or franchise shall place or install a portable toilet in the city without first obtaining a permit for the same. The fee for the permit shall be $15.00, payable at time of issuance of the permit in the building department. Application for permit shall be submitted by the owner of the property where to be placed, by the sponsor of the event, by the contractor engaged in the construction project or by the supplier of the portable toilet(s). The following information shall be provided as part of the permit application forms provided by the city: 
(1)  The owner of the property. 
(2)  The contact information for the owner of the portable toilets. 
(3)  Dates during which toilets are to be provided. 
(4)  Site plan identifying the proposed locations of the toilets. 
(5)  Number of and type of toilets to be put in place. 
    A permit shall be valid for no more than four days, and if the portable toilet(s) remain in place after expiration of the permit without application for extension, such placement shall be a violation of this section punishable as provided. 
    No permit or application shall be required of the Coloma Park District or by any public school district as condition to the placement or use of portable toilet(s) on property owned by that district. 
(e)  Permit exemption. No permit shall be required in the following instances: 
(1)  Community events. The placement of portable toilets on public property for community events of either the municipality or a non-profit organization lasting no more than seven calendar days. 
(2)  Public road and utility projects. Portable toilets placed on public or private property in conjunction with public road and utility construction projects, as long as the location is approved by the building department. 
(3)  Private events. The placement of portable toilets on private property for private outdoor events lasting no more than four days when a permit for the event has been granted by appropriate city department or by council approval. 
(4)  Other projects. Any portable toilet placed on a site as part of a project which has received city council approval. 
(f)  Emptying and maintenance. All portable toilets shall be emptied in a timely fashion by a person or firm engaged in the business of cleaning or emptying portable toilets, and recharged at a sufficient frequency to prevent escape of offensive odors or spillage. Individuals engaged in the business of cleaning or emptying toilets shall use a suitable vehicle properly provided with water-tight, completely enclosed tanks or boxes designed to prevent leakage onto streets or highways and further designed to prevent the escape of offensive odors in the atmosphere. The person, firm, partnership or other entity to whom the permit has been issued shall be responsible for the maintenance requirements of this section, and shall be liable for any damages caused by failure to maintain as required. 
(g)  A violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class C violation as provided in section l-41. 
(Ord. No. 2015-2236, § 1, 11-3-2015) 
Secs. 32-315-32-342. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - ELECTRICITY 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 32-343. - Connection; application, certificate of wiring compliance. 
    Applications for connection to the municipal electric distribution system shall be made in writing to the director of electrical utilities and shall be accompanied by a certificate of the director that the wiring of the premises complies with all ordinances of the city and with any applicable provisions of building codes in effect and adopted from time to time by the city, and with any provisions of the National Electrical Code as in effect from time to time, as may be applied by duly adopted ordinance of the city. No premises, whether located within or without limits of the city, shall be connected to the electrical distribution system of the city unless the premises complies with the provisions of this section. In addition, in each of the following instances, in order for a residence to be connected, remain connected or be reconnected to the electrical distribution system of the city, the residence, regardless of whether located within or without the limits of the city, shall conform to the requirements of city ordinances and adopted and in effect building and electrical codes which require a minimum of 100 amps capacity service panel and external disconnect, and the application for connection shall be accompanied by a certificate of the director of electrical utilities or his designee that the service does comply. The instances are: 
(1)  When the residence has been damaged by fire or other catastrophic event the repair for which necessitates the issuance of a building permit; 
(2)  When renovation, remodeling or addition is to be made to the residence for which a building permit is required to be issued; 
(3)  When ownership of the residence changes, except for a change of ownership from one spouse to another, from one spouse to both spouses, when the change is in compliance with a property settlement following a dissolution of marriage, or from one co-tenant to another co-tenant or co-tenants. 
(Code 1977, § 13.24.010; Code 1990, § 15-291; Ord. No. 2012-2084, § 1, 11-20-2012) 
Sec. 32-344. - Wiring conformance required prior to connection. 
    No premises shall be connected with the municipal electrical distribution system unless the wiring in such premises fully conforms with the provisions of the building code of the city applicable thereto. 
(Code 1977, § 13.24.020; Code 1990, § 15-292) 
Sec. 32-345. - Location of electrical meters and water readers. 
    All electrical meters and water readers must be installed on an outside wall of a building and be accessible to meter readers and other city personnel. Fenced-in yards must have an unpadlocked gate. Dogs must be secured either safely out of reach or in a separately fenced location away from the location of the service meters. Failure of the customer to comply with this section within 90 days of written notice will be cause for the termination of the service. 
(Code 1977, § 13.24.030; Code 1990, § 15-293) 
Sec. 32-346. - Meters required. 
    No premises shall be served with electricity from the electrical distribution system of the city unless the premises is equipped with a meter of a type designated by the superintendent of electricity, placed in accordance with the requirements of the electrical department. 
(Code 1990, § 15-294; Ord. No. 87-1469, § 13.28.010, 6-1-1987) 
Sec. 32-347. - Rates generally. 
    The rates to be applied to wholesale and retail customers of the city's electrical distribution system for electrical energy furnished and the conditions of service and payment for service shall be in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1990, § 15-295; Ord. No. 87-1469, § 13.28.020, 6-1-1987) 
Sec. 32-348. - Purchase power adjustment factor. 
(a)  The charges to all customers under all rates for all kilowatt hours in the billing period shall be increased or decreased by a purchase cost adjustment charge or credit (PPA factor) for each $0.0001 or major fraction thereof by which the average cost of purchased power per kilowatt hour of input to the electrical system exceeds or is less than $0.071 per kilowatt hour. The PPA factor shall be calculated by dividing the annual purchased power costs by the annual purchased and generated (hydroelectric plant) kilowatt hours, and by multiplying the quotient times a loss factor of 1.04 and by then subtracting from the product a base power cost of $0.071 per kilowatt hour. The PPA to be applied to all customer charges shall be determined in March of each year based upon the prior 12 month period (March through February) and shall be effective as to all meter readings and billings rendered on and after the next succeeding May 1. 
    Notwithstanding, the PPA factor for the period July 1, 2017 through April 30, 2018 shall be $0.0003. 
(b)  The formula for calculation of the purchased power adjustment factor shall be: 
PPA = C over K times 1.04 minus $0.071, where: 
C = Total costs of purchased power for the previous period March 1 through February 29 (including Commonwealth Edison Company transmission charges) 
K = total kilowatt hours of purchased power plus hydroelectric plant generated energy for the previous period March 1 through February 29; 
1.04 = the multiplier adjustment for system losses; 
$0.071 = the base power cost. 
(c)  This section 32-348 shall become effective as to all meter readings for electrical energy supplied where the readings of the meter for such energy occur on July 1, 2017 and thereafter, and shall be applied to the billings generated from such meter readings issued thereafter. 
(Code 1990, § 15-296; Ord. No. 91-1594, § 2, 5-6-1991; Ord. No. 93-1666, § 1, 8-2-1993; Ord. No. 96-1798, § 1, 10-1-1996; Ord. No. 2010-2381, § 1, 2-16-2010; Ord. No. 2017-2320, § 1, 6-20-2017) 
Sec. 32-349. - Delayed payment. 
(a)  Each bill for electric energy service which is prepared and sent to any customer of the city shall provide on its face a due date for payment, which due date shall be no longer than 17 days after the date of mailing the bill. If the bill shall not have been paid by the customer on or prior to the due date shown on the face of the monthly bill, then there shall be added to the bill as a late charge an amount equal to five percent of the portion of the bill which is unpaid as of the due date, unless the customer listed on the bill is 65 years or older before the time listed as the due date, or if the customer is receiving federal Social Security Disability and can provide proof of coverage to city staff. If the monthly bill shall not have been paid on or prior to ten days after the due date as shown on the monthly bill, service to the meter shall be disconnected until such time as the bill, any late payment charges and any applicable reconnection charges shall be paid by the customer. The director of electrical utility shall, from time to time, determine the cost incurred and charge necessary to reimburse the city for the expense of reconnecting service following disconnect for non-payment. 
(b)  Any commercial or industrial customer of the electric utility which has incurred or is likely to incur the penalty for late payment provided for in this section may request relief from the late payment penalty under the following circumstances and upon the following conditions: 
(1)  The business conducted by the customer is under financial strain due to loss of business, reduction of revenue, general economic conditions, or extraordinary costs or expenses incurred, and the financial strain is not the result of intentional or willful action by the customer. 
(2)  Strict application of the provisions of subsection (a) of this section may result in the closing of the business conducted by the customer, may result in reduction of work force, layoff or cutback in jobs of the customer, or may have other substantial adverse economic impact upon the community. 
(3)  The customer shall have made written request for relief from the strict application of subsection (a) of this section, which written request shall include the following. 
a.  Financial information of the customer in sufficient detail to support the basis upon which the claim for relief is made; 
b.  Copies of documents in support of the request for relief; 
c.  Documentation and material establishing the amount of salaries paid to owners or principal shareholders of the business during the preceding 12 months; 
d.  Documentation and information evidencing the number of employees, the number of employees or job positions which will be eliminated unless relief is granted, and documentation establishing the amount of payroll which will be affected if relief is not granted; 
e.  Such other and further information and documentation as may from time to time be requested by the committee established in this section. 
(4)  The request for relief submitted by the customer shall be submitted to a committee consisting of the director of electric utilities, the mayor, the director of the customer service office and city accountant. Such committee shall convene as soon as practicable following receipt of the request for relief by a customer, to consider the request, the evidence submitted, and to determine whether the request for relief should be granted. 
(5)  The committee, upon review of the material submitted by the customer, may determine to deny the request for relief, or to grant the request for relief. Relief which may be granted shall include elimination of all delayed payment charges, establishment of a payment schedule for payment of delayed payment charges, reduction of delayed payment charges, establishment of a payment schedule for payment of any delinquent utility charges or such other relief as may from time to time be determined by the committee necessary to avoid substantial negative impact upon the community. Relief shall be granted by the committee only if the committee finds, based upon the evidence submitted, that substantial negative economic impact will result if the relief is not granted. In addition to the evidence and documentation submitted by the customer, the committee shall also consider the impact upon the electric utility resulting from the granting of any relief. 
(6)  The committee shall report the relief granted to the city council and the city council shall have authority to reject and overrule the relief granted. 
(7)  Upon receipt of a request for relief by a customer pursuant to this section, the mayor and director of electrical utilities shall have authority to delay any disconnection for non-payment until the committee shall have been convened and shall have considered the application of the customer. 
(8)  In considering any request for relief by a customer, the committee shall take all steps reasonably available for securing payment of the full amounts due and owing by the customer, to the extent that such security is obtainable. 
(Code 1990, § 15-297; Ord. No. 93-1667, § 1, 8-2-1993; Ord. No. 93-1686, § 1, 10-19-1993; Ord. No. 2001-1964, § 1, 3-6-2001; Ord. No. 2002-2027, § 1, 11-5-2002; Ord. No. 2005-2148, § 1, 10-18-2005; Ord. No. 2010-2406, § 1, 6-15-2010; Ord. No. 2011-2472, § 2, 7-19-2011) 
Sec. 32-350. - Security deposit. 
(a)  In addition to any service connection charges required by section 32-25, the city may require an applicant for electrical service to pay a security deposit to the city. The security deposit paid shall be held by the city until the customer shall have terminated service with the city, whereupon the amount of the deposit shall be applied against any outstanding charges due from the customer to the city for electrical service, and the balance shall be refunded. It shall be the duty of the customer to notify the city utility collection office as to the forwarding address for return of any deposit refund. 
(b)  The city may require that any existing customer of the city make a security deposit in the amounts as provided for herein, if any of the following conditions exist: 
(1)  Service to the customer has been disconnected for nonpayment of charges; 
(2)  Late payment charges have been assessed to the customer four or more times during the preceding 12-month period; 
(3)  The customer is indebted to the city for services under a statement which is past due beyond the time when services ordinarily would have been disconnected under section 32-349; 
(4)  The customer has been found to have tampered with any electric service meter of the city or has obtained electrical service illegally. 
(c)  Any customer required by subsection (b)(1) of this section to pay a security deposit shall pay such security deposit on or before reconnection of service. Any customer required by subsection (b)(2), (3) or (4) of this section shall pay such deposit within ten days after notification of request for payment Upon failure of the customer to pay by or within the time required, the customer shall be disconnected from service in accordance with the provisions of section 32-349, as though the failure to pay security deposit were a delayed payment. Reconnection of the customer shall be in accordance with the provisions of sections 32-25 and 32-349. 
(d)  The amount of the deposit to be paid by the customer shall, in the case of residential service, be an amount equal to one-sixth of the estimated annual charges for average residential service, and in the case of commercial service, shall be an amount equal to one-third of the estimated annual charges for the commercial customer. 
(e)  The city shall have the authority, upon approval of the director of electrical utilities, to waive payment of any deposit by an applicant for electrical service, if any of the following conditions exist: 
(1)  The applicant is a previous customer of the electrical department of the city, and has established a satisfactory payment history, with no late charges being assessed for at least the last two years of the prior service. 
(2)  The applicant is a previous customer of the electrical department of the city, and currently has on deposit with the city a security deposit for the service provided at the previous location. 
(3)  The applicant provides to the city a letter of guarantee from a charitable organization or governmental agency whereby the organization or agency guarantees payment of any future charges for electrical service to the customer. 
(4)  The applicant has otherwise provided to the director of electrical utilities satisfactory credit references which establish a strong likelihood the applicant will pay promptly charges for future electrical service. In such case, however, if the applicant shall later fail to pay when due a charge for electrical service, then the city shall have authority to require the customer to make a security deposit to be held pursuant to this section as a guarantee of payment of charges for electrical service to be provided subsequent to the late payment. Failure by the customer to make and pay the deposit to the city within ten days of notification and request for payment of same shall result in disconnection of the service until such time as the security deposit, any late payment charges under section 15-297 and any applicable reconnection charge shall have been paid by the customer. 
(f)  A customer requesting termination or disconnection of electrical service shall promptly pay when due all charges for electrical energy supplied, and shall apply for and request of the city, on forms to be provided by the city, a refund of any excess security deposit of the customer, after application by the city of the deposit towards any outstanding and unpaid charges for electrical service. The city shall have the right to require proof of authority to receive the deposit of any person purporting to act on behalf of the maker of the deposit, as executor, administrator, guardian, or under any power of attorney; provided, however, no refund of excess security deposit shall be made until 30 days after the request has been received by the city. 
(g)  The city council may provide by rule for refund of deposits prior to termination of service to customers with satisfactory payment history. No interest shall be paid to a customer upon refund of any part of a security deposit. 
(h)  An owner of any single-family or multifamily rental dwelling may elect to direct the electric utility office to cause electric service to remain connected and service to be provided to the dwelling following vacation of the dwelling by any tenant, provided that upon such election, the owner of the dwelling shall agree to be responsible for and to pay any charges for electric service furnished following vacation by the tenant. Any owner of residential dwelling so requesting shall be required to make a deposit against future service in the minimum amount of $50.00. If request is not made by the owner of the dwelling for continuance of service following vacation, and if the owner elects to have service disconnected following vacation by a tenant, any reconnect and continuation of service thereafter shall be made only upon payment by the owner of a $25.00 reconnection charge. Such reconnection charge shall not apply to reconnection for a tenant who is a new customer at the dwelling location. 
(Code 1990, § 15-298; Ord. No. 93-1684, § 1, 10-4-1993; Ord. No. 93-1691, § 1, 11-15-1993; Ord. No. 2002-2031, § 1, 11-19-2002; Ord. No. 2009-2342, § 1, 6-2-2009) 
Secs. 32-351-32-373. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - RESIDENTIAL RATE 

Sec. 32-374. - Availability. 
    The residential rate (known as rate R) shall be available for residential lighting and appliance service to installations served through one meter for each family unit in a residence or apartment, including service to single-phase motors with locked rotor current not to exceed 1,130 amperes served at 240 volts (nominal). This rate shall not be available for commercial, institutional or industrial service. When the service is used through the same meter for both residential and commercial purposes, the commercial rate shall apply to all electrical energy purchased. 
(Code 1990, § 15-311; Ord. No. 87-1469, § 13.28.030, 6-1-1987) 
Sec. 32-375. - Character of service. 
    The character of the service supplied under rate R shall be single-phase, 60 hertz at 120-240 volts (nominal). 
(Code 1990, § 15-313; Ord. No. 87-1469, § 13.28.050, 6-1-1987) 
Sec. 32-376. - Monthly rates, rate R (residential). 
(a)  Each customer receiving service from the city electric utility who qualifies for rate R shall be charged for such service: 
(1)  A net monthly customer charge to each meter, designated herein as "MC"; plus 
(2)  An energy charge net per kilowatt hour to be applied to the meter reading and to be applied to all energy used and taken during the billing cycle, referred to herein as "KWh", and consisting of: 
a.  A power supply charge net per kilowatt hour, referred to herein as "PS"; plus 
b.  A distribution charge net per kilowatt hour, referred to herein as "DC"; and 
(3)  A capital cost recovery charge net per kilowatt hour, referred to herein as "CCR". 
The formula for calculation of charges for electric energy usage (E) in each billing period under Rate R is: 
E = MC + KWh(n) + CCR, where KWh equals the sum of PS and DC, and n equals total kilowatt hours of energy used during the billing period as determined by meter reading. 
(b)  The amounts set forth in the following table shall constitute the charges, respectively, for KWH, PS, DC, and CCR, to be applied in accordance with the formula set forth in paragraph (a) (2) of this section, and shall apply effective as of the dates specified in the table, and shall be effective and applied on all invoices and bills to customers issued or generated through, or on or after the date set forth in the table, regardless of when the electrical energy shall have been supplied.

Sec. 32-377. - Taxes. 
    The net bill as calculated under rate R, including minimum and adjustments, shall be increased by an amount equal to that paid to the state as utility tax. 
(Code 1990, § 15-316; Ord. No. 87-1469, § 13.28.090, 6-1-1987) 
Sec. 32-378. - Multifamily dwellings. 
    Where three or more families with separate cooking facilities occupy a residential dwelling, the wiring shall be so arranged that the service to each family unit is metered and billed separately. All common service facilities (i.e., passageways, stairs, heating, air conditioning, general area lighting) serving all occupants of a multifamily dwelling shall be separately metered and shall be classified as a commercial service and billed under rates applicable to such service. 
(Code 1990, § 15-317; Ord. No. 87-1469, § 13.28.100, 6-1-1987) 
Secs. 32-379-32-399. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - COMMERCIAL RATE 

Sec. 32-400. - Availability. 
    There is hereby established a rate schedule for commercial customers, to be known as rate C, which shall be available to any commercial (nonresidential) customer where peak annual demand is less than 35 kilowatts for all uses, including, but not limited to, heating, lighting, water heating, cooking, clothes drying, refrigeration, etc. All energy, whether single- or three-phase, shall be taken at one point of service and through a single meter for an individual customer, or if there is more than one individual customer in a single structure, the energy shall be taken at one point of service and through a single meter for each individual customer. 
(Code 1990, § 15-336; Ord. No. 87-1469, § 13.28.200, 6-1-1987; Ord. No. 93-1669, § 1, 8-2-1993) 
Sec. 32-401. - Character of service. 
    The character of service to be supplied to a customer under rate C shall be alternating current, 60 cycles, at nominal voltage of 120-240 or 120-208 single-phase or 120-208 or 277-480 three-phase as available from suitable facilities of adequate capacity adjacent to the premises to be serviced. 120-240 volts three-phase delta service will only be made available from presently existing transformer stations and will not be made available if additional transformer capacity or a new transformer station is required. 
(Code 1990, § 15-338; Ord. No. 87-1469, § 13.28.220, 6-1-1987) 
Sec. 32-402. - Monthly rates, rate C (commercial). 
(a)  Each customer receiving service from the city electric utility who qualifies for rate C shall be charged for such service: 
(1)  A net monthly customer charge to each meter, referred to herein as "MC;" plus 
(2)  An energy charge net per kilowatt hour to be applied to the meter reading and to be applied to all energy used and taken during the billing cycle, referred to herein as "KWh," and consisting of: 
a.  Power supply charge net per kilowatt hour, referred to herein as "PS;" plus 
b.  A distribution charge net per kilowatt hour, referred to herein as "DC;" and 
(3)  A capital cost recovery charge net per kilowatt hour, referred to herein as "CCR." 
The formula for calculation of charges for electric energy usage (E) in each billing period under rate C is: 
E = MC + KWh(n) + CCR, Where KWh equals the sum of PS and DC and n = Total kilowatt hours of energy used during the billing period as determined by meter reading.

(Code 1990, § 15-341; Ord. No. 87-1469, § 13.28.260, 6-1-1987) 
Sec. 32-404. - Power factor correction. 
    The electrical department may, at its option, test or meter the power factor on a load for a customer under rate C where there is evidence of a lagging power factor less than 85 percent. If the department determines that such a lagging exists, then the department may require the customer to install power factor correcting equipment, and, upon the failure of the customer to so install, the department may install such equipment near the customer, and shall add the cost for installation to the customer. No correction will be made or required where the power factor is leading or greater than 85 percent lagging. 
(Code 1990, § 15-342; Ord. No. 87-1469, § 13.28.270, 6-1-1987) 
Secs. 32-405-32-421. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - GENERAL SERVICE RATE 

Sec. 32-422. - Availability. 
    A general service rate to be known as rate GS shall be available for electrical energy supplied to any customer whose peak annual demand is 35 kilowatts or greater for all uses, provided that the customer shall elect to be billed upon this rate. Any customer desiring to elect shall furnish notice in writing to the superintendent of electrical utilities of the city. Any customer electing to be billed under rate GS shall remain on such rate GS until such time as 12 consecutive months shall have occurred without the customer's peak monthly demand being equal to or in excess of 35 kilowatts, but in no event less than 12 consecutive months from the date of election. All energy served under rate GS shall be taken at one point of service and through a single meter or an individual customer. The rate shall not be available for auxiliary or stand-by service of any type. 
(Code 1990, § 15-356; Ord. No. 87-1469, § 13.28.280, 6-1-1987; Ord. No. 93-1671, § 1, 8-2-1993) 
Sec. 32-423. - Character of service. 
    The character of service to be supplied to a customer under rate GS shall be alternating current, 60 cycles, at nominal voltage of 120-240, or 120-208 single-phase, or 120-208 or 277-480 three-phase as available from suitable facilities of adequate capacity adjacent to the premises to be serviced. 120-240 volts three-phase delta service will not be made available under rate GS. 
(Code 1990, § 15-358; Ord. No. 87-1469, § 13.28.300, 6-1-1987) 
Sec. 32-424. - Monthly rate, rate GS. 
(a)  Each customer, including any municipal or governmental user, receiving service from the city electric utility who qualifies for rate GS shall be charged for such service: 
(1)  A net monthly customer charge to each meter, designed herein as "MC"; plus 
(2)  A monthly demand charge, designated herein as "DE", which shall be the sum of: 
a.  A power supply demand charge per kilowatt of billing demand, designated herein as "DSE"; and 
b.  A distribution demand charge per kilowatt of billing demand, designated herein as "DDC"; plus 
c.  An energy charge net per kilowatt hour to be applied to the meter reading consisting of: 
1.  A power supply charge net per kilowatt hour, designated herein as "KWh"; plus 
2.  A payment for capital cost recovery per kilowatt hour, designated herein as "CCR" 
(b)  The amounts set forth in the following table shall constitute the rates and charges, respectively, for MC, DE, DSE, DDC, KWh and CCR to be applied pursuant to the formula set forth in paragraph (a)(2) of this section to customers qualifying for Rate GS, including municipal or governmental entities. The amounts so set forth shall apply effective as of the dates specified in the table, and shall be effective and applied on all invoices and bills to customers issued or generated through, or on or after the date set forth in the table, regardless of when the electrical energy shall have been supplied.

Sec. 32-425. - Minimum bill, rate GS. 
    The minimum billing cycle charge under rate GS shall be equal to the demand charge (DE) plus the monthly customer charge (MC), and shall apply regardless of whether energy is used or taken by the customer during the billing cycle. 
(Code 1990, § 15-360; Ord. No. 87-1469, § 13.28.320, 6-1-1987; Ord. No. 2010-2381, § 5, 2-16-2010) 
Sec. 32-426. - Billing demand. 
    For the purposes of application of rate GS, it is determined that the billing demand of the customer shall be equal to the highest of the following: 
(1)  Peak 30-minute integrated demand occurring during the month; 
(2)  75 percent of the peak 30-minute integrated demand occurring in the preceding 11 months; 
(3)  20 kilowatts. 
Provided, however, that the billing demand for any school served under rate GS shall be determined to be the peak 30-minute integrated demand occurring during the month. 
(Code 1990, § 15-361; Ord. No. 87-1469, § 13.28.330, 6-1-1987) 
Sec. 32-427. - Special contracts. 
    The city may, at its option, require any customer with demand in excess of 300 kilowatts to be served under a special contract, and if the city so exercises the option, rates as determined and fixed by that special contract shall apply in lieu of any other rate schedule established by ordinance of the city. 
(Code 1990, § 15-362; Ord. No. 87-1469, § 13.28.350, 6-1-1987) 
Sec. 32-428. - Taxes. 
    The net bill as calculated under rate GS, including minimum and adjustments, shall be increased by an amount equal to that paid to the state as utility tax. 
(Code 1990, § 15-364; Ord. No. 87-1469, § 13.28.370, 6-1-1987) 
Sec. 32-429. - Power factor correction. 
    The electrical department may, at its option, test or meter the power factor on a load for a customer under rate GS where there is evidence of a lagging power factor less than 85 percent. If the department determines that such a lagging exists, the department may require the customer to install power factor correcting equipment, and upon the failure of the customer to so install, the department may install such equipment near the customer, and shall add the cost for installation to the customer. No correction will be made or required where the power factor is leading or greater than 85 percent lagging. 
(Code 1990, § 15-365; Ord. No. 87-1469, § 13.28.380, 6-1-1987) 
Sec. 32-430. - Customer-owned transformer rider. 
(a)  Availability. Any customer being supplied under the GS rate shall have available, at the customer's option, the customer-owned transformer rider. The rider shall be applicable only where electricity is supplied at 2,400 volts or more and is metered at the primary voltage of the line or lines entering the customer's premises, and where the customer furnishes, installs and maintains any and all transformers and other facilities necessary to reduce the primary voltage of each such line to the customer's utilization voltage. 
(b)  Credit applied. The customer shall be allowed a credit of $0.20069 (20.069¢) each month for each kilowatt of the highest 30-minute demand of the customer established during the month. 
(Code 1990, § 15-367; Ord. No. 87-1469, § 13.28.387, 6-1-1987) 
Sec. 32-431. - Economic development rate rider. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Qualifying customer means: 
(1)  Any new customer not previously receiving service from the city electrical utility department with a monthly peak of a least 1,000 kilowatts; or 
(2)  Any presently existing customer of the electrical department which adds a new monthly peak load of 1,000 kilowatts or more, but provided that for such new load, the existing customer shall meter separately to determine that the load requirement is met; and 
which meets all other requirements of the state municipal electric agency schedule B-6. 
(b)  Established. There is hereby established an economic development rate rider for qualifying customers (as defined in this section), which economic development rate rider shall operate to reduce the demand charge (DE) to such qualifying customers. The reduced demand charge provided for herein shall be instead of the demand charge specified in section 32-424. 
    Any customer who shall qualify for the economic development rate rider established pursuant to this section, and who first takes the qualifying service from the city electric utility on May 1, 2010, or thereafter, shall, instead of the demand charge set forth in said section 32-424, be entitled to a reduced demand charge in accordance with the following table with each column being applicable as to the date of first taking service, and with each row specifying the demand charge applicable to a customer during the 60-month period following the first date of service by the customer: 
Date of First Service Beginning 5-1-2014 1 st -12 th month $9.60 per kW 13 th -24 th month $10.85 per kW 25 th -36 th month $12.10 per kW 37 th -48 th month $13.35 per kW 49 th -60 th month $14.60 per kW  
    The monthly customer charge and energy shall be billed in accordance with the applicable rate structure for the customer as established from time to time by the city. 
(c)  Applicability. The economic development rate rider shall be applicable to any month in which the load of the qualifying customer meets the definitional standards of this section, and the economic development rate rider shall be available for a five-year period from the date of commencement of service under the rate to the customer. 
(d)  Availability. The economic development rate rider shall be available only for so long as the state municipal electrical agency makes available to the city, for wholesale purchase, an economic development rider rate, and if at any time such economic development rate rider is not available from the state municipal electric agency, then the city shall not be obligated or required to provide such rate rider and reduction in rate to any customer. 
(Code 1990, § 15-368; Ord. No. 91-1597, 5-20-1991; Ord. No. 2000-1923, § 1, 2-3-2000; Ord. No. 2010-2381, § 7, 2-16-2010; Ord. No. 2017-2339, § 1, 9-19-2017) 
Sec. 32-432. - Economic development rate rider, 150-Kilowatt demand. 
(a)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Qualifying customer means any new or existing retail customer of the city electric utility system which establishes new or additional monthly peak load of 150 kilowatts or greater, but provided that such customer shall first have made application for this economic development rate rider, and provided further that the new or additional load shall be determined by a separate meter applicable to such load only. 
(b)  There is hereby established an economic development rate rider for qualifying customers (as defined in this section), which economic development rate rider shall operate to reduce the demand charge to such qualifying customer. The amount of the reduction in the demand charge to the qualifying customer shall be equal to the otherwise applicable rate demand charge, less the dollar amount for the applicable period as set forth in the following schedule: 
Period to Which Reduction in Demand Charge 
Applied After Qualification Per Kilowatt Amount Of Reduction 1 st -12 th month $2.40 per kW 13 th -24 th month $1.60 per kW 25 th -36 th month $0.80 per kW  
The monthly customer charge and energy shall be billed in accordance with the applicable rate structure for the customer as established from time to time by the city. 
(c)  The economic development rate rider provided for in this section shall be applied from the first month in which the new or additional load of 150 kilowatts or greater is established, and prospectively thereafter, but provided that the new or additional load of 150 kilowatts or greater must be attained by the customer prior to December 31, 2017. The economic development rate rider provided by this section shall not be applied retroactively to any period before application for the rate rider by the customer, or to any period before adoption of the ordinances establishing this rate rider, and from which this division is derived. 
(Code 1990, § 15-369; Ord. No. 93-1648, § 1, 3-1-1993; Ord. No. 2000-1924, § 1, 2-3-2000; Ord. No. 2017-2339, §§ 2, 3, 9-19-2017) 
Sec. 32-433. - Seasonal demand proration adjustment. 
(a)  Any customer being supplied under general service rate (rate GS) may request a seasonal proration adjustment in the billing demand of the customer provided that all of the following conditions occur: 
(1)  The customer experiences an abrupt decrease of at least 50 percent of maximum billing demand as the result of a vacation shut-down or a seasonal slow-down or shut-down of activity within any billing period; 
(2)  The period of decreased billing demand continues for at least seven consecutive days immediately following the onset of such billing demand decrease for which the seasonal demand proration adjustment is requested. 
(3)  The customer shall have supplied to the superintendent of electric utilities of the city a written request, in advance, requesting the seasonal demand proration adjustment, which written request shall stipulate the date of onset of the decrease in billing demand; 
(4)  No more than one seasonal demand proration adjustment shall be granted to any one customer in any one calendar year; 
(5)  The period to which the seasonal demand proration adjustment shall apply shall not exceed 30 consecutive days. 
(b)  The director of electrical utilities shall grant each customer request for seasonal demand proration adjustment provided that all of the preconditions thereto have been met. 
(c)  Upon granting of the customer request for seasonal demand proration adjustment, there shall be substituted for the billing demand calculated under section 32-426 for the billing period to which the adjustment applies a billing demand calculated by dividing the maximum demand by the number of demand days in the billing period times the number of days within the billing period when the decrease in demand is not in effect. 
(Code 1990, § 15-370; Ord. No. 2000-1919, § 1, 1-4-2000) 
Sec. 32-434. - Load retention rate schedule. 
(a)  There is hereby created a load retention rate which shall be available to any customer of the electric utility of the city that: 
(1)  Is currently receiving service under rage GS; 
(2)  Registers a minimum load of 1,000 kilowatts during the monthly peak load of the city for at least five months during any calendar year; and: 
a.  Can legally be served through facilities owned by another electric supplier; or 
b.  Is at risk of being lost by the city as a customer due to relocation of the facilities by bankruptcy of, or self generation by the customer. 
(b)  A customer of the electric utility qualifying under subsection (a) of this section for the load retention rate shall be charged for electric service an amount computed in accordance with the demand component plus energy charge of the state municipal electric agency schedule B-4 as in effect from time to time (excluding any portion attributable to debt service), plus no more than ten percent, plus an amount attributable to line capacity and energy loss, as determined from time to time by the superintendent of the electric utility of the city. A copy of schedule B-4 as adopted and in effect from time to time by the state municipal electric agency shall be provided to the customer to substantiate the basis upon which charges for electric service are made. 
(c)  Prior to initiating the load retention rate for any customer, the customer shall supply to the superintendent of the electric utility of the city such information and documentation as the superintendent requests to substantiate the eligibility of the customer for the load retention rate. Any information supplied by the customer shall remain confidential, and shall not be subject to disclosure under any Freedom of Information Act request, except that the city may supply such documentation and information to the state municipal electric agency executive board in order to obtain consent of the agency for application of the load retention rate. 
(d)  Any customer granted service under the load retention rate shall be eligible to receive and pay for electrical service under this rate schedule for a maximum period of one year, unless special extension is granted by the executive board of the state municipal electric agency, or unless the rate is extended or renewed after application for such extension or renewal by the customer. 
(e)  The load retention rate adopted by this section shall be effective as to qualifying customers for all electrical energy purchased and for billings made commencing February 1, 2001, and thereafter. 
(Code 1990, § 15-371; Ord. No. 2001-1965, § 1, 3-6-2001) 
Sec. 32-435. - Irrigation system off-peak rider. 
(a)  Availability. Any customer being supplied under rate C for a farm or agriculture related irrigation system may, at the option of the customer, elect to be billed under the irrigation system off-peak rate rider. The customer election to be billed shall be made in writing to the superintendent of the electric utility department of the city and the rate shall not be effective until the electric utility department shall have installed a time-of-day meter, which shall be supplied at no charge to the customer. The customer shall be required to grant reasonable access to employees of the electric utility department for purposes of installation of the time-of-day meter, and until the meter is installed, the customer shall not qualify for the irrigation system off-peak rate rider. This rider shall only be available to customers for electricity purchased for operation of a farm or agricultural irrigation system. 
(b)  Peak period. The rates established under this irrigation system off-peak rate rider shall be effective only during off-peak periods, which are defined as all hours other than 6:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. of each weekday Monday through Friday. The city, upon giving notice to the customer under this rider, in writing, not less than one month in advance, may change the definition of peak and off-peak periods. 
(c)  Charges for service. Each customer receiving service from the city electric utility and qualifying under this irrigation system off-peak rate rider shall be charged for such service: 
(1)  A net monthly customer charge to each meter, designated herein as "MC;" plus 
(2)  An energy charge net per kilowatt hour to be applied to the meter reading and to be applied to all energy used and taken during the billing cycle, during off-peak hours, referred to herein as "KWh", and consisting of: 
a.  A power supply charge net per kilowatt hour, referred to herein as "PS;" plus 
b.  A distribution charge net per kilowatt hour, referred to herein as "DC;" and 
(3)  A capital cost recovery charge net per kilowatt hour, referred to herein as "CCR." 
The formula for calculation of charges for electric energy usage (E) in each billing period under the irrigation system off-peak rider rate is: 
E = MC + KWh(n) + CCR, where KWh equals the sum of PS and DC, and n equals total kilowatt hours of energy used during the billing period as determined by meter reading. 
(4)  The amounts set forth in the following table shall constitute the charges, respectively for KWh, PS, DC and CCR, to be applied in accordance with the formula set forth in paragraph (c)(2) of this section, for all power taken and supplied during off-peak periods, as defined herein, and the amounts so set forth shall apply effective as of the dates specified in the table to all invoices and bills to customers issued or generated through, or on or after the date set forth in the table, regardless of when the electrical energy shall have been supplied.

(Code 1990, § 15-375; Ord. No. 99-1893, § 1, 7-20-1999; Ord. No. 99-1896, § 1, 7-28-1999; Ord. No. 2001-1971, § 6, 4-26-2001; Ord. No. 2010-2381, § 8, 2-16-2010; Ord. No. 2017-2320, § 5, 6-20-2017 
Sec. 32-436. - Urban security light rate. 
(a)  Any customer located within the service territory of the city electric utility may request installation of an urban security light by the electric utility department. The customer shall be responsible for supplying the pole or other apparatus to which the security light shall be affixed, and shall pay to the city, upon invoice, the reasonable charges made and assessed for installation expense incurred, which may include costs for installation and connection of the necessary energy lines to supply electrical energy, costs for attachment of the security light, costs for placement and installation of a pole or other apparatus to which the light is to be attached, and including both labor and materials. For this purpose, the electric utility department reserves the right to refuse to install a security light for any customer if the location requested by the customer is deemed or declared by the superintendent of the department or his designee, to be a location which would create a hazard to the health or safety of persons or property. 
(b)  Security lights to be installed pursuant to this section shall be high pressure sodium, or such other type as may, from time to time be determined advisable by the electric utility department and shall be available in two rated wattages of 100 watts or 250 watts. Billing cycle charges applicable to security lights installed shall be a flat rate per billing cycle, and shall be in accordance with the following table, which shall apply effective as of the dates specified therein for all invoices and bills to customers issued or generated through, or on or after the date set forth in the table, regardless of when the security light shall have first been installed.
