Secs. 32-437-32-474. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - MUNICIPAL AND WHOLESALE CUSTOMER RATE 

Sec. 32-475. - Availability. 
    There is established a municipal and wholesale customer rate to be known as rate M, which shall be available to all metered municipal services and to the county housing authority wholesale service. 
(Code 1990, § 15-386; Ord. No. 87-1469, § 13.28.500, 6-1-1987) 
Sec. 32-476. - Character of service. 
    The character of service to be supplied under rate M shall be alternating current, 60 cycles, at nominal voltage of 120-240 or 120-208 single-phase, 120-208 or 277-480 or 120-240 three-phase if available. 
(Code 1990, § 15-387; Ord. No. 87-1469, § 13.28.510, 6-1-1987) 
Sec. 32-477. - Monthly rate. 
    For all services provided under rate M, there shall be applied a net monthly charge equal to the net monthly charge under rate C or rate GS, whichever is applicable to the service. 
(Code 1990, § 15-388; Ord. No. 87-1469, § 13.28.520, 6-1-1987) 
Sec. 32-478. - Taxes. 
    The net bill as calculated under rate M, including minimum and adjustments, shall be increased by an amount equal to that paid to the state as utility tax. 
(Code 1990, § 15-390; Ord. No. 87-1469, § 13.28.550, 6-1-1987) 
Sec. 32-479. - Payment of prior balances. 
    The city shall not be required to connect or provide any service to any customer until all previous balances for electrical service owed by the customer shall have been paid to the city. Payment may be defined as either payment in cash or the entering into a satisfactory payment plan through the city's utility collection office. 
(Code 1990, § 15-391; Ord. No. 87-1469, § 13.28.600, 6-1-1987) 
Sec. 32-480. - Temporary service fee. 
    A fee of $50.00 shall be charged for one temporary service hookup to a building site for the purpose of providing electrical service until the permanent service is installed. All electrical equipment at the site, including a meter base, shall be supplied by the owner or customer. Energy used will be billed at rate C (commercial rate). This temporary service charge shall also be available to any not-for-profit, charitable, civic or service group, association, organization or club requiring temporary service for an event of not more than four days' duration. 
(Code 1990, § 15-393; Ord. No. 93-1674, § 1, 8-2-1993) 
Secs. 32-481-32-498. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - SOLID WASTE[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Disposal of refuse, garbage and ashes, 65 ILCS 5/11-19-1 et seq.; removal of garbage and debris from property, 65 ILCS 5/11-10-13; Environmental Protection Act, 415 ILCS 5/1 et seq.; land pollution and refuse disposal, 415 ILCS 5/20 et seq.; Litter Control Act, 415 ILCS 105/1 et seq.; dropping objects from aircraft, 620 ILCS 5/43b; spilling loads on highways, 625 ILCS 5/15-109; removal of litter by probationers, 730 ILCS 115/1. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 32-499. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Bags means plastic sacks designed to store refuse with sufficient wall strength to maintain physical integrity when lifted by the top. Total weight of a bag and its contents shall not exceed 50 pounds. (See also Garbage bags and Kraft bags .) 
    Bulky waste means rubbish such as stoves, refrigerators, water heaters, washing machines, "white goods," furniture and other waste materials other than construction debris, dead animals, hazardous waste, automobile parts, or stable matter with weights or volumes greater than those allowed for containers. 
    Bundle means yard waste such as trees, shrubs and brush trimmings securely tied together forming an easily handled package not exceeding 48 inches in length or 50 pounds in weight. The diameter of any individual piece must not exceed four inches. 
    Christmas tree program means a once per year program offered to all city residents the first or second week of January in which the city will collect Christmas trees placed at the curb for collection. 
    City means the City of Rock Falls or its authorized contractor. 
    Commercial container means large containers of 1.5 yards or more utilized by commercial business for the deposit of commercially generated refuse. 
    Construction debris means waste building materials resulting from construction, remodeling, repair or demolition operations. 
    Container means a container or containers meeting the requirements of this article in which recyclable materials, refuse, rubbish, and garbage can be stored and later placed for curbside collection as approved by the city. This also includes all 1.5-yard dumpsters for residential use, toters and recycling bins. 
    Contractor means the person, corporation or partnership performing recycling, refuse and yard waste collection and disposal under contract with the city. 
    Curbside collection means the collection of all recyclables, refuse, rubbish, garbage, yard wastes and bulky items placed in accordance with the city ordinance regulating the placement of same and shall include alley collection. 
    Dead animals means animals or portions thereof equal to or greater than 20 pounds in weight that have expired from any cause, except those slaughtered or killed for human use or consumption. 
    Disposal site means a refuse depository, including, but not limited to, sanitary landfills, transfer stations, incinerators, and waste processing/separation centers, licensed, permitted or approved by all governmental bodies and agencies having jurisdiction and requiring such licenses, permits or approvals to receive refuse for processing or final disposal. 
    Garbage means all animal and vegetable matter from handling, preparation, cooking, consumption, storage, decay or decomposition of food (meats, fish, fowl, fruits, grains) and/or any other animal or vegetable matter whatsoever subject to decay which may putrefy or generate noxious or offensive odors, may be a food source for rodents, or may be a breeding or feeding place for insects or vermin, and shall include all dead animals of less than 20 pounds in weight, except yard waste, construction debris, bulky waste, rubbish, stable matter and hazardous waste. 
    Garbage and refuse collection or collection means the taking up and collecting of all garbage and refuse accumulated in containers at residential dwelling units within the corporate limits of the city and the transportation to an approved disposal site by the city. 
    Garbage bags means plastic bags designed to store refuse with sufficient wall strength to maintain physical integrity when lifted by the top. Total weight of a garbage bag when placed for pickup shall not exceed 50 pounds. 
    Garbage can means a plastic or galvanized metal can of a capacity of not less than four gallons and not to exceed 35 gallons and not to exceed 50 pounds in weight when placed for curbside collection. 
    Hazardous waste means waste, in any amount, which is defined, characterized or designated as hazardous by the United States Environmental Protection Agency or appropriate state agency by or pursuant to federal or state law, or waste, in any amount, which is regulated under federal or state law. The term "hazardous waste" shall also include motor oil and gasoline. 
    Kraft bags means special biodegradable 30-gallon Kraft paper bags available through various retailers which will shred and degrade quickly in the composting process. Kraft paper bags are to be used for soft yard waste disposal and collection. 
    Litter means any discarded, used or unconsumed substance or waste. The term "litter" may include, but is not limited to, any garbage, trash, refuse, debris, rubbish, yard or garden waste, newspaper, magazines, glass, metal, plastic or paper containers or other packaging construction material, abandoned vehicle, motor vehicle parts, furniture, oil, dead animals, any noxious or offensive matter of any kind, any object likely to injure any person or create a traffic hazard, or anything else of an unsightly or unsanitary nature which has been discarded, abandoned or otherwise disposed of improperly. 
    Prepaid bulky waste tags or stickers means a special biodegradable tag or sticker, the terms are interchangeable, stamped with the city logo, sold through retailers to the public wherein the purchase price of the tag or sticker includes collection, processing and disposal costs. Prepaid bulky waste tags are to be used for bulky wastes. 
    Producer means occupants of a residential dwelling unit who generate refuse and residential refuse. 
    Receptacle means a container which shall be of such size and form as to permit collection by one man. Garbage cans shall not exceed 32 gallons in capacity and shall be fitted with handles and lids. This definition shall include all toter containers, recycling containers, and 11/2-yard dumpsters placed in accordance with city ordinance. 
    Recyclable materials means newsprint, glass, household metals, plastics and other materials as determined by the city and the contractor. 
    Recycling means the use (collection, remanufacture, etc.) of secondary materials as feedstock for the production of new materials or products. 
    Recycling collection means the collection of all recyclable materials accumulated in recycling containers at residential dwelling units receiving refuse and garbage collection. 
    Recycling containers means a plastic container stamped with the city logo, purchased by the city and distributed by the city to residents receiving residential curbside service. 
    Refuse means all wastes which normally result from the operation of a household, including all garbage, rubbish and bulky wastes. 
    Residential dwelling unit means any single-family dwelling (of less than four units) within the corporate limits of the city occupied by a person or group of persons. A residential unit shall be deemed occupied when either water or domestic light and power services are being supplied thereto. Multifamily dwellings (of less than four units) and condominiums, whether of single-level or multilevel construction, shall be treated as a residential dwelling unit, except that each single-family dwelling within any such residential unit shall be billed separately as a residential unit. 
    Residential refuse means all garbage and rubbish generated by a producer at a residential dwelling unit. 
    Rubbish means all nonputrescible solid wastes consisting of both combustible and noncombustible wastes, including, but not limited to, paper, plastics, bottles, glass, cardboard, metal, cans, bricks, ashes, sod, dirt, rocks, cement, trees, wood, leather and any other like materials small enough for one man to handle. The term "rubbish" shall not include yard waste, construction debris, bulky waste, dead animals, garbage, stable matter and hazardous wastes. 
    Stable matter means all manure and other waste matter normally accumulated in or about a stable or any animal, livestock or poultry enclosure, and resulting from the keeping of animals, poultry or livestock. 
    Toter means a 60- or 90-gallon plastic container provided by the resident or rented from the city to the resident. 
    Trash includes garbage and rubbish. 
    Unacceptable recyclable materials means materials not properly prepared, separate and/or located in accordance with this article as generally accepted recycling practices established by this Code. 
    Yard waste means compostible, organic material consisting of dead plants, weeds, Christmas trees, tree or hedge trimmings, grass clippings and leaves but excluding tree limbs over four inches in diameter, 48 inches in length and 50 pounds in weight. Yard wastes are further defined as follows: 
(1)  Bulk yard waste. Soft yard waste and/or hard yard waste in such volume as to warrant the use of toters or dumpsters. 
(2)  Hard yard waste. Brown-stemmed branches and shrub prunings with large diameter stems/trunks not to exceed 48 inches in length and four inches in diameter individually. Evergreen Christmas trees fall under this definition, however, their collection and disposal will be defined under the Christmas tree program. 
(3)  Soft yard waste. Grass clippings, leaves, pruning of small diameter green-stemmed shrubs and plant stalks. 
(Code 1990, § 15-411; Ord. No. 90-1556, 6-18-1990; Ord. No. 90-1559, § 1, 7-2-1990; Ord. No. 2012-2489, § 1, 1-17-2012; Ord. No. 2013-2124, §§ 1, 2, 10-1-2013; Ord. No. 2015-2222, § 1, 8-18-2015) 
Sec. 32-500. - Containers required; specifications. 
(a)  Containers required. Each owner, tenant, lessee or occupant of a residential dwelling unit or place of business is required provide or cause to be provided at all times an approved trash container of sufficient number and capacity to accommodate and contain all trash generated and accumulated by occupants of the structure. 
(b)  Type of approved containers: 
(1)  Containers to be used for the pickup of garbage and rubbish shall be: 
a.  For residences of less than four dwelling units: Garbage bags or plastic or galvanized metal garbage cans for each dwelling, each can or bag not exceeding 35-gallon capacity and each not exceeding 50 pounds total weight when filled; 
b.  For multifamily residential dwelling units with four or more units: 11/2-yard or larger dumpsters approved by the city; 
c.  For authorized group homes: One or more toters or 11/2-yard or larger dumpsters approved by the city; or 
d.  Commercial container or dumpster as permitted by section 32-516. 
(2)  Containers to be used for the pickup of soft yard waste materials shall be biodegradable, Kraft paper bags (as defined herein), or in a container of not greater than 90 gallon capacity with an "X" clearly marked on the exterior of the container. 
(3)  Recycling containers shall be 18-gallon containers, made available through or obtained from the city exclusively, to be used for the pickup of recyclable materials. 
(c)  Disposal in containers required. For single-family dwelling and multifamily dwelling units, it is unlawful to dispose of any garbage and rubbish or yard waste material anywhere except through placement of such material in the types of approved containers herein described and placed for collection as herein prescribed. No commercial container, as that term is defined within this article, shall be placed, used, nor permitted to be located as a receptacle for waste collection for any residential location except at multifamily residential dwelling units with four or more units or except as permitted pursuant to section 32-516. The owner and/or occupant of each residential unit containing three or fewer dwelling units shall be responsible for compliance with this provision prohibiting the placement of commercial containers, and a violation of any of the provisions of this subsection shall be punishable as a Class C offense in accordance with the provisions of section 1-41. 
(Code 1990, § 15-412; Ord. No. 90-1556, 6-18-1990; Ord. No. 2003-2057, § 1, 7-1-2003; Ord. No. 2012-2489, § 2, 1-17-2012; Ord. No. 2013-2130, § 1, 10-1-2013; Ord. No. 2015-2217, § 1, 7-7-2015) 
Sec. 32-501. - Collection. 
(a)  In single-family residential dwelling units and multifamily residential dwelling units of less than four units, it shall be the responsibility of the owner and occupants to place trash containers for curbside collection. 
(b)  Collection services of materials under this article for any building used as a residence having four or more dwelling units, or for business, commercial, manufacturing or industrial uses or schools or churches shall be only pursuant to contract with a person, firm or corporation holding a hauler's license issued pursuant to division 2 of this article. A collection area shall be provided on the premises of any of the described buildings and shall be accessible to the collection crew of the licensed hauler. All such buildings shall be provided by the owner with a trash container consisting of a dumpster-style container with a minimum of 11/2 yards' capacity. Regulations shall be adopted from time to time by the mayor and city administrator regulating the placement and location of the collection area on the premises, the screening of such collection area from adjacent parcels of real estate, the discharge of odors or aromas and liquid from the collection receptacles, and such other subjects as may be required to protect the public health, safety and welfare. 
(Code 1990, § 15-413; Ord. No. 90-1556, 6-18-1990; Ord. No. 90-1559, § 3, 7-2-1990) 
Sec. 32-502. - Storage area regulations. 
(a)  No trash storage facilities shall be placed within the front yard setback area, within 15 feet of side yard lot lines of a corner lot, or within the limits of any street or alley. Trash containers may be placed in these areas only on days appointed for trash pickup. 
(b)  For the purpose of this section, a "day" is defined as that period of time from sundown on the day preceding the collection of garbage, rubbish and recyclables to sundown of the day of trash collection. 
(Code 1990, § 15-414; Ord. No. 90-1556, 6-18-1990) 
Sec. 32-503. - Trash containers to be kept on premises. 
(a)  No trash containers shall be placed within the limits of any street or alley but shall be kept by the adjacent property owner upon his own property. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of all persons occupying or controlling any residential dwelling unit to place trash containers either at the alley lot line or at the curbline of the premises on the day of collection. 
(c)  All trash containers shall be stored and maintained in a neat manner complementary to the area and the neighborhood. 
(Code 1990, § 15-415; Ord. No. 90-1556, 6-18-1990) 
Sec. 32-504. - Interference with containers. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person, other than the owner, occupant or members of their families, the owner's agent or the city, to deposit, remove, deface, destroy or disturb trash containers, recycling containers or bulky wastes. 
(b)  From time of placement of recyclables at the curb or in recycling drop boxes for collection in accordance with the terms hereof, items shall be and become the property of the city or its authorized agent. No person not authorized by the city shall collect or pick up or cause to be collected or picked up any such items. A violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class C violation as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1990, § 15-416; Ord. No. 90-1556, 6-18-1990; Ord. No. 2011-2458, § 59, 4-5-2011) 
Sec. 32-505. - Placement and storage. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to sweep or deposit any refuse or litter in any public place or public way except in public trash containers provided for such purposes. Persons owning or occupying property shall keep the sidewalk and any right-of-way bordering their property free of litter. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit any residential refuse in any public place or public trash container. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to place or maintain paper, litter, excelsior, garbage, trash or rubbish of any kind whatever in open deposits on the ground or in open containers which do not meet the requirements of this article. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful to use any nonapproved container in violation of the provisions of this article. Such containers may be confiscated and disposed of by the city. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any person to place or maintain garbage, rubbish, recyclables or trash for curbside collection in violation of this article. 
(f)  It shall be unlawful for any person to place or deposit residential refuse in any commercial container. 
(g)  A violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class C violation as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1990, § 15-417; Ord. No. 90-1556, 6-18-1990; Ord. No. 2010-2421, § 57, 10-5-2010) 
Sec. 32-506. - Condition of deposits. 
(a)  General preparation. Any refuse placed in containers for collection shall be drained of all free liquids and shall be less than 50 pounds. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for any container to be filled with material which may cause injury to persons handling the containers, including, but not limited to, explosives, poisons, acids or caustic materials. 
(2)  Fats, oils and grease shall be placed in sealed containers to prevent leakage. 
(b)  Preparing recyclables. Preparing recyclables for collection shall follow the below-listed guidelines: 
(1)  Newspaper. 
a.  Only newspapers and newspaper inserts. 
b.  No magazines, junk mail, catalogs or phone books. 
c.  Newspaper should be stacked loosely on the bottom or side of the recycling container to reduce litter problems. 
d.  Newspaper should not be bundled. 
e.  Newspaper should not be placed in plastic or brown paper bags. 
(2)  Glass containers. 
a.  Only unbroken bottles and jars are acceptable. 
b.  Clear, brown and green glass are all acceptable. 
c.  Everything should be rinsed and free of visible food debris. 
d.  Labels and rings may be left on. 
e.  No Pyrex, window glass, mirrors, dishes or ceramics. 
f.  Place on top of the newspaper; may be mixed with cans, glass bottles and jars. 
(3)  Cans. 
a.  Only aluminum and tin cans are acceptable. 
b.  No other metal containers or aluminum products are acceptable. 
c.  Crushing cans is recommended. 
d.  Cans should be rinsed and free of visible food debris. 
e.  Place on top of newspaper; may be mixed with glass and plastic. 
(4)  Plastic milk and water jugs and soda containers. 
a.  Only plastic containers with the #1 through #7 recycling symbols are acceptable. 
b.  Plastic (HDPE) milk and water jugs. 
c.  Soda (PET) bottles. 
d.  Milk jugs shall be rinsed and free of food debris. 
e.  Crushing is recommended. 
f.  Materials shall be placed on top of newspaper and may be mixed with cans, glass bottles and jars. 
(5)  Loading the recycling container. Recyclables should be arranged in the recycling container before placing the container at the curb as follows: 
a.  All newspapers should be placed loosely at the bottom or side of the container. 
b.  Glass and plastic should be placed on top of the newspaper. 
c.  Any material other than newspapers, glass containers, plastics and cans shall be left at the curb with a report card from the hauler indicating the reason(s) the recyclables were rejected. 
(c)  Preparing yard waste. Yard wastes will be collected April 1 through November 30 of each year. Yard waste is to be prepared as follows: 
(1)  Soft yard waste. 
a.  Must be contained in special Kraft paper bag (as defined herein); or 
b.  Must be contained loosely in a container of not greater than 90-gallon capacity with an "X" clearly marked on the exterior of the container. 
(2)  Hard yard waste. Hard yard waste will be collected at the curb only if it is tied into bundles not exceeding 48 inches in length or 50 pounds in weight. The diameter of any individual piece must not exceed four inches. Discarded Christmas trees will be collected and disposed of during the Christmas tree program during the two-week period following January 1 of each year. 
(d)  Preparing garbage. Residents shall dispose of their household garbage as follows: 
(1)  Place loose garbage in an approved container; or 
(2)  Place a special prepaid bulky waste sticker or tag on bulky waste items. 
Bags may be placed inside a 90-gallon toter or used as a liner in 32-gallon garbage container as defined by city ordinance. The city's contractor will pick up garbage and rubbish if contained in accordance with this section only. 
(Code 1990, § 15-418; Ord. No. 90-1556, 6-18-1990; Ord. No. 2001-1977, § 1, 7-3-2001; Ord. No. 2013-2124, §§ 3, 4, 10-1-2013) 
Sec. 32-507. - Pollution of water, streets. 
(a)  No person shall throw, place, or deposit or cause to be deposited any garbage, refuse, litter, manure, carrion, dead animals, offal, putrid or unwholesome substance upon the margin, banks or into any stream or water, or upon any street, alley, ditch or public grounds, or upon any property of another within the limits of the city. 
(b)  No person shall allow or permit any litter, other offensive substance, or noxious matter of any kind to run or fall from or out of any building or vehicle into or upon any street or public place, nor allow or permit such litter or other noxious matter to stand or remain on any ground or premises within the limits of the city. 
(Code 1990, § 15-419; Ord. No. 90-1556, 6-18-1990) 
Sec. 32-508. - Pick up. 
(a)  The city will pick up only from residential premises. No materials will be picked up from commercial or industrial establishments. 
(b)  The materials to be collected include: 
(1)  Garbage and rubbish when placed in a special prepaid city garbage bag. Special prepaid garbage bags may be placed in a toter. 
(2)  Bulky waste when displaying a special prepaid bulky waste tag. 
(3)  Soft yard waste material when placed in a special Kraft yard waste bag or placed loose in a toter. 
(4)  Hard yard waste when bundled and displaying a special prepaid yard waste tag. 
(5)  Christmas trees under the Christmas tree program. 
(6)  Recyclable materials, including glass, plastic (HDPE and PET), newspaper and cans, when packaged in accordance with this article. 
(c)  The materials that will not be collected by the city include earth, sod, concrete, refuse from remodeling or construction, automobile parts, hazardous wastes and large trees. 
(Code 1990, § 15-420; Ord. No. 90-1556, 6-18-1990) 
Sec. 32-509. - Vehicles to be covered. 
    Any person operating a vehicle hauling garbage, rubbish, recyclables, or yard waste shall keep the same securely covered with a tarpaulin or other cover at all times while in the city limits while the vehicle is in motion and at all other times except when such substances are in the actual process of being loaded into or onto the vehicle. 
(Code 1990, § 15-421; Ord. No. 90-1556, 6-18-1990) 
Sec. 32-510. - Burning. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to burn any garbage, rubbish, refuse or waste within the city limits, or for any owner or occupant of real property within the city limits to permit the burning of any garbage, rubbish, refuse or waste on such property. For purposes of this section, there shall be a rebuttable presumption that the property owner or lawful occupant of a parcel upon which burning in violation of this section is or has occurred has permitted such unlawful burning. However, nothing shall prohibit the operation of any incinerator in accordance with the rules and regulations of the state pollution control board, as the same may be in effect from time to time, and operation of an incinerator as such shall not be a violation. 
(b)  A violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class C violation as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1990, § 15-422; Ord. No. 90-1556, 6-18-1990; Ord. No. 93-1685, § 1, 10-19-1993; Ord. No. 97-1824, § 1, 11-4-1997; Ord. No. 2010-2421, § 58, 10-5-2010; Ord. No. 2013-2110, § 1, 6-18-2013; Ord. No. 2014-2183, § 1, 11-4-2014; Ord. No. 2017-2318, § 1, 7-5-2017) 
Sec. 32-511. - Incinerators. 
(a)  Any commercial establishment desiring to burn any trash shall burn the same in an incinerator which conforms to the requirements and standards established, approved and in effect from time to time, by the state pollution control board. 
(b)  After June 30, 1998, no person shall allow, permit, nor suffer to be or remain upon any public or private property within the city limits, any container, including any barrel, drum, wire basket or other devise or container, used for the purpose of burning waste, rubbish, trash or refuse. Any such containers found to exist upon any public or private property after June 30, 1998, shall be removed by the owner of the parcel where the item exists, and upon failure to so remove, the owner of said parcel of land shall be subject to citation for violation of this article. 
(c)  A violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class C violation as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1990, § 15-423; Ord. No. 90-1556, 6-18-1990; Ord. No. 97-1824, § 2, 11-4-1997; Ord. No. 2010-2421, § 59, 10-5-2010) 
Sec. 32-512. - Billing, revenues, accounts. 
(a)  Bills. Refuse collection service charges shall be payable monthly. The owner of the premises, the occupant thereof and the user of the service shall be jointly and severally liable to pay for the service to such premises and the service is furnished to the premises by the city only upon the condition that the owner of the premises, occupant and user of the service are jointly and severally liable therefor to the city. All refuse collection bills are due and payable within 20 calendar days after being rendered. A penalty of five percent shall be added to all bills not paid by the twentieth calendar day after they have been rendered. 
(b)  Delinquent bills. If the charges for such services are not paid within 90 days after the rendition of the bill for service, the city clerk and city attorney shall begin lien proceedings in accordance with subsection (c) of this section. In addition thereto, the city clerk and the city administrator may submit delinquent accounts over 90 days old to a collection agency for further services and efforts in an attempt to collect said delinquent accounts. The city clerk and city administrator are hereby authorized to enter into a contract with a credit collection agency upon the terms and conditions agreed upon by the city clerk, city administrator and credit collection agency. In the event that such delinquent accounts cannot be collected by the credit collection agency and the amounts of the delinquent accounts are less than $100.00, the city clerk, city administrator and a member of the city council appointed by the mayor may determine to take no further efforts to collect said delinquent account and may "write-off" said delinquent accounts. 
(c)  Lien, notice of delinquency. Whenever a bill for refuse collection service remains unpaid for 90 days for monthly service after it has been rendered, the city clerk may file with the county recorder of deed a state of lien claim. This statement shall contain the legal description of the premises served, the amount of the unpaid bill, and a notice that the city claims a lien for this amount as well as for all charges subsequent to the period covered by the bill, including accrued penalties, monthly service charges, and recording fees. 
(d)  Registration for service. Effective with the passage of this article, new residents to the city or residents relocating within the city are hereby required to register for sewer-solid waste disposal service with the finance department on forms prescribed by the finance director. 
(Code 1990, § 15-424; Ord. No. 90-1556, 6-18-1990) 
Sec. 32-513. - Exclusive rights of city collection. 
    Any garbage, refuse, trash, recyclables, yard wastes or other residential solid wastes generated by any residential dwelling unit, including multifamily dwellings with less than four individual dwelling units, shall be collected solely and exclusively by the city or its officially designated solid waste disposal contractor; provided, however, that the exclusive right and obligation for collection provided in this section shall not apply to construction debris or to rubbish, to the extent that the construction debris or rubbish is to be disposed of pursuant to the provisions of section 32-516. The owner of any multifamily residential dwelling containing four or more individual dwelling units shall be responsible for supplying solid waste, garbage, refuse, trash and yard waste disposal services for that multifamily dwelling and the units therein. Except as otherwise provided in this section, no other person, firm or corporation shall collect, contract to collect or provide collection, disposal, treatment or recycling services for any garbage, refuse, ashes or yard waste material generated from any residence within the city except for multifamily residential buildings with four or more individual dwelling units. 
(Code 1990, § 15-425; Ord. No. 90-1556, 6-18-1990; Ord. No. 2003-2063, § 2, 9-19-2003; Ord. No. 2003-2064, § 2, 10-7-2003; Ord. No. 2008-2284, § 1, 7-1-2008) 
Sec. 32-514. - Fines. 
(a)  No refuse shall be disposed of at any site other than a disposal site designated by the city. 
(b)  A violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class B violation as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1990, § 15-426; Ord. No. 90-1556, 6-18-1990; Ord. No. 2011-2458, § 60, 4-5-2011) 
Sec. 32-515. - Fees charged. 
(a)  There is hereby assessed to each single-family residential unit a fee for garbage and waste collection services, payable to the city, in the amount of $15.00 per month, effective as of February 1, 2012, and for each succeeding month thereafter. 
(b)  The city shall from time to time arrange for the placement at various retail outlets and establishments within the city, for distribution and additional purchase, bulky waste tags and stickers, which are required for use for disposal of materials pursuant to this article. 
(Code 1990, § 15-427; Ord. No. 90-1559, § 4, 7-2-1990; Ord. No. 93-1690, § 1, 11-1-1993; Ord. No. 94-1717, § 1, 7-25-1994; Ord. No. 2000-1918, § 1, 1-4-2000; Ord. No. 2000-1921, § 1, 2-3-2000; Ord. No. 2001-1981, § 1, 8-8-2001; Ord. No. 2003-2048, § 1, 6-3-2003; Ord. No. 2003-2071, § 1, 12-2-2003; Ord. No. 2004-2102, § 1, 10-5-2004; Ord. No. 2005-2146, § 1, 9-20-2005; Ord. No. 2012-2489, § 3, 1-17-2012; Ord. No. 2013-2130, § 3, 10-1-2013) 
Sec. 32-516. - Residential commercial containers. 
(a)  When permitted. The owner or occupant of a residential dwelling shall be allowed to utilize a commercial container at that dwelling as a container for waste in accordance with the requirements of this section. 
(b)  Construction debris. When a building permit has been issued for construction, demolition or remodeling at a dwelling, the owner or contractor in charge of the project may place a commercial container for the disposal of construction debris. In such case, the commercial container shall be allowed for a period equal to the duration of the construction project as outlined in the building permit for the site. 
(c)  Rubbish. In accordance with provisions of this section, the owner or occupant of a residential dwelling may place upon that location a commercial container for the disposal of rubbish. Placement of such commercial container shall be for a period of no longer than 30 days. Any commercial container provided for disposal of rubbish pursuant to this subsection (c) shall be obtained from the contractor who has been granted by the city exclusive rights and obligations for collection and disposal of residential solid waste within the city. 
(d)  Use requirements. Commercial containers placed pursuant to this section shall be utilized only for the disposal of construction debris or rubbish, and no other materials shall be placed nor disposed of therein. Any other waste products generated at the location on which the commercial container has been placed for construction debris or rubbish shall be disposed of in otherwise approved containers and in compliance with the requirements of this article. Commercial containers placed pursuant to this section shall be "tipped" or dumped at least two times per month, and shall be placed on the premises as otherwise required by this chapter. 
(e)  Penalty. A violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class C violation as provided in section l-41. 
(Code 1990, § 15-428; Ord. No. 2003-2064, § 1, 10-7-2003; Ord. No. 2005-2131, § 1, 4-19-2005; Ord. No. 2010-2421, § 60, 10-5-2010; Ord. No. 2015-2237, § 1, 11-3-2015) 
Secs. 32-517-32-540. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - HAULER'S LICENSE 

Sec. 32-541. - Required. 
    No person shall remove or haul any garbage, refuse or recyclable materials from any lot or tract of real estate or from street or alley for hire without first procuring a license therefor as provided in this division. 
(Code 1990, § 15-437; Ord. No. 90-1556, 6-18-1990) 
Sec. 32-542. - Application. 
    Application for a license under this division shall be made on forms provided by the city clerk's office. 
(Code 1990, § 15-438; Ord. No. 90-1556, 6-18-1990) 
Sec. 32-543. - Bond. 
    Application for a license shall be accompanied by a surety bond in the sum of $5,000.00, conditioned upon the observance of this Code. 
(Code 1990, § 15-439; Ord. No. 90-1556, 6-18-1990) 
Sec. 32-544. - Certificates of workers' compensation insurance and public liability insurance required. 
    Prior to issuance of a license under this division, the applicant shall present a certificate of workers' compensation insurance and a certificate of public liability insurance in the amount of $1,000,000.00. 
(Code 1990, § 15-440; Ord. No. 90-1556, 6-18-1990) 
Sec. 32-545. - Fee. 
    Application for a license under this division shall be accompanied by a license fee of $100.00, which amount is established as the annual license fee. 
(Code 1990, § 15-441; Ord. No. 90-1556, 6-18-1990; Ord. No. 2016-2248, § 3, 1-5-2016) 
Sec. 32-546. - Term. 
    All licenses issued under this division shall be valid until April 30 next succeeding the date of issuance of such license. 
(Code 1990, § 15-442; Ord. No. 90-1556, 6-18-1990) 
Chapter 33 - RESERVED 
Chapter 34 - ZONING[1] 
Footnotes:

State Law reference- Zoning, 65 ILCS 5/11-13-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - DEFINITIONS 

Sec. 34-1. - Scope of definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter, certain terms or words are used in a limited or special sense, as herein defined. Words used in the present tense include the future, words in the singular number include the plural, and words in the plural number include the singular; the word "shall" is mandatory and not directory. 
(Code 1990, § 16-1; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 2(1.0), 4-19-1993) 
Sec. 34-2. - Accessory use or structure. 
    Accessory use or structure means a use or structure subordinate to the principal use or building on the same lot and serving a purpose customarily incidental thereto. 
(Code 1990, § 16-2; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 2(1.1), 4-19-1993) 
Sec. 34-3. - Alley. 
    Alley means a public way less than 20 feet in width affording secondary means of access to abutting property. 
(Code 1990, § 16-3; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 2(1.2), 4-19-1993) 
Sec. 34-4. - Automobile repair. 
    Automobile repair means general repair, rebuilding or reconditioning of engines, motor vehicles or trailers; collision service, including body, frame or fender straightening or repair; over-all painting or paint shop; vehicle steam cleaning. 
(Code 1990, § 16-4; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 2(1.3), 4-19-1993) 
Sec. 34-5. - Basement. 
    Basement means a story having part but not more than 50 percent of its height below the average grade of the adjoining ground (as distinguished from a cellar). A basement shall be counted as a story for the purpose of height measurement. 
(Code 1990, § 16-5; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 2(1.4), 4-19-1993) 
Sec. 34-6. - Building. 
    Building means any structure for the shelter or enclosure of persons, animals or personal property. 
(Code 1990, § 16-6; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 2(1.5), 4-19-1993) 
Sec. 34-7. - Cellar. 
    Cellar means a story having 50 percent or more of its height below the average grade of the adjoining ground. A cellar shall be counted as a story, for purposes of height measurement, only if used for dwelling purposes other than by a janitor or caretaker employed on the premises. 
(Code 1990, § 16-7; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 2(1.6), 4-19-1993) 
Sec. 34-8. - Communication antenna. 
    Communications antenna means a free standing structure, 50 feet or less in height, or an apparatus located on an existing structure, designed to transmit or receive telephone, personal wireless service, radio or television communications, as authorized by the Federal Communications Commission. 
(Code 1990, § 16-7.4; Ord. No. 97-1827, § 1, 12-2-1997) 
Sec. 34-9. - Communication tower. 
    Communication tower means a structure greater than 50 feet in height and which does not exceed 150 feet in height (including antenna) which supports communication (transmission or receiving) equipment or a communication antenna. 
(Code 1990, § 16-7.7; Ord. No. 97-1827, § 2, 12-2-1997) 
Sec. 34-10. - Dwelling. 
    Dwelling means a building or portion thereof occupied or intended to be occupied exclusively for residence purposes, but not to include a tent, cabin, trailer or trailer coach, or a room in a hotel or motel. 
(Code 1990, § 16-8; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 2(1.7), 4-19-1993) 
Sec. 34-11. - Essential services. 
    Essential services means the erection, construction, alteration or maintenance, by public utilities or municipal or other governmental agencies, of underground or overhead gas, electrical, steam or water transmission or distribution systems, collection, communication, supply or disposal systems, including poles, wires, mains, drains, sewers, pipes, conduits, cables, fire alarm boxes, police call boxes, traffic signals, hydrants, and other similar equipment and accessories in connection therewith; reasonably necessary for the furnishing of adequate service by such public utilities or municipal or other governmental agencies or for the public health or safety or general welfare, but not including buildings. 
(Code 1990, § 16-9; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 2(1.8), 4-19-1993) 
Sec. 34-12. - Family. 
    Family means one or more persons related by blood, marriage or adoption, or a group of not more than five persons (excluding servants) who need not be related by blood, marriage or adoption, living together and maintaining a common household. 
(Code 1990, § 16-10; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 2(1.9), 4-19-1993) 
Sec. 34-14. - Height. 
    Height means in the case of a wall, or part of a building, the vertical distance from the average established curb grade in front of the lot or from the average finished grade at the building line, if higher, to the average height of the top of the cornice of a flat roof, or roofline, or to the deck line of a mansard roof, or to the middle height of the highest gable or dormer in a pitched or hipped roof, or if there are no gables or dormers, to the middle height of such pitched or hipped roof. 
(Code 1990, § 16-12; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 2(1.11), 4-19-1993) 
Sec. 34-15. - Highway or primary thoroughfare. 
    Highway or primary thoroughfare means an officially designated federal or state numbered highway or other road designated as a highway or major arterial on the major street plan as official adopted and amended from time to time by the planning commission. 
(Code 1990, § 16-13; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 2(1.12), 4-19-1993) 
Sec. 34-16. - Land use plan. 
    Land use plan means the comprehensive long-range plan for the desirable use of land in the community as officially adopted and as amended from time to time by the planning commission; the purpose of such plan being, among other things, to serve as a guide to the zoning and progressive changes in the zoning of land to meet changing community needs, in the subdividing and use of undeveloped land, and in the acquisition of land for such public purposes as streets, parks, schools and other public buildings or public uses. 
(Code 1990, § 16-14; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 2(1.13), 4-19-1993) 
Sec. 34-17. - Lot. 
    Lot means a parcel of land, abutting on a street, whose area, in addition to the parts thereof occupied or hereafter to be occupied by a building and its accessory buildings, is sufficient to provide the yards and courts required by this chapter. 
(Code 1990, § 16-15; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 2(1.14), 4-19-1993) 
Sec. 34-18. - Lot area. 
    Lot area means the horizontal area within the lot lines of the lot. 
(Code 1990, § 16-16; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 2(1.15), 4-19-1993) 
Sec. 34-19. - Lot depth. 
    Lot depth means the mean horizontal distance between the front and rear lot lines. 
(Code 1990, § 16-17; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 2(1.16), 4-19-1993) 
Sec. 34-20. - Lot width. 
    Lot width means the mean horizontal distance across the lot between the side lot lines at the building line measured at right angles to the depth. 
(Code 1990, § 16-18; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 2(1.17), 4-19-1993) 
Sec. 34-21. - Lot, corner. 
    Corner lot means a lot of which at least two adjacent sides abut for their full lengths upon a dedicated public street. 
(Code 1990, § 16-19; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 2(1.14.1), 4-19-1993) 
Sec. 34-22. - Motor fuel station. 
    Motor fuel station means a place where gasoline, diesel oil, kerosene, or any other motor fuel or lubricating oil or grease for operating motor vehicles is offered for sale to the public and deliveries are made directly into motor vehicles, including greasing and oiling and the sale of automobile accessories on the premises. 
(Code 1990, § 16-20; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 2(1.18), 4-19-1993) 
Sec. 34-23. - Nonconforming use. 
    Nonconforming use means a building, structure or premises: 
(1)  Lawfully occupied at the time of the enactment of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived by a use that does not conform with the provisions of this chapter for the district in which it is located; 
(2)  Lawfully occupied at the time of annexation of the tract upon which the building, structure or premises is located and occupied by a use that does not conform with the provisions of this chapter for the district applied upon annexation; or 
(3)  In a lawfully occupied use which fails to continue to be lawful and such failure results from changes in zoning districts or in textual provisions made to this chapter. 
(Code 1990, § 16-21; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 2(1.19), 4-19-1993; Ord. No. 2005-2144, § 1, 9-20-2005) 
Sec. 34-24. - Parking area, accessory. 
    Accessory parking area means an area of one or more parking spaces located on the same property as the building, structure, or premises it is intended to serve, or on adjoining or nearby property other than the public right-of-way, and of such shape and nature as to be appropriate and usable for the parking or storage, loading and unloading of self-propelled vehicles. 
(Code 1990, § 16-22; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 2(1.20), 4-19-1993) 
Sec. 34-25. - Story. 
    Story means that portion of a building included between the upper surface of any floor and upper surface of the floor next above, or the ceiling or roof next above such floor; provided that for the purpose of determining the required dimensions of yards and courts, when the average story height of a building exceeds 12 feet, each 12 feet or fraction thereof of the total building height shall be considered a separate full story or fractional story respectively, except the first story which may be 15 feet high. 
(Code 1990, § 16-23; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 2(1.21), 4-19-1993) 
Sec. 34-26. - Story, half. 
    Half story means a partial story under a gable, hip or gambrel roof, the wall plates of which on at least two opposite exterior walls are not more than four feet above the floor of such story. 
(Code 1990, § 16-24; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 2(1.21.0.1), 4-19-1993) 
Sec. 34-27. - Street. 
    Street means any public way set aside as a permanent right-of-way for vehicular or pedestrian access 21 feet or more in width if it existed at the time of the enactment of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived; and any such public way created after enactment of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived, provided it is 50 feet or more in width. 
(Code 1990, § 16-25; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 2(1.22), 4-19-1993) 
Sec. 34-28. - Structural alteration. 
    Structural alteration means any change in the supporting members of a building including but not limited to bearing walls, load-bearing partitions, columns, beams, or girders, or any substantial change in the roof or in the exterior walls. 
(Code 1990, § 16-26; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 2(1.23), 4-19-1993) 
Sec. 34-29. - Structure. 
    Structure means anything constructed, the use of which required permanent location on the ground or attached to something having permanent location on the ground. 
(Code 1990, § 16-27; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 2(1.24), 4-19-1993) 
Sec. 34-30. - Yard, front. 
    Front yard means any open space extending the full width of the lot between a building and the front lot line, unoccupied and unobstructed from the ground upward, except as hereinafter specified. 
(Code 1990, § 16-28; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 2(1.25), 4-19-1993) 
Sec. 34-31. - Yard, front, least depth. 
    Front yard, least depth, means the shortest distance, measured horizontally, between any part of a building, other than such parts as hereinafter excepted, and the nearest side lot line. 
(Code 1990, § 16-29; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 2(1.25.1), 4-19-1993) 
Sec. 34-32. - Yard, rear. 
    Rear yard means an open space extending the full width of a lot between a building and the rear lot line, unoccupied and unobstructed from the ground upward, except as hereinafter specified. 
(Code 1990, § 16-30; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 2(1.26), 4-19-1993) 
Sec. 34-33. - Yard, rear, least depth. 
    Rear yard, least depth, means the shortest distance, measured horizontally, between any part of a building, other than such parts as hereinafter excepted, and the rear lot line. In the case of an irregular, triangular or gourd-shaped lot, a line ten feet in length entirely within the lot, parallel to and a maximum distance from the front lot line shall be considered the rear lot line. 
(Code 1990, § 16-31; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 2(1.26.1), 4-19-1993) 
Sec. 34-34. - Yard, side. 
    Side yard means an open space extending from the front yard to the rear yard between a building and the side lot line, unoccupied and unobstructed from the ground upward, except as hereinafter specified. 
(Code 1990, § 16-32; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 2(1.27), 4-19-1993) 
Sec. 34-35. - Yard, side, least width. 
    Side yard, least width, means the shortest distance, measured horizontally, between any part of a building, other than such parts as hereinafter excepted and the nearest side lot line. 
(Code 1990, § 16-33; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 2(1.27.1), 4-19-1993) 
Secs. 34-36-34-58. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - DISTRICTS AND MAP 

Sec. 34-59. - Districts designated. 
(a)  For purpose of this chapter, the following districts are designated: 
(1)  A-1 Agricultural District; 
(2)  R-1 One-Family Residence Districts; 
(3)  R-2 Two-Family Residence Districts; 
(4)  R-3 One- and Two-Family Residence Districts; 
(5)  R-4 Multifamily Residence Districts; 
(6)  B-1 General Business Districts; 
(7)  B-2 Community Business Districts; 
(8)  M-1 Light Industrial Districts; 
(9)  M-2 General Industrial Districts; 
(10)  MU-1 Mixed Use District. 
(b)  An A-1 Agricultural District classification shall be available only to land upon its initial annexation into the city and an A-1 district classification shall not be applied to or granted to any parcel, lot or land which has previously been within the city limits and classified under this article as any other district or zone classification, and an A-1 Agricultural District classification shall not be available to nor granted on any application for change of zoning classification from such other district classification. 
(Code 1990, § 16-50; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 2(2.0), 4-19-1993; Ord. No. 2006-2173, § 1, 3-7-2006; Ord. No. 2014-2148, § 1, 3-4-2014) 
Sec. 34-60. - Zoning map. 
    The boundaries of these districts are hereby established as shown on a map entitled "zoning map," which accompanies and is hereby made a part of this article. The district boundary lines on said map are intended to follow lot lines, the centerlines of streets or alleys, the centerlines of streets or alleys projected, railroad rights-of-way, or the corporate limit lines, all as they existed at the time of enactment of this article; but where a district boundary line does not clearly coincide with lot lines, it shall be determined by scaling. 
(Code 1990, § 16-51; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 2(2.1), 4-19-1993; Ord. No. 2008-2274, § 1, 5-20-2008; Ord. No. 2015-2199, § 1, 3-3-2015) 
Sec. 34-61. - District boundaries-Division between lots. 
    Where a district boundary line divides a lot which was in single ownership and of record at the time of enactment of the ordinance from which this article is derived, the use authorized on and the other district requirements applying to the less restricted portion of such lot shall be considered as extending to the entire lot, provided that where the more restricted portion of such lot is more than 50 feet beyond such dividing district boundary line, such less restricted use shall be limited to the portion of the lot lying within 50 feet of such boundary line. 
(Code 1990, § 16-52; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 2(2.2), 4-19-1993) 
Sec. 34-62. - Same-Zoning board of appeals to determine. 
    Questions concerning the exact location of district boundary lines shall be determined by the zoning board of appeals according to rules and regulations which it may adopt, as hereinafter provided under section 34-541. 
(Code 1990, § 16-53; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 2(2.3), 4-19-1993) 
Sec. 34-63. - Classification of annexed territory. 
    All territory which may hereafter be annexed to the city shall be classified as R-2 Two-Family Residence District until such classification shall have been changed by amendment or unless changed by specific action of the city council at the time of approval of the annexation. Any change to a classification different from R-2 shall only occur following the procedure for amendment or district zoning classification change as required and set out in article XIX of this chapter. 
(Code 1990, § 16-54; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 2(2.4), 4-19-1993; Ord. No. 2012-2086, § 1, 12-5-2012) 
Secs. 34-64-34-84. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - GENERAL PROVISIONS 

Sec. 34-85. - Zoning affects every structure and use. 
    Except as hereinafter provided, no building, structure or land shall hereafter be used and building or part thereof or structure shall be erected, constructed, reconstructed, occupied, moved, altered or repaired, except in conformity with the regulations herein specified for the class of district in which it is located. 
(Code 1990, § 16-70; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 2(3.0), 4-19-1993) 
Sec. 34-86. - Continuing existing uses. 
    Any building, structure or use lawfully existing at the time of enactment of the ordinance from which this article is derived may be continued, except certain nonconforming uses as provided in section 34-87. Nothing in this article shall prevent the strengthening or restoring to a safe condition any part of a building or structure declared unsafe by the building inspector. 
(Code 1990, § 16-71; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 2(3.1), 4-19-1993) 
Sec. 34-87. - Nonconforming uses; discontinuance. 
    Except as hereinafter provided under subsection (3) of this section: 
(1)  Any nonconforming use building or structure which has been or may be damaged by fire, flood, explosion, earthquake, war, riot or other act of God may be reconstructed and used as before if such reconstruction and use is completed within 12 months of such damage, unless damaged more than 50 percent of its fair market value, as determined by the board of appeals at the time of such damage, in which case any reconstruction or use after reconstruction shall be in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(2)  No building, structure or premises where a nonconforming use has been discontinued or abandoned for more than one year, or has been changed and utilized for a use permitted within the district in which the nonconforming use is located, shall again be devoted to a nonconforming use. 
(3)  The foregoing provisions under subsections (1) and (2) of this section, insofar as these limit reconstruction or require certain uses to cease, or require buildings or structures to be removed or changed, shall not be applicable where any such building, structure or use would be conforming under the land use plan adopted and as defined in section 34-16. 
(Code 1990, § 16-72; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 2(3.2), 4-19-1993; Ord. No. 2005-2144, § 2, 9-20-2005) 
Sec. 34-88. - Street frontage; minimum requirement. 
    No lot created after the adoption of the ordinance from which this article is derived shall contain any building used as a dwelling unless it abuts as least 30 feet on a street or has a permanent exclusive nonobstructed easement of access not less than 30 feet wide to a street. 
(Code 1990, § 16-73; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 2(3.3), 4-19-1993) 
Sec. 34-89. - Lot area requirements. 
(a)  Existing lots of record. 
(1)  In any district where dwellings are permitted, a one-family detached dwelling may be constructed on any lot of official record at the time of enactment of the ordinance from which this article is derived, provided that proposed yard spaces satisfy requirements stipulated for the district in which such lot is located, or requirements as may be modified by the board of appeals as set forth hereinafter under section 34-541. 
(2)  In any R-2 or R-3 district, and on any lot of official record of less than 60-foot width improved with an existing dwelling as of July 1, 2012, accessory buildings may be constructed with less than the required minimum side yard setbacks, provided that the minimum side yard setbacks shall not be less than three feet. 
(b)  Lots unserved by sewer and/or water. In any district, where neither water nor public sanitary sewer is accessible, the otherwise specified lot area and width requirements shall be a minimum of 20,000 square feet, and 100 feet; provided, however, that where a public water supply system is accessible and will be installed, these requirements shall be 10,000 square feet, and 75 feet respectively; provided further, that the city engineer has certified that such areas will be large enough to satisfy all applicable requirements concerning water supply and the disposal of sanitary wastes. 
(Code 1990, § 16-74; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 2(3.4), 4-19-1993; Ord. No. 2012-2071, § 1, 8-21-2012) 
Sec. 34-90. - Accessory buildings in residence districts. 
(a)  No accessory building shall occupy more than 30 percent of a required rear yard. Accessory buildings shall be limited to 20 feet in height, and shall be distant at least six feet from all lot lines of adjoining lots which are in any R district and at least six feet from alley lines and ten feet from any other building or structure on the same lot. 
(b)  An accessory building may be connected to the principal structure by a breezeway or similar structure if such accessory building is at least ten feet from the principal structure, provided all yard and court requirements of this chapter for a principal building are complied with. 
(Code 1990, § 16-75; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 2(3.5), 4-19-1993; Ord. No. 2005-2125, § 1, 2-15-2005) 
Sec. 34-91. - Required yard cannot be reduced or used by another building. 
(a)  No lot, yard, court, parking area or other open space shall be so reduced in area or dimension as to make any such area or dimension less than the minimum required by this article, and if already less than the minimum required it shall not be further reduced. No required open space provided about any building or structure shall be included as part of any open space required for another building or structure. 
(b)  The space occupied by a required private garage or parking area shall be considered the same as any required open space provided about a principal building, and such space shall not be reduced or included as any part of any required open space for another building or structure. 
(Code 1990, § 16-76; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 2(3.6), 4-19-1993) 
Sec. 34-92. - Conversion of dwellings. 
    The conversion of any building into a dwelling, or the conversion of any dwelling so as to accommodate an increase number of dwelling units or families, shall be permitted only within a district in which a new building for similar occupancy would be permitted under this article, and only when the resulting occupancy will comply with the requirements governing new construction in such district with respect to minimum lot size, lot area per dwelling unit, dimensions of yards and other open spaces, and off-street parking. Each conversion shall be subject also to such further requirements as may be specified hereinafter within the article apply to such district. 
(Code 1990, § 16-77; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 2(3.7), 4-19-1993) 
Sec. 34-93. - Transitional uses in R districts. 
    In any R-1, R-2, or R-3 district, a transitional use shall be permitted on a lot the side lot line of which adjoins, either directly or across an alley, any B or M district. The permitted transitional uses for any such lot in an R-1 district shall be any use permitted in the R-2 district; for any such lot in an R-2 district any use permitted in the R-3 district; and for any such lot in an R-3 district any use permitted in the R-4 district. In the case of any such lot in an R-1, R-2, or R-3 district, the requirement governing lot area per dwelling unit, off-street parking, yards and other open spaces shall be same as for the district respectively next listed in article II of this chapter. Any transitional use authorized under this section shall not extend more than 100 feet from the side lot line of the lot abutting on the zoning district boundary line. 
(Code 1990, § 16-78; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 2(3.8), 4-19-1993) 
Sec. 34-94. - Minimum ground floor area for dwellings. 
    A dwelling shall contain not less than 800 square feet of usable ground floor area, exclusive of open porches, garages or steps. 
(Code 1990, § 16-79; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 2(3.9), 4-19-1993) 
Sec. 34-95. - Traffic visibility across corner lots. 
    In any R district on any corner lot, no fence, structure or planting shall be erected or maintained within 20 feet of the corner so as to interfere with traffic visibility across the corner. 
(Code 1990, § 16-80; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 2(3.10), 4-19-1993) 
Sec. 34-96. - Essential services. 
    Essential services shall be permitted as authorized and regulated by law and other ordinances of the city, it being the intention hereof to exempt such essential services from the application of this article. 
(Code 1990, § 16-81; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 2(3.11), 4-19-1993) 
Sec. 34-97. - Off-street parking and loading. 
(a)  In any district, spaces for off-street parking and for loading or unloading shall be provided in accordance with the provisions of section 34-424. In any R district, no vehicle of any type shall be parked or stored in the front yard thereof for a period longer than: 
(1)  24 consecutive hours; or 
(2)  24 hours within any seven consecutive day period, unless the vehicle is parked on an area which conforms to the requirements of section 34-424(e). 
(b)  A violation of this section shall be punishable as a Class C violation as provided in section 1-41. 
(Code 1990, § 16-82; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 2(3.12), 4-19-1993; Ord. No. 2008-2302, § 1, 11-18-2008; Ord. No. 2010-2421, § 61, 10-5-2010) 
Sec. 34-98. - Pending applications for building permits. 
    Nothing herein contained shall require any change in the overall layout, plans, construction, size or designated use of any development, building, structure or part thereof, for which official approvals and required building permits have been granted before the enactment of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived, the construction of which, conforming with such plans, shall have been started prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived and completion thereof carried on in a normal matter within the subsequent six-month period, and not discontinued until completion, except for reasons beyond the builder's control. 
(Code 1990, § 16-83; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 2(3.13), 4-19-1993) 
Secs. 34-99-34-123. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - A-1 AGRICULTURAL DISTRICTS 

Sec. 34-124. - Scope. 
    The provisions of this article apply to the A-1 Agricultural Districts. 
Sec. 34-125. - Permitted principal uses. 
    The following uses are permitted in the A-1 districts: 
(1)  Agriculture, agricultural buildings and farm dwellings. 
(2)  Single-family dwellings including underground dwellings and modular or manufactured housing with the exception of single-wide manufactured dwellings. 
(3)  Public parks, playgrounds and recreational areas. 
(4)  Essential services as defined in section 34-11. 
(5)  Cemeteries of ten acres or more in size. 
(6)  Any building or structure occupied or used for nursery, elementary, junior high or high schools, public libraries and similar public cultural uses located not less than 20 feet from any side lot line. 
(7)  Sale of nursery and greenhouse products. 
(8)  Railroad right-of-way and trackage, not including switching, storage, terminal facilities of freight yards. 
(9)  Residential single-family dwellings existing previous to this amendment, including the conversion of buildings used as farm dwellings to non-farm single-family dwellings, provided all other requirements of this section are met. 
(10)  Storage structures which do not exceed 200 square feet in size and are used for storage of personal (non agricultural) property of the owner of the property. 
(Code 1990, § 16-84; Ord. No. 2006-2173, § 2, 3-7-2006) 
Sec. 34-126. - When authorized by board of appeals. 
(1)  Pollution control facilities, in accordance with county and state regulations, except that no pollution control facility shall be operated within 1,320 feet of any "R" district. 
(2)  Privately operated country clubs, golf courses, swimming clubs, riding stables, and similar recreation uses; provided, that any accessory building in connection therewith shall be located not less than 200 feet from any lot in an "R" district. 
(3)  Airports and landing fields. 
(4)  Communication towers, as provided by section 16-340. 
(5)  Veterinary clinics and animal boarding kennels; provided that an open air confinement of animals shall be at least 1,320 feet from any 'R' district. 
(6)  Single-wide manufactured dwellings (mobile homes). 
(7)  Public stables as defined in section 16-24. 
(8)  Child care facilities. 
(9)  Churches, chapels or parish houses located not less than 20 feet from any side lot line in the 'R' district. 
(10)  Agricultural supplies, sales and service businesses, including, but not limited to, feed, fertilizers, seeds, pesticides and herbicides. The special use provisions do not apply to the previously mentioned uses when they are conducted, as an incidental use, on and by the occupant of a working farm. This will not include agricultural machinery sales and service or elevators and storage. 
(11)  Bed and breakfast facilities as provided by section 16-145. 
(12)  Landscape contractor facilities. 
(13)  State and local facilities for police and fire protection. 
(14)  Retail nursery and garden shops. 
(15)  Fuel, fuel oil and liquid petroleum products dealers. 
(16)  Private camps and trailer parks. 
(17)  Drive-in motion picture theatres. 
(18)  Commercial sports, amusement parks, and membership sports and recreation clubs, provided that they are located no closer than 1,320 feet to any confinement operation, "R" district or platted subdivision. 
(19)  Wind power generating facilities as provided by section 16-340. 
(Code 1990, § 16-85; Ord. No. 2006-2173, § 2, 3-7-2006; Ord. No. 2017-2327, § 1, 7-18-2017) 
Sec. 34-127. - Permitted accessory uses. 
    The following are accessory uses permitted in the A-1 district: 
(1)  Buildings, structures and uses ancillary to agriculture, including roadside stands selling produce grown on the premises, provided such roadside stands are located not less than 20 feet from a street or highway right-of-way line. 
(2)  Private garages and parking area. 
(3)  Living quarters of persons employed on the premises. 
(4)  Office of a physician, dentist, lawyer, architect, engineer, clergyman or accountant within own dwelling. 
(5)  Home occupation as defined in section 34-426. 
(6)  Private stables. 
(7)  Signs as regulated by chapter 24. 
(8)  Outdoor residential swimming pools. 
(Code 1990, § 16-86; Ord. No. 2006-2173, § 2, 3-7-2006) 
Sec. 34-128. - Height regulations. 
    The following height and floor area regulations apply in the A-1 districts: No principal structure shall exceed 21/2 stories or 30 feet in height and accessory structures shall meet the requirements of section 34-90, except as provided in section 34-476. 
(Code 1990, § 16-87; Ord. No. 2006-2173, § 2, 3-7-2006) 
Sec. 34-129. - Lot area, frontage and yard requirements. 
    The following minimum requirements shall be observed, subject to the additional requirements, exceptions and modifications in sections 34-477 through 34-479, inclusive. Each lot shall have a minimum lot area of five acres:

ARTICLE V. - R-1 ONE-FAMILY RESIDENCE DISTRICTS 

Sec. 34-156. - Scope. 
    The provisions of this article apply to the R-1 One-Family Residence Districts. 
Sec. 34-157. - Permitted principal uses. 
    The following are permitted principal uses: 
(1)  One-family detached dwellings. 
(2)  Any buildings or structures occupied by or used for churches, Sunday schools, parish houses, public and parochial schools, public libraries, museums, art galleries and similar public cultural uses, located not less than 20 feet from any side lot line in any R district. 
(3)  Essential services, as defined in section 34-11 and municipal administrative of public service buildings or properties, except such uses as storage yards, warehouses, garages or other uses customarily conducted as gainful business, provided any building is located not less than 20 feet from any lot in any R district. 
(4)  Public parks, playgrounds and community centers. 
(5)  Gardening and general farming, but not confinement feeding operations. 
(6)  Hay baling as permitted by section 34-434. 
(Code 1990, § 16-100; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 2(4.0), 4-19-1993; Ord. No. 2008-2261, § 1, 1-15-2008; Ord. No. 2013-2125, § 2, 9-17-2013) 
Sec. 34-158. - When authorized by board of appeals. 
    The following uses shall be permitted by special use permit only: 
(1)  Branch telephone exchanges, electric substations and booster or pressure regulating stations, without service yard storage. 
(2)  Country clubs, golf courses, swimming clubs, tennis clubs, and similar recreational uses, provided that any principal building or swimming pool shall be located not less than 100 feet from any lot in any R district. 
(3)  Kindergartens, child care centers or nursery schools, provided that any play lot used in connection therewith be suitably fenced and screened in accordance with the requirements of the board. 
(Code 1990, § 16-101; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 2(4.1), 4-19-1993) 
Sec. 34-159. - Permitted accessory uses. 
    Accessory uses customarily incidental to a permitted principal use on the same lot therewith shall be permitted, including: 
(1)  Private garages or parking areas. 
(2)  Living quarters of persons employed on the premises. 
(3)  Home occupations as regulated by section 34-426. 
(4)  Communication antenna (which does not require support by a new communication tower), free standing or attached to an existing residential structure, or to an existing communication tower, provided: 
a.  The freestanding structure does not exceed 50 feet in height; 
b.  Communication antennas located on an existing structure shall not extend more than 20 feet above said structure; 
c.  The communication antenna complies with all applicable FCC and FAA regulations; 
d.  The communication antenna complies with all applicable building codes; 
e.  The communication antenna complies with all other requirements of this chapter. 
(Code 1990, § 16-102; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 2(4.2), 4-19-1993; Ord. No. 97-1827, § 3, 12-2-1997) 
Sec. 34-160. - Height regulations. 
    No principal structure shall exceed 21/2 stories or 30 feet in height, and no accessory structure shall exceed 11/2 stories or 20 feet in height, except as provided in section 34-476. 
(Code 1990, § 16-103; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 2(4.3), 4-19-1993; Ord. No. 2005-2125, § 2, 2-15-2005) 
Sec. 34-161. - Lot area, frontage and yard requirements. 
    The following minimum requirements shall be observed, subject to the additional requirements, exceptions and modifications in sections 34-477 through 34-479, inclusive. Each lot shall have a minimum lot area of 8,000 square feet.

ARTICLE VI. - R-2 TWO-FAMILY RESIDENCE DISTRICTS 

Sec. 34-192. - Scope and purpose. 
    The provisions of this article apply to the R-2 Two-Family Residence Districts. 
Sec. 34-193. - Permitted principal uses. 
    Any use of structure permitted and as regulated in section 34-157 shall be a permitted principal use, except as hereinafter modified. 
(Code 1990, § 16-120; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 2(5.0), 4-19-1993) 
Sec. 34-194. - When authorized by board of appeals. 
    The following uses shall be permitted by special use permit only: 
(1)  Any use as regulated in section 34-158 except as hereinafter modified. 
(2)  Private hospitals, sanitariums, and nursing homes. Hospitals shall be located on lots of five acres or more, sanitariums on lots of ten acres or more and nursing homes on lots of one acre or more. 
(3)  Cemeteries of ten acres or more in size. 
(4)  Planned unit developments exempt from district height regulations (see section 34-453). 
(Code 1990, § 16-121; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 2(5.1), 4-19-1993) 
Sec. 34-195. - Permitted accessory uses. 
    R-1 residence district accessory uses shall be permitted accessory uses. 
(Code 1990, § 16-122; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 2(5.2), 4-19-1993) 
Sec. 34-196. - Height regulations. 
    No principal structure shall exceed 21/2 stories or 30 feet in height, and no accessory structure shall exceed 11/2 stories or 20 feet in height, except as provided in section 34-476. 
(Code 1990, § 16-123; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 2(5.3), 4-19-1993; Ord. No. 2005-2125, § 3, 2-15-2005) 
Sec. 34-197. - Lot area, frontage and yard requirements. 
    The following minimum requirements shall be observed, subject to the additional requirements, exceptions and modifications in sections 34-477 through 34-479, inclusive. Each lot shall have a minimum lot area of 7,200 square feet.

ARTICLE VII. - R-3 ONE- AND TWO-FAMILY RESIDENCE DISTRICTS 

Sec. 34-219. - Scope. 
    The provisions of this article apply to the R-3 One- and Two-Family Residence Districts. 
Sec. 34-220. - Permitted principal uses. 
    The following are permitted principal uses: 
(1)  Any use or structure permitted and as regulated in section 34-193 except as hereinafter modified. 
(2)  Two-family dwellings. 
(Code 1990, § 16-140; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 2(6.0), 4-19-1993) 
Sec. 34-221. - When authorized by board of appeals. 
    The following are permitted when authorized by board of appeals: 
(1)  Any use as regulated in section 34-194, except as hereinafter modified.

(Code 1990, § 16-141; Ord. No. 93-1658, § 2(6.1), 4-19-1993)
